DOC.HEAD: Snow Falls at Home While Eskimo Marines Swelter in Middle East
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: For days, Lee Barr Sr. has seen occasional falling snow when he looks out his window in the northwest Alaska village of Kiana. In a couple of weeks, he said, the Kobuk River will be ice. It's hard for him to imagine what his serviceman son, Marvin, is experiencing in the hot desert of Saudi Arabia. ``He's doing good so far - he says he's getting used to it,'' Barr said of the 21-year-old Marine, one of several Alaska Eskimos stationed in Saudi Arabia. Marvin's first letter home arrived recently. He said he missed his mother's baking and native food. His father laughs at the thought of smoked salmon and dried caribou meat in Saudi Arabia. ``He said it was kind of warm - and it must have been hot down there if he says warm,'' his father said in a telephone interview. ``When he talks about something he can't make things sound bad. He's always been like that.'' Marvin is one of Lee and Viola Barr's eight children and has been a Marine for nearly four years. He has been in Saudi Arabia for about a month. ``It was kind of hard at first, I guess,'' said his father. ``The heat and wondering what they were going to do - whether they were going to have action.'' ``It's kind of hard for us too, wondering.'' Lee Barr hopes his son and all American military personnel will come home soon. He doesn't think they should be in Saudi Arabia to begin with. ``It's just for the money,'' he said of the American military presence in the Persian Gulf. ``There's a lot of other things that need to be done. The people that are starving, people who are sick - those things we just ignore and we're getting into somebody's business.'' The Barrs' neighbors, Lorenze and Nellie Schuerch, have two sons in the Marines, but neither has gone to Saudi Arabia yet. One of them, 20-year-old Vincent, is home on leave for 20 days from his base at Camp Pendleton, Calif. Vincent Schuerch said he's has been hunting and helping out around home, but is ready to go back when needed. He'd like to see Saudi Arabia. ``If the opportunity came to see a different country, yes, I would like to go,'' he said. ``Just to say I've been down there.'' His mother supports the U.S. action in the Middle East but hopes things settle down before her boys are sent over. ``My concern is the possibility of chemical warfare,'' she told the Arctic Sounder newspaper in Kotzebue. ``If that doesn't happen, we still have that heat in Saudi Arabia. Living in the Arctic all of their lives, and then going to 120-degree Saudi Arabia heat, I don't know how anybody can adjust to that. I don't know how an Eskimo can adjust to that.''

DOC.HEAD: Sexual Problems in Priesthood Expected To Get Airing at Vatican Synod
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: More than 200 bishops from around the world gather in Rome this weekend for a synod expected to consider the issue of sex and the Roman Catholic priesthood. Pope John Paul II called the assembly of 238 bishops to discuss the formation of priests in today's world. An advisory body, it will make recommendations to him at the end of the monthlong meeting, which starts Sunday. The church's rules that priests be celibate and foresake marriage are not expected to be subjects up for debate, according to church sources involved in preparations for the meeting. John Paul has shown no indications the rules might be changed under his papacy. But a major concern of the bishops is finding and training candidates able to live up to the priestly vows of poverty, chastity and obedience. Several sexual scandals involving churchmen have made headlines in recent months: -The archbishop of Atlanta, Eugene A. Marino, resigned July 10 after revelations of a two-year ``intimate relationship'' with a young woman singer and lay minister. -A report in July by a church-appointed commission in Newfoundland said priests had sexually abused boys in the Canadian province for more than a decade and that the church had failed to stop it. The archbishop, Alphonsus Penney, accepted responsibility and offered his resignation to the pope. Such in-house problems are usually handled with great discretion by the Vatican. It has never commented publicly on the Marino case, announcing only that he resigned for reasons of health. But the Vatican has issued several documents this year expressing concern over the qualifications of candidates for the priesthood, particularly at a time when the church is trying to increase the number of priests and nuns. The paper bluntly declared that aspiring priests and nuns must overcome sexual desires that would break their vows of chastity. It said those unable to overcome their homosexual tendencies or who maintain it is possible to ``adopt a third way, living in an ambiguous state between celibacy and marriage'' must be dismissed from religious life. And it suggested that psychological testing can be useful in determining sexual problems in candidates. ``I don't think anyone would say it was easy to be celibate,'' said the Rev. Howard Bleichner, director of the Department for Priestly Formation of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops in Washington, D.C. But he said the highly publicized failures of priests did not reflect a problem with the nature of the priesthood. ``If a prominent man is unfaithful in marriage, I wouldn't take that as a reason to re-think the institution of marriage,'' Bleichner said. While the number of worldwide ordinations has been growing after hitting a decade low in 1979, the numbers are still down in the United States and Western Europe. Bleichner said students in the past four years of U.S. seminary numbered 3,698 this year, compared with 7,855 in 1968. ``The question in our society is of long-term commitment. Examples of that are becoming increasingly rare. Look at the break-up of marriages.'' A 1988 report by the U.S. bishops found that many of the nation's priests were overworked, lonely and sexually troubled. It contended that the mandatory celibacy is a major reason why priests leave. The American bishops, Bleichner said, are looking forward to hearing the experiences on priestly training from other countries. There are clearly great differences in experiences from country to country, brought home by two bishops attending a Vatican news conference on the synod. Cardinal Lucas Moreira Neves of Sao Salvador da Bahia, Brazil, lamented the ``frightening lack'' of priests in his diocese, noting there were 340 to serve the 3 million people. Bishop Henryk Myzinski of Wloclawek in the pope's native Poland said he had 590 priests for 1.1 million faithful. The U.S. bishops will be represented by Cardinal Joseph Bernardin of Chicago, Cardinal James Hickey of Washington, D.C., Archbishop Daniel Pilarczyk of Cincinnati and Bishop John Marshall of Burlington, Vt., who headed a study of U.S. seminaries in the early 80s. The pope, who appoints 15 percent of the delegates, named Bishop Harry Flynn of Lafayette, La., Bishop Robert Brom of San Diego and Bishop Donald Wuerl of Pittsburgh, all former seminary rectors.

DOC.HEAD: Saudis Praise U.S. Troops' Behavior
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Good guidance, limited personal contact and no booze - whatever the reasons, American troops are on their best behavior in Saudi Arabia, and the locals are impressed. In the eight weeks since the first U.S. military forces were deployed in Operation Desert Shield, officials said there have been no reported criminal incidents and no serious insults to Saudi culture - things that American and Saudi officials had most feared. Despite the presence of more than 150,000 foreigners, most of them armed, only one Saudi is reported to have died in an armed forces-related incident, a man killed Sept. 25 when his taxi collided with a Marine Corps pickup. The accident is under investigation. From top generals to GIs, Americans say they have found the Saudis to be friendly, hospitable and tolerant of ignorance about their desert kingdom and its traditions. For their part, numerous Saudis say the American soldiers appear to have been well advised on what to expect and how to behave. ``They're strangers in a strange land. They know it, and they act like it,'' said a Saudi who has a Western perspective from several years of living abroad. ``Some of them seem even overly sensitive. In the briefings they're told not to say things like `hey, dude,' because dude is Arabic for worm. But I doubt whether many Saudis would even understand what they meant.'' U.S. commander Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf said in a recent interview that he encounters ``every day ... a new aspect of cultural differences,'' and tries to work with the Saudis to ``figure out a commonsense, intelligent way'' to solve problems. One area of concern is the mailing of packages containing alcohol, religious articles and other materials prohibited by Saudi law. But even fears about this have proved generally groundless, U.S. officials say. A heck showed only three minor incidents in which Saudi customs officials seized a jar of whiskey, a bottle of vodka and three copies of Playboy magazine, said a U.S. spokesman, Navy Cmdr. David Knox. Another serviceman was investigated after his wife sent a package with three bottles of liquor, but no charges were filed. Americans, and some Saudis, say the absence of alcohol is probably a major factor in explaining the troops' exemplary behavior. ``There's no R-and-R in the Saudi cities ... no way for them to raise hell,'' said the former Saudi expatriate. ``When that doesn't go on, you don't have the things that create resentment.'' There have been some incidents of misunderstanding or affronts to the Saudis, but very few involving religion, the most sensitive aspect of Saudi culture. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and Jordan's King Hussein have sought in speeches to persuade Moslems that American troops are defiling Islam's holiest shrines at Mecca and Medina, which non-Moslems are not allowed to visit. Saudi leaders scoff at the claim. ``The foreigners are 1,000 miles from the holy places,'' said a Saudi diplomatic source. ``If anything, King Hussein needs a crash course in Saudi geography.'' A Saudi prince who also spoke on condition of anonymity said he hoped the presence of Americans ``will lead to us understanding each other better.'' That has not always been easy. When American civilians in the Dhahran area put on an amateur stage show for the troops, it lasted only one performance. The Saudis complained that female performers showed too much leg. Privately, they were said to hve felt that television coverage ``flaunted'' the event in their faces. Saudi citizens also complained to Prince Mohammed Bin Fahd, governor of the Eastern Province and son of King Fahd, about U.S. troops carrying their M-16 rifles in the streets of Dhahran and nearby Khobar. U.S. military officials quickly expressed regrets and said they would brief troops again on weapons decorum. There were reports, too, that some Saudi women were upset over the presence of American women in uniform, fearing they were here to steal their men. ``That was just women's gossip,'' said the Saudi who has lived abroad. ``The educated people have been pleasantly surprised by the conduct of the Americans. ``The thing that's impressed our people most is how polite they are. These are pretty young kids. I almost feel sorry for them, being so patient and saying `thank you' all the time.''

DOC.HEAD: Swelling Number of Asylum Seekers Causing Problems in Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BER1,2,3
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: This report is one of a series on the German countdown to unity on Oct. 3. ---

As Germany rushes toward unification, it is also becoming the promised land for tens of thousands of people swarming into the country to escape poverty in the Third World and Eastern Europe. The influx is further strapping West Germany, already hard-pressed to come up with the tens of billions of dollars needed to rescue East Germany from economic catastrophe. German unification, which will formally take place Wednesday, appears to have given a boost to the pace of arrivals. Authorities expect a record number of 200,000 political asylum-seekers this year. Last year, the figure stood at 120,000. Last year, West Germany became the new home for 350,000 ethnic German immigrants from Eastern Europe. About 500,000 East Germans resettled across the border in 1989 and in the early months of 1990. Authorities are aware that many refugees are seeking a brighter economic future, even if they say they are fleeing political persecution. They are trying to stem the tide. But it won't be easy. ``All they have to do to stay here is make it believable that they are foreign and that they are politically persecuted,'' said Volker Moeser, who runs a government reception center just outside Frankfurt for seekers of political asylum. The center, in Schwalbach, is housing about 850 refugees, and dozens of 12-bed tents have been put up to deal with the influx. The opening of East European borders has contributed dramatically to the increase. Once registered, asylum applicants settle down to wait until authorities decide whether to recognize them as political refugees - a process that can take five years. Only about 3 percent receive refugee status, but the statistics don't seem to be a deterrent. At the Schwalbach camp's cafeteria, Poles and Romanians mingled with Turks, Ghanaians, Pakistanis, Somalis, Afghanis and a variety of other nationals as they lined up to buy cheap lunch. Outside a tent, a Romanian gypsy family of 13 enjoyed a recent sunny day by relaxing on a blanket. The head of the clan, its only male, made a few declarations of support for the new Romanian authorities and claims of past persecution by Securitate secret police. Then he talked about why he really brought the family to Germany. ``One day they closed the factory and I lost my job. There is no future in Romania,'' said the man, who gave his name only as Novakovic and said he was from Timisoara. In the latest twist, West Germany suddenly faces the prospect of Soviet deserters as well. Officials have expressed fears that many of the 360,000 Soviet soldiers stationed in East Germany may ask for asylum rather than return to a bleak future in their homeland as the troops are pulled out under German unification agreements. Eight Soviet soldiers deserted in August and 26 more applied for asylum in the central Hesse state in recent weeks, some coming over with their wives. Also, Bonn officials have temporarily halted the immigration of Soviet Jews in order to prevent a virtual stampede. The West German consulate in Kiev alone has received 10,000 applications. The rush of new arrivals from all over is stretching social services to the limit. Communities have been refusing to accept the refugees because they lack housing, or even sending them to East Germany. But East Germany itself still has to persuade 80,000 workers from Vietnam, Cuba and Mozambique to return home. Citizens of East bloc countries once had free access to East Germany, but visa requirements have been tightened. In some Third World countries, newspapers carry advertisements touting the advantages of seeking political asylum in West Germany. The ads are placed by rings that then organize the trips for a hefty fee. Some officials think that only legitimate asylum-seekers should be allowed to cross the borders. They also want the paperwork speeded up and those refused asylum to be expelled immediately. The federal government's blueprint calls for aid at the source. Under the proposal, Germany would help build housing and create jobs in poor countries in an attempt to keep potential asylum-seekers from leaving. ``We want a larger Germany to remain friendly to foreigners,'' said Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble.

DOC.HEAD: Estate Sells for $14.3 Million, Tops Trump Mansion Price Tag
DOC.TEXT: A secretive buyer paid a record $14.3 million for a 15-room ocean front estate in this resort city. Wilson and Hilda Lucom sold their six-acre estate to Ocean Bay Holding Ltd., showed county records that wer filed this week. Ocean Bay was the agent for an undisclosed buyer, who will likely raze existing buildings to put up a mansion, said Carol Digges, the Lucoms' real estate agent. ``The main house on the property is a modest ranch built in the 1950s,'' Digges said. ``It has no architectural significance. When you buy a piece of property of that value, the natural thing to do is to erect a sizable mansion.'' Also facing the wrecking ball are two guest houses, a swimming pool, tennis court, fountain, cabana and dock. Casa Apava, which held the record for Palm Beach County real estate, sold for $14.2 million in 1987. Donald Trump paid $10 million for the historic Mar-a-Lago estate, including furniture, in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Excalibur Luxury Automaker Files for Bankruptcy Protection
DOC.TEXT: Excalibur Automobile Corp., the maker of neoclassic luxury cars fancied by well-heeled collectors, has filed for court protection from creditors. Excalibur President Scott Dennison said court papers were filed this week under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code as negotiations continued with two suitors interested in buying the company. The company stopped production at its suburban West Allis plant in June. As of Aug. 14, Excalibur had $4.7 million in assets and $3.9 million in debts, the company said in documents filed in federal bankruptcy court. Excalibur luxury cars typically sell for $75,000 to $150,000. Debts secured by mortgages amounted to about $2.4 million. Unsecured debts totaled about $1.5 million.

DOC.HEAD: School No Longer Wants Convicted Ex-Gov's Name
DOC.TEXT: A vocational school named after former Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. has decided to get a new name now that Moore is serving a prison sentence for political corruption. ``I don't think it's good for our students to be looking at it as a name for a school,'' Roane County Schools Superintendent C.N. Evans said. ``I would just as soon not name any type of building after anyone.'' The administrative council at the Arch A. Moore Jr. Vocational-Technical & Adult Education Center voted this month to drop Moore's name. The council is asking the public for suggestions for a new name. Moore, a three-term Republican, pleaded guilty in May to one count each of obstruction of justice, extortion and mail fraud and two counts of tax fraud. In August, he began a 5-year, 10-month sentence at a federal prison in Montgomery, Ala.

DOC.HEAD: Section Of Berlin Wall Installed at Westminster
DOC.TEXT: A section of the Berlin Wall was installed on the campus of Westminster College, where Winston Churchill gave his famous 1946 speech describing an ``Iron Curtain'' dividing the world. Churchill's granddaughter, Edwina Sandys, used a 32-foot wide section of the dismantled wall to create a sculpture she calls ``Breakthrough.'' Ms. Sandys, daughter of Churchill's eldest daughter, Diane, was on hand Thursday to watch as construction crews used a crane to lower slabs of the wall near a statue of her grandfather. Sandys, a New York sculptor, said she wanted the work at Westminster because it was here that Churchill gave the speech that outlined the developing Cold War era of East-West conflict that started after World War II and ended last year. ``I feel the wall is really the physical embodiment of the Iron Curtain,'' she said. ``I'm really pleased to have it here. It's really a perfect fit, the whole thing. ``First and foremost, it's a piece of art, but also it's a political statement,'' she said. ``Sometimes they intertwine.'' Churchill came to Fulton on March 5, 1946, with President Truman. In his speech at Westminster he warned of new problems facing the world after the Allied victory in World War II. In the best-known passage, he said, ``A shadow has fallen upon the scene so lately lighted by Allied victory. . . . From Stettin in the Baltic to Trieste in the Adriatic, an Iron Curtain has descended across the Continent.'' The 10-foot-high sculpture has sections cut out, in the shape of a man and woman, through which people can walk. One side is covered with graffiti left by West Berliners after the wall went up in 1962. After Ms. Sandys approached East German officials in February about her idea for the sculpture, they allowed her to survey the wall and choose the sections she wanted. Those she took had been in an area frequented by artists, she said. ``I chose these sections out of 200,'' she said, ``because I thought the colors'' of the graffiti ``were dynamic and lovely.'' Westminster, a small liberal arts college in this central Missouri community of about 11,000, has about 750 students.

DOC.BYLINE: AP World Desk Supervisor, Ex-Foreign Correspondent, Angelo Natale,
DOC.TEXT: Dies

Angelo Natale, editorial supervisor at the World Service and Foreign desks of The Associated Press and a former AP foreign correspondent, has died at the age of 64. His AP career spanned almost five decades. Natale died at his home in Manhattan on Wednesday. He had suffered from chronic diabetes and vascular problems. Natale joined the AP in 1942 and served in a variety of news assignments that took him to Cairo and Moscow, as well as to several AP bureaus in the eastern United States. His only time away from the AP was a 20-month stint with the U.S. Army Air Force during World War II. In 1968, Natale joined the World Service division at AP headquarters in New York. He was promoted to editorial supervisor in 1973 at the desk responsible for transmitting AP news reports to 8,500 subscribers in 105 countries worldwide. ``Angelo was not only a supervisor but was a friend to everyone in the department and to AP people around the world,'' said Tom Kent, who is in charge of AP's Foreign and World Service desks. A native of the Bronx, Natale was educated in New York City public schools and went to Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan. He entered The City College of New York in September 1941 and then went to work for the AP as an office assistant in March 1942. After military service, he returned to the AP in 1945 and worked in various clerical positions while attending college at night. Natale was graduated from City College with a Bachelor of Social Science degree in 1950 and then became a reporter at AP's Newark bureau. He became correspondent in Atlantic City in 1956. In November 1956, he entered the AP's foreign service in Cairo, Egypt, at the height of the Suez Canal crisis. He later covered stories throughout the Middle East. In early 1958, Natale was transferred to the AP bureau in Moscow, and in 1959 he returned to the United States and was assigned to AP's New Haven, Conn., bureau. He transferred to the World Service desk in 1968. Natale is survived by his mother, Rachel Natale, and his brother, Salvatore Natale. Services are planned for Saturday at Gleason's Funeral Home in Flushing, Queens. Burial will follow at Mt. St. Mary cemetery in Flushing.

DOC.HEAD: Border Patrol Arrests 35 at Church-Operated Immigrant Shelter
DOC.TEXT: Immigration agents reportedly acting on a tip that terrorists with Iraqi connections had entered the United States raided a church-operated shelter for Central American immigrants Thursday. Immigration officials previously had maintained a hands-off policy toward Casa Romero, operated by the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brownsville, because it is considered a church. Thirty-five people were arrested. Silvestre Reyes, chief patrol agent with the U.S. Border Patrol's McAllen Sector, said immigration officials obtained the search warrant after learning that there might be 21 Indians, Pakistanis and Iranians there. He said officials particularly were interested in finding individuals from the Sikh religious sect of India. ``We have some information regarding national security regarding those individuals,'' Reyes said. Five Indians, two Pakistanis, four Guyanese, two Salvadorans, six Hondurans, a Guatemalan and 15 who said they were Mexican, were arrested at Casa Romero for allegedly being in the country illegally, Reyes said. Reyes said officials believe some of those identifying themselves as Mexicans might be actually be from India. An immigration official who asked not to be identified said the agents had obtained intelligence reports that terrorists were trying to enter the United States to carry out actions on behalf of Iraq. Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein has threatened terrorist strikes since the U.S. military buildup began in the Persian Gulf in response to Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. About 25 U.S. Border Patrol agents with a search warrant entered the six-acre compound while residents were in line for dinner. ``They're scared,'' Sister Norma Pimentel, shelter director, said of the immigrants after the raid. ``They don't know why this happened.'' The shelter opened in 1982 in San Benito and moved to the outskirts of Brownsville in 1987. The area around Brownsville, Texas' southernmost city on the Mexican border, is a popular crossing point for Central Americans, because it is the closest U.S. point by land to that region. Reyes said although it was the first time the Border Patrol had entered the shelter with a search warrant, he always had maintained the right to enter. He said six Indians arrested at Kingsville in south Texas earlier Thursday told agents that alien smugglers had made arrangements for their trip at Casa Romero and had picked them up there. The shelter is named for Monsignor Oscar Romero, who was gunned down while saying Mass in El Salvadora on March 24, 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Rage Fuels Father's Obsession With Lockerbie Bombing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Jim Swire is a country doctor whose days and evenings are devoted to his patients. His nights belong to his obsession: airport security and the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103, which killed his daughter, Flora. ``Why, Oh Why, Flora?'' Swire wrote that on his briefcase, around a circular photograph of his firstborn. In frequent meetings with government officials, he makes sure they see it. ``You can see their hackles rising when they see a person they've allowed to be killed. I don't see why they shouldn't see it,'' said the soft-spoken, gray-haired physician. Flora Swire, a happy medical student, a gifted artist and musician, was traveling to the United States to spend Christmas with her American boyfriend. She was one of 270 people who died when the plane blew up at 7:04 p.m. on Dec. 21, 1988, and rained wreckage on the Scottish town of Lockerbie. It was the day before her 24th birthday. In the 21 months since then, her father has had periods of intense depression and rage. But his campaign to point out security flaws, bring the terrorists to justice and reform British airport security has been relentless. On Monday, Swire will be in Dumfries, 10 miles west of Lockerbie, for the opening of a public Scottish inquiry into accident. ``Rage is my secret weapon. When I am sitting at this desk, it's 2 a.m. and I have another letter to write but I want to go to bed, I just think about that flight, that warm airplane at four minutes past 7, and it makes me so angry that the adrenalin starts going and I can last for a few more hours,'' he said. The desk is Swire's communications center: a large computer, fax machine and desk telephone to supplement a mobile phone tucked in the breast pocket of his gray suit. There are many photographs of Flora - smiling with alert, playful eyes - in the Swires' sandstone house overlooking the Malvern Hills of central England. A son, William, is taking a year off before college. Catherine, who saw her sister off at Heathrow Airport, still lives at home. ``She was excited about Flora's trip and even thought about buying a ticket, too,'' Swire said. He took a deep breath, fighting to keep the voice steady. ``I came within a hair's breadth of losing both of them.'' The Swires keep a comfortable house, where the Burmese cat has free rein over the oriental rugs, the dog's long tail slaps against antiques and dinner in the kitchen is beef stew and home-grown fruit. But talk around the table is about Mohammad Abu Talb, the Palestinian terrorist serving a life sentence in Sweden for bombings against American and Israeli targets in Europe. Lockerbie investigators have identified Talb as a suspect. A telephone call from a Swedish journalist takes Swire from the table. ``A (doctor's) family is used to being interrupted at the dinner table but this is just unbelievable,'' said Jane Swire, her voice trailing off, her eyes cast down. The inquiry beginning Monday, the Scottish version of an inquest, is not the wide-ranging investigation that Swire has been demanding. But he intends to spend as much of the opening week in Dumfries as his practice allows. He hopes to testify. ``I am a thorn in the flesh of the British government. Thorns fester and I am determined not to leave off until we have some answers,'' he said. Swire wants to know why Department of Transport warnings about a cassette recorder bomb like the one that blew up Flight 103 reached airport security staff after his daughter was dead. Why was a warning of a terrorist threat given to U.S. Embassy staff in Helsinki and other cities but not to the public? Why has the British government refused an independent inquiry, even after a U.S. presidential commission reported in May that the disaster could have been prevented? There were 259 passengers on the flight, including 31 British citizens. As spokesman for U.K. Families Flight 103, Swire frequently travels to the United States for meetings with the two active family groups there. In May, he risked arrest by flying to New York with a fake bomb in his suitcase to dramatize his belief that airport security is still too lax. Swire, 54, learned about explosives during army service in the Royal Engineers. He says it took him six hours to buy the parts and duplicate the terrorist's bomb, substituting marzipan for Semtex, the Czechoslovakian-made plastic explosive. ``When I smuggled the bomb on the flight to New York, and we flew up over Scotland, and climbed to 31,000 feet, it was a strange sensation that the other passengers didn't have a clue that there was a fake bomb in the hold.'' Swire's record for interviews is 24 in one day and his news conferences are as well-run as any politician's. A scholarship in Flora's memory has been established at Nottingham University. But the young woman may be most vividly remembered in the dark circles under her father's eyes, a sign of his determination. Swire said he has matured from initially wanting vengeance and having people fired to a desire for improved airport security to prevent another disaster. He admits the goal is distant. Swire said his initial rage was stoked by officials who treated him as an ignorant outsider. ``It made me livid,'' he said. ``I had seen dead bodies lying in pieces in a mausoleum in Lockerbie. The experts didn't know what the death of 270 people looks like and they never would. That's why they can forget it and have such a lackadaisical approach to security.'' The Swires traveled to Lockerbie a few days after the disaster. Families were told they could not see the bodies because it would be too upsetting, a policy Swire says goes against psychological practices. ``Being a doc, I pulled some strings and the pathologist put my daughter's body aside for me,'' Swire said. There were flowers around her body in the makeshift mortuary, and the pathologist had clipped a lock of Flora's thick, black hair to give to the father. ``My mind was blank and I half expected to feel rage,'' Swire said. ``But I just felt waves of sadness passing over me, wave after wave, a flying carpet of sadness.'' The Swires at first worked out their grief on their 16 acres of pasture land, planting 4,500 trees. ``I was so sort of shellshocked,'' he said. ``I began planting (the trees). It was a mindless job but it kept me busy, just digging a hole, putting the tree in and tamping it down.'' Cherry, oak, beech and mountain ash saplings now grow in Flora's Wood. Some are planted to form a large ``F,'' a memorial visible only from an airplane.

DOC.HEAD: For Today's Unification, Bismarck Provides Important Lessons
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BER2,3 sent Sept. 27.
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: This report is one of a series on the German countdown to unity on Oct. 3. ---

Otto von Bismarck became a hero when he unified Germany through blood and iron. As Germany merges peacefully, he takes on renewed importance for a generation seeking to draw lessons from the past. Tens of thousands of Germans, including political leaders, have flocked to a major exhibit in West Berlin attempting to analyze Bismarck and the consequences of his policies for Germany and for Europe. The German Historical Museum's exhibit, ``Bismarck - Prussia, Germany, and Europe'' was planned three years ago, when the question of unity seemed a distant dream to most Germans. ``Nobody could have known three years ago how current the Bismarck topic would be by the summer of 1990,'' says Christoph Stoelzl, director of the German Historical Museum. The impact of German unity next Wednesday has preoccupied today's politicians, diplomats, financiers and historians much as it did when Bismarck united the country the first time in 1871. Some Europeans have expressed concern the new Germany will be too big and too powerful, and more interested in itself than in European unity. Again, there is a parallel to the Bismarck era, because those same problems developed after 1871. ``It is important to think about what the concept of nationhood means because of what is happening in Germany, but also in the framework of European unity,'' said Bernard Falge, director of the French Intitute in West Berlin. The institute has set up two academic conferences on the topic. The Bismarck exhibit has already attracted leading politicians since it opened Aug. 26. West German President Richard von Weizsaecker, Social Democratic chairman Hans-Jochen Vogel and his East German counterpart, Wolfgang Thierse, are among more than 50,000 people who have seen it. The exhibit runs until Nov. 25. It is hard to ignore Bismarck in Germany. Many towns have a Bismarck street. There have been Bismarck submarines and ships. There are hundreds of books devoted to the statesman known as the ``Iron Chancellor.'' Nearly 300 institutions in more than a dozen countries lent paintings, sculptures, letters, books, uniforms, maps and other items to form the biggest collection of objects connected with Bismarck ever assembled. ``It is rather overwhelming to go see so many things from that time,'' said Manfred Jehle, a researcher at the Historical Commission in West Berlin, after he saw the exhibit for the first time. The first part of the exhibit concentrates on the powerful region of Prussia, named for an exterminated pagan tribe. Bismarck, a native Prussian, set German unity as one of his major goals when he became prime minister of Prussia in 1862. But he looked down on a peaceful way to uniting Germany's principalities, duchies, kingdoms, and states, which were constantly being overrun by the French or the Austrians because of their lack of unity. ``The great questions of the time will not be decided by speeches and majority decisions, but through iron and blood,'' Bismarck said in one of his most famous speeches in 1862. The exhibit follows through Prussian battles in the 1860s to the Franco-Prussian war and the 1871 proclamation of a constitutional monarchy - and a unified Germany. This time, Germans are unifying after four decades of living with the legacy of the country's Nazi past. And in contrast to Bismarck, current Chancellor Helmut Kohl got what he wanted in large part through skillful and patient diplomacy. This time, the united Germany will combine the 11 West German states with five new states being reorganized in East Germany. Much of Bismarck's Prussia now lies in the Soviet Union and Poland following Nazi Germany's loss in World War II. The exhibit also focuses on Bismarck's policy toward Europe, which was based on isolating France and building up an army powerful enough to defeat the enemy. Several of Bismarck's spiked helmets form part of an extensive display of German military dress. His strategy drove Europe apart and led to the glorification of the military, which continued through the world wars that defeated and then divided Germany. Kohl, however, espouses West Germany's postwar pro-European policies and is committed to European unification. Kohl, the next chancellor of a unified Germany, has promised to maintain that policy rather than take Bismarck's militaristic path.

DOC.HEAD: 4-Minute Showers, Breakfast in the Desert, and No Stealth Shows
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Until the showers arrive, the M-12 Decontamination Unit is the favorite spot at this Marine camp in the northern Saudi desert. The unit is supposed to be used to wash troops free of chemical weapons or any other dangerous substances they come in contact with in the field. But for now, it's also doubling as the shower. Everyone follows the same routine: two minutes of water followed by one minute to lather up followed by two minutes of water to rinse. Or, as Capt. Adrian Burke of Deer Park, Texas, puts it: ``You wet down, wash up, rinse off and dry up and you're good to go for another day.'' You have to spend some time in the Saudi desert, where the powdery sand clings to everything and everyone, to appreciate such niceties. ``A four-minute shower might not seem like much, but out here it's the highlight of the day,'' Burke said during a recent visit to the camp, named after World War II Marine Ace Joe Foss.

No matter where a soldier goes, there are constants - such as military food. When there are no other meals available the troops get modern-day C-rations, known today as Meals Ready to Eat. They're 3,000 calories, with the choice ranging from chicken a la king to beef stew. uffice it to say they're not too tasty. ``Anyone who can eat an MRE ought to be able to take a hill,'' Marine Commandant Gen. Alfred Gray told a group of Marines during a visit to their camp Wednesday. These men had just had a treat - a hot breakfast in the desert, including what several men said was their first cup of hot coffee since they arrived in Saudi Arabia five weeks ago. But the breakfast menu had a familiar, chow-hall ring: creamed beef, ham and eggs, potatoes and pound cake.

The Air Force is keeping its F-117 Stealth fighter-bomber away from reporters, but not because they don't want to show it off. The Stealth was deployed to the region more than a month ago and Air Force spokesmen soon after began taking names of reporters and photographers who wanted to see the radar-eluding aircraft and interview its pilots. But those plans are now on hold because of objections raised by the Saudi government, according to miliary sources. The Stealth is considered an offensive weapon, and the American deployment in Saudi Arabia is described as a defensive mission. ``The Saudis are worried it would send the wrong signals,'' one of the military sources said.

DOC.HEAD: Caste Still Plays Social, Political Role
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Prabhat Aggarwal knows by his very name his place in life. ``Aggarwal'' is also his caste. ``Aggarwals were the masters of the economy in India. Kings and rajas were dependent on us. We were the moneylenders,'' the 17-year-old student said. Aggarwal, whose caste puts him in the upper rank of Indian society, was on a downtown street demonstrating against Prime Minister V.P. Singh's policy to reserve more government jobs for low-caste Indians. Singh described the policy as ``a glimmer of hope to those who have known only oppression for centuries'' because of their caste. He said Wednesday he would rather quit than ``barter away the aspirations of the deprived.'' Upper-caste students, angered and feeling threatened that jobs historically dominated by their classes would be reserved for the lower castes, have rioted across northern India, crippling New Delhi for several days this week. On Sept. 19, a 20-year-old upper-caste student, Rajeev Goswami, doused himself with gasoline and lit a match. Goswami survived, but seven other students and a farmer have committed suicide, and dozens have tried. Forty-six have died in clashes with police, which prompted officials Thursday to declare curfews in eight cities. ``We love Mother India,'' Aggarwal complained. ``But when a mother says one child is good and the other is bad, what can we do?'' The upper-caste feel tremendous pressure from their families to succeed, and the threat of losing jobs to people who are less-qualified is driving them to desperate acts, said Ashis Nandi, of the Center for the Study of Developing Societies. Critics say the timing and manner of announcing the policy made it look like a political maneuver to undercut the support of one of Singh's populist rivals. The policy is based on a much-criticized study by an obscure politician of low caste, B.P. Mandal, which languished for 10 years until Singh revived it in his election platform last year. The Mandal Commission classified 3,000 castes as ``socially and educationally backward,'' and recommended that 27 percent of government jobs be set aside for them. The government employs some 18 million people, though the military and defense jobs are excluded from the quota system. Previously, 22 percent were reserved for the lowest sector of society, native tribes and ``untouchables.'' The new policy left slightly more than half the jobs available on merit alone. In a nation where millions of educated Indians lack work, the new quota sent shivers through the college campuses. ``If I get 85 percent on my marks and he (a low-caste student) gets 40 percent, he will get the job,'' Aggarwal said. ``I work very hard. I know I must face competition. Now what's the point?'' Nandi said only 1,700 jobs a year are affected by the government plan. ``The students are overreacting,'' he said.``The upper castes have a feeling of insecurity. They are few in number, and the lower castes are in a great majority.'' Singh argues his quotas will blur the distinctions of caste. Critics say he has revived the notion of caste as an instrument of state policy. The caste system, which began perhaps 2,500 years ago, categorized Hindus into a social hierarchy determined by birth and sanctioned by religion. Some 20,000sub-castes derive from the four primary castes: the Brahmins who are priests, teachers and astrologers; Kshariyas who comprise the royalty and warrior class; Vaisya who are merchants and traders; and Sudras who do the menial tasks. Below them all are the untouchables. Tradition forbids them from wearing shoes, riding bicycles, sharing a water well with caste Hindus. Modern India, which is 82 percent Hindu, embraced secularism and socialist ideals when it became independent from Britain in 1947, and pledged to discard the caste system. Urbanization, economic mobility and the growth of a middle class have dimmed the traditional power of caste, which once dictated who one married, where one worked, and even how one carried himself. But its power is still considerable. Weekend classified pages publish columns of matrimonial offers based on caste. Most marriages still are arranged by parents. ``Caste is surviving, there's no doubt. But the role of caste is changing,'' Nandi said. ``It's not much different than ethnic groupings in the United States.''

DOC.HEAD: Water Well Suggests Ancient Man Wwas Smarter Than We Thought
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: An 8,000-year-old village under the sea has yielded an intriguing discovery: a water well thought to be the oldest in the world. The archaeologist who found the well says it suggests ancient man was smarter than previously thought. The 6-year-old dig beneath the Mediterranean seabed has already turned up a trove of information about neolithic man. Findings include the remains of stone houses, a fireplace preserved with its charred wood, 23 buried skeletons, the bones of the animals the villagers ate, the seeds they planted, the tools they made from bone and stone. The latest excitement is over the discovery of several wells, one of which was excavated and found to be 16 feet deep. Ehud Galili, the archaeologist heading the dig, said the village is 7,700 to 8,000 years old, so that the well is some 1,000 years older than the oldest well known until now. ``It is surprising because for the first time we have figured out that prehistoric man was aware of the existence of water tables under the ground and was able and had the proper technology to dig these wells and to use this fresh water,'' he told reporters visiting the site Thursday. ``As far as I know this is the oldest well discovered from that period,'' he said. It raises fascinating questions: How did ancient man know that if he dug deep enough, he would strike fresh water? And where did he acquire the skill to sink a round shaft, paved with stone, in much the same way as many modern wells are built? The well was full of prehistoric trash - bones, broken tools and stones, Galili said. He speculated that at some point its water had grown salty and it was turned into a garbage disposal pit. With the end of the Ice Age, the village disappeared beneath the Mediterranean as melted ice raised the earth's sea levels. Sea sand up to 12 feet thick preserved it. The village covers about 10 acres and lies beneath 39 feet of water about 400 yards off the coast. It is in a small bay overlooked by a Crusader fort at Athlit, 10 miles south of the port city of Haifa. The dig is sponsored by the government's Antiquities Authority. Like many underwater sites off Israel's coast, it came to light because the creation of the Jewish state in 1948 led to a construction boom. Huge amounts of beach sand were quarried, depleting the protective layer over the undersea sites. For archaeologists, the underwater location is a cause for crises. Every storm disrupts the ancient undersea world, and ``a wall or a skeleton that has lain undisturbed for thousands of years can be destroyed in a matter of weeks,'' Galili said. Among Galili's more striking finds is the skeleton of a woman aged about 18, lying in a fetal position, her hand making a clutching gesture. Nodules in the earholes of some skulls point to the inhabitants having been divers, since such nodules result from a disease common among people who spend too much time under water, he said. Galili said marks on the teeth in one skull suggest the man worked with ropes, using his teeth to help knot them. While there is no indication the villagers had already domesticated animals, the seeds found at the site imply that they had learned to grow crops, Galili said.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev in Danger of Becoming Irrelevant, Administration Official Says
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is wielding less and less power and is in danger of becoming irrelevant as restive Soviet republics wrest authority from the central government, a senior administration official says. The official, insisting on anonymity, said Thursday that Gorbachev's loss of power is a bigger threat to him than any coup by the military. Rumors of a military takeover have surfaced in Moscow in recent days, but the senior official discounted that possibility. It is highly unusual that a government official - even when guaranteed protection against being identified - would offer such a candid and damaging assessment of a world leader of Gorbachev's stature. Moreover, the portrayal of Gorbachev as a faltering figure clashes with the picture that President Bush tried to project when he flew thousands of miles to Helsinki this month to stand alongside the Soviet president in a demonstration that the superpowers are united against Iraq in the Persian Gulf crisis. As a result, the official's comments raised questions about whether the administration is reassessing its view of Gorbachev. Asked if Gorbachev's problems could complicate the way the United States deals with Moscow, the official replied: ``I think it could. It hasn't happened yet.'' Publicly, Bush has acknowledged that Gorbachev has serious problems, particularly with his crisis-ridden economy. Yet, he has been unreserved in his praise of the Soviet leader and has said it is in the best interest of the United States for him to remain in power. The official made his comments in response to questions during an interview with news service reporters. In a separate interview, Brookings Institution scholar Helmut Sonnenfeldt said, ``The administration is quite conscious of this decay of authority and power'' of Gorbachev and his government. ``I think that there is a crisis of authority that's been accumulating for some time,'' said Sonnenfeldt, a specialist in East-West relations who served in the Nixon and Ford administrations. ``The central government and the president (Gorbachev) himself are seriously lacking in authority,'' Sonnenfeldt said. ``He (Gorbachev) has this power that he has been getting from the Supreme Soviet, but is it not clear that anybody pays any attention and implements'' his orders. Rumors have swept Moscow in recent days of a military takeover amid curious troop movements in and around the city. The rumors reached the point where Soviet Defense Minister Dmitri Yazov felt compelled Wednesday to pledge the military's allegiance to the power structure and assert that the troop movements were routine. The senior administration official said Soviet history offers no precedent for such an attempt by the military. ``I think one of Gorbachev's big problems is not his own staying power,'' the official said. ``He's shown himself a pretty good master of that. But he's commanding less and less, and I think his real danger is becoming irrelevant. ``In other words,'' the official continued, ``power just kind of gravitates away from the union government to the constituent - to the republic governments.'' The official said the Kremlin still prevails on matters of foreign policy and the military. ``But I think that's his danger now, that he's being denuded of power,'' the official asserted. The official said it would be a setback if Gorbachev were unable to make agreements that are binding on the system. ``But we're not there yet.'' The official said most of the subjects being negotiated between Washington and Moscow are foreign policy and arms control matters that ``would be the last to be affected by the internal competition between the central government and the republics.'' Many of the Soviet Union's republics have declared independence, and nationalist groups have been agitating for a break with Moscow. Boris Yeltsin, elected recently as president of the Russian republic, the largest of the 15, has criticized Gorbachev for the slow pace of economic reforms. Yeltsin has demanded aditional powers for the republics. On Monday, the Soviet legislature granted Gorbachev sweeping new powers to take measures to stabilize the economy and to maintain law and order.

DOC.HEAD: Superpowers Move to Accord to Limit Conventional Arms in Europe
DOC.TEXT: The United States and the Soviet Union are close to agreement on a new treaty to cut their conventional arms in Europe. Two of the three remaining disputes were basically resolved Thursday at a meeting of Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. That left a disagreement over limiting aircraft to be ironed out in time for a 34-nation summit in Paris in mid-November. The steady withdrawal of Soviet troops and tanks from Eastern and Central Europe, along with sizable reductions in U.S. forces among the NATO countries, are already accomplishing what the treaty negotiators set out to do. However, the accord would make reductions of weapons - troops are being omitted - legally binding. And it would be a symbolic milestone in the easing of East-West tensions. Baker and Shevardnadze plan to meet again soon in New York to chip away at the aircraft issue and to make sure the tentative agreements on the two other issues stick. One would establish zones in which Noth Atlantic Treaty Organization and Warsaw Pact arms would be limited. The other would impose a ceiling on the percentage of either bloc's weapons that any one nation could retain. Baker said after seeing Shevardnadze that they had made ``some good progress'' toward the treaty, the projected centerpiece of the 34-nation summit. Shevardnadze said they had made ``real headway.'' The treaty, between NATO and the Warsaw Pact, has been in negotiation in Vienna since February 1989. An earlier, 15-year attempt to reduce tensions through cutbacks in troops and weapons failed. But when Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev set out to end the Cold War the outlook brightened. Still, nagging disputes stood in the way. U.S. and Soviet negotiators, racing the clock, have been meeting daily since last week - first in Washington and since then in New York. Although the treaty is not complete, Baker and Shevardnadze agreed to submit the tentative understandings on two of the three most troublesome issues to their allies. Immediately after the session, Baker briefed NATO foreign ministers, in New York for the special session of the United Nations General Assembly, on the results. A senior State Department official told reporters, meanwhile, there was ``basic agreement'' with the Soviets on establishing zones in which numerical limits would be placed on non-nuclear weapons. Also, Baker and Shevardnadze tentatively agreed on how high a percentage of permissible weapons any one nation could have in its arsenal, said the official, who demanded anonymity. The third major issue remains unresolved, although Baker volunteered that progress had been made on it. It concerns whether all European land-based aircraft of the two alliances should be included in the treaty, as the United States has proposed, or whether planes the Soviets say have defensive missions should be exempt. ``We have removed most of the gaps,'' the State Department source said separately. Much of the spadework was done by U.S. and Soviet negotiators before Baker and Shevardnadze met. They are trying to have all key issues settled so the painstaking process of preparing a text can begin and be completed by the time of the projected summit. A senior French official, briefing American reporters, said he was confident the treaty would be ready for signing at the Paris meeting. One of Thursday's breakthroughs concerned what technicians call the sufficiency rule. It concerns whether any single member of NATO or the Warsaw Pact should be allowed to hold more than 30 percent of permitted weapons, as the Bush administration proposes; or be allowed up to 40 percent, as Moscow favors. Evidently, Baker and Shevardnadze struck a compromise on that question. Asked if they had agreed on 30 percent or 40 percent, Baker said: ``It's neither one of these.'' ``We had a very productive discussion,'' Shevardnadze said. ``I would like to note quite substantial progress and a better understanding. ... We have made real headway.'' Earlier, Baker said the two sides still anticipate having a conventional forces treaty ``essentially agreed to in November, or we will be unable to have'' a summit. Still unresolved are verification procedures for determining whether provisions of the treaty are being observed. Also unsettled is a separate proposed U.S.-Soviet treaty to reduce long-range nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines by about 30 percent. Bush hopes to sign that accord in Moscow in December. Bush is expected to see Shevardnadze when the president comes to New York this weekend to address the special General Assembly session Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Ike's Hometown Celebrates 100th Anniversary of 34th President's Birth
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: By 1944, Army careerist Dwight David Eisenhower had five stars, an Allied Forces command, but no hometown. For years, the man who later became the nation's 34th president had incorrectly given Tyler, Texas, as his birthplace. Enter Jennie Jackson, a retired schoolteacher, principal and amateur historian in Denison, a small town 70 miles north of Dallas. She remembered rocking an Eisenhower infant on her knee in 1890, and wondered if it was the general. She secretly wrote Eisenhower, who told her to contact his mother, Ida. She wrote back confirming the general was indeed the same ``David Eisenhower'' Miss Jackson remembered. She then went public with a campaign to save the small clapboard house where Eisenhower was born. Miss Jackson died shortly after she persuaded the city to buy the house in 1946, but not before a reunion with the future president that year when he visited Denison. Eisenhower was elected president in 1952. ``The main thing was he was born in Denison and that means a lot to have a president born here,'' said Vivian Hassel, 82, a former tour guide at the birthplace, now a state historic landmark. A failed grocery business in Kansas and a new job with the Katy Railroad brought the Eisenhower family to Denison in 1888, Mrs. Hassel said. About eight months after Eisenhower, the third of seven sons, was born Oct. 14, 1890, the family moved to Abilene, Kansas. Originally named David Dwight Eisenhower, he reversed the names by high school. On Saturday and Sunday, Denison residents will celebrate the 100th birthday of the native son they almost never had, with a parade, 10-kilometer run, birthday party, ball and even a President and Mrs. Eisenhower look-alike contest. Attending the ceremonies will be Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, and Eisenhower's nephew Earl Eisenhower Jr. A special coin commemorating the 100th birthday will be unveiled by the U.S. Department of Treasury. City officials are holding the anniversary early to prevent an overlap with the Abilene celebration next month. Although the Kansas city is also closely associated with Eisenhower, his Denison connection is no secret. Last year, more than 75,000 tourists visited the modest two-story home, and Mayor Ben Munson said there are plans to double the size of the two-acre park where it is located. A 15-minute tour of the house includes the humorous tale of the tumbling block quilt, the only original Eisenhower family possession inside the birthplace. Sewn by Eisenhower's mother and her sons, including the former president, it was donated by a family member years ago, spurring a controversy among the Eisenhower relatives. For years the family fought over the ownership of the quilt, said Ajkeem Elahi, the park's manager. This year, a family member visited the house and laughed when she saw it. ``She said they're still fighting over that,'' he said. Other items in the house include Miss Jackson's black spindle rocker. And there is an oil portrait of an American Indian, painted by Eisenhower after he became president. ``Winston Churchill got him started on painting,'' Elahi said.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Moving to Transform Kuwait Into an Iraqi Province
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein is moving to transform Kuwait into an Iraqi province by altering the country's demography, erasing its national identity and removing its infrastructure, U.S. analysts say. ``What we are seeing is the de-Kuwaitization of Kuwait. This is the history of the Iraqi regime,'' one U.S. official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The Iraqi president has been changing Kuwait since the Aug. 2 invasion - even renaming streets and institutions to eliminate signs of the ousted government, officials said. Every passing day takes the country further away from what it once was. At the same time, the Kuwaiti resistance inside the occupied country is faltering. ``The resistance is past its apex,'' an official said. ``They put up a brave effort, but they can't sustain it'' There were reports after the invasion of car bombings and killings of Iraqi soldiers. But the Iraqis retaliated brutally, making house-to-house searches to find resistance leaders, Kuwaiti exiles said. Saddam's pattern in Kuwait is similar to the way he rid Iraq of internal dissidents, analysts said. ``It's a fairly basic notion of depopulation,'' said another official, who also spoke on condition on anonymity. ``So far, what you see is a logical unfolding of (Saddam's) plan to secure Kuwait as the 19th province of Iraq. He is changing the Kuwaiti demography,'' said Richard W. Murphy, a former assistant secretary of state for the Middle East and a scholar at the Council of Foreign Relations. The man Saddam put in charge of Kuwait has a bloody past, officials said. Known as the ``butcher of Kurdistan,'' Iraq's minister of local government, Ali Hasan Al-Majid, ordered poison gas used against Kurdish dissidents in 1988, U.S. officials said. He was involved in the forced resettlement of 500,000 Kurds who were moved from the mountains to unfamiliar desert villages. Moreover, he was responsible for rounding up 60,000 Shia Moslems in 1980 and forcibly trucking them to Iran. The Shias were suspected of planting bombs in Iraq. The most recent attempt to make over Kuwait came Thursday when Iraq gave Kuwaitis until Oct. 31 to adopt Iraqi citizenship. The Iraqi Interior Ministry did not say what would happen to Kuwaitis who did not change their citizenship. Saddam might be planning to seek U.N.-sponsored elections once he has given Kuwait a new complexion, officials said. That scenario could create fissures in the worldwide alliance against Iraq partly because the al-Sabah royal family of Kuwait is not resoundingly popular with other Arab leaders, according to Hermann Eilts, director of Boston University's Center for International Relations. Kuwait had a population of about 2.5 million when Iraq invaded, officials said. But only 550,000 people were native Kuwaitis, and about 450,000 of them were in the country at the time of the invasion. Since then, the native Kuwaiti population has dwindled to about 250,000, officials said. When Kuwaitis have been allowed to flee the country - as when Iraq opened up the border to Saudi Arabia 10 days ago - the Iraqis have seized their identity cards and other papers before letting them go. Iraq also has detained young Kuwaiti men. Large numbers of foreigners also live in Kuwait, including an estimated 300,000 Palestinians, the largest foreign community still in Kuwait. There also are about 120,000 Indians, many of whom are trying to leave. Scores of thousands of Asians already have fled. Saddam has placed close to 200,000 troops in Kuwait, with at least that many more across the border in Iraq. Although Saddam has yet to move Iraqi citizens into Kuwait to take over jobs, he may do so in the future, officials said. Saddam's soldiers also have been aggressive in looting Kuwait, stealing everything from hospital equipment to traffic lights. Many goods - food, fruit and video recorders - have shown up in the markets of Baghdad where international trade sanctions have taken a toll on the number of goods available, officials said. ``Saddam may be telling his people, in effect, that here is a payback,'' one official said.

DOC.HEAD: CDC Statistics On U.S. AIDS Cases
PM-AIDS Conference
DOC.TEXT: Here are the latest statistics on acquired immune deficiency syndrome in the United States, as reported by the national Centers for Disease Control:
DOC.HEAD: Number of Cases
DOC.TEXT: Total cases reported since June 1981: 146,746. Total deaths: 89,761, or 61 percent of all cases.
DOC.HEAD: Transmission Categories
DOC.TEXT: Homosexual or bisexual males: 86,113, or 59 percent. Intravenous drug abusers: 31,114, or 21 percent. Homosexual male and drug abusers: 9,776, or 7 percent. Heterosexual cases: 7,418, or 5 percent. Transfusion or blood cases: 3,659, or 2 percent. Hemophilia patients: 1,417, or 1 percent. Children of parents with AIDS or at risk: 2,091, or 1 percent. Other or undetermined transmission cause: 5,158, or 4 percent.
DOC.HEAD: Age and Race
DOC.TEXT:
Childhood cases (under age 13): 2,525, or 2 percent. Cases among whites: 81,120, or 55 percent. Cases among blacks: 41,166, or 28 percent. Cases among Hispanics: 22,983, or 16 percent. Cases among Asians or Pacific Islanders: 898, or 1 percent. Cases among American Indians or Alaskan natives: 210, or 0 percent.
(NOTE: These statistics are through August 1990 and have been rounded to the nearest whole percent. Cumulative totals are for AIDS cases reported since June 1981, and include at least 75 cases subsequently found to have occurred prior to that date.)

DOC.HEAD: Easy Senate Confirmation Seen for Supreme Court Nominee
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court nominee David Souter can expect an easy confirmation vote in the Senate next week following a lopsided endorsement by the Judiciary Committee. But the breadth of voting support enjoyed by the New Hampshire jurist belies widespread doubt lawmakers are expressing about what kind of justice he'll make. ``I will vote for Judge Souter's confirmation. I do not do so enthusiastically,'' Judiciary Committee Chairman Joseph Biden said before his panel voted 13-1 in favor of Souter on Thursday. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., was the dissenter. If President Bush takes the ease of Souter's approval as a sign it can easily win an even more conservative choice in the future, he would be wrong, said Biden, D-Del. ``Judge Souter falls within the sphere of candidates acceptable to this committee,'' he said. ``Other nominees ... could well fall outside of that sphere.'' Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, announced Thursday night that he and Republican leaders had agreed to hold the Senate confirmation vote Tuesday. Bush hailed the committee action and renewed his request for a Senate vote before the Supreme Court begins its new term Monday. But the Jewish holiday of Yom Kippur this weekend and Senate rules led Mitchell to rule that out. Souter, who would replace retired Justice William Brennan, a liberal, did not attend the committee meeting but issued a statement from New Hampshire thanking the senators ``for their courtesy and consideration.'' ``I am gratified by their action. I await the decision of the full Senate,'' he said. The key to Souter's acceptability to the committee was his insistence during the hearings that he was open-minded on whether the court should reverse its 1973 Roe vs. Wade ruling that legalized abortion. ``Is it likely that President George Bush will nominate anyone who is strong in civil liberties and civil rights?'' said Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill. ``We probably have as moderate a choice as George Bush will send to the Senate.'' Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, said he was willing to give Souter the benefit of the doubt, of which he saw much. ``The bottom line is that we just don't know how he will vote on such issues as privacy and discrimination,'' Metzenbaum said. ``My sense is that David Souter is a fair and open-minded jurist who knows well the weight of the responsibilities which will be placed upon him.'' ``I hope I'm not wrong,'' Metzenbaum said. ``I hope I am wrong,'' said Kennedy, one of only a handful of senators to oppose Souter so far. ``I am troubled that if Judge Souter joins the current closely divided Supreme Court, he will solidify a 5-4 anti-civil rights, anti-privacy majority inclined to turn back the clock on the historic progress of recent decades,'' Kennedy said. Conservative Republicans also had doubts about the nominee but felt obliged to support the president. ``Aspects of Judge Souter's testimony were of little comfort to legal conservatives, including this senator,'' said Sen. Gordon Humphrey of New Hampshire, who still voted for him in committee. Norma McCorvey, the plaintiff in the Roe vs. Wade case, said at a news conference in Los Angeles, ``It is appalling that women may lose their reproductive rights. The U.S. Senate Judiciary Committee should not have voted to confirm Judge Souter because he refused to answer the ultimate question of how he feels about abortion.''

DOC.HEAD: Don't Mention it Seems to Be the Policy
DOC.TEXT: ``Fear matters,'' says Georgia State University economic forecaster Donald Ratajczak, so it doesn't surprise him if the Bush administration is dancing away from using the word ``recession'' to describe the state of the economy. It doesn't surprise Alfred Kahn, either. A retired Cornell University professor, Kahn was chairman of President Carter's Council on Wage and Price Stability. He recalls what happened in 1978 when he suggested that unless inflation were brought under control pronto the nation might face a deep depression. Stuart Eizenstat, a presidential aide, called up and asked him if he might just quit using that word. So next time out, Kahn used ``banana'' when he meant ``depression.'' He talked about The Great Banana of 1929. He said if inflation weren't brought under control, the nation might have a big banana. Kahn learned a political lesson. Fear matters and words alone can trigger fear. Recession is a loaded word, and economists who can't agree on whether the country is in one yet concur that the word itself can spur one on. ``Fear matters,'' said Georgia State's Ratajczak. ``But obviously what's in the pocketbook matters, too. If the pocketbook is still jingling, fear can soon be overcome.'' ``People start looking at their budgets and seeing what they can live without. They tend to make business slow down when they do that,'' said Bob Dieli, an economist for the Northern Trust Co. of Chicago. Small wonder that when the bad news came out Tuesday, six weeks before an election, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said, ``We don't believe we are in a recession right now.'' He was commenting on the Commerce Department's report that the economy grew at a stagnant annual rate of 0.45 percent in the second quarter of this year. And small wonder, at least to linguist Walker Gibson, that Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board of Governors, says he'd like to redefine recession. Gibson is founder of the Committee on Public Doublespeak of the National Council of Teachers of English. The usual definition is that a recession occurs after six months of decline in the gross national product, the total value of new goods and services in the nation. Greenspan told Congress last week he'd prefer a less rigid definition. A true recession, he said, is a ``cumulative unwinding of economic activity.'' Richard Rahn, chief economist for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, said he can't blame the White House for refusing to label the economy's current state a recession. ``If I were the president, I wouldn't say we were in a recession, either,'' Rahn said. ``They are not in a position to give judgment calls the way we and other outsiders are. They are the guardian of the statistics. They need to be very, very cautious.'' The fear that the word recession triggers, said Gibson, tells something about language itself. The word ``recession,'' he said, ``almost certainly started as a euphemism for an even more fearsome word, depression. ``But it's been used so long as a euphemism that it's lost its power to euphemize,'' he said. ``Now they talk about `downturns.'''

DOC.HEAD: Budget Bargainers Grapple With Tax Differences, Hope For Deal
DOC.TEXT: White House and congressional negotiators narrowed differences Thursday over their budget problems with reported agreements on energy and luxury taxes and cuts in benefit programs. But key disputes remained to block a deal that would avoid bone-deep cuts in federal programs on Monday. The two sides, racing the calendar, swapped offers into the early hours Friday, trying to put together the final pieces of a $500 billion, five-year deficit-cutting package. Parts of the pact tentatively agreed to were an additional 8-cent-per-gallon gasoline tax; a small tax on the energy content of all fuels and 10 percent taxes on luxury items ranging from fancy cars to electronic equipment, said one official who asked to not be identified. About $60 billion in savings over the five years would come from cuts in Medicare. Half would hit the elderly, including about a $5.70 increase in the $28.60 monthly premium they pay for the program's hospitalization coverage. Another $14 billion in cuts would be made in federal workers' employment and retirement benefits, and $12 billion more would come from reductions in support payments for farmers. The federal gasoline tax is now 9 cents per gallon. States add additional taxes on top of that. The energy tax would be three-quarters of a cent per million BTU, a measure of eergy. It takes about eight or nine gallons of gasoline to yield a million BTU, so the extra tax would amount to about 0.08 cents per gallon, hardly enough to register at the pump. Applied to high-quality coal burned by an electric utility, the tax would raise the cost of a 500-kilowatt-hour monthly electric bill for a small home by about 4 cents. If successful before Monday, the bargainers would allow the government to sidestep $85 billion in spending cuts that the law would otherwise require. The slashes would result in furloughs for many of the 2.1 million federal civilian workers, including FBI agents and air traffic controllers. Republicans were willing to accept a toned-down version of the cut in capital gains tax rates that President Bush has sought since he was a presidential candidate in 1988. The battle between Democrats and the administration over the tax has been the key barrier to a budget deal. Capital gains - the profits from the sale of assets such as corporate stock or houses - are now taxed like ordinary income. But Democrats seemed uncertain about whether in return they would demand higher income tax rates on the wealthy or a limit on the tax deductions the well-to-do could take, said officials who asked to not be identified. ``I don't mean to put it in a negative way, but there is still a possibility of failure,'' said House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash. ``The odds are we will succeed.'' Bush had argued that cutting capital gains tax rates would boost the economy. Democrats say the tax cut would benefit the rich and want higher taxes on the wealthy in return. But the president was now willing to leave the rates constant if the increased value of an asset due to inflation is exempted, officials close to the talks have said. The proposal would apply only to property purchased after the plan became law. This official, like all the others who discussed the various proposals Tuesday night, spoke on condition of anonymity. Still undecided, however, was which tax boost the two sides would agree to as a trade-off. Republicans have proposed limiting income tax deductions for the wealthy, said one official who asked to not be identified. In one variation of the idea, people earning more than $200,000 annually would only be able to claim 95 percent of the deductions to which they would otherwise be entitled. Democrats are interested in that idea, but have also advanced two other proposals, said another official who demanded anonymity. They remain interested in raising the top-bracket income tax rate on the wealthiest Americans from the current 28 percent. People who are somewhat less well-off pay 33 percent in their top bracket. Democrats would like to boost the top rate on the rich, but they are willing to settle for a new level below 33 percent. They have also proposed lifting the earnings ceiling above which Medicare taxes are not taken out of paychecks. As part of Social Security withholding, people now pay a 1.45 percent tax to support Medicare on earnings up to $51,300 per year. They pay nothing on money they earn above that amount. Under the proposal, that ceiling would be lifted to $65,000 or $75,000. The bargainers remained close to agreeing on cuts in defense and domestic programs. The two sides appeared close to agreeing to reduce the military budget by $170 billion over the next five years from the amount it would need to stay abreast with inflation. They were also trying to find a way to reduce spending on benefit programs by $120 billion over the five years. One GOP suggestion for finding additional savings in benefit programs was to delay next year's cost-of-living increase for the 39 million Social Security recipients for three months. Another official said Republicans had offered to delay cost-of-living increases for 60 days for all federal benefits, including Social Security, veterans' benefits, and federal retirement programs. Democrats prefer increasing the tax on Social Security benefits. Recipients who earn $25,000 annually - $32,000 for couples - now must pay taxes on half their Social Security benefits. The Democratic proposal would boost that proportion to 85 percent. Earlier in the day, Bush continued to assail Democrats as the culprits in the months-long budget standoff, which has brought the government to the brink of the new fiscal year without any spending legislation in place. ``There may be senior citizens wondering why their Social Security checks are late,'' Bush said Thursday at a GOP breakfast in Minneapolis, citing a federal program that would be damaged by Monday's automatic cuts. ``We can't afford business as usual. The American people deserve better.'' Increasingly restive rank-and-file lawmakers, Democrat and Republican, complained that the compromise package in the works went too far to satisfy the opposite party. The disgruntlement signaled potential problems for whatever Congress is finally asked to vote on.

DOC.HEAD: Gunfire at Cabinet Member's Home, One Dead, One Wounded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with details of shooting, witness quote, guards under investigation. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Philippines-Aquino
DOC.TEXT: Shots were fired Friday at the Mindanao home of a member of President Corazon Aquino's Cabinet. One person was killed and another wounded. It was not immediately known who fired the shots at the home of Luis Santos, secretary of local governments, but Santos' guards were under investigation. Santos' home is in Davao City, 610 mles southeast of Manila, on Mindanao island. In a report from Davao, radio station DZXL said Santos had leaned over to kiss a grandchild when a bullet whizzed passed him and struck a member of his household. Santos told The Associated Press by telephone that a 67-year old family friend, Marcosa Reyes, was fatally wounded in the neck, and his 17-year old maid, Arlene Caballero, was hit in the left shoulder. He then hung up the telephone without giving further details. ``Suddenly there was shooting,'' said another maid, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``I don't know where it came from. No one came in or out.'' Police chief investigator Lt. Col. Efren Arayata said Santos' guards were being questioned and would undergo paraffin test to see if one of them fired the shots. The test determines if a person fired a weapon based on presence of powder on the hands. Santos arrived in Davao on Thursday at the invitation of local business leaders who were concerned about rumors of an impending military coup attempt. During a meeting, Santos assured the businessmen that the government was stable and could cope with any emergency.
