Local fears intensified with the arrival of a marine battalion reinforcing troops chasing a renegade colonel who defected from Mrs. Aquino's guard force and joined last December's attempt to oust her. Santos was a former police chief of Davao. He assumed the Cabinet post following the Aug. 20, 1987, assassination of Local Governments Secretary Jaime Ferrer. Two people were convicted of killing Ferrer, but the court never established who ordered his murder.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Actress Sharon Gless says she was worn out after six years of tracking bad guys on television's ``Cagney & Lacey.'' ``I just retreated. I worked on getting my act together, finding me again,'' she said. ``It sounds so corny. But I had to find out what I liked to do besides work.'' Miss Gless, who portrayed New York detective Chris Cagney on the CBS show, is feeling better now and has a new TV series, ``The Trials of Rosie O'Neill.'' The blond-haired, blue-eyed actress stars as an attorney who left a prestigious law firm for a job as a public defender after her husband dumped her for a younger woman. Miss Gless, 47, says Rosie isn't a hero but nn ordinary woman trying to find a meaningful life after spending her 43 years pleasing others. ---
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also moving on sports circuits.
DOC.TEXT: Hank Aaron says Oakland A's outfielder Jose Canseco is the best bet for breaking his major league baseball home run record. If he keeps playing, that is. ``That's the problem. Baseball players today can afford to quit,'' Aaron said Thursday. ``I had to keep playing. I needed the money.'' Aaron slammed 755 home runs in 23 seasons and retired after the 1976 season. He played all but two of his seasons with the Milwaukee and Atlanta Braves. Aaron, 56, in Lincoln to go to bat at fund-raisers for the Big Brothers and Big Sisters programs, said too much focus in baseball today is on money. ``You can't put a dollar value on the home runs, the runs batted in in your career,'' he said. ``Besides, a fool and his money always part.'' --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Actor Corey Feldman must stick to drug rehabilitation this time to avoid another arrest, a judge warned the teen-ager. Judge Gordon Ringer issued a warrant Thursday for Feldman's arrest but said he wouldn't have it enforced if Feldman completed a residential rehabilitation program. ``He realizes he has a real addiction problem. He has tried to deal with it through other means and has obviously been unsuccessful,'' said Feldman's lawyer, Richard Hirsch. ``He is committed to putting his career on hold and saving his life.'' Feldman, 19, who entered the program this week, was arrested twice on heroin-related charges. He began an outpatient abuse program shortly after his first arrest on March 9 and declared his independence from drugs. Then came his second arrest Sept. 21, when police said they found two balloons of heroin in his sock. Feldman appeared in the movies ``Goonies,'' ``Gremlins'' and ``Stand By Me.'' --- LAS VEGAS (AP) - The Riviera Hotel and Casino signed Frank Sinatra to an exclusive, two-year contract. The singer will perform at the Las Vegas Strip resort beginning New Year's Eve, Sam Distefano, the hotel's vice president of entertainment, said Thursday. The terms of the contract were not disclosed. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Julian Lennon wanted a little scenery - at most any cost. The son of the slain John Lennon recently bought his third home in less than three years. He paid nearly $1.3 million for his new Beverly Hills digs. ``He moved this time because he missed having a view. He didn't have a view at his last house, but he has one of Los Angeles at this one,'' said Erin Caldwell of Alvarez, Hyland & Young realtors. The 3,000-square-foot home is on a private drive and has three bedrooms, two bathrooms and a guest apartment. ``He likes its views, trees, big lawn and pool. He likes the country feel to it, with its pitched beam ceilings. And he likes its privacy,'' Caldwell said. ---
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version moving on sports circuits.
DOC.TEXT: A.J. Foyt will be on the racing circuit next year, despite a second operation on his injured legs and months of rehabilitation. ``I am not quitting. I plan to race Indy cars in 1991,'' Foyt said Thursday from a hospital. A four-time Indianapolis 500 winner, Foyt was in fair condition after a crash Sunday during a race in Wisconsin. Foyt, 55, broke his left leg, left heel and right foot. He also broke several toes and dislocated his left knee and right heel. ``It's been real rough, but I'm making real good progress,'' Foyt said from Methodist Hospital. Foyt said he should be able to race again early next year after rehabilitation.

DOC.HEAD: Fine Singing, Including Debuts, in `Giovanni'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will stand for PMs.
DOC.TEXT: The Metropolitan Opera's fourth opera in four nights of its new season was a resoundingly sung ``Don Giovanni,'' without a famous cast, and with two notable debuts. Met Artistic Director James Levine conducted the Mozart masterpiece. The young American baritone Thomas Hampson, from Spokane, has the figure and voice for Don Giovanni. Bass Paul Plishka, from Old Forge, Pa., was a nice contrast, deeper and more mature sounding, as his servant Leporello. Hampson might stress the swashbuckling a bit more; he seemed more at ease when Don Giovanni was trying to woo subtly than when he was being his most rakish. Plishka's comic timing and stage presence were always on target. Hans Peter Blochwitz, a tenor from Garmisch, Germany, made his Met debut as Don Ottavio. He's so good that if the baritone had been bad, we'd still have loved the evening. Blochwitz has sung Ottavio with the Vienna State Opera, in Hamburg and Amsterdam. He has the perfect voice for Mozart, Handel and Bach, which he has been singing. One hopes that he has no interest in heavier music that would harm his voice and that he will return often to the Met. Patricia Schuman, a native of Los Angeles, made the other debut, as Donna Elvira. She switched from mezzo-soprano to soprano in 1985, has sung both the title roles in ``Carmen'' and ``Madama Butterfly'' in San Francisco. In December, she'll sing opening night of the La Scala season in Mozart's ``Idomeneo.'' Her voice is lovely and has enough vibrato for texture, making a contrast to the evening's other two sopranos. Cheryl Studer of Detroit began the evening as the virginal Donna Anna with a small voice. After Don Giovanni kills her father, she is determined on revenge and sings with much more strength. She hit and held high notes beautifully, then sometimes grated when releasing notes. But her final aria, which includes coloratura singing, was splendid and received much applause. The other soprano, Marie McLaughlin of Motherwell, Britain, as Zerlina was excellent, too. Her bridegroom-to-be, Masetto, who can often be ignored, was sung by Julien Robbins, who made a solid role of it. Robbins, from Harrisburg, Pa., also sang on opening night. The current production, by Franco Zeffirelli, was new last March.

DOC.HEAD: Ethics Panel Reaching Time to Decide on Probe of Senators
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Ethics Committee is at a turning point in its investigation of five senators who tried to help former savings and loan operator Charles H. Keating Jr. when his institution was heading toward collapse. Committee members have been meeting over the last two weeks to decide whether the cases of some or all the senators should be either dismissed or expanded. Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan Association in Irvine, Calif., was taken over by the government in April 1989, and it could cost taxpayers more than $2 billion to cover the thrift's losses. Keating and his associates contributed some $1.3 million to the campaigns and causes of the five senators: Republican John McCain of Arizona and Democrats Alan Cranston of California, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona, John Glenn of Ohio and Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan. All have said their intervention was routine assistance for someone who complained of unfair treatment by regulators. The committee meetings could end a preliminary inquiry. Any cases kept alive could bring those senators long ethics hearings structured like a trial. The preliminary phase was announced by the six-member committee last Dec. 22, and a few senators have grumbled that ethics investigations take too long. In response, Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., a member of the committee of three Democrats and three Republicans, said the senators on the panel ``wish it could be expedited.'' Asked if the long investigation was unfair to the senators known as the ``Keating Five,'' Helms replied: ``How do you define unfairness? Do you suggest we don't work every angle? We just have a heavy load.'' The case is proving difficult because no specific Senate rule provides guidelines on what constitutes undue influence by a member of Congress who intervenes with regulators. In this case, all five senators met with regulators on Keating's behalf. The Ethics Committee must determine if the senators' actions in the Keating case violated a resolution prohibiting ``improper conduct which may reflect upon the Senate.'' The senators intervened with U.S. banking regulators in April 1987 on behalf of Keating. Edwin J. Gray, then chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said the four senators with whom he met in the first of two meetings backed a deal to aid Keating's future operations. The senators - all except Riegle, who did not attend - vigorously denied that any deal was proposed. At a second meeting with the regulators in charge of the Lincoln examination, all five senators were told that matters in the case would be referred to the Justice Department for a criminal investigation. Keating this month was indicted in California on state criminal fraud charges. Congressional sources said that lacking a specific rule on senators' conduct with executive branch officials, the ethics panel could seek guidance from the recent cases of former House Speaker Jim Wright, D-Texas, and Sen. Dave Durenberger, R-Minn. Wright resigned from Congress more than a year ago after the House ethics committee filed formal charges against him. Durenberger was denounced by the Senate in July for violating Senate rules on receipt of gifts, speaking fee limits, financial disclosure and campaign contributions. In Durenberger's case, one key issue was not covered by a specific rule. The Ethics Committee found that Durenberger acted deceptively to hide his ownership in a Minneapolis condominium from the Senate, so he could receive rent reimbursements to which he was not entitled. The committee said the senator abused his office and misused funds ``through a pattern of improper conduct that has brought discredit upon the United States Senate.'' Wright, like the senators in the Keating inquiry, had intervened with the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. In the speaker's case, he did so on behalf of Texans who complained of unfair treatment. While the House ethics committee eventually found little evidence of undue influence by Wright, the special counsel in the case wrote of the principles governing proper and improper intervention. The counsel, Richard Phelan, said a House advisory opinion considered it proper for a member to request information or a status report from regulators; to urge prompt consideration of a matter; arrange for interviews or appointments; express judgments and call for reconsideration of a decision. But Phelan said a member should treat all constituents equally, and there should be no direct or implied suggestion of favoritism or reprisal involving the agency.

DOC.HEAD: Refuelers Vote to End Walkout
DOC.TEXT: Aircraft refuelers voted to return to work today, ending a strike that crippled airline schedules for three days and stranded thousands of passengers. The two major domestic airlines, Ansett and Australian, canceled 200 flights Thursday and also had cut back today's schedule. The strike hit during the school holidays and had threatened to extend to the three-day Labor Day holiday starting Saturday in some areas. The walkout affected an estimated 20,000 travelers and led to bus and train services being completely booked. The strike began in Perth over reports of plans to reduce refueling crews from two people to one. Workers Union assistant national secretary Ken McGrath told a news conference that the workers accepted offers of talks with oil companies.

DOC.HEAD: Arts Endowment Denies Claim it Backed `Oral Sex' Puppet Show
DOC.TEXT: The National Endowment for the Arts is vigorously denying evangelist Pat Robertson's claim that it subsidized an Atlanta arts festival last week where a ``children's puppet show'' allegedly featured simulated oral sex. ``This is just the latest example of the continual distortion of fact by the arts endowment's most virulent critics, those intent on eliminating the agency at any cost, even that of the truth,'' said NEA spokesman Jack Lichtenstein. Robertson said Thursday that his Christian Coalition, based in Chesapeake, Va., had responded to the puppet show by sending every member of Congress petitions demanding that the arts endowment be abolished. ``The Atlanta Arts Festival is supposed to be a family affair,'' Robertson said in a statement. ``If the weirdos on the federal dole do not stop peddling obscenity and pornography, members of Congress will hear from angry voters in November.'' Robertson, who was a presidential candidate in 1988, blanketed Congress with the petitions as the House braced for an expected floor showdown next week over proposals to impose new anti-obscenity curbs on the $171 million federal arts agency. One of the proposed amendments, sponsored by Rep. Phil Crane, R-Ill., would abolish the NEA. The main bill would extend the agency's life for five years beyond Sunday, when its statutory authority expires. Lichtenstein and the Georgia Council on the Arts, which received $400,000 from the NEA this year, denied that any federal funds were spent on the Atlanta festival or the puppet show. Festival officials said the puppet show, staged as a ``surrealistic morality play'' for adult audiences only, was financed entirely by ticket sales and concession receipts, without support from any government source. Atlanta puppeteer Jon Ludwig, who wrote and designed the show titled ``Zeitgeist,'' denied Robertson's charge that the performance featured ``approximately five minutes of simulated foreplay between two puppets followed by an exhibit of oral sex acts.'' ``This was a scene about temptation,'' Ludwig said. ``It was intended to be satirical. After all, what literally happened is that two pieces of plastic rubbed against each other. ``It was not simulated oral sex. It's impossible. How can puppets do that? They don't even have the parts. It was like finding children playing with Ken and Barbie dolls in the back room and calling Pat Robertson,'' Ludwig said. Robertson's protest apparently originated with the Rev. John Norton, a 55-year-old Methodist minister from the Atlanta suburb of Marietta, who said he wandered into the puppet show at the festival last Friday night. ``I have no problem with oral sex,'' Norton said the next day. ``But an open oral sex show for children to visualize and experience in one of their popular forms of entertainment is more than I felt belonged on public display.'' Ludwig said the show won a standing ovation from the audience of 800 people and a favorable review in the local press. Patricia Gann, the festival's executive director, said the only complaint came from Norton. Ms. Gann said a half-dozen children watched the 45-minute show, even though the audience had been warned repeatedly - through posted signs and pre-performance announcements - that the production was suitable for adults only.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela to Make Eight-Country Trip Next Month
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela will leave next month on an eight-country trip that will include the Soviet Union, the African National Congress has announced. Mandela, 72, has traveled widely as ANC deputy president since his release from 27 years' imprisonment last February. The black nationalist leader visited the United States in June. The itinerary announced Thursday called for Mandela to arrive Oct. 8 in Paris for a meeting with French President Francois Mitterrand, then travel to Moscow on Oct. 9. He would also visit India, Malaysia, Brunei, Australia, Indonesia and Japan before returning to South Africa on Nov. 2. The ANC aims to bring an end to white minority rule in South Africa, where 28 million blacks have no vote in national affairs. The 5 million whites control the economy and maintain separate districts, schools and health services.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Luckless Sudan - Every Calamity That Can Befall a People
DOC.TEXT: Not many Americans have ever thought much about the Sudan but, for the State Department, that East Africa giant suddenly has become a problem that is making a lot of diplomats sit up and take notice. It's hard to imagine a more luckless place than Sudan, a country three times the size of Texas with the potential to be Africa's breadbasket. But it has been plagued by virtually every calamity that can befall a people - drought, civil war and misrule. The Sudan story lacks the drama or the security component of the Persian Gulf for U.S. policy makers. It is, above all, a story of human deprivation on a massive scale, a story of millions of desperate people, many of whom are dying slow deaths. Things are bad and getting worse, and U.S. officials hope to be able to talk about the situation with Sudanese President Omar el-Bashir, who was arriving in New York this afternoon for the United Nations summit meeting on children. When describing el-Bashir's tenure as head of a military government, U.S. officials no longer bother about diplomatic niceties. ``I think it would be well if Sudan's leaders looked back at the last drought (in sub-Saharan Africa). Eleven of 13 governments were overthrown by popular outrage by failure to respond,'' said Andrew Natsios, the top U.S. official for foreign disasters. ``Half the country is starving to death. That is a recipe for massive political convulsions.'' Among other alleged misdeeds, Natsios accuses el-Bashir of ordering air raids on a barge carrying food supplies this past week at a time when top officials of his government were seeking $150 million in new food aid from the United States. The presumed purpose of the bombing missions is to prevent food from reaching the hungry in territory held by southern-based rebels who have been fighting northern domination for years. Other air raids have taken place near U.N. food relief sites, Natsios said. The Sudanese Embassy had no comment on the allegations. More than a quarter of a million Sudanese died of disease and starvation two years ago. Experts predict an even worse situation this year - some estimates run into the millions - because the drought has returned and interest among donors in a major relief effort is feeble so far. Other contributing problems are rampant nepotism and the country's ``awful economic policies,'' according to a State Department expert. Chronic civil war between the Moslem north and the non-Moslem south has produced more than 3 million displaced people out of a population of more than 20 million. More than 380,000 have fled to refugee camps in Ethiopia. Numerous foreign relief workers have abandoned the Sudan in frustration. As an example, a train loaded with food earmarked for the hungry in southern Sudan, officials say, has been sitting idle for more than a year at a northern site, denied permission by the government to deliver its cargo. With the help of a 100,000-ton food contribution, the United States and other foreign donors were able to keep human suffering in Sudan to a minimum last year. Now, Sudanese authorities have asked the United States for a food donation 10 times last year's combined total. How the United States will respond has been the subject of internal deliberations this week. There is another issue, almost forgotten in the face of more pressing problems, on the U.S.-Sudanese agenda: Sudan is one of the few countries worldwide that has shown sympathy for the Iraqi side in the Persian Gulf crisis. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - George Gedda has covered foreign affairs for the Associated Press since 1968.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Prime Minister Leaves for U.S., Middle East Trip
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu left for New York today to begin a 12-day trip to the United States and the Middle East in which he will explain Japan's response to the Persian Gulf crisis. Kaifu will be the first leader of a major industrialized country to visit the gulf region following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait nearly two months ago. He will travel to Egypt, Jordan, Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Oman after attending a United Nations conference on children in New York and meeting with President Bush on Sunday. One topic of discussion is certain to be the plan unveiled by Kaifu on Thursday to send non-combat military personnel overseas despite Japan's no-war constitution. They would participate in a U.N. Peace Cooperation Corps, which Kaifu stressed would only be used for peacekeeping activities and would not need to be armed. The government argues that creation of the corps would not require revision of Japan's post-World War II constitution that renounces the use of force to settle international disputes. It is unclear if the corps would be available to assist U.S. and other forces in the Saudi Arabian desert because Parliament will have to approve the plan. Kaifu's announcement came amid criticism from the United States that Japan should do more to support the multinational force arrayed in the gulf to deter further aggression from Iraq, which invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. Japan has pledged to contribute $4 billion, including $2 billion in logistical support for the gulf forces and $600 million in emergency commodity loans to Egypt, Turkey and Jordan. The remaining $1.4 billion is to be disbursed to those three nations and other countries hurt by the crisis. Japan last month also pledged to send about 100 civilian medical personnel to the Middle East.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmaker Calls for Stricter Controls on 900 Phone Service
DOC.TEXT: A computer-generated telephone call tells an 11-year-old boy he can win a trip and a prize if he dials a 900 long-distance number and answers the question: ``What is the name of Batman's car?'' He gets confused when he calls the number and keeps dialing repeatedly. He gets nothing. Mom gets a $120 phone bill. A TV ad asks kids to call Santa Claus using a 900 number. The callers then are told that Santa is in the bathroom, so they should call back later. No Santa. Big phone bills. Rep. Bart Gordon, D-Tenn., cited these and other ``horror stories'' Thursday while urging the House telecommunications subcommittee to adopt his bill to impose strict federal regulations on the burgeoning 900-number audiotext industry. Gordon said ``$120 is not as much as some have lost on these services, but it is more than many people have for such nonsense.'' He said it was ironic that the telephone company involved in the Batman case, in which the answer was ``the Batmobile,'' had a policy of not carrying services directed at children. ``The attitude seems to be, `Policy or no policy, if there is money to be made, let it slide,''' Gordon said. There is a lot of money to be made in 900 calling, said the subcommittee's chairman, Rep. Edward Markey, D-Mass. He said the industry had revenues of $480 million in 1989 and is expected to double that this year. By 1992 it is expected to be a $3.2 billion industry, he said. Most of the audiotext industry is legitimate, witnesses said. But they said companies that impose excessive charges and use deceptive ads for games of chance, sex talk, easy credit pitches and chats with Santa Claus are creating the prospect that a few renegades will kill off a valuable public service. Markey cited examples of consumers being duped into calling a 900 number ``to obtain a pre-approved credit card or to claim nonexistent prizes, only to receive a message to call yet another 900 number at a cost of up to $25 per call.'' Gordon's bill, among other things, would require free blocking of 900 numbers; free introductory messages describing the service; clearly stated charges and billing procedures; and a one-time opportunity to stop charges incurred through misunderstandings or unauthorized use. The Federal Communications Commission would be given oversight of the audiotext industry. Industry representatives testified against the bill. They said it would increase costs for everyone and that more vigorous enforcement of existing state and federal laws was the answer. They also said they were starting to police themselves. Audiotext companies offer many popular services to callers who dial 900-prefix numbers, including weather, sports, theater information, one-way ``chats'' with music personalities, shopping information, stock quotes and political pitches. The calls usually are carried by long-distance companies that do the billing under contract with the service provider. Customers typically receive flat-rate or per-minute charges for the calls on their phone bills. ``It is my view that 900-number services have the potential to be the telemarketing consumer fraud problem of the 1990s,'' said Daniel Clearfield, executive deputy in the Pennsylvania state attorney general's office. ``Each day throughout the United States, thousands of telephone consumers are being victimized by 900 numbers which provide either fraudulent or worthless services or which fail to adequately advertise or otherwise inform callers of their 900-number call,'' Clearfield said. He said attorneys general in Pennsylvania, Texas, Missouri, Kansas, California, Wisconsin and New York were pursuing remedies to 900-number fraud, but that national standards were needed. He said the Federal Trade Commission also was conducting some investigations. Ken McEldowney, executive director for San Francisco-based Consumer Action of California, rejected industry contentions that a few bad apples were spoiling the 900 barrel. He said a national survey by his group concluded that ``most advertised 900 numbers are unfair at any price.''

DOC.HEAD: Germany's Social Democrats Merge
DOC.TEXT: The Social Democrats from the two Germanys have merged and launched their uphill battle to end Helmut Kohl's reign as chancellor of united Germany. The merger of the two left-leaning parties on Thursday came six days before the Germanys are united and Kohl, head of the conservative Christian Democrats, becomes chancellor of the united country. Elections for a new all-German parliament are slated for Dec. 2. The Christian Democrats, bolstered by Kohl's drive for quick unification, have a healthy lead over the Social Democrats in opinion polls. On Friday, the Social Democrats are slated to formally confirm Saarland governor Oskar Lafontaine as their candidate for chancellor in December elections. ``There is nothing more important for us at this moment than helping Oskar,'' said former chancellor Willy Brandt, the honorary chairman of the Social Democrats. ``This is a great day for the Social Democrats of Germany,'' Brandt said as he addressed the party's congress. Banned by Adolf Hitler's Nazis, the Social Democrats regrouped in West Germany after World War II. But the Social Democrats in East Germany were forced to merge with the Communists in 1946 and ceased to exist. The party was revived after the popular revolution and the downfall of the Communist government last fall. Hans-Jochen Vogel, chairman of the West German Social Democrats, also became leader of the merged party. The East German Social Democratic leader, Wolfgang Thierse, became one of his four deputies.

DOC.HEAD: Bill to Compensate Miners, Downwind Residents Clears Congress
DOC.TEXT: Uranium miners and Western residents who lost their health from exposure to nuclear weapons tests would get a formal apology and compensation under legislation headed to President Bush's desk. The House on Thursday approved a bill that authorizes $100 million for a Radiation Exposure Trust Fund to pay people who developed cancer from either mining uranium or because they lived downwind of the Nevada test site for the atomic bomb. The Senate passed the bill previously. ``We are here saying that as a nation in the dangerous and difficult post-war period we were confronted with a brand new technology,'' said Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass., who led debate on the bill before the voice vote. ``Feeling very much threatened and needing that technology for our defense, we acted hastily.'' He said residents in the test area were exposed to levels of radiation ``we would not allow now. Miners were sent into the mines without even the slightest protection against the material they were being asked to mine.'' Frank said the bill is an acknowledgement that the government was wrong. People with cancer who lived in Nevada, Arizona or Utah downwind from nuclear testing between 1951 and 1958, or between June and July 1962, would be eligible for compensation under the legislation. Uranium miners in Colorado, New Mexico, Arizona, Wyoming and Utah from 1947 to 1971 who got cancer also would be eligible. It would be up to the Justice Department to determine the amount of compensation for each person and process claims. A driving force behind the legislation was Stewart Udall, a former congressman and interior secretary, whose brother Rep. Morris Udall, D-Ariz., is chairman of the House Interior Committee. He represented the uranium miners in a lawsuit against the federal government. The courts ruled the government was immune from prosecution because national security dictated a need for the uranium, but judges involved in the case urged the miners to seek redress from Congress. Rep. Wayne Owens, D-Utah, who once was a lawyer for the downwind residents, sponsored the legislation. Owens said the government, knowing the dangers of nuclear fallout, did not conduct testing when the wind was blowing toward the higher population centers in California and Las Vegas. ``In very real fact, the federal government made the decision to bomb these people to whom this bill makes an apology and a compensatory payment of a small amount,'' he said. Further legislation is needed to appropriate the money to actually pay the victims if this bill becomes law.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Save Weather Satellite
DOC.TEXT: A $70 million satellite is sending important weather data today because engineers overcame a problem that threatened to send it crashing to Earth. ``We would have lost half of our capability,'' Russell Koffler, deputy assistant administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, said Thursday of the near-failure. The satellite, known as NOAA-11, is the more important of two that orbit the Earth pole-to-pole, providing visible and infrared pictures to forecasters, Koffler said. ``It actually takes the temperature measurements of the atmosphere over the globe,'' he said. ``It provides the basic underlying information for the guy who gets on the radio and says it's going to be sunny tomorrow.'' The satellite was launched Sept. 24, 1988, from Vandenberg Air Force Base, Calif. It operates normally, at an altitude of 529 miles, with four gyroscopes - three for directional control so it won't tumble, and one backup. One gyro failed in August 1989 and the backup was put into service. That left no spare and NOAA asked programmers at General Electric's Astro Space Division in Princeton, N.J., to write new computer instructions to allow the satellite to operate on a single gyro. That work was to have been finished in 1991, but ground controllers recently sensed that a second gyro was about to fail. Programmers from GE, NOAA and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration accelerated the effort, which cost $230,000. The instructions were radioed to the satellite Aug. 8. Forty-four days later, last Friday, the ailing gyro failed as predicted. Koffler said there are no more miracles in store for NOAA-11 if the operative gyro fails. ``The other one can't be used to control the satellite,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Moving to OK Bigger Tapping of Strategic Reserve
DOC.TEXT: Congress is moving to give President Bush authority to conduct a bigger ``test'' sale from the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve. Energy Secretary James Watkins provided the opening Thursday for a second release of oil from the stockpile without forcing the declaration of an energy emergency by saying the 5-million-barrel sale Bush ordered a day earlier is too small to test the system. Recalling that the administration just two weeks ago had threatened to veto a larger test sale, Rep. Phil Sharp, D-Ind., asked Watkins at a hearing by House Energy and Commerce subcommittees how large a test he would like. ``Three times the (5 million) number is the number,'' the secretary replied. ``We want to run half a million barrels a day to test the system.'' The strategic reserve, created in 1975, consists of 590 million barrels of crude oil stored in salt deposits in Texas and Louisiana. ``We welcome the change,'' said Sharp, who had his staff draft a bill authorizing a new test sale of 15 million barrels and gather the signatures of several other committee members on it while Watkins was testifying. Anticipating no opposition in the Senate, Sharp said the bill could be on Bush's desk in two weeks. Despite the test sale that Bush's spokesman said was also intended to ``signal'' traders to slow their speculation on the future cost of oil, spot prices for West Texas Intermediate Crude rose another 90 cents per 42-gallon barrel Thursday to $39.55, double its price in July. ``We're not going into this test with the idea that it's going to bring the cost down $8 a barrel or something,'' Watkins said. ``That's not the purpose. If (Iraqi President) Saddam Hussein makes another threat, the market could jump again irregardless of the test sale.'' He emphasized that the test is ``not a drawdown'' but will ``give us optimum readiness to open the spigot if that is required in the future.'' Bid notices on the 5-million-barrel test were to be sent out today and the Energy Department expects to award contracts for it in mid-October. Bob Porter, a department spokesman, said an average of 167,000 barrels of oil - far short of the 500,000 barrels that analysts say is needed to drive prices down - will be released daily for 30 days. ``We think the bulk of the oil will be transported in November,'' Porter said. ``If the pipelines or tankers can take it, we'll deliver it to them the next day. But typically it takes 30 days for the commercial docks to schedule pickups.'' Top lawmakers, including Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas, have been urging Bush for more than a month to tap the reserve to stem the rapid rise in oil prices since Iraq's takeover of Kuwait on Aug. 2 and the subsequent embargo removing about 4.3 million barrels daily from the world market. Before acting Wednesday, Bush had repeatedly contended there was no actual shortage and no justification for tapping the government's emergency oil stockpile just because of rising prices. Watkins reaffirmed that policy Thursday, but acknowledged it could change quickly because of the growing tightness in world supplies as winter nears. He also cited problems that Saudi Arabia is having with corroded pipelines in trying to make up for production from Iraq and Kuwait and increased chances of fire or explosions at U.S. refineries now running near 100 percent capacity. ``U.S. crude stocks are above normal as of the moment, but they could go below normal by the end of October,'' Watkins said. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, said the administration needs to follow up on the test sale by calling on West Germany and France at a meeting today in Paris of the 21-nation International Energy Agency to also tap their emergency stockpiles. ``The tankers that left Iraq and Kuwait when the crisis began will soon unload their cargo,'' Dingell said. ``No more oil will follow, and at that point the real effects of a shortfall will hit. The administration should prepare for those eventualities now.''

DOC.HEAD: Brown Says He Doesn't Think Jackson Will Run in 1992
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Party chairman Ronald H. Brown says his ``personal view'' is that Jesse Jackson won't make a third run for president in 1992. Right now, no Democrat is showing much interest in a 1992 race, and Brown said he intends to encourage the presidential ambitions of prominent Democrats after the 1990 elections. ``I'm not advocating smoke-filled-room politics,'' the party chairman said during a wide-ranging interview. ``I am advocating common-sense, pragmatic politics which says we're serious about winning the White House and which says, if you're serious about that, you've got to take some risks and you've got to be willing to take some heat.'' ``We haven't been real successful five of the last six times and to ignore that fact is really lacking in good judgment,'' Brown said this week, referring to the fact the Democrats have elected only one president since 1968. Brown also said he won't urge the Senate leadership to grant floor privileges to Jackson as a shadow senator from the District of Columbia. ``I'm for statehood,'' Brown said during the interview. ``I'm not into the perks debate.'' As for presidential politics, Brown, who helped Jackson in the closing stages of his 1988 campaign, said, ``I think it's a tougher political environment for him now, a more difficult political environment, more to overcome.'' Brown said he believed it was appropriate for a party chairan to urge people to get into the race and also to urge candidates to drop out when it is clear someone has outdistanced the field. Brown said he was determined to ``get a consensus candidate early in the process and start running against George Bush rather than against each other.'' In his two previous campaigns for the nomination, Jackson fought on to the convention, long past the time he had any hope of becoming the nominee. But when asked if he had Jackson in mind when he talked about the need to persuade some candidates to get out of the race when they no longer had any hope of winning, Brown replied: ``I think there is too much emphasis, almost to the point of obsession, with whether Jesse is going to run or not going to run. It's significant, but I don't think it's the principal factor in the 1992 race. It's a decision he'll have to make and if he does, he does; if he doesn't, he doesn't.'' The chairman added, ``my personal view is that he doesn't run,'' but he said that view was not based on any clear signal from Jackson. In fact, in the summer of 1989, when Jackson moved to the District of Columbia, Brown predicted he would run for mayor, a plan he still insists was Jackson's intent. After mulling the race, Jackson announced he would not run. Instead, he opted for the symbolic office of shadow senator. In November, voters in the nation's capital will elect two shadow senators to lobby Congress to grant the city statehood. Jackson got close to 80 percent of the vote in the Sept. 11 primary. Jackson has not said he would demand access to the Senate floor, but his certain election to the post has spurred speculation that he would make such a request. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, has kept his silence on the subject. Brown said he thought it was a mistake for Jackson to run for shadow senator and indicated he assumes Jackson would seek floor privileges. ``That creates a very unpleasant confrontation with the senate leadership,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: President's Son Feisty, Insistent During Conflict-of-Interest Hearing
LaserPhoto DX2 of Sept. 27
DOC.TEXT: Neil Bush, the president's son, combatively denied conflict-of-interest charges stemming from his role as adirector of a failed savings and loan. At the final day of an administrative hearing Thursday, Bush interrupted a government lawyer and drew admonitions several times from the judge. Bush acknowledged he was a ``go-between'' for a line of credit that Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver extended to two developers he had business dealings with. But Bush said he had no financial interest in the projects for which the credit was extended. The two developers eventually defaulted on more than $132 million in Silverado loans. Bush, 35, was a director of the thrift, which failed in 1988, leaving taxpayers with a $1 billion tab for bailing out depositors. On several occasions, Adminstrative Law Judge Daniel J. Davidson warned Bush to answer questions directly and not to interrupt the government lawyer, Stephen Hershkowitz. ``You're doing it again,'' Davidson scolded Bush at one point. ``But you have to wait until the counsel finishes his question, because it's very difficult for the (court) reporter to take down two people talking at once.'' Bush replied, ``My lawyers advised me I should listen. I'm sorry.'' He quickly resumed his combative tone, however, and drew new warnings from the judge. In February, the federal Office of Thrift Supervision brought an administrative action against Bush that could lead to his being barred from the banking industry. The regulators contend Bush failed to adequately inform fellow Silverado directors of his business ties with developers Kenneth Good and Bill Walters. Bush insisted he ``had absolutely no doubt'' that his business dealings with Good and Walters did not conflict with his role as a Silverado director. Consequently, Bush said, he did not consult with Silverado's management about the question of a potential conflict. Aside from an appearance in May before a congressional committee investigating Silverado, Bush's fight with regulators mainly had taken the form of briefs and counterbriefs submitted to Davidson. At his long-awaited appearance at the three-day administrative hearing, Bush hadn't lost any of the defiance of his testimony on Capitol Hill. Bush insisted several times that, although Good and Walters invested in his oil company, JNB Exploration, he had no financial interest in the projects for which they got loans from Silverado. Previous testimony showed Silverado extended a $900,000 line of credit to a partnership formed by Bush and Good to explore for oil and gas in Argentina. The line of credit, intended to persuade Argentine officials that the venture had strong financial resources, never was used. Under questioning from Hershkowitz, Bush said lawyers for Good's company suggested Bush present the credit line proposal to the Silverado board. ``I was a go-between,'' Bush said. Bush insisted there was no conflict of interest in his role because he didn't stand to gain any financial benefit from the credit line, which he described as a sort of ``letter of referral,'' and because he abstained from voting on the proposal. Bush said he couldn't remember if it was his own idea to abstain from voting on the line of credit or if someone suggested it to him. Davidson will examine testimony from the hearing and in January recommend to Timothy Ryan, Office of Thrift Supervision director, what sanctions, if any, should be taken against Bush. Ryan is expected to make a decision in May. Bush would have the right to appeal to a federal court. Last week, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. sued Bush and other former Silverado directors for $200 million, alleging that gross negligence on their part contributed to the S&L's collapse. Bush was a director of Silverado from August 1985 to August 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Hair Loss From Chemotherapy May be Prevented, Experts Say
DOC.TEXT: First a patient hears the cancer diagnosis and then learns that the needed chemotherapy may cause temporary baldness. For many, the loss of hair is a huge cosmetic burden piled on the already terrible physical trauma of disease. But help may be on the way, according to a study published today in the journal Science. Dr. A.A. Yunis, of the University of Miami Jackson Memorial Hospital Medical Center, reports that he and his colleagues have discovered ``by chance'' that an experimental cancer drug blocks hair loss in laboratory rats injected with some chemotherapy agents. If the finding can be translated into drugs to treat humans, an expert said, ``it would be of tremendous benefit'' to cancer patients who now must endure the characteristic mark of chemotherapy baldness. Yunis said his team made the discovery while testing cancer-fighting drugs on lab rats that had been injected with leukemia cells. Half of the rats were treated with a drug called cytosine arabinoside, or ARA-C. The rest were treated with a combination of ARA-C and an experimental drug called ImuVert. ``We found, lo and behold, that the rats with ARA-C only became nude. They lost all their hair,'' said Yunis. ``The ones with both ARA-C and ImuVert, however, did not lose hair at all.'' Yunis said his group then tested ImuVert with another common cancer drug, doxorubicin, or DX. He said they found that rats with the DX-ImuVert combination also experienced no hair loss, while rats receiving only the DX lost hair on their heads and shoulders. ImuVert combined with a third cancer drug, cyclophosphamide, however, did not prevent hair loss in the rats, said Yunis. Dr. Ed Gelmann, chief of the department of medical oncology at Georgetown University in Washington, said that if a way can be found to prevent hair loss ``patients will feel much better about chemotherapy.'' Chemotherapy baldness is nearly always temporary. The hair usually grows back after the treatment cycle. Nonetheless, said Gelmann: ``A lot of patients focus on hair loss because it is so apparent. It can be quite a stigma. It would be a tremendous benefit to eliminate hair loss as long as it did not change the efficacy of the cancer chemotherapy.'' Yunis said that ImuVert appears to help combat leukemia while it is preventing chemotherapy baldness. He said the drug teamed with ARA-C halted the progression of leukemia in all but 20 percent of the laboratory rats tested. This result was better than among rats treated with ARA-C alone, he said. Dr. Gregory Curt, director of the clinical oncology department at the National Cancer Institute, said controlling hair loss during chemotherapy ``is a very serious thing for patients.'' ``The two things that concern patients the most about chemotherapy are nausea and that some people can get bald,'' he said. There are drugs to control the nausea, but there is no pill to block the hair loss. ``For both men and women, it is one of the side effects that concerns people the most because it changes one's body image,'' said Curt. The physician said he remembers at least two patients who were so concerned about the loss of hair that they actually refused lifesaving chemotherapy. ImuVert now is being tested as a chemotherapy agent against brain cancer. Yunis said it could be several years before it is approved for use on patients. He said the discovery also gives researchers a clue that may help find even more effective drugs to block hair loss among chemotherapy patients. He said ImuVert is a drug known as a biological response modifier because it alters the way some cells in the immune system act. If the precise effect of this drug on the hair follicles could be identified, then new drugs with this action could be developed, said Yunis. Science, which today published the University of Miami research report, is the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. Coauthors of the paper with Yunis are Atif M. Hussein and Joaquin J. Jimenez of the University of Miami, and Catherine A. McCall of Cell Technology Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Down
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 20,983.50, down 788.41 points or 3.62 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS: The Worst Is Yet to Come, Experts Say
With PM-AIDS-Stats
DOC.TEXT: More than half a million people developed AIDS worldwide in the past decade, but ``the worst is yet to come,'' an expert said at an international AIDS symposium. ``There is clearly going to be a wave that makes the experience of the '80s look relatively small - at least a 10-fold increase,'' said Dr. Jonathan Mann, director of the International AIDS Center at the Harvard School of Public Health. ``This is still a very new pandemic,'' Mann told delegates at a conference Thursday sponsored by the Morehouse School of Medicine and the federal government's Research Centers in Minority Institutions. ``The worst is yet to come.'' A pandemic is an epidemic over a large region. Mann cited projections saying at least 8 million people worldwide are infected with HIV, the virus that causes AIDS. That includes an estimated 5 million in Africa, and 1 million in the United States. A comparatively low 600,000 AIDS cases occurred worldwide in the 1980s, he said. ``We are not in a good state of affairs when it comes to AIDS and HIV in the United States and in the world,'' concurred Dr. James Curran, medical director of the HIV-AIDS division at the Centers for Disease Control. The United States, where 4,000 AIDS cases were reported between 1981 and 1984, reported that same number in just the past four weeks, Curran said. ``Those at the greatest risk have to learn to change their behavior or die. It's that simple,'' Curran said. Nationwide, 146,746 AIDS cases have been reported in the United States since the disease was first detected in 1981; 89,761 patients have died. The U.S. Public Health Service projects between 390,000 and 480,000 AIDS cases in this country by the end of 1993. ``We are far from turning a corner with AIDS in our own country,'' Curran said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Fatally Shoots Alleged Bank Robber
DOC.TEXT: Employees of a savings and loan hugged a 71-year-old man after he shot and killed a man they said was trying to rob the thrift. Charles Still shot Anthony Cipriano Tapia, 43, of Albuquerque, during the alleged robbery Thursday at Sandia Federal Savings and Loan, police spokeswoman Mary Molina Mescall said. Police questioned Still for several hours after the shooting but he didn't arrest him. The district attorney's office will investigate, Mescall said. Witnesses said a robber walked into the bank, pulled out a gun and demanded money. Authorities refused to release any other details of the attempted robbery or the shooting. In the bank parking lot after the shooting, two employees of the thrift hugged and thanked Still. Sandia employees described him as a regular customer. Still refused to discuss the shooting. His wife, Pearl, said Thursday her husband carries a weapon, but refused to say anything else about him. Still's friend and frequent companion on hunting and fishing trips said Still is honest, patriotic and obeys the law. ``He's not a troublemaker,'' Chester Gregory said. ``He doesn't start arguments. He's just about the nicest man you ever saw. ``But he's not the kind of guy you can push around either.'' A sticker on the front door of the Stills' home in southeast Albuquerque identified the residents as lifelong members of the National Rifle Association. Another sticker said: ``Warning! This house protected by a 12-gauge shotgun three nights a week. You guess which three.''

DOC.HEAD: New CIA Deputy Director For Operations Appointed
DOC.TEXT: Thomas A. Twetten, a career Central Intelligence Agency officer, has been named the CIA's deputy director for operations. The CIA said in a statement released Thursday that director William H. Webster had appointed Twetten, 55, to succeed Richard F. Stolz, 64, as head of the division that oversees espionage and covert activities. Twetten will assume his new duties Jan. 1, the agency said. Stolz, who served in the agency from 1950 to 1981 and then returned to CIA duty in 1988, is retiring. Webster's statement said Stolz ``has made an enormous contribution in charting the role of human intelligence in a rapidly changing world. He has dealt with some extraordinarily challenging issues, serving the agency and the country with great distinction.'' Twetten has served as Stolz's deputy since June 1988.
DOC.HEAD: Toy Bear and Elephant Recalled
DOC.TEXT: Toy bears and elephants are being recalled by two distributors, according to the Consumer Product Safety Commission. The commission said in a Thursday announcement that consumers may return the toys to the stores where they were purchased for a refund. The 3,600 ``Music Maker'' toy elephants are being recalled by the F.J. Strauss Co. of North Bergen, N.J., because of excessive lead in the paint and small parts that could choke young children if broken off. The Music Maker is a blue plastic elephant, painted yellow in some places, with a xylophone, drum, bells and ball popper built into the top. The commission said it carries the legend ``STRACO MADE IN CHINA.'' No injuries from the toy have been reported, the commission said. Being recalled by Soft Things Inc. of Brooklyn, N.Y., are 30,240 Video Bear Babies. The commission said the eyes and nose of the stuffed bear could break off and choke young children. The 5{-inch toy comes in various colors with a sewn-in tag reading ``China Berries for China House, Los Angeles XXX MADE IN CHINA.'' The commission said it knew of no injuries from the bear.
DOC.HEAD: Ex-AID Official Sentenced for Fraud
DOC.TEXT: A nine-month prison term has been handed a former U.S. foreign aid official who admitted accepting $11,130 from a medical consultant awarded contracts for public-health assistance programs. John Massey on Thursday also was fined $2,000 by U.S. District Judge George Revercomb. Massey was the last of three defendants receiving prison terms for corrupting the award of contracts for aid projects in Central America. The No. 2 official who supervised humanitarian aid to the Nicaraguan Contras earlier this year was given a 12-month sentence by another federal judge. The consultant was sentenced on Sept. 11 to eight months in prison and fined $6,000 for bribing an undercover operative of the Agency for International Development's inspector general's office. Massey, 51, had previously pleaded guilty plea to conspiring to defraud the government, a charge that carried a maximum five-year prison term. The AID project officer in Guatemala City, Guatemala, from 1987 to 1989, he admitted receiving the money during a time when he was giving the consultant inside information about contracts the agency was preparing to put out for bids. Massey also admitted helping the consultant write bid proposal documents.
