DOC.HEAD: Mitchell Denounces Black Supporters of Campbell
DOC.TEXT: Democratic gubernatorial candidate Theo Mitchell called black supporters of his Republican rival ``house niggers'' and ``Uncle Toms.'' Mitchell's comments, aired Thursday on WWDM-FM of Sumter, were in reference to the Rev. Richard Fisher, bishop of the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church, who this week announced his endorsement of Gov. Carroll Campbell. Campbell is vying for re-election in November. Mitchell, seeking to become South Carolina's first black governor, also criticized five members of the South Carolina Black Mayors Association for their support of Campbell. ``These are house niggers. These are the individuals we must expose. And let it be known that black leadership is no longer going to be this type to sell out its people,'' said Mitchell, a state senator. ``These are Uncle Toms. These are black prostitutes who are being still bought by white politicians, selling out their people, selling their integrity, their dignity and their honor,'' Mitchell said. Meanwhile, Bishop Johnnie M. Smith, a black Republican from Greenville, urged Mitchell to apologize to the black leaders he called prostitutes in comments earlier this week. ``The thing that concerned me is that if today, I were to hear Governor Campbell say to white leaders, `If you don't vote for me, something's wrong with you,' then I would think something was wrong with him,'' Smith said.
DOC.HEAD: U.S. Senate Candidate Parmer Accuses Gramm of Improper Reporting
DOC.TEXT: Democratic U.S. Senate candidate Hugh Parmer accused Republican incumbent Phil Gramm of hiding support from someone associated with a failed financial institution. Parmer said Gramm bought property from Louis Gibson, former board chairman of First Republic Bank in Corsicana, now NCNB Texas-Corsicana. He described the $25,000 loan to buy the property as a ``personal loan'' from Gibson. Gramm spokesman Larry Neal and Gibson said it was an owner-financed loan, secured by the property. The senator did nothing wrong and the charge is ``a new handful of mud,'' said Neal. Parmer said Gramm reported the transaction in his 1984 ethics filing from the House of Representatives, but not in any of his Senate ethics filings since 1985. He said Gramm was required to report the loan. Neal said Gramm only was required to report the transaction when it occurred.
DOC.HEAD: Branstad Adviser Contacted Lender In Brother's Case
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Terry Branstad's former top aide and current campaign adviser contacted federal lenders on behalf of Branstad's brother during negotiations over a farm loan. The aide, Des Moines attorney Doug Gross, said that he spoke with Farm Credit Service officials about the loan but said he did so as a private lawyer after being contacted by Branstad's brother, Monty. ``He was thinking about suing them and called me and asked me about the merits of the suit,'' Gross said. ``I never talked to the governor about it, ever.'' The flap first surfaced in reports published by the Mason City Globe-Gazette. The newspaper quoted Farm Credit officials as saying Gross called to urge them to ``sell to Monty at a low figure.'' Monty Branstad had been bargaining over land that had been foreclosed on but that he wanted to repurchase. Gross said he spoke twice to Ray Mechem, assistant vice president for Farm Credit Services' Mason City office. ``I identified myself as an attorney from Des Moines,'' Gross said. ``I told him this had nothing to do with the governor.'' Gross said Farm Credit Services officials told him they would not sell the land back to Monty Branstad for less than the assessed value. ``He ended up paying the assessed value and didn't even talk to me about it,'' Gross said. Democratic State Chairman John Roehrick said the account raises ``new questions about whether Republican Governor Terry Branstad used his political clout to improperly help his brother, Monty Branstad, obtain preferential treatment for his troubled farm finances.'' Gross and Branstad aides labeled the Democrats' assault as ``pretty sleazy.''

DOC.HEAD: New Iraqi Intimidation Draws Fire; West Meets On Oil Supplies
LaserPhoto NY6
DOC.TEXT: Western governments and Kuwait's emir have angrily protested new Iraqi efforts to intimidate diplomats and civilians, and industrialized countries sought ways to cushion the blow of the anti-Iraq embargo on world oil supplies. Kuwait's exiled emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmad al-Jaber al-Sabah, was expected in Washington today for talks with President Bush, while 21 nations gathered in in Paris to discuss how to guarantee adequate stocks of crude. Oil hit $40 a barrel Thursday, exactly eight weeks since Iraqi President Saddam Hussein sent his troops into Kuwait and increased his share of world oil reserves to 20 percent. Oil sold for $22 per barrel before the invasion. The U.S. Navy did its best to keep a tight seal on Iraqi marine trade Thursday. The Pentagon said a U.S. frigate fired warning shots at an Iraqi tanker in the Red Sea after it ignored an order to halt. In a surprise move Thursday, Britain announced the restoration of diplomatic ties with Iran. They were severed after the late Ayatollah Khomeini's death decree against author Salman Rushdie for his book ``The Satanic Verses.'' Neither side publicly linked the move to the Persian gulf crisis, but Iran's relations with the West have been improving. It has said it is cooperating with the U.N. economic boycott of Iraq. At the United Nations in New York on Thursday, the deposed Kuwaiti emir spoke emotionally of his homeland. Al-Sabah said ``rape, destruction, terror'' now reign in Kuwait, overrun by Iraq's ``naked, brutal aggression.'' The Iraqi delegation stalked out when al-Sabah began speaking, but the Kuwaiti emir won a standing ovation from the General Assembly. Bush's invitation for al-Sabah to visit the White House today underscores the U.S. view that the emir is still the legitimate ruler of Kuwait. Iraq's Interior ministry Thursday published a new law saying citizens of Kuwait - which Iraq has proclaimed its 19th province - have until Oct. 31 to adopt Iraqi citizenship. It did not say what would happen to those who failed to meet the deadline. Iraq was the target of a blistering new round of Western criticism on Thursday after a threat against diplomats who shelter foreigners. In a note delivered to some Western embassies on Wednesday, Iraqi officials said giving sanctuary to a foreigner was punishable by death. The Iraqi Foreign Ministry refused to elaborate on the message, but Iraqi officials speaking on condition of anonymity said it was referring to Iraqis harboring Westerners, not to diplomats giving refuge to their own nationals. Western governments reacted with anger anyway. ``Iraq's threat makes it impossible to take seriously any pretensions on its part to be a civilized state,'' Britain's Foreign Office said. In Paris, a French Foreign Ministry spokesman in Paris called the threat ``utterly intolerable.'' The State Department reported Thursday that another American had been picked up in Kuwait a day earlier, bringing the total of Americans detained by Iraq to at least 101. Thousands of Westerners trapped by the invasion have been prevented from leaving. Some are being held by Iraq at key installations to serve as human shields against potential attack. In Kuwait, Iraqi forces have been trying to starve diplomats out of their embassies. About 300 to 350 U.S. citizens are stranded in Iraq, and 600 to 700 in Kuwait, according to figures released Monday by the State Department. Altogether about 6,000 Westerners are in Iraq and Kuwait. On the Red Sea, a team from the USS Elmer Montgomery boarded the Iraqi tanker Tadmur after firing the wiring shots. The team inspected the tanker, but it was empty. It was allowed to proceed. The incident marked the fourth time a U.S. warship fired shots to enforce the U.N. trade sanctions. Scores of U.S. and other warships have assembled in the gulf region to enforce the embargo against Iraq, which invaded Kuwait Aug. 2 in a dispute over oil, land and money. Iraqi forces in and around Kuwait include an estimated 430,000 troops. About 165,000 U.S. soldiers have been deployed in Saudi Arabia and the gulf. Thousands of Arab and European troops also have been sent to the Saudi desert. Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu on Thursday unveiled a plan to dispatch Japanese military personnel to the gulf region in what would be the first such overseas deployment of Japanese forces since World War II. But Kaifu said they would be unarmed and kept away from combat. He left Tokyo today for the United States and visits Bush on Sunday. In Washington, U.S. officials said Saddam's security shield is so thick and mobile that the only way the Iraqi president will be toppled is if one of his intimate advisers turns against him. ``He doesn't allow a whiff of opposition,'' said an official. Another, also speaking on condition of anonymity, said Saddam is believed to be preparing ``for what he sees as an inevitable battle'' over Kuwait but is unwilling to provoke war himself. Meanwhile, relief officials, especially in Jordan, struggled to cope with the huge influx of refugees from Iraq and Kuwait. At a desert transit camp in Jordan, there were several disturbances involving Indian refugees angered by poor conditions and long delays. Authorities worried about the possibility of large-scale riots.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Uses Terror to Control Kuwaitis
With PM-Gulf-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has tightened its vise on occupied Kuwait through systematic terror in an effort to wipe out remaining resistance, residents and officials say. Iraqi authorities are trying to force-feed Kuwaitis a new Iraqi nationality. They have ordered Kuwaitis to trade their nationality documents for Iraqi citizenship and change their Kuwaiti currency for Iraqi dinars. In his latest pledge to retain control over Kuwait, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein told a visiting delegation of Islamic theologians Monday he will never withdraw ``even if we have to fight for 1,000 years.'' Iraq has increased its troop strength in Kuwait to 430,000, adding 70,000 soldiers in just two weeks, U.S. officials said in Washington this week. Iraq also continues to deploy tanks and other armor within striking distance of Saudi Arabia, the Dfense Department officials said. Meanwhile, refugees from Kuwait are still trickling out, bringing more tales of terror. A Kuwaiti refugee interviewed in the Saudi capital of Riyadh, who gave his name only as Abdullah, told of a man he knew who complied with the Iraqi order to turn in firearms. ``The police shot him in the head, put his body in a garbage bag, and left it in front of his house,'' he recalled. Egyptian doctors who recently left Kuwait, where they had been working at hospitals, said Iraqi soldiers claim officers lied to troops to trick them into taking part in the Aug. 2 invasion. ``They were originally told ... that troops all over the Arab world were gathering together and going to Egypt, and then they would invade Israel,'' Jilan Abdel-Wahab, one of the doctors, told a news conference in Cairo. Another doctor, Yehia Mohammed, said he saw Iraqi soldiers shoot to death five Kuwaiti children for joining anti-invasion demonstrations. Ten other children, brought to his hospital with bullet wounds, also died, he said. The U.S. ambassador-designate to Kuwait, Edward Gnehm Jr., told reporters Monday that Kuwaiti health officials told him 22 babies born prematurely died when Iraqi troops removed them from incubators they stole. Gnehm has been named to replace current ambassador Nathaniel Howell, who is holed up inside the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait. Defiance runs strong among Kuwaitis who have stayed, said Michael McMurtry, a British geologist still in Kuwait, in a letter published in The Times this week. ``Nearly all Kuwaitis remaining can be said to belong to the Kuwait resistance,'' he wrote. He said the resistance had killed Iraqi troops and destroyed ammunition trucks. ``Although they are helplessly outnumbered, the resistance have played an invaluable role in keeping the Iraqi troops on the alert,'' he wrote. Some Palestinians are reportedly helping the Iraqis run the occupied country, but Palestinians sympathetic to the Kuwaitis have also emerged, the daily Al-Khaleej, a newspaper in the United Arab Emirates, reported Thursday. The paper also reported that Iraqi units were ``turning cemeteries into military barracks ... because they know a Kuwaiti respects the dead and believes it is sinful to kill anyone in a burial site.'' Iraq's efforts at changing the face of Kuwait continued with Thursday's announcement that ``first-class'' Kuwaiti citizens - or native-born Kuwaitis whose parents are also Kuwaiti - must adopt Iraqi nationality by Oct 31. On Monday, Iraq said the Kuwaiti currency, the dinar, would be invalid after Oct. 6 and must be exchanged for Iraqi dinars. Iraqis continue to be resettled in Kuwait as part of an effort to change Kuwait's demographics, according to a dissident Iraqi minority. But Iraqi soldiers are suffering from food shortages and low morale themselves, said the dissident group, the Kurdistan Democratic Party of Iraq, in recent statements. Exiled Kuwaiti officials say Iraq is trying to force Kuwaitis from their homeland and repopulate it with Iraqis and others sympathetic to Baghdad's government.

DOC.HEAD: Higher Oil Prices Mean Windfall for Alaska
With PM-Gulf-Oil Prices, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Alaska stands to reap a windfall of millions of dollars in oil revenue thanks to the Persian Gulf crisis, and Gov. Steve Cowper wants to sock most of it away for a rainy day. Cowper and many lawmakers argue that a fund is needed to ease an expected drop in oil revenues later this decade as Alaska oil production declines. Oil, gas taxes and royalties account for about 85 percent of state revenues. The governor said Thursday if oil prices don't collapse before the end of the year, the state will have a ``substantial surplus.'' The increase in state revenues since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2 already has erased the projected deficit that prompted Cowper in July to veto $325 million from the $2.9 billion fiscal 1991 budget. Each $1 rise in the price of one barrel of oil adds $150 million to Alaska's treasury over a year. This year's budget was based on oil selling at $19.33. Prices this week have been double that. Cowper, who declined to seek a second term and leaves office Dec. 3, said he will propose that the 1991 Legislature restore some budget cuts when it convenes in late January but place most of the windfall in a budget reserve. Voters will decide Nov. 6 whether to amend the state constitution to create a reserve fund. ``It's prudent to do because oil prices can go down as quickly as they went up,'' Cowper said. Also, the huge Prudhoe Bay oil field, the nation's largest, is in decline. When it dries up, so will Alaska's free ride on oil. The state has no state sales or income taxes. It's uncertain how next year's new Legislature will react to the windfall. Some lawmakers likely will push to deposit the cash in the Alaska Permanent Fund, an $11.2 billion state savings account funded with a fixed percentage of the state's oil and mineral revenues since 1977. But tapping that fund for future government expenses may be difficult. The fund's principal by law cannot be spent, and there's strong public and political opposition to spending the earnings for other uses. It also would reduce the size of dividends each Alaskan receives every year from the fund. Past legislatures spent oil surpluses on roads, sewers, power projects, buildings and other publi works projects in the young and largely undeveloped state. ``The rationale will be, `Hey, we've got the money, let's sow the seeds for the future while we can,' '' said Sen. Pat Pourchot, a Democrat. But Rep. Ramona Barnes, a Republican, predicted there will also be strong public pressure to save the cash. ``The public is not going to stand for the Legislature to just spend that money willy-nilly on everything that comes by,'' she said. ``They're going to expect that money to be saved for a rainy day.''

DOC.HEAD: Justice Minister Apologizes to U.S. Ambassador to Japan
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese Cabinet official has apologized to the U.S. ambassador for remarks in which he compared black Americans to prostitutes, the government said today. Justice Minister Seiroku Kajiyama, 64, visited U.S. Ambassador Michael Armacost Thursday to convey his apology to ``the government and people (of the United States),'' the Foreign Ministry said in a statement. The visit came in the wake of sharp criticism from the State Department and American blacks after the newly appointed Kajiyama said last Friday that foreign prostitutes in Tokyo ``ruin the atmosphere'' of the neighborhoods they move into. ``It's like in America where neighborhoods become mixed because blacks move in, and whites are forced out,'' Kajiyama said. The minister told Armacost, ``I have retracted the remarks and apologized to those concerned, but again, I would like to deeply apologize to your government and people. And I would like you to convey my apology to your government and people.'' In response, Armacost said the ``insensitivity'' of Kajiyama's remarks had shocked all Americans, not just blacks. The comments were only the latest by a Japanese politician to provoke outrage from U.S. minorities. In 1986, for instance, former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone precipitated an outpouring of criticism from the United States when he implied that blacks and hispanics had a low intellectual level. On Monday, a State Department said ``such remarks are offensive to the American people.'' Ralph Neas, executive director in Washington of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, called them ``reprehensible and racist.'' A group of blacks living in Japan released a statement of protest Thursday and is also planning a demonstration in front of the Justice Ministry building next Tuesday, according to local news reports. ``American blacks want to be friendly to Japanese because we think Japanese are also colored people. But Japanese see themselves as different. They indulge in finding commonality between themselves and whites,'' John Russel, an American researcher here, told the Asahi Journal, a liberal weekly magazine. He said the Japanese media has also contributed to creating a negative image of blacks as ``barbaric, and superior only in sports and sex.'' J. R. Dash, a foreign securities house employee in Tokyo, also told the Asahi Journal: ``Japanese are trying to get around the issue by stressing they don't understand minority problems because Japan is an isolated, island nation. But ignorance should not be stressed as an excuse.''

DOC.HEAD: Civilian Aircraft Strays Across South Korean Border into North Korea
DOC.TEXT: A small civilian plane accidently strayed over the heavily armed Korean border today and flew 10 miles into Communist North Korea before turning back, officials said. Some reports said there had been gunfire. The Cessna aircraft apparently veered off course in bad weather and turned around on its own after the pilot realized he was in North Korea, military sources said on condition of anonymity. Some reports said there had been gunfire. Yonhap, the national news agency, quoted unidentified military officials as saying South Korean marines heard about 200 rounds of gunfire, probably from the Northern side of the border about the time the incident took place. The marines heard an aircraft overhead and fired one warning flare to guide it southward, the Defense Ministry said. The ministry declined to confirm reports of gunfire. A ministry spokesman, requesting anonymity, said four Korean F-5 fighters scrambled to intercept the plane and guided it back to Seoul's Kimpo International Airport where it landed without damage. The official identified the pilot as Song Jae-sun, 55, an employee of Koroyo Industrial and Development Co., a subsidiary of the conglomerate Hyundai. The Koroyo firm is engaged in a land reclamation project near Sosan, about 55 miles southwest of Seoul along the coast. South Korean military officials said the pilot was being held and the incident was under investigation.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Shows Support for Gulf Policy
DOC.TEXT: President's Bush's handling of the Persian Gulf crisis has been endorsed in a resolution adopted by a House committee, although the panel avoided approving any future military action. The Foreign Affairs Committee's voice vote came Thursday after three weeks of painstaking effort and in the wake of an earlier effort that unraveled amid fears that lawmakers might be issuing an implicit blank check for war. The panel acted in a hastily called session after Chairman Dante Fascell, D-Fla., worked out final details with president's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft. The full House is expected to consider the resolution on Monday. Also on Thursday, a new $7.5 billion arms sale to Saudi Arabia proposed by the Bush administration was gaining qualified support on Capitol Hill. Included in the Saudi arms assortment is 150 advanced M-1A2 tanks, six Patriot anti-missile batteries with 384 missiles, a dozen Apache ground-attack helicopters with 155 Hellfire missiles, 1,750 improved TOW anti-tank missiles with 150 launchers, nine multiple-launch rocket systems with 2,880 rockets, seven KC-130 tanker planes, 10 C-130 cargo planes and 10,000 assorted trucks, transporters and trailers. In other congressional matters, legislation that would provide about $400 million in special benefits for military personnel stationed in Saudi Arabia, won Senate Armed Services Committee approval. Also contained in the bill is a provision setting up a system by which Congress and Bush administration officials would oversee and manage the expected donations from foreign governments to defray the cost of Operation Desert Shield. The committee, in adopting the measure, wanted to ensure that the Pentagon ``couldn't go out and spend money on some weapons systems that are unrelated'' to Desert Shield without congressional approval, said Armed Services Committee Chairman Sam Nunn, D-Ga. Among the benefits in the legislation are $11 million in free postage, $265 million to make danger pay retroactive to Aug. 1 and $12 million to compensate some people for leave they cannot take. The pared down version of the legislation seemed less disturbing to supporters of Israel than a previous $21 adaptation. But there remained a few worries about some elements of the revised package. ``It is a big improvement,'' said Rep. Mel Levine, D-Calif. But he said he planned to closely question administration officials about the tanks, the Apaches and the Patriots at a hearing next week. Levine suggested some of the concerns might be calmed if the administration comes up with a counterbalancing security package for Israel. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams called the proposed Saudi sale urgently needed.'' Contained in the immediate package are items deemed necessary to meet Saudi defense needs in the current crisis, including weapons that can be delivered from current stocks or quickly taken off the production line. Sources said the White House planned to send Congress a follow-up request in late January for the other $14 billion worth of weapons it believes the Saudis need, including new-generation F-15F fighter planes. The House Foreign Affairs Committee session broke up at one point when it appeared no agreement could be reached between committee Democrats and the White House on a Persian Gulf resolution could be reached. A primary hangup was lawmakers' nervousness that any congressional resolution might be seen as implicitly endorsing any future use of force by the United States, said Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind.. As the resolution has gone through the drafting stages over the past three weeks, there have been echoes of the Tonkin Gulf resolution, a 1964 act that was seen as authorizing widening U.S. involvement in Vietnam. Fascell sought to make it clear that the document would only approve Bush's actions so far in the gulf crisis, and leave out any mention of next steps. It voiced support for Bush's ``emphasis on diplomatic efforts, international sanctions and negotiations under the auspices of the United Nations'' to achieve the goals of forcing Iraq out of Kuwait and restoring Kuwait's previous government to power. Similar internal debates are under way on both sides of the Capitol between those who believe Congress should take a formal role in the gulf situation and those who prefer to keep their political distance from it.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Gives Away City Hall
DOC.TEXT: Walter DeBow and his family fought City Hall, and now they own it. DeBow, 55, suffered permanent brain damage after being beaten into a coma by a fellow prisoner at the city jail more than six years ago. He and his family were awarded $3.4 million in a 1985 court settlement with the city. With interest, that amount has grown to $4 million, and the debt-ridden city has not paid at least $1 million of it, said the DeBows' attorney, Clyde Kuehn. So on Thursday, Judge Roger Scrivner of St. Clair County Circuit Court awarded the East St. Louis Municipal Building and 220 acres of city-owned property to the DeBows. Kuehn said the DeBows planned to sell the property. ``Definitely my clients want what they were awarded, and I think this is necessary to accomplish that,'' he said. City officials estimated the municipal building alone cost $10 million to build. City Attorney Eric Vickers said the value of the properties far exceeds anything owed the DeBows. ``I think this decision is just a major miscarriage of justice and demonstrates bias against the city of East St. Louis,'' Vickers said. ``The city has not defaulted on its payments. It's ludicrous.'' Another lawyer for East St. Louis, Irvin Williamson, said the city would ask a court to stay the judgment pending appeal. ``If the court allows the judgment to stand against the city, what's next? The police cars? The fire trucks?'' Williamson said. East St. Louis is plagued by debt estimated at $47 million. Gov. James R. Thompson signed a $34 million bailout bill Aug. 30. The money will come from state bond issues. The population of the city, which has one of the highest murder rates in the country, fell from 55,000 in 1980 to 40,000 this year, the Census Bureau estimates. Mayor Carl E. Officer declined to comment on the judge's order. Aldermen were flabbergasted. ``It's amazing,'' said Alderman Percy McKinney. ``I guess we pay rent from now on.'' State law gives DeBow's family the right to evict the city in seven days, but Kuehn said his clients weren't likely to do that. Walter DeBow was comatose for three months following the January 1984 beating, which occurred while he was being held on a traffic charge of illegal transportation of alcohol. He is being cared for at a head-injury rehabilitation center in New Jersey. Kuehn has taken the city to court several times since DeBow was awarded the $4 million. In March 1988, he won an order to freeze the city's assets, stopping city workers' paychecks and threatening to push the city into bankruptcy. The city later tried to pay off the debt by issuing nearly $5.2 million in bonds.But Thursday, Kuehn said the actual value of the bonds was only $2.8 million, prompting him to ask the judge to award the city property to DeBow's estate to make up the difference. DeBow also will continue to hold the bonds and receive biannual bond payments, Kuehn said.

DOC.HEAD: Baker to Meet With Vietnamese Foreign Minister
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Vietnam's foreign minister are expected to discuss such topics as efforts to form a new government in Cambodia and the fate of more than 2,400 Americans missing since the Vietnam war in a meeting scheduled for this weekend. Baker has arranged the half-hour session for Saturday with Nguyen Co Thach, who is also deputy prime minister. It is the latest move by the United States toward improved relations with its former bitter foe. Some 1,700 Americans are still unaccounted for in Vietnam and others elsewhere in Indochina. The meeting was announced Thursday in New York by State Department spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler. Baker was in New York conferring with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. His meeting with the Vietnamese leader will be the highest-level U.S. session with a Vietnamese official since the 1973 Paris peace talks brought the Vietnam War to a close. In July, the U.S. altered its policy of shunning Vietnam except for occasional inquiries about missing Americans. At that time, Baker announced that the Bush administration was withdrawing diplomatic recognition of the Cambodian guerrilla coalition and opening negotiations with Vietnam on settling the 11-year-old civil war in Cambodia. While Vietnam has heavily influenced the Cambodian government, Cambodia has shown recent signs of pursuing a more independent course. The guerrilla coalition includes the Communist Khmer Rouge, which killed at least 1 million Cambodians when it ran the country in the late 1970s. Vietnamese troops ousted the Khmer Rouge in an invasion in December 1978. The guerrillas and the Cambodian government have been negotiating over formation of a Supreme National Council to run the war-ravaged country until an election can be held under a plan approved by the United Nations. The announcement said Baker wanted to discuss formation of the council and ``its early assumption of its seat in the U.N.'' However, Cambodian Radio reported on Wednesday that Cambodian Prime Minister Prime Minister Hun Sen had rejected a proposal from the guerrilla coalition to install Prince Sihanouk as chairman in exchange for an additional seat for the Hun Sen government. The report said that Hun Sen felt his government should be allotted the slot of deputy prime minister and that he had urged his forces to keep fighting against the guerrillas.

DOC.HEAD: General Says Soviets Remove Nuclear Warheads From Troubled Areas
DOC.TEXT: Published reports today quote the Soviet Union's top military officer as saying Moscow has removed nuclear warheads from areas of the country where there is a risk of ethnic unrest. Gen. Mikhail Moiseyev, the Soviet Union's armed forces chief of staff, told The Washington Post that the trouble spots were cleared of the nuclear weapons because his nation recognizes its obligation ``before mankind'' to ensure complete security over its nuclear arsenal. The newspaper interviewed Moiseyev on the eve of the Soviet official's tour of the United States. It was the first official confirmation that part of the Soviet Union's 30,000 nuclear warhead arsenal was being relocated. While the general did not specifically identify affected areas, the newspaper said Western defense attaches believe Central Asia, the southern Transcaucasus region and the Baltic Republics are involved. Those areas have been the scene of sometimes violent ethnic and nationalist unrest in the past two years. Moiseyev said similar actions have been taken to ensure the security of non-nuclear weapons. He also predicted that Iran would join forces with Iraq in the event of a war in the Middle East, which he said could escalate into a world war.

DOC.HEAD: 16 Soldiers Convicted in Murder of Aquino's Husband, But Mastermind Unknown
LaserPhotos NY40, NY48
DOC.TEXT: A court today convicted 16 soldiers in the murder of President Corazon Aquino's husband but failed to say who ordered the assassination which set the stage for the 1986 revolution. The impact of the decision was further clouded by the court's acquittal of 20 people in the 1983 slaying of Sen. Benigno ``Ninoy'' Aquino, the country's top opposition leader at the time. Other defendants, including a former military chief of staff, have fled the country to avoid prosecution. The verdict in the 3{-year trial was announced on the first anniversary of the death of the late dictator Ferdinand Marcos, who many Filipinos believe ordered the Aquino's slaying. The assassination outraged many Filipinos and heralded the 1986 popular uprising that toppled Marcos and catapulted Mrs. Aquino to power. The three-judge court sentenced the 16 convicted defendants to life imprisonment and ordered them to pay $300,000 to the late senator's heirs. It was unclear if that figure is a total or if each defendant is expected to pay that sum. Aquino was cut down by gunfire on Aug. 21, 1983, moments after returning from self-imposed exile in the United States to challenge Marcos. He had just stepped off a China Airlines jet that brought him back to Manila to challenge Marcos for leadership of this nation. ``I think not only I, but the entire Filipino people have been waiting for the decision of the court,'' Mrs. Aquino told reporters after today's verdict. Later, she said she had become frustrated by the slow pace of the proceedings and as president would refrain from ``expressing my true feelings'' about the verdict. Marcos claimed Aquino was slain by an alleged Communist assassin, Rolando Galman, who was himself shot to death moments after Aquino. The 16 were also convicted in the slaying of Galman. Marcos died in exile in Hawaii on Sept. 28, 1989. The court said it could not convict Ferdinand Marcos and his wife, Imelda, because ``there has been no evidence to prove a prima facie case against them.'' Those convicted included Brig. Gen. Luther Custodio, former chief of the airport security command. He is terminally ill with cancer. The rest of the convicted were security guards on the tarmac of Manila's airport when Aquino's plane arrived. Chief defense lawyer Rodolfo Jimenez said the 16 would appeal to the Supreme Court. Among those acquitted were Rep. Jose Aspiras, former tourism minister; former Air Transport Minister Jose Singson; and Col. Arturo Custodio, former commander of Villamor Air Base. In its summation, the court said evidence pointed to Constable 1st Class Rogelio Moreno, one of the 16 convicted, as the triggerman. But the court noted that the broader question of who ordered the killing could not be answered. Following the verdict, Aquino's sister, Rep. Teresita Oreta, said she was disappointed that the court could not establish the mastermind. ``I would have wanted a clearer statement on who ordered the killing,'' she said. ``These are soldiers who will not move without any orders.'' Twenty-six people, including former military Chief of Staff Gen. Fabian Ver, were originally charged with the killing but acquitted in December 1985 by a court appointed by Marcos. Six months after Marcos was ousted, the Supreme Court overturned the acquittals and ordered a new trial, saying Marcos engineered the original verdict. The first trial was marked by frequent street demonstrations and rallies, but the second attracted virtually no spectators apart from relatives of the accused. Newspapers rarely covered it. The Aquino case has often been cited as an example of the country's inefficient judiciary. Midway during the proceedings, the Supreme Court disbarred chief prosecutor Raul Gonzalez after he publicly charged justices were misappropriating funds. One defendant died during the trial and three others, including Ver, have fled the country. Philippine law does not permit trials in absentia. During a coup attempt in December, more than 12 of the defendants escaped from a military stockade, but all eventually surrendered.

DOC.HEAD: Hostages Recount Their Night of Terror
LaserPhoto FX1
DOC.TEXT: Hostages of a schizophrenic who hated Americans and claimed to hear voices endured seven hours of bizarre conversations and gunfire in a hotel bar. They also saw one of the hostages killed and seven other people wounded before the gunman died in an explosion of police bullets. ``When he took a head count of us he started counting his rounds as well,'' said Doug Moore, among 33 people held by Mehrdad Dashti. ``He watched every single move. Every time someone moved, he flinched.'' Dashti, 30, commandeered Henry's Publick House and Grille at the Durant Hotel, a block south of the University of California's Berkeley campus, early Thursday. The siege, punctuated by Dashti's gunfire and the escape of some hostages, ended when police decided they could not talk him into coming out and stormed the bar. Dashti was described as a paranoid schizophrenic on an Alameda County mental health form found in his cluttered Berkeley apartment. Police knew of no clear motive for the attack. ``He was apparently very confused,'' said Berkeley police Capt. Phil Doran. ``Deranged is not a bad description.'' Dashti, who grew up in Iran and came to the United States eight years ago, expressed animosity toward Americans. ``The foreigners in there, he told them he wasn't going to bother them. He was after the Americans,'' Moore said. He claimed the ``government owed him $16 trillion for mental telepathy work and this was his way of getting it back,'' said Moore, 25, a student at the nearby campus and manager of the hotel bar, a popular gathering place for students. Dashti, in an unmailed letter to President Bush obtained by the San Francisco Examiner, claimed to have spoken with ``invisible intelligent species'' from the world of the dead. Moore said Dashti also disliked blond women. During the ordeal, Dashti made them take off their pants but let them keep on their underwear, hostages said. Carrying a briefcase, Dashti walked into Henry's shortly before midnight and had a drink, Moore said. Moore made a ``last call'' and the remaining crowd of more than 40 people clustered at the bar. There was a bang. Dashti had concealed a pistol, a revolver and an ``assault-type pistol'' in the briefcase, police said. Moore said he looked up to see Dashti point a gun into the crowd and fire several more shots. ``I saw the gun and I hit the ground,'' said John Landa, 21, who was shot in the right arm but escaped with several others. San Francisco police Sgt. Jerry Senkir said Dashti was named in a March 1989 warrant charging grand theft in connection with cashing two checks, worth more than $16,000, stolen from a bakery. Dashti's roommate, 19-year-old Fred Smith, described him as ``pretty religious'' and fond of guns. John Sheehy, 22, of Lafayette, died after he was shot in the chest at close range. The gunman allowed a man at the bar to carry him outside, then ordered the others into strategic positions around the room. During the next seven hours, Dashti terrified his hostages by shooting ``for the hell of it,'' Moore said. ``He would say, `Cover your heads,' and then shoot.'' Dashti used two male hostages as mouthpieces, having them answer telephone calls from police trying to negotiate with him and shout his demands out the window. One of his demands was that San Francisco Police Chief Frank Jordan ``drop his drawers'' on television, Doran said. Moore said Dashti had ``lots of negative things to say'' about San Francisco police. Dashti, who received a degree in engineering from San Francisco State University, also was upset he didn't get a student loan for UC Berkeley, police said. The gunman, who drank beer and whiskey, suggested everyone have a drink and invited the hostages to talk about anything, Moore said. Dashti began a guessing game. He thought up numbers between one and 15 and the others tried to guess, Moore said.

DOC.HEAD: Resumption Of Iran-Britain Diplomatic Ties Raises Hostage Hopes
DOC.TEXT: Agreement between Britain and Iran to resume diplomatic ties has raised hopes that British hostages in Lebanon may be freed soon and that author Salman Rushdie can again live without fear of assassination. The London newspaper The Guardian today quoted unnamed British officials as saying that following Thursday's announcement at the United Nations of resumed ties, Rushdie should be able to resume a normal life without fear of being killed. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd and Iran's U.N. Mission said the embassies will reopen in London and Tehran within a month. Iran cut diplomatic ties with Britain in March 1989 over Rushdie's novel ``The Satanic Verses,'' which many Moslems regard as blasphemous. Iran's late religious leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini had called on Moslems to kill the Indian-born writer. Rushdie, a naturalized Briton, remains in hiding under British police guard. Paul Handley, spokesman for Archbishop of Canterbury Robert Runcie, leader of the Church of England, said the resumption of diplomatic ties between Iran and Britain was good news for the three British hostages. Runcie's envoy, Terry Waite, was seized in January 1987 trying to negotiate the freedom of American hostages. ``Of course it does not mean all the problems are solved,'' added Handley. ``But they will be much easier to solve through normal diplomatic channels.'' Pressure on Britain to get talking to Iran about Waite and the two other hostages - television journalist John McCarthy and retired fighter pilot Jack Mann - increased this month with the release of Irish teacher Brian Keenan. It made Britain the only Western country which has so far failed to get a single hostage released from Lebanon. Speaking on TV-AM this morning, Waite's brother David called the move ``a major step forward'' which would allow problems between the two countries to be resolved more easily. ``I just hope the families of all the other hostages don't have to cope much longer,'' Waite said. Cooper's brother Paul, speaking on the same program, called the restoration of ties ``very encouraging.'' ``There has been an enormous amount of suspicion and hostility between Britain and Iran and it's very important that these bridges are built and both sides start to trust each other,'' he said. Another London newspaper, The Independent, reported that following resumption of diplomatic ties between Britain and Iran, Britain is expected to raise with Israeli the issue of Shia prisoners in south Lebanon. The prisoners are held by the Israeli-backed South Lebanese Army in what the paper described as deplorable conditions. Iran says they are as much hostages as the 13 Westerners, including six Americans, held in Lebanon. The 13 are believed held by Islamic fundamentalists loyal to Iran's Shiite revolution. The longest-held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correpondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Iran wanted relations with London as part of improving ties with the West and opening up trade channels. Britain wanted relations with Iran partly because of the hostages and, increasingly now, because of the realignment in the Middle East following Iraq's seizure of Kuwait Aug. 2.

DOC.HEAD: Marvin Gaye Gets Walk of Fame Star
LaserPhoto LA10 of Sept. 27
DOC.TEXT: Marvin Gaye, shot to death by his father 6{ years ago, was honored with a Hollywood Walk of Fame star and praise from Motown friends Stevie Wonder and Berry Gordy. ``Let us pledge we can make a better world in the spirit of Marvin Gaye,'' Wonder told the Gaye family and hundreds of fans and friends gathered Thursday on Vine Street near the Sunset Boulevard headquarters of Motown Records. Gaye, born in 1939, originally was a member of the 1950s vocal group The Moonglows and joined Motown in the early 1960s. He released a stream of hit records, including ``I Heard It Through the Grapevine,'' ``What's Going On'' and ``Ain't No Mountain High Enough,'' one of several duets with Tammi Terrell. He left Motown in the late 1970s and made the 1982 album ``Midnight Love'' for Columbia Records. ``There are many special talents that only come along once in a while,'' said Gordy, the founder of Motown. ``A talent like Marvin Gaye comes along only once. There will never be another Marvin Gaye.'' Gaye's three children, Frankie, Nona and Marvin III, and his brother, Frankie, were at the unveiling. Others attending included Smokey Robinson; Motown president Jheryl Busby; Dick Clark; Lou Rawls; Natalie Cole and eight members of the Japanese chapter of the Marvin Gaye fan club. Representatives of Armed Forces Radio were on hand and taped the ceremony for troops in the Persian Gulf. Gaye was shot to death on April 1, 1984, following an argument with his father, Marvin Sr., who received five years probation. Gaye's parents did not attend Thursday's ceremony.

DOC.HEAD: CDC: Smokers Know Their Health Would Be Better Without Cigarettes
DOC.TEXT: Even the most veteran of smokers know their health could improve if they kick the habit, federal researchers say. The Centers for Disease Control said Thursday that 83 percent of smokers believe they could avoid health problems if they quit, and 85 percent believe there are health benefits for those who quit even after 20 or more years of smoking. The figures were taken in a canvass of 4,351 smokers, ages 25 to 64, during a random telephone survey conducted from January to April 1989. The CDC reported that about 90 percent of college-educated smokers ages 55 to 64 indicated they believe there are health benefits for long-term smokers who quit. Knowledge of the advantages of not smoking was lowest in smokers in that age group who had no college education; 67 percent of them said they saw a benefit to quitting late in life. The survey was part of a battery of new studies intended to freshen decades-old warnings about smoking, CDC officials said. The overall message, though, wasn't new. The research ``found that quitting smoking increases life expectancy,'' said Dr. Ronald Davis, director of the CDC's Office on Smoking and Health in Rockville, Md. ``Even though we knew quitting smoking was good for you, we never really had an idea of how much the risk goes down after quitting,'' Davis said. According to the CDC, risks associated with smoking drop dramatically - in some cases almost from the moment the last cigarette is snuffed out. The Atlanta-based CDC concluded that smokers gain an average of 5 pounds after quitting; only 4 percent of those who quit gain more than 20 pounds. The psychological effects of nicotine withdrawal - irritability, difficulty with concentration, sleep disorders, increased appetites and cigarette cravings - peak after about two days, then subside rapidly over the next several weeks, he said. ``We recognize that many smokers don't quit because they think they might gain some weight, or suffer withdrawal,'' Davis said. ``We are trying to get the message out that these effects go down very quickly, so smokers should do all they can to get beyond those first two weeks and increase their chances of becoming permanent non-smokers.'' The CDC also cited a study of pregnant smokers in Ohio which found that women who stopped smoking before pregnancy or during the first four months of pregnancy would have the same risk of delivering low birth-weight babies as women who never smoked. The CDC report came two days after Surgeon General Antonia C. Novello issued a report that said older smokers could increase their life expectancy and improve their health if they quit, even after decades of smoking. According to her report, 50 million Americans smoke or chew tobacco and 390,000 die every year from smoking-related diseases. Novello said about half of living Americans who tried tobacco products have quit.

DOC.HEAD: French, Soviet and U.S. Engineers Test Balloon for Mars Exploration
LaserPhoto LA5
DOC.TEXT: Giant balloons, built by the French to hop slowly across Mars' surface during a Soviet space mission, are undergoing field tests in California's Mojave Desert. The six-day series of low-altitude tests being conducted by French, Soviet and U.S. engineers started Thursday over dry lakebeds, lava and boulder fields and sand dunes near Barstow and Desert Center. Tests were scheduled today on lava fields about 40 miles southeast of Barstow, after the successful half-mile test Thursday on flat Coyote Dry Lake. ``It's a test of the system to see if it works over Marslike terrain,'' said Harris Schurmeier, retired associate director of the NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory and Mars Balloon project manager for The Planetary Society. The delicate balloon was intentionally destroyed after the test. The French brought about 10 balloons for the test flights, Schurmeier said. The 30-foot-tall, 10-foot-wide cylindrical balloons will be aboard two spacecraft the Soviets plan to launch into orbit around Mars in a 1994 mission, Schurmeier said. Each orbiter will deploy an entry capsule, which will parachute toward the red planet, the fourth from the sun. Before landing, each capsule will deploy a balloon. ``The resuls are very good,'' said Christian Tarrieu, Mars Balloon project manager for the National Center for Space Studies in France. The transparent, mylar balloons are designed to explore a large area of Mars without having to negotiate difficult terrain. The balloons are filled with helium and nitrogen, so they act as both gas and hot-air balloons. ``During the day, the sun heats up gas in the balloon and the whole thing lifts off the ground,'' Schurmeier said. ``Then the winds blow it around. When it cools at night, it goes back toward the ground.'' He said the French and Soviets hope the balloons will operate for 10 days - the life of the batteries they will carry - covering a distance of 600 to 900 miles. A gondola hanging beneath each balloon probably will carry a television camera and instruments to measure atmospheric temperature, humidity and clarity, Schurmeier said.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Awards Comic $725,000 in Steam Bath Battle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `His bitter ...' to raise reference to eye injury. Pick up 4th graf, `We're very ...'
DOC.TEXT: A federal jury believed a hot burst from a Caesars Palace steam bath kept Rodney Dangerfield from performing at the casino-hotel and awarded the comic $725,000. ``The truth won out,'' Dangerfield said. ``I wouldn't have gone through this unless I was right.'' Dangerfield's bitter legal battle with the Las Vegas resort culminated Thursday when jurors said Caesars was responsible for a March 1988 steam bath accident that left him unable to perform because of eye injuries. ``We're very disappointed,'' said Bruce Aguilera, a lawyer for Caesars Palace. ``We'll have to have our lawyers look at the case.'' Jurors awarded Dangerfield $500,000 for pain and suffering and $225,000 for shows he missed after the March 1988 accident. Dangerfield sued Caesars for $5 million in damages and $225,000 for missed performances. The bug-eyed comic, who has made a career out of the premise that he receives no respect, thanked jurors outside a court elevator. ``We showed Rodney some respect,'' an unidentified juror said. The jury said Caesars was obligated under a contract to pay Dangerfield for the missed shows because the injury should have excused him from performing. Jurors also rejected Caesars' $100,000 countersuit against its former headliner. Dangerfield, 68, criticized Caesars for filing papers in court before the trial accusing him of drug use. He called the accusations ``nonsense and untrue.'' ``I'm surprised they went to that level to degrade me falsely like they did,'' he said. ``All they did in this entire trial was to try to degrade my character. ``I wasn't concerned with the amount of money,'' he said. ``Money is money. I was concerned about the truth.'' Dangerfield said Henry Gluck, chairman of the resort's parent Caesars World Inc., had refused to settle for $225,000. Dangerfield missed five shows the week of the accident, claiming Caesars was negligent in installing and maintaining a steam bath he used immediately after his performances. The hotel, in its countersuit, claimed Dangerfield breached his contract by not performing shows as scheduled and contended during the 2{-week-long trial that the comedian showed no signs of permanent injury from the accident. Dangerfield testified he was hit in the eyes by a burst of steam as he opened the door to the steam room. Caesars introduced evidence that Dangerfield went out two nights he was supposed to perform. A doctor who examined Dangerfield after the steam bath incident said he thought Dangerfield could perform. But an ophthalmologist hired by Dangerfield's attorneys said he examined Dangerfield three times in the last year and concluded he continues to suffer pain caused by the steam injury.

DOC.HEAD: Dee Dee Ramone Arrested on Marijuana Charge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 3-4 with 3 grafs to UPDATE with amount of marijuana, ADD Ramone's real name; pick up 5th graf pvs, `The arrests . . .'
DOC.TEXT: Rocker Dee Dee Ramone was arrested on a marijuana possession charge in a drug sweep of a Greenwich Village park, police said. Ramone, 39, was among 26 people arrested Thursday in Washington Square Park, said Charles Campisi, police deputy inspector. An undercover officer observed Ramone buying marijuana, police spokesman Edward Burns said. He said police found a marijuana cigarette and a small bag of the drug in Ramone's possession. The bass player and a founding member of the rock 'n' roll band the Ramones was released on his own recognizance on the misdemeanor charge. Ramone, whose real name is Douglas Calvin, faces a maximum sentence of nearly a year in jail if convicted. The arrests came after undercover officers watched and participated in drug buys, Campisi said. Nine people were charged with the sale of marijuana and 17 people were charged with possession, he said. The Ramones, Blondie and Talking Heads led the so-called new wave rock movement in the mid-1970s. The Ramones cut their first album in 1976.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against most foreign currencies in quiet European trading this morning. Gold prices were up slightly. Dealers said they expected the dollar to weaken for the rest of the day amid concerns about the U.S. economy. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.45 yen to a closing 137.95 yen. Later in London, it was quoted higher at 138.15 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Thursday: -1.5655 German marks, down from 1.5685 -1.2985 Swiss francs, down from 1.3055 -5.2410 French francs, down from 5.2555 -1.7740 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7695 -1,171.00 Italian lire, down from 1,175.50 -1.1567 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1573 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.8755, more expensive for buyers than $1.8690 late Thursday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $406.10 per ounce at midmorning, up from $405.75 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, the bid price was $406.10, up from $406.00 late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.10 to close at a bid $403.39. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.78 a troy ounce, down from Thursday's $4.80.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in Florida; Fog in East
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell in southern Florida early today and fog blanketed parts of the East. Unseasonably warm weather was expected in the East today, with high pressure from the Atlantic to bring sunshine and temperatures in the 70s and 80s. Thunderstorms were expected in Florida from a disturbance over the Gulf of Mexico, and in Nevada from a low pressure front. Today's forecast also called for sunshine in most of the Southwest, South, Pacific Northwest and Midwest. Showers were expected in Indiana and Illinois. A large storm system was expected to develop across southern Montana and into South Dakota. Temperatures were expected to reach the 60s in the northern central region of the country and the Midwest, the 70s in the Pacific Northwest and the 90s in the South and the Southwest. The high temperature for the nation Thursday was 101 degrees at Coolidge, Ariz. DOC.HEAD: Locksmith Cleared of 1,000 Break-Ins, Suspected of Others
DOC.TEXT: A locksmith so skilled at burglary that he once made a police training videotape was cleared of 1,000 Florida break-ins but was a suspect in 100 Maryland burglaries, police say. Richard D. Makofski, 36, was arrested Sept. 20 and held without bond on three burglary charges while police investigate more break-ins in Baltimore County, police Cpl. Stephen Doarnberger said. Makofski, of Columbia, was considered a suspect in 100 burglaries in the county dating to March 1989, Doarnberger said Thursday. In 1984, Makofski was charged with 63 burglaries in nearby Howard County, pleaded guilty to three and was sentenced to three years in prison. His burglary skill so impressed Howard County authorities that they asked him to teach a class on burglary methods and detection. Makofski also made a training videotape. In November, Makofski was implicated by the Palm Beach County, Fla., sheriff's office in 1,000 burglaries in southern Florida. At the time, investigators seized 12{ pounds of gold ingots valued at $78,000, lock-picking tools and surveillance equipment. Ellen Roberts, a Palm Beach prosecutor, dropped the case in August, saying she couldn't prove it in court.

DOC.HEAD: Mulroney Gets Queen's Permission to Expand Senate By Eight Seats
Es: fixes typo in ``Brian'' in lead.
DOC.TEXT: Opposition leaders say they'll try to stop Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's move to pack the Canadian Senate with eight new members in an attempt to ram through a proposed 7 percent sales tax. Manufacturers say the new tax would replace one that hurts their competitiveness with imports. But Liberal leader Jean Chretien said Thursday that Canadians will not back Mulroney, whose popularity has dipped sharply in polls. ``When you are 15 percent in the polls and taking an abuse of power and stacking the Senate, he might find that he will not go very far politically with that,'' said Chretien. Mulroney used an obscure constitutional provision to seat the new senators of his Conservative Party late Thursday after receiving permission from Queen Elizabeth II. The new members take their seats next week. The appointees, who serve until age 75, bring the Senate to 112 seats. Mulroney's party now has 54 seats, just three short of a majority. Consumers, already paying 8 percent to 10 percent in provincial sales taxes, are horrified at the prospect of seeing higher taxes on their purchases, plumbing bills, haircuts and music lessons. But manufacturers favor the new 7 percent tax because it would replace a 13 percent levy on Canadian industries. The old tax was a longstanding source of competitive disadvantage for Canadian manufacturers, exporters and all businesses that compete with imports in the domestic Canadian market, business leaders say. A free-trade pact with the United States that went into effect last year has raised concerns that some Canadian businesses could be hurt by increased competition from companies over the border. The nation's 1867 Constitution allows the British monarch to add four or eight members to the Senate on a request by the governor-general, the Canadian representative to the Commonwealth. The only other similar request was in 1873, but it was not granted. Mulroney used the measure as a last resort to save the goods and services tax, which has been stalled in the Liberal-dominated Senate. The Commons, dominated by Conservatives, supported the tax. Mulroney said the debate goes beyond the tax proposal itself, arguing that the elected Commons should prevail over the appointed Senate. ``The consequences for our parliamentary system are enormous,'' he said. ``What is at stake is one of the principles of our freedom. '' John Haslam, a spokesman for the queen, said Elizabeth, as the constitutional monarch of the former British colony, followed the provisions of the Canadian Constitution in making the decision. But even with the additional seats, the fate of the tax could rest on the votes of a handful of Independents. Before Mulroney's move, the Liberals held 52 seats and the Conservatives 46, with one Reform Party representative, four Independents and one Independent Liberal. The 46 Conservative seats, combined with the eight new seats, still only make a total of 54 - three votes short of a majority. Over the last two months, Mulroney has filled 15 Senate vacancies with Conservative loyalists to narrow the gap.

DOC.HEAD: Police Brace for Gathering of World Leaders
DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf crisis is causing extra headaches for police officials charged with security at a United Nations gathering of 70 heads of state billed as the largest ever of world leaders. The heads of state, including President Bush, and 90 foreign ministers, scheduled to attend the two-day U.N. World Summit for Children beginning Sunday. The session aims to highlight social problems in the Third World and the inner cities of the United States. The United Nations says it will be the largest gathering of world leaders ever concentrated in two days. ``There are about 20 high-risk heads of state we're concerned about,'' said Assistant Chief Thomas Walsh, commanding officer of the Manhattan precincts where most of the activities will occur. Police officials declined to name the 20 leaders, but Deputy Chief William O'Sullivan said a ``significant number'' are from the Middle East. O'Sullivan, in charge of police intelligence, said the Middle East crisis has introduced new elements to security efforts, but refused to elaborate. A small army of police has been assigned to the 24-hour-a-day weekend security detail: as any as 900 officers on Saturday, 950 officers on Sunday and 1,600 police officers on Monday, Walsh said. Officials also said members of elite police details, such as the bomb squad, will be on 24-hour standby. ``There has to be a heightened sense of awareness anytime there's trouble in the world and all the leaders are coming to New York,'' Walsh said. More than 19 demonstrations are scheduled to take place over the weekend, police said. Bush is expected to arrive Saturday afternoon, the day before he is scheduled to address the children's summit. On Monday, Bush is scheduled to address the U.N. General Assembly and then attend a foreign ministers economic convention at the Jacob Javits Convention Center.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS ALEXANDRIA, Va.-dated last item in rdp to add day of death.
DOC.HEAD: Cornelius P. Turner
DOC.TEXT: Cornelius P. Turner, developer of the tests that permit non-graduates to win a high school diploma, died Wednesday at age 83. Turner died of blood poisoning at Alexandria Hospital. As a Navy lieutenant from 1943 to 1945, Turner directed a program that developed high-school diploma equivalency tests for use by members of the armed services during World War II. After the war, he held a number of positions that helped expand use of the General Educational Development tests until all U.S. states and Canadian provinces adopted them. About 700,000 people a year take the tests.

DOC.HEAD: Martinez Fund-Raiser Features Reagan; Chiles Serves Hot Dogs
DOC.TEXT: Former President Ronald Reagan urged the re-election of Gov. Bob Martinez at a $1,500-a-plate fund-raiser, while the governor's Democratic rival spoke at a $1.50 hot dog rally at the county fairgrounds. The glittery GOP affair Thursday night that featured a Western motif was juxtaposed against Lawton Chiles' folksy get-together, which the former U.S. senator said was meant to show that ``people are more important than money.'' ``For a dollar and a half you can have dinner with the next governor of Florida,'' Chiles said. ``You don't have to pay $1,500 to see the next ex-governor of Florida and the last president of the United States.'' Reagan asked some 1,200 Republican faithful during his speech to ``win just one more for the Gipper.'' ``It's up to all of us to assure that Bob Martinez can continue the job he started,'' Reagan said. Reagan, who just returned from a trip to Europe and the Soviet Union, came to Orlando from his California home to pay some old campaign debts to Martinez. The governor was a leader in the Reagan presidential campaigns, and Florida delivered large majorities in two elections. ``Bob Martinez is the embodiment of the American dream,'' said Reagan, recalling the governor's Spanish ancestry. ``There is no question that this race is important to Florida and the nation.'' The former president and Martinez recalled a July 1983 meeting in the Oval Office when, Martinez said, ``He convinced me to become a Republican. ... Without that visit, I doubt very seriously that I would be standing here as governor.'' The fund-raiser was expected to raise some $2 million for Martinez's campaign. At the central Florida fairgrounds, more than 300 attended the event for Chiles and running mate Buddy MacKay. The Chiles-MacKay ticket also was calling its rally a fund-raiser and was distributing cards for contributions up to the $100 individual limit it has set for the campaign.

DOC.HEAD: Iranians Stage Anti-American Demonstratrions
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Millions of Iranians took to the streets today for anti-American demonstrations, chanting ``Death To America!'' and denouncing the presence of U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf region, Tehran radio said. Iran has condemned Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, but it has also deplored the deployment of multinational military forces to protect Saudi Arabia and enforce a U.N.-imposed embargo against Baghdad. In a live broadcast from the streets of the Iranian capital, Tehran radio called the demonstrations ``an opportunity for the nation to announce its stance on the attack on Kuwait, followed by the U.S. forces' hasty departure to take up positions in Saudi Arabia.'' The broadcast, monitored in Nicosia, accused the Western forces in Saudi Arabia of having ``defiled our sacred lands, the land of divine revelations, just as they did in Jerusalem, by bringing corruption, devastation, godlessness and debauchery to that hallowed region.'' ``This has naturally wounded the hearts of all the Moslems,'' the state-run radio said. It did not provide details about the number of people participating in the nationwide demonstrations, other than saying millions took part. It did not say where the protests were held, other than in Tehran. Iran has repeatedly condemned King Fahd for allowing the U.S. and other forces into Saudi Arabia, where Islam's holiest shrines are located. Today's protests capped a week-long commemoration of the start of the 1980-1988 war with Iraq. Iran claimed victory after Baghdad hastily moved to make peace with Iran following the invasion of Kuwait. Iraq's withdrawal of troops from Iranian territory freed up soldiers for Baghdad to send to Kuwait and the Saudi front. President Hashemi Rafsanjani is under pressure from vehemently anti-Western radicals, who want him to help Iraq confront the United States. The demonstrations come one day after the government announced the resumption of relations with Britain. Tehran severed ties with London in March 1988 over the death decree by the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini against British writer Salman Rushdie. Khomeini said Rushdie defamed Islam in his novel the ``The Satanic Verses.''

DOC.HEAD: Shooting Breaks Out at Home of Philippines Cabinet Minister
DOC.TEXT: An unidentified gunman today fired at the home of a Cabinet minister in an apparent assassination attempt. The gunfire missed the official but killed a family friend and wounded a visitor. According to one of official's maids, who spoke on condition of anonymity, Minister Luis Santos had leaned over to kiss a grandchild when a bullet whizzed past him and struck the other two people. Police said both victims were hit by the same bullet, but it was not known if other gunmen were involved. A police investigator, Lt. Col. Efren Arayata, said Santos' guards were being questioned. Santos, the secretary of local governments in President Corazon Aquino's Cabinet, lives in in Davao City, 610 miles southeast of Manila, on Mindanao island. Santos told The Associated Press by telephone that a 67-year-old family friend, Marcosa Reyes, was fatally wounded in the neck, and his 17-year-old maid, Arlene Caballero, was hit in the left shoulder. ``Suddnnly there was shooting,'' said the maid. ``I don't know where it came from. No one came in or out.'' She said Santos was unarmed. The maid said she saw a man wearing a black jacket running away from a storeroom opposite the house. Santos came back to Davao on Thursday at the request of local business leaders worried about rumors of an impending coup attempt. At a meeting, he assured them the government was stable and could cope with any emergency. Mrs. Aquino has been the target of several coup attempts, the most serious in December. Santos was a former police chief of Davao. He assumed the Cabinet post following the assassination of Jaime Ferrer in August 1987. Two people were convicted in that killing, but the court never established who ordered the attack.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Guild Authorizes Strike If Talks Stall At San Francisco Papers
DOC.TEXT: A union representing about 1,200 San Francisco newspaper workers unanimously authorized a strike if contract talks fail to forge an agreement soon. ``We've been bargaining since last February, and our members are increasingly upset that no contract has been reached yet,'' said Bernie Beck of the Northern California Newspaper Guild's unit at the San Francisco Chronicle. Local Guild President Steven R. Michael said after Thursday's strike authorization vote that he hoped a strike wouldn't be necessary. No deadline for completion of contract talks had been set, he said. The Guild represents reporters and certain other employees at the Chronicle, Examiner and the Newspaper Agency, the jointly owned company that prints and distributes both papers. They have worked without a contract since Feb. 2. The current contract contains an ``evergreen clause,'' which means it remains in force until a new agreement is reached, Beck said. He said that publishers ``still are at some distance about work rules'' and that negotiations about things such as wages and hours haven't even begun. In all, about 4,500 employees, represented by the 10 unions, are working without contracts at the two papers and Newspaper Agency. The Conference of Newspaper Unions will represent all 10 unions in wage and economic bargaining, which is expected to begin next week.

DOC.HEAD: Pravda Claims Democratic Group Plotted to Seize Power
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party daily Pravda today condemned what it said was an opposition group's plot to seize power, and some radical politicians expresssed fears the article was setting the stage for a government crackdown. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev referred to rising tensions today in a Kremlin meeting with Jack Welsh, the president of General Electric. ``It really is an exciting time, so exciting that people are completely confused,'' the Soviet leader said. ``We must ... galvanize the whole country or we will not get out of this vicious circle.'' ``The command system has almost completely fallen apart,'' Gorbachev said in a television report on the meeting. Gorbachev now has new powers he could use to put down unrest. On Monday, the Supreme Soviet legislature gave him the authority to issue decrees to rescue the collapsing Soviet economy and ensure law and order. He issued his first directive Thursday, ordering businesses nationwide to fulfill supply contracts and the government to ensure distribution. In today's report, Pravda said a group called the Russian Democratic Forum had drafted a plan seeking the ``elimination'' of the Communist Party from the political arena, the breakup of its ranks and nationalization of its property. Little is known about the group, which is said to have drafted its plan in July. The Moscow newspaper Leninskoye Znamya said it was formed by some members of the Russian People's Front, a grass-roots political movement. The front-page article in the party newspaper called the group's plan ``destructive, permeated by a spirit of intolerance and lack of acceptance of those unsuitable to its authoss.'' Pravda said the document calls for a violent overthrow of the state, and urged that it be made the target of legal scrutiny. Other democratic leaders distanced themselves from the group at a news conference today. ``We want to act strictly within the framework of the law and observance of law and order,'' said a joint statement from the Inter-Regional Deputies' Group and the Democratic Russia parliamentary opposition group. Moscow Mayor Gavriil Popov, a radical economist, told reporters that ``extremists'' were planning disruptive actions for the Soviet Constitution Day holiday on Oct. 7. He said they were trying to provoke conservatives and prompt a government crackdown. The statement from the two groups said such actions would ``play into the hand of those who would like to find some kind of plot, to have a pretext to introduce a state of emergency in the country and devastate democratic forces.'' ``For whom is it generally advantageous to spread rumors about a plot? In the existing situation, only conservatives and extremists are dreaming of destabilization,'' it said. Mikhail Poltoranin, a member of Democratic Russia, told reporters a ``wave of provocations'' including demonstrations, strikes and calls to smash windows is possible on Oct. 6 or 7. ``We don't want any demonstrations or strikes,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Lawmakers, North Korea Call for Rapid Establishment of Ties
DOC.TEXT: Leading Japanese lawmakers and North Korea's ruling party agreed today that the two countries should begin formal negotiations in November to establish diplomatic ties. The joint declaration, signed in Pyongyang, North Korea's capital, marked a sharp departure from the North's past policy of opposition to ties with countries that recognize rival South Korea. South Korea's Foreign Ministry today reacted with caution to the news of improving relations between Japan and North Korea. Officials said they welcomed a liberalization of the North's isolationist policy, but said Japanese moves to strengthen ties should be made slowly and in consultation with South Korea. Some observers have suggested North Korea's move to establish relations with Japan might have been triggered by South Korea's steps toward ties with the Soviet Union, a close ally of North Korea. Normalization of ties by Tokyo and Pyongyang would end 45 years of estrangement between Japan and North Korea, beginning at the end of World War II when the peninsula was divided. South Korea normalized relations with Japan in 1965. The joint communique came at the end of five days of talks in North Korea between the Japanese lawmakers' group and North Korean officials, including President Kim Il Sung. The talks were the highest-level discussions ever by the two countries. The Japanese delegation, made up of lawmakers from Japan's governing and largest opposition parties, agreed that Tokyo should pay compensation to North Korea for its past colonial rule over the Korean peninsula, Japanese and North Korean news reports said. Although the discussions were between North Korean and Japanese political parties rather than their governments, the communique is believed to represent a commitment by both sides. The Japanese group was headed by former Deputy Prime Minister Shin Kanemaru, a powerful leader of the governing Liberal Democratic Party, and by Japan Socialist Party Vice Chairman Makoto Tanabe. The Socialists have served as a bridge between the two nations in the absence of formal diplomatic relations. During the talks, Kim agreed to release two Japanese seamen detained since 1983 on espionage charges, removing a key impediment to relations. North Korean officials said Thursday the two men will be freed in October, Japan's Kyodo News Service reported. Today's declaration said the two countries should quickly establish satellite communications links and direct air flights to help improve relations. The two countries now have no direct telephone, mail or travel connections. The joint declaration also called for an end to discrimination against Koreans living in Japan and for peaceful unification of North and South Korea through dialogue between the divided nations.

DOC.HEAD: Leading Indicators Down 1.2 Percent; Sharpest Drop in Nearly 3 Years
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 5 grafs to include that last big drop came after 1987 stock market crash; picks up 5th graf pvs, The index...
DOC.TEXT: The government's main economic forecasting gauge in August sank 1.2 percent in the wake of the Persian Gulf crisis, the government said today. It was the steepest drop since the month following the 1987 stock market crash. The Commerce Department's Index of Leading Economic Indicators had been unchanged in the month prior to the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Since then, however, an already sluggish economy has shown signs of further weakening as oil prices more than doubled, slowing both sales and production. Both consumer confidence and the stock market also have plunged. The August decline was the first in four months and the sharpest since a 1.4 percent fall in November 1987. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks plummeted 508 points a month earlier, on Oct. 19. The 22.6 percent drop was the biggest percentage decline in stock market history. Other stock indices also fell sharply. The index is designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months in advance. Three consecutive declines in the gauge are viewed as a fairly reliable - although not infallible - signal that the economy is headed for a recession. A survey of the nation's top economic forecasters in late August and early September showed they were growing more pessimistic about chances the economy could avoid a recession in the next 12 months. Indeed, some believed the downturn already has begun. ``Up until now, a large majority of NABE forecasters have expected the expansion to last through 1990 and 1991,'' the National Association of Business Economists said in a report on the survey. ``But this prospect is now in jeopardy,'' it continued. ``Although the median forecast shows positive real growth in both 1990 and 1991, the pace is slow enough to make two quarters of decline in a row - the informal definition of recession - a distinct possibility.'' Seven of the forward-looking indicators dragged the index under in August. They were a drop in an index measuring consumer confidence, declining stock prices, falling orders for new plants and equipment, a decrease in unfilled orders, a rise in weekly unemployment claims, a drop in building permits and a fall in the money supply. The only positive contributors were slower business delivery times, an increase in orders for consumer goods, a longer workweek and an increase in the price of raw materials. The various changes left the index at 144.2 percent of its 1982 base of 100 and down 0.4 percent from its level a year ago. If a recession could be avoided through November, the economic expansion will have reached its eighth anniversary. It already is the nation's longest in peacetime. And if it lasted until October 1991, it would set a new overall record of U.S. economic growth, surpassing the 106 months of continuing expansion between February 1961 and December 1969. Just four months ago, the NABE survey found 82 percent of the 68 professional forecasters surveyed in April and May saying the business expansion would continue through next year. But, in answer to the question, ``What is the probability of a recession within the next 12 months?'' the new survey found ``the median probability of recession has jumped to 50 percent from prior readings which have been in the 20-30 percent zone.'' The latest survey of 71 forecasters also found 60 percent anticipating a recession within three years.
