Of those, 76 percent ``believe it has already begun (in the second or third quarter) or will begin imminently (in the fourth quarter, or the first three months of 1991),'' the report said. ``Of course, information and conditions are changing rapidly as this analysis is prepared,'' the NABE economists said. Indeed, on Tuesday, the same day the survey results were released, the government sharply revised second-quarter economic growth down from an annual rate of 1.2 percent to a barely perceptible 0.4 percent. But even before that change, the survey showed, the forecasters already had shaved their estimate of economic growth for 1990 from 2.0 percent in May to 1.2 percent in August, and for 1991 from 2.4 percent four months ago to 1.4 percent last month. Other highlights of the survey projected: -Inflation as measured by the Consumer Price Index would rise 5.3 percent in 1990, compared to 4.7 percent in the pre-oil-price shock poll. The 1991 forecast is for a 4.9 percent increase, up from 4.3 percent in the May survey. Inflation for all of 1989 was 4.6 percent. -The merchandise trade deficit would improve from $109.4 billion in 1989 to $95 billion this year and $90 billion in 1991. -The federal budget deficit would total $225 billion, including the cost of the savings and loan bailout, in 1990 and $240 billion in 1991. The 1989 deficit was $152.0 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Attack Kills Soldier's Son in Staging Area for French Gulf Deployment
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A grenade attack killed a French soldier's son and injured 17 other people in Djibouti, a small Red Sea country that serves as a staging ground for French forces deployed in the Persian Gulf, officials said today. Thursday night's attack, at a cafe frequented by French military personnel, killed the 9-year-old son of a soldier, French military officials said. All but two of those injured were French, they said. A West German and a Djiboutian were also hurt, officials said. French President Francois Mitterrand expressed ``horror'' at the ``cowardly attack.'' No one immediately claimed responsibility, and it was not known whether the attack was related to the standoff with Iraq. Djibouti's port and airport serve as rear bases for French naval forces sent to the Persian Gulf region to enforce U.N. sanctions against Iraq. The small country, a former French territory, lies on the Red Sea at the mouth of the Gulf of Aden. Six of those injured remained hospitalized, including the parents of the dead boy, according to medical officials. Anne Suard, first secretary at the French Embassy in Djibouti, said the attackers arrived on foot at the Cafe de Paris, threw grenades into the crowd on the terrace and sped away in a waiting taxi. French military personnel were ordered to return to their base, she said. In a message to the head of French forces in Djibouti, Gen. Claude Gautier, Mitterrand expressed confidence the forces would ``face with determination and dignity the situation confronting France in this region of the world.'' One of the hospitalized victims said the slain child was seated on his father's knee at the time of the attack, medical officials said. A third grenade was found unexploded in front of the terrace of the L'Historil Cafe, 100 yards away from the cafe where the attack took place. In March 1987, an attack at the L'Historil killed 12 people, four French military men and a French civilian, four West Germans and three Djiboutians. That attack was allegedly committed by a man carrying a Tunisian passport, recruited in Damascus, Syria, by a Mideast terrorist group. There are 3,850 French troops stationed permanently in Djibouti, the former French territory of Afars and Issas, under a defense accord signed in June 1977 when the small nation gained independence.

DOC.HEAD: Army Closes Crossings into Aoun Enclave
LaserPhoto BEI1
DOC.TEXT: President Elias Hrawi's army closed all crossing points into rebel Gen. Michel Aoun's enclave in Lebanon's Christian heartland today in a bid to starve him into submission. A communique from Hrawi's army command under Gen. Emile Lahoud said only diplomats, Red Cross officials and lawmakers would be allowed to drive into Aoun's zone. Civilians are allowed to cross on foot. Troops set up iron barricades and installed barbed wire at all gateways into Aoun's territory, and thoroughly searched pedestrians' bags. ``I don't know how we are going to survive the blockade,'' said a 22-year-old college student who did not want to be identified by name. ``I'm not even sure I'll go to university on Monday.'' By mid-afternoon, about 100 cars had driven out of Aoun's enclave. Troops, who checked the occupants' identities, said all were Moslems visiting friends or on business. The move tightened an economic blockade imposed by Hrawi's government on July 30 against Aoun and his 15,000 mainly Christian soldiers in pockets they hold in east Beirut and the neighboring Metn mountains. Supplies of flour, food and vegetables were kept out of Aoun's 80-square-mile zone today. Fuel supplies and money transfers had been banned for two months. Aoun, who refuses to recognize Hrawi's presidency, called the new squeeze a ``blockade to starve people down to their knees.'' ``But they are not going to escape the people's wrath. The people will not knuckle under,'' Aoun was quoted as saying today by the conservative Beirut newspaper Al-Anwar. Hrawi's mainly Moslem troops earlier took over the coastal and mountainous crossings into Aoun's enclave from the Lebanese Forces, the Christians' main militia headed by Samir Geagea. The peaceful handover put the final seal on Geagea's allegiance to Hrawi, leaving Aoun ringed from all sides in his small pocket with no air, sea or land outlets. Hrawi's government is giving the new siege two weeks to work. If it fails, Hrawi's army backed by Syrian troops would attack to oust Aoun by force, several Beirut newspapers reported.

DOC.HEAD: Son of Lottery Winner Jailed, Hospitalized After Spree, Three Arrests
DOC.TEXT: The 30-year-old son of a man who recently won a share of the state's biggest-ever lottery jackpot was taken to jail and the hospital after apparently going on a wild spree over several days. Richard D. Piasecki was taken to the Volusia County Branch Jail on a charge of disorderly conduct Tuesday after his third arrest in three days. On Thursday, he was transferred to the emergency room at Halifax Medical Center in Daytona Beach, but hospital officials would not release information on his condition. Piasecki's father, Richard J. Piasecki, who won more than $17 million, one-sixth of a record $106.5 million Florida Lottery jackpot, had said he would share it with his children. The younger Piasecki's troubles started Sunday night in South Daytona. A restaurant worker called police after Piasecki allegedly screamed obscenities at a man driving a Mercedes-Benz because the car was not made in America, according to police reports. Piasecki threatened to hunt down the driver with a shotgun, a witness said. When Piasecki was stopped, he was abusive and tried to make sexual advances toward a policewoman, police said. He later failed a blood alcohol test, refused to sign a traffic citation and was found to have part of a marijuana joint in his van. Piasecki was charged with drunken driving and possession of marijuana under 20 grams. He was released after posting $1,000 bond. On Tuesday afternoon, De Land police responded to complaints that a man was raving in front of a grocery store. There they found Piasecki screaming vulgarities. He allegedly swore at a patrolman and was taken to the Volusia County Branch Jail on a disorderly conduct charge. He apparently paid the $250 bond and returned to De Land. Tuesday night, De Land police responded to a report of a fight at the bus station. They found Piasecki screaming, again arrested him and took him to the police station, where he refused to be fingerprinted. While in the holding cell, Piasecki stuffed paper towels into a toilet and stood in it, flushing until water spilled onto the floor, authorities said. He was then taken back to the jail.

DOC.HEAD: Performance Artists Sue NEA Over Denial of Grants
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 3rd graf, `The suit...', to UPDATE with no-comment from NEA.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Mapplethorpe Trial
DOC.TEXT: Four avant-garde theater performers are suing the National Endowment for the Arts, contending they were denied funds for political reasons. Karen Finley and Holly Hughes of New York, John Fleck of Los Angeles and Tim Miller of Santa Monica filed a lawsuit in federal court Thursday asking for the $23,000 grants for which they applied - or at least review of their applications. The suit, filed on the artists' behalf by the American Civil Liberties Union, claims the NEA ``violated their First Amendment rights by denying their applications for impermissible political reasons.'' Josh Dare, a spokesman for the NEA, said today that the agency had no immediate comment on the suit. Grants for the performance artists, known as the ``NEA Four'' in arts circles, received unanimous approval in February from a peer review board. But NEA chairman John E. Frohnmayer vetoed the grants on June 29, and last month rejected appeals of his decision by the artists. He was named as a defendant. When Frohnmayer vetoed the four grants, he refused to give any reasons, citing a longstanding policy against discussing grant rejections. In an unusual departure from that policy late in August, the NEA issued a statement saying that Frohnmayer decided against giving the four grants because the artists' work would not ``enhance public understanding and appreciation of the arts.'' Congress, at the urging of Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., last year amended the NEA appropriations bill for the current fiscal year to prohibit federal support for works that ``may be deemed obscene.'' The action came after controversy arose over exhibits by artists such as the late photographer Robert Mapplethorpe, whose work included sexual themes. The four who sued Thursday, each of whom had received NEA grants in the past, do monologues and other stage routines that generally deal with politics, racism and sexual oppression and frequently include strong sexual content. The performers had been singled out by conservative members of Congress as examples of the NEA's willingness to subsidize works that might be offensive.

DOC.HEAD: Millions of Iranians Protest U.S. Gulf Presence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with grenade attack in Djibouti, economic fallout in Japan, United States. Pickup 4th graf pvs, `Oil hit...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY6
DOC.TEXT: Millions of Iranians staged anti-American demonstrations today, chanting ``Death To America'' and denouncing the U.S.-led forces deployed in the Persian Gulf in the standoff with Iraq, according to a news report. Turkey enforced the U.N. air embargo against Iraq by searching planes bound for Baghdad, and Spain and South Korea joined other nations in pulling envoys from embassies besieged by Iraqi troops in Kuwait. A grenade attack killed the 9-year-old son of a French soldier and injured 17 other people in Djibouti, a small Red Sea country that serves as a staging ground for French forces in the Persian Gulf, officials said today. No one immediately claimed responsibility for the attack Thursday night at a cafe frequented by French military personnel, and it was not known whether it was related to the standoff with Iraq. In Paris, representatives of the United States and 20 industrialized nations met behind closed doors to discuss how to replenish oil supplies if they are depleted by the gulf crisis. Jitters over the crisis sent stocks plunging on major markets. Stock prices dropped to the lowest point in 3{ years in Tokyo today, and analysts blamed fear of war in the Middle East, high interest rates and climbing oil prices. In New York, the Down Jones average of 30 industrials plunged 43.83 points to 2,383.66 in the first half-hour of trading. The key barometer has shed 600 points, or lost 20 percent in value, in the past six weeks. The U.S. government said today that its main economic forecasting gauge declined 1.2 percent in August following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, the steepest drop in three years. The Commerce Department's Index of Leading Economic Indicators had been unchanged in July. Since the invasion, however, consumer confidence and the stock market have plunged, hurting an already sluggish economy. Oil hit $40 a barrel Thursday, exactly eight weeks after Iraqi President Saddam Hussein sent his troops into Kuwait and increased his share of world oil reserves to 20 percent. Oil sold for $22 per barrel before the invasion. Kuwait's exiled emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmad al-Jaber al-Sabah, was to meet today with President Bush in Washington. The White House invitation underscored the U.S. view that the emir is still the legitimate ruler of Kuwait. Tehran radio, monitored in Nicosia, covered the protest in the Iranian capital live from the streets. It said others were held across the nation. A reporter said the demonstrations were ``an opportunity for the nation to announce its stance on the attack on Kuwait, followed by the U.S. forces' hasty departure to take up positions in Saudi Arabia.'' Iran has condemned Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, but it has deplored the U.S.-led multinational forces sent to protect Saudi Arabia and enforce a U.N.-imposed embargo against Baghdad. However, it has said it is cooperating with the embargo. And on Thursday, Britain and Iran suddenly announced the restoration of diplomatic ties. They were severed after the late Ayatollah Khomeini's death decree against author Salman Rushdie for his book ``The Satanic Verses.'' Spain and South Korea said they were withdrawing envoys from their embassies in Kuwait following a day of angry protests from Western governments over Iraq's efforts to intimidate foreign diplomats in Baghdad. For the past five weeks, Iraqi soldiers have been trying to starve diplomats out of their compounds in Kuwait. At last word, the U.S. ambassador and envoys in more than a dozen other embassies were still holding out. The Iraqi forces have cut off water, electricity and any supplies to the embassies. Baghdad says the embassies must close because Kuwait was annexed and made a province of Iraq. The diplomatic war escalated this month when Iraq raided several Western diplomatic compounds in Kuwait City. The Spanish Foreign Ministry said today that Spain's last diplomat in Kuwait had fled to Baghdad. But the ministry said the embassy remained technically open, and a spokesman added, ``The government reaffirms that it does not recognize the annexation of Kuwait by Iraq.'' Spain on Thursday ordered two Iraqi diplomats to leave the country and denied two others permission to take up their posts. South Korea's Foreign Ministry announced in Seoul today that it temporarily closed its embassy in Kuwait. It said Ambassador Soh Byung-yong and the few remaining staff arrived in Amman, Jordan, on Thursday. In Ankara, Turkish officials speaking on condition of anonymity said two passenger planes, one Indian and one Soviet, landed as ordered at the Adana airport in southern Turkey on Thursday evening. Officials inspected the planes to make sure no cargo was on board that violates the U.N. economic embargo on Iraq. The planes then flew to Iraq to pick up Soviet and Indian nationals, officials said. A Polish civilian aircraft traveling to Iraq was ordered to land today at Esenboga airport near Ankara, officials said. They gave no other details. The United Nations has authorized nations to order planes bound for Iraq to land when they pass over their territory and submit to searches. In Yugoslavia, the Croatian republic accused federal authorities of breaking U.N. sanctions against Iraq by servicing and testing Iraqi warplanes, the state news agency anjug said today. ``Despite Yugoslavia's obligations to observe the resolutions, warplanes with Iraqi markings ... are carrying out test flights over Zagreb,'' Tanjug quoted Croatia's Information Ministry as saying. There was no immediate response from the national government. Iraq's army newspaper today accused Israel and Egypt of setting up an intelligence station in Israel's Negev Desert to gather data on the movement of Iraqi troops. Al-Qaddissiya, quoting unidentified Arab sources, said the electronic and radar reconnaissance station was financed by the former rulers of Kuwait and the government of Saudi Arabia. Another Iraqi newspaper, the government-run Al-Jomhouriya, said Israel would be among targets struck in the ``coming fire,'' for which it said the United States and its allies would bear responsibility.

DOC.HEAD: Vessel Sinks Offshore, Coast Guard Searches for Survivors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates throughout with search resuming, second ship finding debris. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A Coast Guard airplane resumed searching today for possible survivors of a vessel whose sunken hull was spotted 500 miles southeast of Nova Scotia. The identity of the vessel and the conditions under which it sank remained unknown, said Petty Officer Lionel Bryant, a Coast Guard spokesman. A Canadian plane had sighted the hull on Thursday and also saw white, blue and brown boxes in the water that are commonly used by fishing boats to hold their catch, Bryant said. Earlier Thursday, the crew of a Coast Guard plane saw an oil slick and debris in the area, Bryant said. The Coast Guard sent the plane out Wednesday in response to emergency signals picked up that day. A Liberian-flagged merchant vessel in the area, Star Fraser, recovered a fishing buoy and broken plastic buckets, and a second ship also found some debris, but there no sign of survivors, Bryant said. He said the Coast Guard had received no reports of ships overdue.

DOC.HEAD: Walsh Indicates More Prosecutions Possible
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 3rd graf, The independent, to include expense.
DOC.TEXT: Iran-Contra prosecutor Lawrence E. Walsh says he wants to complete his investigation of the Reagan administration's worst scandal by next spring but indicates he might bring more charges in the meantime. Walsh held out the possibility Thursday that his office could seek more criminal indictments in the continuing investigation of the coverup of U.S.-Iran arms deals and the secret delivery of military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels. The independent counsel acknowledged that the ``heavy expense'' of the probe would be a factor in deciding how far to press the almost 4-year-old investigation. Walsh's office has spent more than $21 million. But he said he could not foresee closing his office until after an appeals court rules, probably next spring, on the convictions of former national security adviser John M. Poindexter. ``Ideally, the work of the office - except for possible appeals and the trial of any outstanding indictments - should be completed shortly after this decision,'' Walsh said. ``During the intervening months our investigation should be completed,'' he said in the text of a speech at Washburn University in Topeka, Kan. But Walsh indicated that new charges may be brought by the grand jury, which sources say is examining the role of Reagan administration officials in trying to cover up the Iran-Contra affair. ``If there should be further prosecutions they will be pressed without delay,'' he said. He said his staff had recently obtained new records of the Iran-Contra affair. ``Also, certain witnesses are available now who were not available during earlier stages of the investigation,'' Walsh said in an apparent reference to Poindexter and former White House aide Oliver North. Since their convictions, both men have testified before the grand jury, which continues to meet periodically. Walsh's efforts will be largely focused on defending the convictions of Poindexter and North. The independent counsel recently asked a federal appeals court here to reconsider its July 20 decision to set aside North's three felony convictions pending a hearing on whether North's congressional testimony had unfairly tainted his trial. North and Poindexter both testified before Congress under immunity grants that barred prosecutors from using their testimony as evidence against them. In his speech, Walsh blamed those grants for delaying his investigation by more than a year. Poindexter and North could have been tried together, but ``because of problems related to immunity, the trial court held that they must be tried separately,'' he said. Poindexter recently appealed his six-month jail sentence for lying to lawmakers and obstructing congressional inquiries into the Iran-Contra affair. Walsh responded to critics who have argued that he was prosecuting officials for involvement in a political dispute with Congress over foreign policy. He contended that the prosecutions were necessary to punish government officials who had illegally withheld information from Congress. ``If Congress, as a body, asks for information, it is entitled to information and to the extent possible, accurate information,'' Walsh said. When lawmakers asked about reports the Reagan administration was secretly aiding the Contra rebels in defiance of a congressional ban, ``the executive did not have the privilege of lying as a tactic to achieve a political end,'' Walsh said. Such deception was held by trial judges to be a crime, he said. Walsh's remarks indicated that his original timetable for concluding the investigation had been extended six months. Following Poindexter's conviction in April, Walsh had said he hoped to make that decision by this fall. The Iran-Contra investigation, which began in late 1986, has resulted in eight convictions.

DOC.HEAD: Crude Passes $40 a Barrel Despite Bush Action
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE prices down slightly in early trading today. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `Bush said...'. Version moved on financial wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY35 of Sept. 27
DOC.TEXT: Crude prices topped $40 a barrel for the first time despite President Bush's attempt to soothe oil markets by selling government reserves. Analysts said heightened tension Thursday in the Persian Gulf helped counter Bush's decision to sell 5 million barrels of crude from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. The November contract traded Thursday for light, sweet crude rose 87 cents to settle at $39.54 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange after trading as high as $40.10. It was the first time oil prices on the futures exchange passed the $40-a-barrel mark. Each barrel holds 42 gallons. In early trading this morning, oil prices were narrowly lower. The November contract for light, sweet crude was off 29 cents at $39.25 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange by midmorning. Bush said Wednesday that he was dipping into the nation's reserves of 590 million barrels to counter speculators who have driven up the price of crude despite adequate supplies. Prices have doubled since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. The president succeeded only temporarily. Prices dropped on overseas markets Thursday, and crude opened at $37.67 a barrel in New York. But Persian Gulf developments prompted panic buying. William Byers, an oil market analyst with Bear, Stearns & Co., called news from the Middle East ``more than an offsetting penalty'' to Bush's announcement. He also said many traders viewed Thursday's incident involving the Iraqi tanker Tadmur as an offensive measure by the Baghdad government, designed to increase tensions in the Gulf. The Pentagon said a team from a U.S. warship in the Red Sea boarded the tanker after firing warning shots when orders to stop were ignored. The Tadmur was allowed to proceed after it was found to be empty, the Pentagon said. Analysts said the market continued to be hypersensitive to any rumors or reports that indicate military action is brewing that could cut off output from Saudi Arabia, the biggest producer in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. There also was some skepticism in the market about whether Bush is serious about holding down oil prices by dipping into the nation's reserves. ``It may be more an attempt to show the electorate five weeks before the elections that he's trying to do something and is concerned,'' said Peter Beutel, an oil market analyst at Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. in Hoboken, N.J. But Beutel said sales from the nation's reserves may yet have an impact on the market. ``Over time, as people start to lose interest in pursuing the bear market to an end, it could be a moderating influence on prices,'' he said. Meanwhile, prices for refined products also continued to climb Thursday. Home heating oil for delivering in October rose 1.80 cents to $1.0437 a gallon and prices for wholesale unleaded regular gasoline jumped 2.59 cents to $1.0269 a gallon. The change in seasons is also a factor in heating oil prices, however. Prices always advance as colder weather approaches.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Voices Support for Democracy in Bulgaria
DOC.TEXT: President Bush told the new president of Bulgaria today that democratic reforms in his country have ``the full support of the American people.'' President Zhelyu Zhelev assured Bush, ``This country is no longer a communist, a totalitarian state.'' ``We're anxious to see this democratic change solidified,'' Bush told Zhelev during a brief Oval Office meeting. ``We have great respect for what you're trying to do. ... The changes in Eastern Europe have really captured the imagination of the American people.'' The Bulgarian leader assured Bush during a photo session before their meeting that his country ``has embarked fully on the road to democracy. ``This is a symbolic visit because the greatest democracy in the world is extending a helpful hand to the youngest democracy in the world,'' he added. Zhelev is concluding five days in Washington with his top economic advisers was heading to meetings at United Nations in New York and an address to the General Assembly. Zhelev said Thursday that Bulgaria is prepared to send a contingent of ground troops to join forces with the United States and other countries defending Saudi Arabia and enforcing U.N. sanctions against Iraq. The plan has been delayed to discuss minimizing hardship for about 700 Bulgarian specialists in Iraqi-held territory, he said. A group of U.S. economists is working with the Bulgarians on economic reform proposals for discussion by Bulgaria's first democratically-chosen parliament in more than 40 years. Zhelev said he wants to create a climate for foreign investment, and favors ``privatizing as widely as possible,'' not only large industries and agriculture but also private hospitals and schools. The president leaves Washington with State Department assurances of food aid for the winter. Zhelev, 55, head of the United Democratic Forces opposition, was elected president of the Balkan country Aug. 1 after five earlier unsuccessful attempts in parliament to choose a new chief state. The body is dominated by members of the former ruling communist party who have renamed themselves the Socialist Party.

DOC.HEAD: Italian Dignitaries Honor Writer at Funeral
DOC.TEXT: Italy's film and literary world and hundreds of fellow Romans paid last respects today to novelist Alberto Moravia, considered by many critics to have been Italy's leading writer over the past four decades. ``Moravia represented an authoritative Roman presence,'' said Mayor Franco Carraro at the funeral service held in the Campidologio Square. ``Without him, Rome will be a different city.'' Moravia died Wednesday of a heart attack at his home by the Tiber River. He was 82. Born in Rome, he always lived in the city and set many of his works such as ``The Woman of Rome'' and ``Two Women'' in and around the city. Other speakers at the funeral included film director Bernardo Bertolucci and writer Umberto Eco. Moravia's friend and fellow writer Enzo Siciliano said, ``He believed in one thing, in one value: the value of intelligence and works which through intelligence and knowledge become a patrimony to everyone.'' Bertolucci praised Moravia's style, which was readily adaptable to film due to its detail and imagery. ``I only made one film from a work of Moravia's (``The Conformist'') but I could have made 10. Every time one of his books came out I had the temptation to make a film,'' he said. Moravia is survived by his Spanish wife, Carmen Llera.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
NEW YORK: postmaster general.
DOC.TEXT: O'Brien was elected to succeed the late Walter Kennedy as NBA commissioner in 1975, a year when free agency and big money were reshaping pro sports. It was with O'Brien's guidance that the NBA settled the so-called ``Oscar Robertson suit'' in 1976, which paved the way to free agency in the league. The NBA and its Players Association also reached a collective bargaining agreement. He also supervised the NBA's merger with the rival American Basketball Association. As a result, the four strongest teams from the ABA were absorbed into the NBA. The move ended costly feuding between the two leagues. In 1983, O'Brien and the NBA seemed headed toward a crisis. As the playoffs approached, so the did the possibility of a players' strike. O'Brien helped negotiate a new collective bargaining agreement between the NBA and the Players Association. The agreement provided for a cap on how much money teams could spend on salaries and benefits, in return for which the players were guaranteed 53 percent of the gross revenues of the league. The pact, hailed by owners and players as a major step toward securing the league's stability, was a landmark labor agreement in professional sports. ``It's a tribute to him that a strike was avoided,'' said Julius Erving, one of the league's best and most respected players. In November 1983, O'Brien announced that he had declined a new five-year contract. ``There comes a time when you have to move on,'' he said. He left the post the following year. ``I think the sport is better off by far than it was in 1975 when he came in, and I think that's the measure of success or failure in a commissioner,'' said Larry Fleisher, head of the Players Association and one of O'Brien's chief adversaries. O'Brien died at 6 p.m. Thursday, said Myrna Manners, a hospital spokeswoman. He is survived by his wife, Elva Brassard O'Brien; a son, Lawrence F. O'Brien III of Washington; two grandsons; and a sister, Mary Placzek of Wilbraham, Mass. Funeral services were set for Tuesday in Springfield, Mass. ---

DOC.HEAD: Military Officers Announce Intention To Overthrow Government
With PM-Sudan's Plight
DOC.TEXT: Senior Sudanese army officers have announced their intention to try to overthrow the military government of Lt. Gen. Omar el-Bashir. In an unusual move, they made the announcement in a news release Thursday issued in London. It identified the officers as Gen. Fathi Ahmed Ali, commander-in-chief of the Sudanese armed forces; Lt. Gen. Abdel Rahman Saeed, deputy chief of staff for operations; and Brig. El Hadi Bushra, acting director general of the Sudan Security Bureau. El-Bashir came to power in a 1989 coup, in which he overthrew Prime Minister Sadek el-Mahdi. The news release said Fatni and his colleagues intend ``to challenge the ruling junta and lead a military effort against the present regime in Sudan.'' ``They called on all officers and soldiers to unite your ranks and concentrate all your efforts to carry out a concerted operation ... to topple this murderous, corrupt, ugly and failed regime,'' it added. Cairo's El-Wafd newspaper said Fathi had been commander-in-chief until June 30, the first anniversary of el-Bashir's coup. The group said its statement followed consultations with senior army officers and political parties under the umbrella of the National Democratic Alliance. The whereabouts of the officers who sent the communique was not known. Their statement was accompanied by an announcement of the formation of the political alliance made up of parties banned in Sudan shortly after el-Bashir's coup. Sudan is plagued by a drought, hunger and a civil war between the Moslem North and the non-Moslem South. The war and famine have produced more than 3 million displaced people out of a population of more than 20 million. More than 380,000 of the Sudanese refugees have fled to refugee camps in Ethiopia.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Demand Disclosure of Stasi Members in Their Ranks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with minister resigning, admitting Stasi past. Pickup 4th pvs, `The meeting...'
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's Parliament decided today to go out of business in a blaze of candor by revealing the names of lawmakers who worked for the Communist secret police. Soon afterward, Construction Minister Axel Viehweger resigned from the Cabinet of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere and admitted he had contacts to the former secret police under the old regime. Lawmakers voted overwhelmingly to instruct a commission investigating the former security apparatus to disclose the names of former agents it has compiled. Before releasing the names, the lawmakers gave officials on the list a chance to address the allegations before Parliament. Viehweger did and promptly resigned. He said he had contacts with the secret police while he was on the energy council in the city of Dresden during the former regime. Ten other members of de Maiziere's 24-member Cabinet have stepped down because of political feuds, philosophical differences or incompetence. Other lawmakers trooped to the microphone to describe what they said were contacts with the secret police that they said were required under the old regime. Eberhard Schiffner, a Christian Democrat, said he was the head of a state veterinarian practice in 1963 and had to give information about his practice to the secret police. A member of the secret police committee, lawmaker Peter Hildebrand, said 56 lawmakers or ministers in the current government were informally employed by the secret police unit, known as the Stasi. The meeting of the 400-member Parliament was the second-to-last before the nation unites with West Germany on Tuesday and East Germany's government ceases to exist. ``This Parliament must not go down in history as the Stasi Parliament,'' said lawmaker Marianne Birthler, calling for full disclosure of information gathered by the committee. The nation has been obsessed with how to purge the tens of thousands of former Stasi informants and agents from influential roles in politics and business. The Stasi, many of whose members held other jobs they used as a cover, helped keep the former hard-line Communist regime in power through stifling surveillance, intimidation and purportedly murder. Because they and other elite members of the old regime had access to power, connections and money, they were able to maintain some control of the nation after a new, inexperienced democratic government was elected in March. There have been reports that many former functionaries and Stasi agents are running businesses that were once state-owned but have now been freed to operate as private enterprises.

DOC.HEAD: US, Bolivian Officials Say Cocaine-Trafficking Network Destroyed
DOC.TEXT: Bolivian anti-drug police and U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agents said today they had destroyed one of South America's most important drug-trafficking networks in a five-day series of raids. The U.S. and Bolivian teams simultaneously hit ranches, labs, distribution networks, radio transmitting facilities, air strips and a nightclub, DEA Bolivia chief Don Ferrarone told The Associated Press. He said at least 20 DEA agents and 300 Bolivian anti-drug police were involved in the operation, which was continuing today. The smashed cocaine-trafficking network belonged to Carmelo Meco Dominguez. Law enforcement agents said the 34-year-old kingpin handled five to 10 tons of pure cocaine a month, much of it bound for the U.S. market. They said Dominguez is one of Bolivia's top three cocaine traffickers. Dominguez was arrested Wednesday in Santa Cruz, Bolivia's second-largest city, located 350 miles east of La Paz, said Raul Loayza, Bolivia's undersecretary of the interior. ``We have destroyed one of the top trafficking operations in Bolivia and South America,'' Ferrarone said. He said Dominguez's ring had provided several tons of cocaine a month to trafficking organizations in Colombia and Mexico, and had strong ties to Colombia's Medellin and Cali cartels. The raids have been concentrated in Bolivia's principal coca-leaf and cocaine-producing regions, and resulted in confiscation of property worth at least $10 million, officials said. The seized assets include an automobile dealership and eight airplanes. The raids began Monday in the Chapare coca leaf-producing region. As the operation got under way, traffickers working for Dominguez fired at a police and DEA patrol and set two vehicles on fire. A DEA agent was hurt in the confrontation, in which the traffickers used automatic weapons, officials said. No further details were immediately available about the injured agent. Bolivia, an impoverished country of 7 million people, grows a one-third of the coca leaf that after further processing becomes pure cocaine. It is estimated that at least 300,000 Bolivians make their living from coca-leaf cultivation and cocaine-trafficking activities.

DOC.HEAD: Jaruzelski Declines White House Invitation
DOC.TEXT: Polish President Wojciech Jaruzelski has declined an invitation by President Bush to visit Washington this fall, citing his own decision to step down before his term expires, the White House said today. Bush accepted Jaruzelski's decision ``with full understanding,'' presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said in a written statement. Jaruzelski announced earlier this month in Warsaw that he planned to resign to pave the way for general elections to choose his successor. ``President Jaruzelski ... did not feel it appropriate to proceed as planned with his visit to the United States,'' the statement said. Bush looks forward to a visit from Jaruzelski at White House ``in a private capacity at some time in the future,'' the statement said. ``President Jaruzelski deserves great credit for the role he has played, together with the government of Prime Minister (Tadeusz) Mazowiecki, in working toward Poland's economic recovery and democratic consolidation,'' the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Pontiff to Get Piece of Fallen Berlin Wall
DOC.TEXT: Pope John

DOC.HEAD: Pesticides Found in Health Foods
DOC.TEXT: Health foods contain more pesticide residues than any other foods tested by the Ministry of Agriculture, the ministry said Friday. In a sampling of food avat 60 percent of nuts, beans, seeds and legumes contained traces of pesticides. About half, or 51 percent, of the dried and semi-dried fruit contained pesticide traces, it said. The health foods sampled were not organically grown and many were imported, said Ministry of Agriculture spokeswoman, Christine Jude. ``With health foods like nuts, pastas and seeds, they are mainly non-U.K. produced and in many cases they have quite a long journey,'' she said. ``They are fumigated to prevent them from rotting or becoming pest-infected.'' The lowest level of pesticide residue was found in fresh fruits and vegetables from regular grocery stores, which showed 20 percent containing traces of pesticides. The pesticide traces found in the health foods were well within maximum residue levels set by the government, Ms. Jude said. Of 4,000 food samples, 64 percent contained no detectable traces of pesticides, the ministry said.

DOC.HEAD: Security At Presidential Office Tightened After Stir Involving VP
DOC.TEXT: Police surrounded the presidential office building today after the media reported the vice president had threatened to take over as acting president ``by force'' while his boss is away. Vice President Virgilio Godoy, a leading critic of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, denied making the statement, which was carried by two morning newspapers run by the opposition Sandinistas, and on radio stations. ``These supposed statements about going into the Presidential House by force are not true. That is absurd. How am I going to enter my own house by force?'' he told The Associated Press today. ``I go to the presidential house when I think it's convenient and I am going there later today.'' Since Wednesday, Mrs. Chamorro has been in New York, where she spoke to the United Nations General Assembly. She designated no acting president when she left, a practice she has followed since taking office April 25. In effect, she usually leaves Minister of the Presidency Antonio Lacayo, her son-in-law and right-hand adviser, in charge. Lacayo, who is seen as having shoved Godoy aside, said earlier this week that Mrs. Chamorro ``is president when she's in or out of the country.'' No cars were being allowed to enter the area around the presidential offices this morning. Godoy said the police were on duty to keep Sandinista gangs from getting in, not to keep him out. He accused Sergio Ramirez, who served as vice president under former President Daniel Ortega, of misquoting comments he made to a news agency. Ramirez spoke in the National Assembly, the country's congress, Godoy said. The newspaper accounts quoted Godoy as saying he was ready to become acting president ``by force or however it happens.'' ``After the president left the country, I am who is governing. I am president by law,'' newspapers quoted him as saying. Godoy, who does not have an office in the presidential office building, works from his party headquarters because of differences with Lacayo that date back to the campaign. He and a large sector of the National Opposition Union coalition that supported Mrs. Chamorro in her presidential bid have strongly criticized her for ``cogoverning with the Sandinistas.'' They also quoted him as saying he would not respect ``any agreement'' resulting from talks that began this week between Ortega and Lacayo to avoid another strike. Ortega, the leader of the leftist Sandinistas, turned the presidency over to Mrs. Chamorro after losing Feb. 25 elections. U.S. Ambassador Harry Shlaudemann and U.N. officials joined the talks Thursday night, although no details about their participation were available. Sandinista-led strikes in May and July brought Nicaragua to a virtual standstill. The Sandinistas have refused to take part in a national dialogue aimed at reaching a broad consensus on economic reforms. Instead, they have led a series of strikes aimed at stopping Mrs. Chamorro from returning Nicaragua to a free-market economy.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Agency Studies Tactics to Counter Potential Oil Shortage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with final communique, no call for use of emergency reserves. Adds byline
DOC.TEXT: The United States and 20 other industrialized nations laid plans today to try to protect the West from a potential oil supply crisis but said there was no immediate need to tap strategic reserves to offset the loss of oil from Iraq and Kuwait. The International Energy Agency said that eight weeks after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, oil markets remain adequately supplied and no product shortages have materialized in member countries. After a closed-door meeting, governing board members of the agency urged in a communique that member countries intensify energy conservation and efficiency measures. They also urged governments to allow the full increase in oil prices to pass through to the market, and suggested ``flexibility'' in the area of environmental regulations. The communique called on all member countries to take ``all decisions necessary'' in order to be able to act immediately and effectively if need be. If a significant shortfall of oil supplies develops, the board will convene an emergency session, it said. The governing board will reconvene sometime during October regardless of whether an emergency becomes necessary. Oil companies were advised to continue drawing on commercial stocks and to use discretion in purchases to minimize volatility in the world oil market. Echoing the conclusion of the board's Aug. 31 meeting, the communique said recent oil price rises were driven by ``extreme political uncertainty,'' not by actual shortages. In New York today, oil prices were narrowly lower in quiet early trading today after briefly topping the $40-a-barrel mark on Thursday. The November contract for light, sweet crude was off 29 cents at $39.25 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange by mid-morning. The agency's members include Japan, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, most Western European countries and the United States, which this week decided to tap its strategic petroleum reserves for this first time in response to the Gulf crisis. Most official Western oil stocks are held by the United States, Japan and West Germany. But the energy agency made no call for the Germans and Japanese to emulate the United States. President Bush on Wednesday ordered the sale of 5 million barrels of oil from the U.S. strategic reserve, which contains 590 million barrels of oil. Bush administration officials said the move was a test to see if the system could work in an emergency. Some U.S. officials have advocated similar action from West Germany, with 197 million barrels of reserves, and Japan, with 215 million barrels. Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the former Saudi Arabian oil minister, and onetime chief OPEC strategist, said high oil prices were due to the failure of leading oil companies and Western countries to use reserves. ``If oil companies were will to de-stock and draw from their inventories, we could reduce the price of oil,'' the British newspaper Financial Times quoted him as saying. He said the tapping of strategic reserves by governments would be ineffective unless oil companies cut stocks.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors About to Remove `Brain Dead' Man's Organs Discover He's Alive
DOC.TEXT: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. (AP) - Doctors about to remove the organs of a man they thought had been killed in a traffic accident knew something was wrong when his foot twitched. Curt Coleman Clark wasn't really dead. Clark, 22, was pronounced brain dead Wednesday after he suffered severe head injuries in a car crash near Granite Falls in central North Carolina. After his family agreed to donate his organs, he was placed on a respirator and taken by ambulance from Frye Regional Medical Center in Hickory to Baptist Hospital in Winston-Salem, about 150 miles away. Doctors there noticed the man's foot move, said D. Jesse H. Meredith, a transplant surgeon at the hospital. Hospital spokesman Roger F. Rollman said Clark was then taken to the intensive-care unit where more signs of life were detected. He was in critical condition Friday, said nursing supervisor Dale Spaugh. Highway Patrol officials said Clark was hurt when he lost control of his car on a curve and it flipped several times. Radiologists who examined him after he arrived at Frye concluded he was brain dead, said Dennis Phillips, the hospital's executive director. He added that a review turned up no errors in judgment on the part of the doctors. ``I think we have followed the procedure down the line,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Ambassador Says Former Interior Minister Ordered His Killing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with no comment from Arce Gomez attorney. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `The group...'
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Ambassador to Bolivia said today a jailed former interior minister had ordered his assassination in revenge for the envoy's role in bringing him to justice. The former minister, Luis Arce Gomez, is in jail in Miami, awaiting trial on drug-trafficking charges. Neither his attorney nor the prosecutor were immediately available for comment on the ambassador's allegation. The ambassador, Robert S. Gelbard, said he believed the former minister ordered paramilitary forces in Bolivia to kill him ``because I was instrumental, with the cooperation of the Bolivian government, in getting Luis Arce Gomez to Miami.'' According to the U.S. Embassy, the information about the assassination order was provided by high-ranking Bolivian anti-drug officials, and was being taken very seriously. The embassy said Arce Gomez called on members of the neo-Nazi paramilitary group Lovers of Death, or Novios de la Muerte, to kill the ambassador. No such attack has been made. The group was set up by Arce Gomez in 1979 to help plan and carry out the bloody July 1980 military coup that interrupted democratic rule in the country. The group was advised by Nazi war criminal Klaus Barbie, who was expelled from Bolivia in 1983 and is now serving a life sentence for war crimes in Lyon, France. Arce Gomez became the country's highest-ranking law enforcement official after the coup. But he provided protection to traffickers, the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration says, and was known as the ``minister of cocaine.'' Arce Gomez was arrested by Bolivian police and U.S. drug agents on Dec. 10, 1989 and extradited to the United States by order of President Jaime Paz Zamora.

DOC.HEAD: Toxic Gas Leak Kills 2, Injures 6 At Mississippi Plant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to CORRECT name of company to Magnatek sted Universal Magnatek; CORRECT number of injured back up to six, CORRECT number of workers to 1,400; add detail. Picks up penultimate graf.
DOC.TEXT: Toxic gases leaked at a manufacturing plant south of here this morning, killing two workers and injuring six others, authorities said. There were no reports of an explosion or fire at the Magnatek Inc., plant, which produces transformers for florescent lighting. The cause of the accident has not been determined, said plant manager Dennis Kokaisel. ``This morning between 5:30 and 6 a.m. a maintenance crew of eight men were overcome while working on an annealing furnace,'' he said. Such a furnace is used to temper steel. Kokaisel identified the dead workers as John Hosey, 52, the crew foreman, and Betram Bass, 27. He said three workers were were admitted to hospoitals for observation while three others were treated and released. Sheriff's dispatcher Diana Smith said she was alerted to the gas leak about 5:40 a.m., and authorities immediately ordered the plant evacuated. Plant officials said about 100 of the plants estimated 1,400 employees were at the plant when the accident occurred. Gary Hall of the Mississippi Emergency Management Agency said it appeared the leaking gases ncluded natural gas, liquid nitrogen and liquid hydrogen, all toxic. Kokaisel said he could not confirm what gases were involved but that the three types mentioned by Hall were used at the facility. The body of one of the victims was recovered from the building shortly after authorities vented the gas from the building. The other victim died at a hospital. Dusty Perkins, another spokesman for the emergency management agency, said a hazardous materials team was at the plant and planned to suit up in protective clothing to investigate the furnace area and determine what gases were involved. Hamp Gaston, headmater at Simpson County Academy about 200 yards from the plant, said the 421-student school would be closed for the day as a precautionary measure. It was empty at the time of the accident. Mendenhall is a town of 2,500 about 35 miles south of Jackson. The plant is in a rural area outside of town; no one in the surrounding area had to be evacuated, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Choice Concert Canceled After VA Prohibits Use of Its Theater
DOC.TEXT: A benefit concert for abortion rights candidates featuring Bonnie Raitt, Robin Williams and others was abruptly canceled after the Veterans Administration said its theater could not be used. The Oct. 4 show, which also was to include singers Rickie Lee Jones and Melissa Etheridge, was called off by organizers this week. ``When I found out about this, I was completely shocked. I had to sit down and collect myself,'' Margery Tabankin, executive director of the Hollywood Women's Committee, said Thursday. The group, a political action committee that works on mostly liberal issues, hoped to raise $200,000 from the invitation-only concert. Tabankin said the committee got permission in July to use the VA's Wadsworth Theater from the University of California, Los Angeles, which sublets it. She said UCLA allowed the concert because it was to be a private fund-raiser, not a publicly advertised concert. The tickets were sold to people on a committee mailing list. But VA spokesman Joe Barison said federal guidelines prohibit partisan political events, public or private, on VA property. ``They (UCLA officials) made the commitment. They shouldn't have, and they acknowledged it,'' Barison said. ``It's just an honest error anyone could have made.'' UCLA officials said they were unaware of the concert's purpose until this week. But Tabankin said the committee clearly outlined the nature of the event. ``We even told them the entire hallway would be filled with campaign posters,'' she said. ``Our name is the Hollywood Women's Political Committee. What did they think we are, a canasta club?'' The committee had already spent $37,000 on the show, but it hopes to recoup losses and even make money because many donors were declining to take refunds. Ticket prices ranged from $100 to $1,000.

DOC.HEAD: House Passes NASA Bill with Money for Moon, Mars Trips
DOC.TEXT: The House passed Friday a $44 billion, three-year spending authorization bill for NASA that includes President Bush's proposal to place a settlement on the Moon and begin work on a manned expedition to Mars. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration bill includes no money for the Moon and Mars program in the next fiscal year but would spend $444 million to begin it in fiscal 1992 and $649 million in fiscal 1993. The bill won approval on a voice vote after a brief debate. It goes to a conference committee to work out differences with the Senate. The bill provides a three-year spending authorization to enable NASA to make longer-range plans including space shuttle missions, space exploration and development of expendable launch vehicles and an experimental high-speed aerospace plane. The House passed a multi-year authorization last year, but the Senate never took action. President Bush proposed last year that NASA establish a permanent settlement on the Moon and begin a 30-year project to send a manned expedition to Mars by the year 2019. The bill authorizes the Bush administration's request for the project's start. The bill authorizes total NASA spending of $14 billion in fiscal 1990, $14.4 billion in fiscal 1992 and $16.1 billion in fiscal 1993. But if added to previous bills, NASA authorized spending would be almost $17 billion in fiscal 1991 - nearly $2 billion more than Bush has requested and $4.6 billion more than spent in the current fiscal year. Separate appropriation bills may provide less than the authorized amount.

DOC.HEAD: Mortgage Rates Rise
DOC.TEXT: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 10.22 percent this week, up from 10.16 percent last week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. It was the highest rate since fixed-rate mortgages averaged 10.24 on Aug. 31. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.28 percent, down from 8.30 percent last week. The rates do not include add-on fees known as points.

DOC.HEAD: Retransmits a0572 to fix slugline
Chicago to Name Street After Sammy Davis Jr.
DOC.TEXT: Sammy Davis Jr. will be honored with a street named after him in this city where he performed on the club and theater circuit for more than 40 years. City officials plan to rename 31st Street after Davis in ceremonies on Thursday. For years the South Side street was home to large numbers of jazz and blues artists. ``Legendary artists of the '30s, '40s and '50s were showcased in clubs and theaters and even private homes that lined 31st Street, which was once the hub of jazz and blues,'' said Mayor Richard M. Daley. ``Thus it's only fitting that this street is chosen to honor one of the greatest performers in show business, the late Sammy Davis Jr.'' Davis, who recently died of cancer, first performed in Chicago in the early 1940s as part of the Will Mastin Trio that included his uncle and father. His last performance in the Windy City was in March 1988 when he appeared at the Chicago Theater with Frank Sinatra and Dean Martin.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis, Possible Loss of U.S. Bases Pose Philippine Challenge
DOC.TEXT: An immediate loss of U.S. bases in the Philippines would cause tremendous economic harm in a country that now needs an additional $1 billion to $2 billion as a result of the Persian Gulf crisis, a top Philippine official said Friday. Financial Secretary Jesus Estanislao said President Corazon Aquino has told him to get involved in talks over the future of Clark Air Base, Subic Bay Naval Base and four smaller facilities. The meetings are expected to resume next month in Manila. U.S. negotiators have indicated a phaseout or sharp reduction of the U.S. presence is possible, and Philippine Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus has said the country wants an immediate U.S. pullout from Clark Air Base when the current lease expires nxt September. ``The short-term misbenefit to Filipinos for an immediate cutoff would be tremendous,'' Estanislao said in answer to a question at a news conference. Estanislao said the talks are covering a wide range of U.S-Philippine issues, including the possibility of debt reduction in place of some direct payment if U.S. use of the facilities is continued. He said assessments have been made of the impact of a loss of the bases, but he declined to give figures. He said the figures were not very precise but the country has contingency plans for the bases. ``Internationalism has advantages and isolation has its costs,'' Estanislao said. Members of the U.S. Congress familiar with the negotiations have said they expect the United States to seek agreement to rent some key facilities if a phaseout is necessary. Estanislao said it is important that the talks conclude successfully because it would be a ``very bad signal to investors'' if they end with acrimony between the two sides. The financial secretary said increasing oil prices have not yet been fully felt in Manila because the country is still running on oil purchased prior to Iraq's Aug. 2 takeover of Kuwait. But he said the need for additional funds because of the crisis is expected to be between $1 billion and $2 billion, depending on the price of oil. ``The challenges for us seem to get bigger by the day, no thanks to Saddam Hussein,'' he said, referring to the leader of Iraq. The country also has suffered a major earthquake, drought and massive flooding in recent weeks. The Philippines also is hit by the loss of foreign exchange from thousands of Filipino workers in Iraq and Kuwait and the need to give them jobs when they return. Estanislao said major economic goals for the country include giving more assistance to small and medium-sized businesses rather than larger ``privilege-seeking industries'' and narrowing the gap between the 6-8 percent interest paid to savers and the 22-30 percent charged to borrowers in by Philippine banks. Before the Gulf crisis and recent calamities, the economy was growing at an annual rate of 6 percent and inflations was below 10 percent a year, Estanislao said. He said the country is getting from $2.5 billion to $3 billion under a multilateral assistance program for 1990 and expects an increase in 1991. But officials said the money needed as a result of the Gulf crisis is in addition to those funds which are for economic development.

DOC.HEAD: Cuba to Build 500,000 Bicycles to Help Curb Fuel Shortage
DOC.TEXT: Cuba will build 500,000 bicycles to help curb effects of a fuel shortage caused by a cutback in oil imports from the Soviet Union, the official Cuban news agency Prensa Latina said Friday. The dispatch, monitored in Mexico City, said the first units would go on the market next year. The agency quoted the newspaper Rebel Youth as saying Cuba would build five factories to make the parts for the bicycles. Cuba adopted energy-saving plans a month ago because of cutbacks in oil from the Soviets, long a major Cuban supplier. Measures included a 50 percent cutback in fuel reserved for state-owned cars and a 30 percent cutback for private vehicles. The agency said Cuba also might buy bicycles from China.

DOC.HEAD: Disaster Declaration Asked Two Weeks After Toxic Blast
DOC.TEXT: The president of Soviet Kazakhstan asked the Kremlin on Friday to declare an ecological disaster in part of his republic following a Sept. 12 explosion at a nuclear fuel factory released a cloud of toxic gas, Tass reported. The blast and fire at the Ulbinsky metallurgical plant in a workshop using beryllium spewed the toxic gas that affected ``a considerable part of the population of Ust-Kamenogorsk,'' a city in eastern Kazakhstan near the border with China and Mongolia, the official news agency said. ``The public of Kazhakstan and population of the city demand urgent measures to improve the situation and they demand compensation for damage to their health,'' said a telegram sent by Nursultan Nazarbayev, president of the republic, to Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov. Nazarbayev also asked that a group of Soviet experts be sent to Ust-Kamenogorsk to decide on the continued operation of the plant, and he requested an investigation by independent, international ecological experts, Tass reported. He was quoted as saying in the telegram that local authorities had already declared the region an ecological disaster zone. Several people were injured in the blast. There was no report of any radiation release. The plant is one of the largest producers of fuel for nuclear power plants in the Soviet Union and is situated in a densely populated part of Ust-Kamenogorsk, Tass said. After the explosion and fire, the toxic gas filled the streets and dissipated slowly because of calm wind conditions. Preliminary tests showed twice the permitted levels of beryllium in air and water samples. Beryllium is a very light metal that can catch fire easily and burn like a magnesium flash, vaporizing and releasing a deadly smoke of beryllium oxide. Ust-Kamenogorsk, a city of about 20,000 people, is located in the Altai mountains about 100 miles east of Semipalatinsk, where the Soviet Union conducts its nuclear weapons tests. Residents have campaigned against the nuclear tests, and there have not been any for months. Izvestia reported shortly after the blast that officials involved in the accident were hiding documents to avoid blame.

DOC.HEAD: Royal Shakespeare Company Flops With Glasnost
DOC.TEXT: The Royal Shakespeare Company, whose plays about the lives, deaths and treacheries of English monarchs have intrigued millions, has turned to Gorbachev and glasnost, and it looks like a flop. ``Moscow Gold,'' which opened in London this week with actor David Calder, a lookalike of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in the lead role, was mostly panned by the critics. The company's productions of Shakespeare history plays like ``Richard II'' are still performed to packed houses, but it is on shakier ground with one of the biggest real-life dramas of the twentieth century. ``The whole thing is best forgotten, as I'm sure it will be,'' Jack Tinker in The Daily Mail wrote of the play, co-written by Britons Howard Brenton and Pakistan-born Tariq Ali. ``Moscow Gold'' opened Wednesday at the company's Barbican Theater, where it runs in repertory through Nov. 5. Initial performances have played to about 60 percent attendance in the 1,162-seat auditorium. It's the authors' second collaboration. Last year's ``Iranian Nights,'' was a response to the death threat against Salman Rushdie, the Indian-born British writer, for his novel ``The Satanic Verses.'' ``We started thinking what else we could collaborate on,'' Ali, 47, said in an interview before the press night. ``One of us said it would be great to put glasnost and Gorbachev on stage, and we looked at each other and screamed with laughter, thinking it was too ambitious an idea.'' Ali said of ``Moscow Gold'' that ``all the world is in there: humor, farce, tragedy ... and very, very serious dialogue.'' The critics largely disagreed. Benedict Nightingale in The Times of London called the episodic three-hour drama ``a pretty flaccid history lesson,'' and faulted its ``lumpish dialogue.'' Milton Shulman in The Evening Standard said the play would draw audiences who want ``instant history served up as sketchy cartoons or dramatized captions.'' But he admired actor Calder as an ``impressive ... Gorbachev clone.'' Of the initial reviews, only The Financial Times's Malcolm Rutherford was enthusiastic. He called the play ``a huge success ... a most unusual triumph,'' praising Calder as ``the very image of Gorbachev.'' Directed by Barry Kyle on Stefanos Laziridis's busy, constructivist sets, ``Moscow Gold'' features a cast of 33 playing 57 characters. Sara Kestelman co-stars as Raisa Gorbachev, who is seen in yellow pajamas and a fur coat singing a ditty about her life as ``a simple Soviet girl.'' Later, the couple lie in bed discussing the movie ``Ghostbusters'' and the prospect of a film of their lives, with Robert Redford and Meryl Streep. Alongside the facetiousness is a somewhat didactic history lesson about the threats to socialism throughout this century. Company veterans Clive Merrison, Russell Dixon, and Clifford Rose play such figures as Vladimir Ilyich Lenin, architect of the Russian Revolution; Boris Yeltsin, the maverick politician and former Soviet leader Yuri Andropov. Other characters include a chorus of Kremlin cleaning ladies; Chernobyl Man, a survivor of the 1986 nuclear disaster, and White House astrologer Rona Anderson, played in drag by American Craig Pinder. Calder, 44, said his resemblance to Gorbachev was ``just a lucky coincidence.'' ``This isn't a sort of mechanical imitation,'' he said. ``We're striving to get the theatricality and the content of Gorbachev's life, not a sort of correct portrayal of it.'' To date, the Gorbachevs have not responded to invitations to attend the production. Ali said Raisa was ``a great fan of the Royal Shakespeare Company, in any event.''

DOC.HEAD: Milwaukee County Board Approves `Cashless' Welfare Plan
DOC.TEXT: A voucher system to ensure that welfare payments are used for housing and other necessities won overwhelming approval by county supervisors. The Milwaukee County program would require direct payment of housing and utility bills through vouchers, electronic fund transfers, or third parties for recipients of Aid to Families with Dependent Children. The Board of Supervisors voted 22-2 Thursday to seek state and federal approval required for the plan to take effect. An amendment also approved Thursday calls for providing recipients with an unspecified small amount of discretionary cash. ``What we're concerned about in Milwaukee is that the money is used for what it's intended, which is shelter, gas and electricity,'' said Supervisor Robert L. Jackson Jr. Supervisor Elizabeth Coggs-Jones voted against the proposal. ``I haven't supported cashless welfare vouchers because I believe it's punitive,'' she said. ``Everyone on AFDC is not mismanaging AFDC money.'' The board heard evidence that mismanagement of welfare funds has clogged Milwaukee courts. County Circuit Court Judge Lee Wells said in a letter to the board that 85 percent of the eviction cases he hears involve tenants receiving welfare. The proposal's sponsor, Supervisor Richard D. Nyklewicz Jr., said he wasn't surprised the amendment passed by such a wide margin. ``The Board has traditionally been on record trying to improve the accountability to the program,'' he said. The federal government already permits the use of welfare benefit vouchers to directly pay vendors like landlords and utility companies in cases of demonstrated mismanagement by a recipient. But Nyklewicz said his proposal would require vouchers in all welfare cases to ensure welfare benefits are spent only on housing and essentials. ``The advantage of a voucher system to pay landlords directly for rent is that there should be a dramatic reduction in the number of eviction cases to be heard every day,'' Wells wrote. ``It would also ensure a stable home environment for the children of parents who are receiving AFDC payments.'' Milwaukee County currently distributes $6.4 million per month in food stamps and $16.6 million in AFDC benefits, according the Department of Social Services. Gov. Tommy G. Thompson, who has initiated two welfare experiments, has said he would support the Milwaukee County plan. Thompson urged approval in 1987 of Wisconsin's Learnfare program, which allows the state to cut a welfare family's monthly benefits if a school reports a teen-age student has been consistently absent without excuse. The Thompson administration also has experimented with a program called Workfare, which requires welfare recipients to participate in job training or work part-time to keep their benefits.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Dismisses $1 Billion Lawsuit by Nuke Plant Neighbors
DOC.TEXT: A judge dismissed a $1 billion lawsuit by neighbors of the defunct Rancho Seco nuclear plant, declaring their radiation exposure was no more dangerous than drinking four diet sodas in a lifetime. The class action suit, filed in October 1985, alleged that the residents were exposed to dangerous levels of radiation through the deliberate discharge of contaminated water into a stream. But on Thursday, four days before the case was to go to trial, Sacramento County Superior Court Judge Anthony DeCristoforo Jr. threw it out. He said the 208 plaintiffs were exposed to less than one millirem of radiation a year. That is the same amount absorbed in the body by drinking four diet sodas in a lifetime or smoking less than one cigarette in a lifetime, he said. ``This is unbelievable. ...They've dragged us through the dirt,'' said plaintiff Lynn Davis. Morton Friedman, the residents' lawyer, said he would appeal the decision. Sacramento Municipal Utility District officials had maintained that the level of exposure to residents living within 10 miles of Rancho Seco was well below the 25 millirem limit set by the federal government. The nuclear plant 30 miles southeast of Sacramento, which opened in 1975, was closed by a June 1989 ballot measure after a series of management and operating difficulties.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Appeals Court Upholds At-Large Elections For Judges In Texas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to add quotes from dissent, recast. Picks up 8th graf pvs, `Should Congress...'.
DOC.TEXT: The Texas system of electing district judges at large was upheld today by the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, which ruled that judicial elections do not fall under the Voting Rights Act. The ruling rejected arguments by minorities who said that such at-large voting denies them an equal chance to elect candidates they want by in effect diluting their votes among a large population of voters. The ruling applied specifically to nine urban counties in Texas, but was eagerly awaited because of possible broader application. In Louisiana, a similar challenge to judicial districting is pending, with a court hearing scheduled this afternoon. A challenge is also pending in Georgia, which is in a different circuit of the appeals court. A three-judge panel of the appeals court had upheld the at-large voting system in a 2-1 ruling in May, but brought the case back before the entire 15-member court for reconsideration. The majority opinion, written by Thomas Gibbs Gee of Houston, said the judge are not representatives of the people. ``These offices are not `representative' ones, and their occupants are not representatives,'' he said. ``Indeed, the state processes for filling them need not even be elective, as those for all representative offices presumably must be.'' Sam D. Johnson of Austin, in a scathing dissent, called the decision ``a burning scar on the flesh of the Voting Rights Act; the majority opinion is not simply wrong, it is dangerous.'' ``No previous court has ever even suggested that judicial elections might be exempt from the reach of Section 2 of the the Voting Rights Act,'' he wrote. In the majority opinion, Gee wrote that in 1982 Congress passed a law to test for dilution of voting strength, but stopped short of imposing such a test for judicial offices. ``Should Congress seek to install such a test for judicial elections, it must say so plainly,'' the court said. ``Instead, it has thus far plainly said the contrary.'' The case was brought to court by the League of United Latin American Citizens and other miniority groups, who said at-large voting for state judges prevents them from electing minority candidates. U.S. District Judge Lucius Bunton of Midland agreed, ruling that the system violated the Voting Rights Act. He ordered the state to divide the nine counties into electoral subdistricts. Those counties - Dallas, Harris, Bexar, Tarrant, Travis, Lubbock, Midland, Ector and Jefferson - elect 172 of Texas' 390 district judges, who rule on matters of state law and preside over trials. The three-judge panel of the appeals court reversed Bunton's decision, saying that Congress did not mean for judicial elections to fall under the Voting Rights Act. In the Louisiana district judge case, U.S. District Judge John Parker ordered that 11 districts be redesigned to enhance the chance of electing black judges. Only six of Louisiana's 254 district and appellate court judges are black. Also at issue in Louisiana is a state Supreme Court district in New Orleans, the only district in the state represented by two justices elected at large.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Deplores Sudanese Bombing, Says Relief Efforts Threatened
DOC.TEXT: The State Department said Friday the Sudanese government is threatening an international relief effort by bombing towns in rebel-held areas where assistance programs are in operation. U.S. Ambassador James Cheek has raised the issue with Sudanese President Omar el-Bashir but has received no assurance that the bombing will stop, said deputy spokesman Richard Boucher. ``These bombings are a threat to the relief effort in Sudan,'' he said. ``Relief workers cannot operate if their lives are in jeopardy from military action,'' Boucher said. ``It is bitterly ironic that these bombings come at a time when Sudan is undergoing a drought which will make a massive relief effort necessary next year.'' The combination of drought and civil war eventually is expected to put millions of lives at risk in Sudan, according to independent estimates. A Sept. 20 attack on the town of Bor, Boucher said, occurred while U.N. and international Red Cross relief planes were on the ground in that town. No relief workers have been injured but the bombings have caused civilian casualties. Boucher deplored the bombings and called on the Sudanese government to reach agreement on a cease-fire. The war involves forces loyal to the Moslem-dominated national government against non-Moslem rebels based in the south.

DOC.HEAD: Last Spanish Diplomat Leaves As Iraq Tightens Embassies Blockade
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Five weeks after Iraq's deadline for embassies in occupied Kuwait to shut down, diplomats were still holding out in 15 missions Friday despite meager supplies and cordons of Iraqi troops outside. Spain and South Korea were the latest nations to close their missions because of unbearable living conditions. A Spanish Foreign Ministry spokesman in Madrid said Charge d'Affaires Juan Jose Buitrago left Kuwait on Thursday and was in Baghdad. The South Korean Foreign Ministry announced in Seoul that it had temporarily closed its embassy due to ``the deteriorated situation'' there. It said Ambassador Soh Byung-yong and the few remaining staff arrived in Jordan on Thursday. Most embassies have been under siege since Aug. 24, the Iraqi deadline for foreign missions to close and move to Baghdad. Most that remain open are those of Western countries, and their water and electricity have been cut. Iraq issued the deadline as a way to tighten control over Kuwait following the Iraqi invasion on Aug. 2. Iraq later said it had annexed the occupied land and that embassies that refused to close would lose their diplomatic immunity. Iraq made good on the threat two weeks ago, when its troops forced their way into the diplomatic compounds of Canada, Belgium, France and the Netherlands, briefly detaining five Western consuls. Western capitals retaliated by expelling Iraqi military attaches and envoys, and Iraq responded in kind. Still, none of the four embassies that reported harassment by the Iraqi troops in Kuwait has closed. Italian Foreign Ministry spokesman Alessandro Franco said in Rome that the Iraqis had imposed a total blockade on the Italian embassy as of Wednesday. He said that until then, a clerk had been allowed to take in water, bread, fresh fruit and other supplies every day for the ambassador, Marco Colombo, and the second secretary. Franco said there were no plans for the two diplomats to leave, however. The British Foreign Office said this week that two of the four diplomats still in the British Embassy will be withdrawn to conserve dwindling food supplies. A spokesman in London said British Ambassador Michael Weston and consul Larry Banks will remain. Iraqi troops had forced the diplomats to remain indoors for more than a month, and the swimming pool was being used for washing, he said on condition of anonymity. ``We are determined to keep the embassy open for as long as possible, in the hope this will offer some tangible assurance to the British community that remains,'' he said. ``The government wants to make clear that it does not recognize the annexation of Kuwait by Iraq.'' Some of the Britons, like other Westerners who have been banned from traveling, are being held as human shields at potential military targets. Many other Westerners still are hiding in Kuwait. U.S. Ambassador Nathaniel Howell and a handful of aides remain in the U.S. mission. They have boiled swimming pool water to drink and burned furniture for cooking fuel. The Belgian Foreign Ministry said Friday the situation is ``not physically worse but increasingly more difficult psychologically,'' for its ambassador, his deputy and five other non-diplomatic Belgians in the embassy. The embassies that are still occupied are Bahrain, Belgium, Britain, Canada, France, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, United Arab Emirates, the United States and West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Hiring Freeze in Maryland Causing Cadavers to Stack Up
DOC.TEXT: A month-old hiring freeze by the state has resulted in cadavers stacking up at the state Anatomy Board. Ronald S. Wade, the board administrator of the board, is running the show single-handedly after his embalmer had a heart attack and his secretary quit. Wade, who once had three embalmers working for him, told his board at an emergency meeting Thursday that processing nearly 800 bodies a year for use by doctors and teaching hospitals cannot be done by one person. ``I personally could not continue in that situation,'' he said. And as bodies continue to arrive at a rate of 65 a month, ``we quickly may have a public health problem.''
