If storage space fills to capacity, ``As a cadaver comes in the door, it will simply be sent to the crematorium,'' said board chairman Michael N. Sheridan. But help may be on the way. Sheridan said the state Department of Health and Mental Hygiene has agreed to seek an exemption from the hiring freeze so a secretary and an embalmer can be hired. The board's predicament ``is a very real problem,'' said Deputy Health Secretary Nelson J. Sabatini. ``I told them we would move the request for exemption through very quickly, and support it. I'm confident they will get relief.'' The hiring freeze was imposed by Gov. William Donald Schaefer to cope with a budget deficit that could reach $270 million. The Anatomy Board's members represent the medical schools, private doctors and hospitals that rely on the agency to provide cadavers, organs and tissues for training and education. The board received 743 bodies last year, up from perhaps 150 when Wade first took over the agency 17 years ago. About 250 of the bodies are embalmed for use in anatomy classes by medical and dental students. Many of the others are the sources of bones, eyes and other tissues used in transplants and other medical procedures.

DOC.HEAD: Father: Turtles' Show Not Bad; Sons: Best Concert Of All Time
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs separates planned.
DOC.TEXT: The only way to review the live rock 'n' roll show of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles seemed to be with a pair of Turtle authorities in tow: Matt Raeburn, 9, and Alex Raeburn, 6. Their father had to admit that the opening night performance of the ``Coming Out of Their Shells Tour'' was far better than he had expected. It was imaginative, well produced, technically sophisticated and surprisingly entertaining. It could serve as a model for what a kids' first rock concert ought to be. The Turtle authorities can speak for themselves. ``It was the best concert of all time,'' said Matt. Alex, so dazzled that he couldn't speak until the next morning, pronounced his first concert ``the best thing I've seen yet.'' The show begins before the curtain goes up. April O'Neill, the TV reporter who has befriended the Turtles, appears in the audience broadcasting a live, on-the-scene report of concert preparations. The report appears on large video screens on either side of the stage. Throughout the show, a camera follows her around the theater and her reports punctuate the music as a story line unfolds. The Turtles - Michelangelo, Raphael, Leonardo and Donatello - make their grand entrance from beneath four manhole covers in a burst of fireworks, and open the show with ``Pizza Power,'' a paean to their favorite food. ``It has good guitar, a great melody, and makes me hungry,'' said Matt. The next character to appear is Splinter, the Turtles' ninja master, a human-sized mutant rat who dispenses his philosophy in epigrammatic phrases reminiscent of Yoda in Star Wars. He sings ``Skipping Stones.'' ``It's not about stones. It's about the ways of life,'' said Matt. It is the Turtles' ``most relaxing song, quiet and peaceful and good to move to,'' he said. Roving cameramen follow the Turtles on-stage, transmitting MTV-like concert footage directly to the video screens beside the stage in Radio City Music Hall, where the Turtles will perform until Oct. 7 before beginning a 40-city national tour. No appearance of the Turtles would be complete without an interruption by the evil Shredder, and his foot clan, a troop of ninja robots. Shredder captures April O'Neill, disrupts the Turtles' show, and otherwise attempts to finally rid the world of the Turtles. Does he succeed? ``You'll have to see it to find out what happens,'' said Matt. Based on the comments of the Turtle authorities quoted here, the show captures whatever it is that fascinates kids about the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. As Matt put it, ``They're really funny guys just trying to save the world.''

DOC.HEAD: Economic Indicators Show `Nothing but Dark Clouds' Ahead
DOC.TEXT: The government's main economic forecasting gauge plunged 1.2 percent in August, its steepest fall in three years and an indication, one economist said, of ``nothing but dark clouds'' ahead. Seven of the 11 components of the Commerce Department's Index of Leading Indicators were off, including stock prices and an index measuring consumer confidence. Orders for new plants and equipment dropped. Unfilled orders to U.S. manufacturers fell, as did building permits and the money supply. Weekly unemployment claims were up. The report was the first government look into the economic future since Iraqi occupied Kuwait Aug. 2. The only positive contributors were slower business delivery times, an increase in orders for consumer goods, an increase in the price of raw materials and a longer workweek. But economist Kermit Baker of Cahners Economics in Newton, Mass., said even the longer workweek might be misleading. ``Perhaps it's an indication that industry is trying to get by with its current workforce rather than hire new people,'' he said. Other economists were similarly gloomy. ``The decline in the leading indicators provides further proof that the recession began in August,'' said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers. ``If we're not in a recession, we're skating close to it,'' said John Silvia, a financial economist with Kemper Financial Services Inc. in Chicago. Baker was even more blunt. ``There's nothing but dark clouds,'' he said, noting that preliminary economic indicators released this month ``indicate that the August number was not a one-month phenomenon ... the picture I'm getting is that this is a long-term trend.'' The drop in the index, designed to forecast activity six to nine months ahead, was the sharpest since a 1.4 percent decline in the month after the Oct. 19, 1987, stock market crash, when the Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks plummeted 508 points in one day. Many economists believe Wall Street has now turned bearish again and is in for a prolonged period of falling prices. ``Since the stock market is a forward-looking indicator, the precipitous decline in stock prices is more tied to expectations of recession than to the deterioration in corporate earnings witnessed so far,'' Jasinowski said. Silvia said surveys after the '87 crash showed consumer confidence fell sharply but soon bounced back. Consumer confidence surveys following the Iraqi invasion also plummeted, he noted, without signs of improvement. Lawrence A. Hunter, deputy chief economist with the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, said that ``only consumer spending increases will keep the real GNP (gross national product) from falling in the current quarter. But, beginning in the fourth quarter, the real GNP will fall.'' The general definition of a recession is two consecutive declines in the GNP - the nation's total output of goods and services. If a recession could be avoided through November, the economic expansion will have reached its eighth anniversary. It already is the nation's longest in peacetime. The various August changes in the index left it at 144.2 percent of its 1982 base of 100 and down 0.4 percent over a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Meets with Kuwait's Exiled Ruler
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top 5 grafs new with departure statements; picks up 3rd graf pvs, The president.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush promised the exiled leader of Kuwait today that his country will not remain under Iraqi control. ``Kuwait's sovereignty and territorial integrity will be restored,'' Bush vowed in a departure statement as Sheik Jabir al-Ahmed al-Sabah, the emir of Kuwait, left the White House after a meeting with Bush. Bush said that in their talks he had told the emir, ``that America's resolve to end this aggression remains ... firm and undiminished.'' He also praised the Kuwaiti underground resistance movement that is fighting the Iraqi invaders dispatched by President Saddam Hussein. ``Your principled, courageous and decisive position in the face of the Iraqi aggression of Kuwait is a true expression of the unabated faith and commitment of the American people to the humanitarian morals on which and for which the United States of America was founded,'' the emir told Bush. Earlier, Bush complimented the emir on his speech Thursday before the United Nations General Assembly, calling it ``a marvelous thing.'' The president said he could not recall anyone getting a standing ovation, as the emir did, when Bush was United Nation ambassador from 1971 to 1973. ``I thought it showed that the world was strongly supporting what we all are trying to do,'' Bush told the emir in a photo session at the start of their meeting. The United Nations has passed eight resolutions opposing the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Following their Oval Office meeting, Bush and the emir were having lunch together. Their top aides were meeting in a Cabinet room. The White House meeting was intended as a clear sign that the United States still regards the 64-year-old emir as the legitimate ruler of Kuwait. The president has consistently insisted that not only must Iraq withdraw his invasion troops from Kuwait but that the emir must be restored to the power he has wielded since 1977. ``Those objectives are unchanged,'' Bush told a fund-raising dinner in Detroit for Rep. Bill Schuette, a Republican senatorial candidate. The emir's Oval Office visit is ``a chance for the president to talk with him about how it's going, his latest reports from inside Kuwait,'' said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. During Bush's two-day political swing through four states, he helped raise about $4 million for Republican gubernatorial and Senate candidates and drummed up public support for his Persian Gulf policies. The emir traveled to Washington following a speech Thursday to the United Nations, where he thanked the international community for its stance against Iraq's President Saddam Hussein. Al-Sabah was warmly greeted by the multinational body. Officials pointedly referred to him as leader of the ``state of Kuwait'' in defiance of Iraq's annexation of the oil-rich nation. The emir told the U.N. General Assembly that his country was suffering a crisis that is ``a manifold tragedy whose dire consequences affect not only Kuwaitis, but other peoples as well.'' ``In fact, it has jeopardized stability in the world, especially in the gulf region,'' he said, adding his country now was ruled by ``rape, destruction, terror.'' Al-Sabah got a standing ovation from the General Assembly, but the three-member Iraqi delegation walked out as he began speaking. The emir voiced hope that ``the withdrawal of the invaders is, God willing, undoubtedly imminent.'' Saddam, who sparked an international crisis by sending his troops into Kuwait on Aug. 2, claims Kuwait is an Iraqi province. The two nations have been engaged in a border dispute for a long time. The United Nations has decried the invasion in a series of resolutions that include setting up an international blockade to squeeze Saddam economically by preventing trade. The emir fled Dasman Palace in Kuwait during the invasion, escaping by car just moments before Iraqi troops arrived. His young brother was killed defending the palace. The emir, leader of a huge clan that filled government posts with about 1,000 princes, now maintains headquarters in exile in Saudi Arabia. As Kuwait's leader, al-Sabah walked a precarious line between progressive forces at home who wanted democracy and forces next door in Saudi Arabia who feared democracy might spread and endanger their conservative, theocratic rule. His regime was considered less rigid than Saudi Arabia's. He allowed a lively - if censored - media, and women in Kuwait were allowed to drive and vote. His family engendered loyalty by sharing Kuwait's vast wealth with their countrymen. Pro-democracy demonstrations before the Iraqi invasion called for more power-sharing rather than the emir's ouster. Some members of Congress have criticized the U.S. stance toward the autocratic government, but Secretary of State James A. Baker III said now is not the time to press for structural changes.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Carrie Fisher says people think ``Postcards from the Edge'' is about her relationship with her mother, Debbie Reynolds, because they can't believe she has an imagination for language. ``Now everyone thinks that my mother and I fight on the stairs,'' Fisher told Entertainment Weekly in this week's issue. ``I feel bad that people think that my mother is so self-obsessed that `how are you' never crosses her lips. ``She's not like that,'' said the daughter of Reynolds and crooner Eddie Fisher. Fisher, who played Princess Leia in ``Star Wars,'' wrote the best-selling novel - now a hit movie - in five months after a stay at a drug center in 1985. It's about an actress re-entering the Hollywood scene after drug rehabilitation and her glamorous movie-star mother. ``I wrote about a mother-actress and a daughter-actress,'' she said. ``I'm not shocked that people think it's about me and my mother. It's easier for them to think I have no imagination for language, just a tape recorder with endless batteries.'' --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Peter Bogdanovich knows there will be comparisons between his hit ``The Last Picture Show'' and its sequel, but he's unfazed. He never viewed the 1971 film as great. ``I think of it as a good picture we made 20 years ago, nothing more,'' the director said recently. ``I've never thought of it as a legendary piece of art and, in fact, I never thought it was quite right. I always wanted to go back and fix it a bit.'' ``Texasville'' takes place 30 years later in the same Texas town featured in ``The Last Picture Show.'' Many in the original cast, including Cybill Shepherd and Jeff Bridges, are back. Both films are based on books by Larry McMurtry. --- AMSTERDAM, Netherlands (AP) - Freddy Heineken, now retired from making beer, has turned to a career in what people can hear - in particular, easy listening jazz. The 67-year-old Dutch brewery tycoon wrote several of the songs on ``Dreamscape,'' a compact disc released last week on the Dutch label Dino, recording company spokesman Jan van Akooy said Friday. In a rare interview, published Friday by the International Herald Tribune, Heineken boasted, ``I fool around with drums and I have inborn syncopation.'' Heineken, who controlled a $3.7 billion beer empire until his retirement last year, added: ``I once played the congas with some black guys in Jamaica ... They asked me back. They bought me drinks.'' Van Akooy described Heineken's recording debut as ``Frank Sinatra-style music, kind of middle of the road - not real jazz, but in the jazz corner.'' Heineken was kidnapped in 1983 with his chauffeur and held to an $11.6 million ransom. Police freed the two unharmed a few weeks later and arrested the kidnappers, who got long jail sentences. --- THE HAGUE, Netherlands (AP) - Queen Beatrix and her husband, Prince Claus, are paying a three-day state visit to France March 4-6, a palace announcement said Friday. Beatrix, 52, and 64-year-old Claus are making their trip in return for President Francois Mitterand's state visit here in 1984, according to the announcement. No program has been announced for the visit, which follows a less formal French trip by Beatrix in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Williams Jokes About Richards' Drinking
DOC.TEXT: GOP gubernatorial candidate Clayton Williams said Friday he hopes opponent Democrat Ann Richards ``didn't go back to drinking again.'' Richards is a recovering alcoholic. Thursday, she claimed she's just 6 percentage points behind Williams in the gubernatorial race. When asked by reporters in San Antonio about Richards' claims, Williams said, ``I hope she didn't go back to drinking again.'' Later, Williams clarified the remark. ``Well, she's running for governor of Texas, not mayor of San Francisco. That's a joke. But the 6 percent is way off the mark. I don't apologize for it,'' he said. Williams didn't explain further. A Richards spokesman, Chuck McDonald, said he was stunned, calling it ``an extremely tasteless comment - even for Williams.'' McDonald called the Republican nominee a ``fraudulent, honking goose.'' McDonald also noted that Richards on Thursday announced that it was her 10th anniversary of sobriety.

DOC.HEAD: DEA: Major Cocaine Trafficking Network Destroyed
DOC.TEXT: One of South America's most important drug- trafficking networks has been destroyed in raids by U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agents and Bolivian police, officials said Friday. At least 300 anti-drug police and 20 DEA agents destroyed cocaine-processing labs and confiscated airplanes, radio transmission facilities, ranches and mansions, said Don Ferrarone, DEA chief in Bolivia. A U.S. agent was wounded in gunfire during the raids, which began Monday. Two traffickers were killed and several wounded. Police said at least 70 people were arrested, including Carmelo Meco Dominguez, the reputed head of the smashed drug network. Dominguez, 34, considered one of Bolivia's top three drug traffickers, handled five to 10 tons of pure cocaine a month, much of it bound for the U.S. market, law enforcement agents said. ``We have destroyed one of the top trafficking operations in Bolivia and South America,'' Ferrarone said. He said the network shipped cocaine to Colombia and to Mexico and had strong ties to Colombia's Medellin and Cali cartels. Among those arrested were pilots, chemists and police and air force officers who worked for Dominguez's network, police said. Ferrarone said one of those arrested, automobile dealer Cordoba Simons, faces cocaine-trafficking charges in Miami. ``The capture of all these people is the first step,'' U.S. Ambassador Robert Gelbard said. ``The hard part is for the Bolivian government to follow up with the prosecution and conviction of traffickers. Our experience has been that traffickers escape or are let out of jail.'' The raids were concentrated in Bolivia's principal coca-leaf and cocaine-producing regions, and resulted in confiscation of property worth at least $10 million, officials said. The seized assets include Simons' automobile dealership, eight airplanes and a nightclub with a revolving floor and a $300,000 sound system. Raul Loayza, the undersecretary of the interior, said Dominguez was arrested in Santa Cruz, Bolivia's second-largest city and a cocaine trafficking center 350 miles east of La Paz. As the operation got under way, traffickers working for Dominguez fired at a police and DEA patrol and set two vehicles on fire. A DEA agent was slightly wounded in the ankle and arm in the confrontation, in which the traffickers used automatic weapons, officials said. He was identified as Hawthorne Hope, 35, of Detroit. Two traffickers were killed and several wounded in the confrontation, police said. Bolivia, an impoverished country of 7 million people, grows about one-third of the coca leaf that after further processing becomes pure cocaine. It is estimated that at least 300,000 Bolivians make their living from coca-leaf cultivation and cocaine-trafficking activities.

DOC.HEAD: College Board Defers Decision on Sweeping SAT Changes
DOC.TEXT: Trustees of the College Board voted Friday to postpone for a month a decision on whether to adopt sweeping changes in the Scholastic Aptitude Test, including possible addition of a written section. Board officials refused to comment on the precise nature of the changes. But documents suggest that a key change might be the addition for the first time of a written essay section - a change some fear could work against minority and immigrant groups. The documents were made available to The Associated Press by FairTest, a Cambridge, Mass.-based group critical of the SAT. The SAT, taken by about a million college bound students annually, consists of two multiple choice sections, testing verbal and mathematical skills. The College Board sponsors the exam. Other possible changes under discussion include more problem-solving questions in the math section, and increased emphasis on critical reading in the verbal section. How such questions might be grouped or organized is still being debated, according to knowledgeable sources who insisted on anonymity. Such changes, if approved, probably would not take effect before 1993, according to previous statements from the Educational Testing Service, the Princeton, N.J.-based organization that administers the SAT. A brief statement issued by the board following its meeting said trustees view proposals to revamp the SAT as ``positive and exciting. ``However, because of the importance and complexity of the issues under consideration, they have requested additional financial and programmatic information before making a final decision.'' The board's statement said it anticipated the issues would be resolved within the next three or four weeks. That made it likely that the announcement would coincide with the board's annual National Forum, scheduled Oct. 31-Nov. 2 in Boston. Spokeswoman Janice Gams said College Board president Donald M. Stewart and other board officials would not elaborate beyond the statement until a final decision was announced. Warren Day, a spokesman for ETS in Princeton, also declined to comment on the deliberations and referred all questions to the College Board. However, the documents obtained from FairTest suggest that one factor contributing to the delay were strong objections from several educators and state legislators who fear that the addition of a writing section would be unfair to minority students and recent immigrants. In a letter dated Aug. 1 addressed to University of California-Berkeley President David Gardner, Patrick S. Hayashi, associate vice chancellor of admissions and enrollment objected to the proposed new written SAT section. He wrote that the College Board ``has done an abysmally poor job in examining the possible effects on non-native speakers.'' A letter to Stewart from California state Assembly Speaker Willie L. Brown Jr. also questioned the fairness of giving language skills added weight. ``Doesn't this place recent immigrants and other language minority students at a competitive disadvantage if the test results were used as an integral component of admissions reviews?'' he wrote. Questions have been repeatedly raised in recent years by FairTest and others about alleged racial and cultural bias in SAT questions. The College Board has consistently denied such charges.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Assures Israel U.S. Would Defend Against Iraqi Attack
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration gave assurances Friday that American troops would defend Israel in the event of an Iraqi attack. ``If Iraq attacks Israel, the U.S. will respond immediately and forcefully against Iraq,'' a senior State Department official told reporters after Secretary of State James A. Baker III held talks with Arab foreign ministers. ``It's that simple.'' Asked if the U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf area would be used to defend Israel, the official replied: ``The American forces are there. Obviously they are there to defend against Iraqi aggression. And if that Iraqi aggression extended against Israel the American forces would react to that.'' The United States and Israel don't have a mutual defense treaty. While additional U.S. weapons were sent to Israel in Mideast wars, all Israeli governments have insisted they don't want American soldiers fighting Israel's battles. Last Sunday, however, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein threatened to attack Saudi Arabia, other Arab countries and Israel if the U.S.-led economic boycott of Baghdad strangles his country. The blockade of trade with Iraq is designed to force Saddam to reverse his Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``We have a commitment to Israeli security that is rock-hard and unshakable,'' a second State Department official said. ``There is nothing new in that. It's been there for a long time. ``If there is a threat to Israel, that commitment to Israel's security comes into effect,'' he said. The two officials spoke to reporters under rules that shielded their identity. Their statements were so direct that it seemed clear they reflected the views of Baker, who met with a group of foreign ministers from the Persian Gulf. Baker also met separately with Syrian Foreign Minister Farouk Shara and the foreign ministers of Tunisia and Algeria. Shara told Baker that Syrian President Hafez Assad found on a recent trip to Tehran that Iran was steadfast in demanding an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. Assad discussed the plight of the six American hostages held by pro-Iranian factions in Lebanon with the Iranians but received no solid information to suggest their freedom was imminent, the U.S. officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Enacts Social Measures After Meeting Sandinistas
DOC.TEXT: The government announced Friday it would lower utility bills for the poor, suspend layoffs for civil servants and give food to hungry peasants in an apparent effort to head off a nationwide protest. The announcement came after a meeting Thursday with the leftist Sandinista Front. Sandinista leader and former president Daniel Ortega said ``there was good will'' to alleviate the hunger and unemployment that have accompanied government efforts to make market reforms in the economy. But Sandinista labor leaders say a nationwide protest is still set for Monday. ``What we are seeing here is a divorce between two sectors (of the Sandinista Front) that should be following the same line,'' said Antonio Lacayo, senior aide to President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. ``We hope that common sense prevails,'' Lacayo told a news conference at the foreign correspondents' club. There were some indications that Ortega's Sandinista Front was trying to cool pressures for another strike. ``I can't say we have solved the problems, I don't want to create expectations, but there is good will to do so,'' Ortega said in a radio broadcast Thursday night. Lacayo, considered the real power behind Mrs. Chamorro's government, called Thursday's meeting ``very constructive.'' The measures include lower utility bills for poor people, free milk for schoolchildren, free food for peasants affected by bad crops, temporary work and additional welfare for civil servants who have been laid off and the creation of a commission to oversee land distribution. He said the government will suspend further spending cuts and the trimming of the bureaucracy until agreement is reached on how to fix the economy, beset by inflation and deficit. Lacayo declined to say whether the measures were the result of strike threats. Two Sandinista-led strikes in May and July virtually paralyzed the country and ended only after major government concessions. ``We are in a very difficult situation,'' Lacayo said. ``It is categorized by some officials of the World Bank as maybe the most difficult in the world. It is easily the most difficult in Latin America.'' Lacayo said a 10-point Sandinista agenda contained social, economic and political elements. ``Regarding the economic points, especially those of social import, we are making the effort to see to those sectors mentioned,'' Lacayo said. But on the political points, which asked for presidential decrees to be rescinded, ``when the Sandinista Front rules again, through elections, it can issue whatever decress it wants,'' he said. ``We are not going to co-govern'' with the Sandinista Front, he added. Also Friday, Vice President Virgilio Godoy denied news reports that quoted him as saying he would force his way into the government complex to prove he is giving the orders, now that Mrs. Chamorro is out of the country. ``This is a refried version by the Sandinista communications system and its spokesmen to distort and misinform systematically,'' Godoy told The Associated Press. Mrs. Chamorro, who is in New York and spoke at the United Nations on Thursday, has denied office space to Godoy and not left him in charge the three times she has left the country since taking power April 25. Godoy, a former Sandinista labor minister who became disillusioned with Ortega's movement, is considered more conservative than Mrs. Chamorro. Police surrounded the presidential complex Friday, but Lacayo said the cordon ``is a normal thing in these times of protest.''

DOC.HEAD: Paxton Gets Official Dirt On Massachusetts
DOC.TEXT: A bill designating ``Paxton soil'' as the official dirt of Massachusetts has set the dust flying in this small town, with selectmen convinced the state needs to dig deeper for noteworthy earth. ``We've got clay up to our ears,'' Selectman Thomas J. Cunningham said Friday. ``It's been this way for years and everybody knew it and we were very surprised when we heard about this. We weren't even part of the process.'' But lawmakers and soil officials said the townsfolk don't understand the intent of the designation. ``It's just a little routine thing that was done to bring attention to the success of the soil conservation people,'' said state Rep. Stephen Brewer of Barre, who along with Rep. Kevin O'Sullivan of Paxton, filed the bill designating the official Massachusetts soil. Paxton soil was picked because it is the dominant dirt in the state, he said. Officials in Paxton, a small town of about 3,900 in a hilly, wooded area of central Massachusetts, were surprised when a plaque commemorating the soil showed up at Town Hall. ``We try to be very quiet,'' Cunningham said. Selectmen voted Thursday night to send a letter to local legislators, saying they think the selection was a mistake. ``There's areas that don't grow unless you fertilize the living daylights out of it,'' said Cunningham, adding that he thought legislators should be more concerned about the state's financial woes than naming an official soil. ``There's so many things to do beside giving that award,'' he said. Paxton Fine Sandy Loam occurs all across Massachusetts, but was first described in Paxton, hence the name, said William Taylor, a scientist with the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Soil Conservation Service in Holden. The idea of picking a state soil came up about four years ago, he said. ``It's to bring about the awareness of the soil as a natural resource,'' he said. Paxton soil is the dominant dirt in the state and ``I don't think the soil is that bad,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Group: Oil Supplies Remain Adequate Despite Gulf Crisis
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The International Energy Agency advised Western nations Friday to brace for a possible oil shortage but said there was no immediate need to tap strategic reserves to offset the loss of oil from Iraq and Kuwait. Echoing the conclusions drawn at a meeting last month, the group's governing board said in a comunique that rising oil price rises were driven by ``extreme political uncertainty,'' not short supplies. Supplies lost due to the embargo on Kuwait and Iraq's oil - imposed after Iraq overran the emirate on Aug. 2 - have been offset by increased production by other nations, it said, and oil markets remain adequately supplied. However, the board recommended that the 21 member countries take ``all decisions necessary'' so they could act quickly in the event of a future shortfall. The United States this week decided to tap its strategic petroleum reserves for this first time in response to the Persian Gulf crisis. President Bush on Wednesday ordered the sale of 5 million barrels of oil from the nation's strategic reserve, which contains 590 million barrels of oil. The Bush administration said its move was a test to see if the system could work in an emergency. But the energy agency made no call for the Germans and Japanese to follow Washington's lead and use even a symbolic amount of their reserves. Some U.S. officials have advocated similar action by West Germany, with 197 million barrels of reserves, and Japan, with 215 million barrels. Most official Western oil stocks are held by the United States, Japan and West Germany. If a significant shortage of oil supplies develops, the board will convene an emergency session on short notice, it said in a communique. The energency agency recommended that member countries intensify energy conservation and efficiency measures. It also urged governments to allow the full increase in oil prices to pass through to the market and suggested ``flexibility'' in the area of environmental regulations. Oil companies were advised to continue drawing on commercial stocks and use discretion in purchases to minimize volatility in the world oil market. John Easton, assistant U.S. energy secretary for international affairs, said he was satisfied with the results of the meeting. ``I think got what we wanted,'' he said. ``We've cleared the underbrush and done everything necessary for an effective and efficient response.'' The governing board will reconvene sometime during October regardless of whether an emergency session becomes necessary. The agency's members include Japan, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, most Western European countries and the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Jordanian Appeals for Understanding of Position in Gulf Crisis
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Jordan's Crown Prince Hassan said Friday he was deeply discouraged by the hostile international response to his government's Persian Gulf peace efforts and by the widespread indifference to the economic upheaval the crisis has caused in Jordan. With a mixture of sorrow, bitterness and sarcasm, Hassan spoke for more than an hour to a gathering of Middle East experts and reporters assembled by the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a research group. Hassan defended the efforts of his brother, King Hussein, to try to reach a peace settlement at a time when the parties to the dispute are ``remorselessly moving toward a conflict.'' Given the hardening of positions in recent days, he expressed wonderment that there wasn't a ``niggling of doubt'' that warfare was not the ideal answer. Hussein has been at the forefront of efforts to find a diplomatic solution, having visited Baghdad and a number of other capitals since the crisis erupted eight weeks ago. The Bush administration has ruled out talks with the Iraqis unless Kuwait is restored as an independent state. The international perception of Jordan's position has been one of acceptance of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait but Hassan said his government has implemented U.N. economic sanctions against Iraq with ``complete loyalty.'' This policy has been carried out, he said, even though it has meant a 50 percent decline in the gross national product. Hassan chided wealthy countries for not fulfilling their promise thus far of economic assistance for Jordan to compensate for the loss of trade with Iraq. ``Is it expected that Jordan commit economic hari kari?'' he asked. ``Are we expected to commit economic suicide?'' The Bush administration position is that Jordan deserves credit for reducing economic ties with Iraq but has said it expects total compliance with the embargo. The perception of Hussein's position on the crisis was partly shaped by his statement shortly after the invasion that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein was a ``patriot.'' In an open letter to Hussein published here this week, the Saudi ambassador, Prince Bandar, accused the monarch of ignoring ``horrifying acts of rape and destruction (by Iraq) which are unprecedented in Arab history.'' Hassan expressed regret that there seemed to be a ``total blackout on dialogue,'' adding that ``airwave diplomacy'' has leaders talking at each other instead of to each other. The Jordanian prince said he believes more efforts should be made to work out ``understandings'' concerning the future shape of a settlement once Iraq complies with the U.N. Security Council demand for a complete withdrawal of its forces from Kuwait. Such understandings presumably would entail territorial and financial concessions to Iraq in return for an agreement to a troop pullout from Kuwait. Hassan also urged that the principles the Security Council has applied for a settlement of the gulf crisis should also be applied to the Arab-Israeli dispute - meaning the return of Israeli-held territory to Palestinians. To ignore that aspect of the overall problem would invite conflict in that area once the gulf problem is resolved, he said. In response to criticism from the State Department and others about Jordan's decision to host a meeting of Arab radicals two weeks ago, Hassan said Secretary of State James A. Baker III was conferring with Syrian officials in Damascus at the very time the meeting in Amman was being held. Syria is on the State Department's list of countries that allegedly sponsor international terrorism.

DOC.HEAD: Kemp Applauds First Public Housing Sale
DOC.TEXT: The first sale of federally subsidized public housing units to its residents was completed on Friday - for $1. The transfer of the Kenilworth-Parkside public housing development in the city's northeast quadrant capped a five-year process in which the residents successfully managed the complex and qualified to purchase the property under a program boosted by Housing Secretary Jack Kemp. ``The residents have worked so hard over the past five years to make this possible. This can open the door for residents of other public housing complexes across the country who'd like to have a definite say about their living conditions,'' said Kimi Gray, head of the Kenilworth-Parkside Resident Management Corp. The transfer of 132 housing units to the management corporation was the first phase of the changeover, with the remaining 332 units to be exchanged as renovations were completed. A study by an independent accounting firm showed the program would save the government $6 million over 10 years and $26 million over 40 years. The sale was made possible in part by amendments to the 1987 Housing Act, which gave resident councils the right to manage their own developments. The bill, sponsored by then-Rep. Kemp and Del. Walter Fauntroy, D-D.C., also created procedures allowing residents to buy their developments after three years of sufficient self-management. Kemp said the Kenilworth-Parkside sale helped advance the Bush administration's goal of achieving a million new first-time and low-income home owners by 1992. ``It creates additional hope and opportunity, because it creates ... more jobs, reduces crime and can help reinvigorate our urban communities,'' the secretary said in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Sets Meeting with Savimbi
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will meet with Angolan rebel leader Jonas Savimbi on Tuesday, the White House announced on Friday. The meeting will ``strongly affirm our traditional support for Savimbi at a time when crucial events are occurring,'' including food shortages and peace talks, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said in a statement. Bush last met with Savimbi a year ago at the White House.

DOC.HEAD: Tuna Boat Sinks, Search Under Way for Four Missing
DOC.TEXT: A San Diego tuna boat sank in high seas north of Vancouver Island on Friday, and the Canadian coast guard said one person was rescued and four crew members were missing. The 69-foot Quicksilver went down shortly after midnight about 200 miles west of the northern tip of the island, said Officer Dennis Gee of the coast guard's Rescue Coordination Center in Victoria. At the time, the wind was gusting at speeds as high as 55 mph and waves were 16 to 26 feet, Gee said. Rescue efforts were hampered by 15-foot high waves and winds as high as 40 mph, said Capt. Helen Desnoyers of Air Base Comox on Vancouver Island. Survivor Barry Holberg of San Diego, picked up by another tuna boat in the area, was alert and conscious, said Lt. Cmdr. Mike Considine of the Canadian Forces. Authorities said he was taken by helicopter to a hospital on Vancouver Island for treatment of shock and hypothermia. They said an empty life raft was discovered two hours after the distress call was received. A Canadian aircraft and three other fishing vessels were on the scene, and the naval auxiliary vessel Endeavour and coast guard ship Darby were en route. Bill Perkins, president of the San Diego-based Western Boat Association, said the Quicksilver was a member of his cooperative. The boat, which left San Diego several months ago, is believed to be about 20 years old, Perkins said.

DOC.HEAD: Commodity Prices at Farm Drop in September, Says USDA
DOC.TEXT: Prices farmers get for raw products declined 2 percent from August to September, but the overall commodity index was still 3.5 percent above a year ago, the Agriculture Department said Friday. Lower prices were reported for corn, hogs, potatoes and cattle. Those more than offset increases for apples, broilers and eggs, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said in its preliminary report. Milk prices were at a record high for September, but cattle prices were down slightly from the all-time record levels of August. Hog prices were down sharply from August. ``The 25-cents-per-bushel drop in the corn price from August to September was the largest month-to-month decrease since a 28-cent decline during the same two months in 1986,'' the report said. Wheat prices declined 10 cents per bushel in September after a 28-cent decline in August, 29 cents in July and 32 cents in June. At $2.48 per bushel, wheat prices at the farm were down $1.24 from a year ago. Most prices are mid-September averages that will be revised next month. For example, the latest report showed August prices declined 0.7 percent instead of the 1.3 percent drop indicated a month ago. No new figures were released to show how much farmers pay to meet expenses. Those are adjusted quarterly. The previous adjustment announced in July showed the prices-paid index was up 0.5 percent from April. A new quarterly figure will be released in October. Meanwhile, department economists say consumer food prices are going up 5 percent to 7 percent this year, compared with 5.8 percent in 1989, the most since 1981. A recent forecast this week put 1990 net cash income of farmers at a record in the range of $59 billion to $63 billion, up about one-tenth from last year. The previous high was $57.2 billion in 1988. Net cash income is the money nationally that farmers have left from gross cash income during a calendar year after deducting cash expenses. It includes government payments and proceeds from crops grown previously but sold during the year. In another method taking into account changes in inventories, depreciation and other allowances during a calendar year shows that 1990 net farm income may be in a range of $47 billion to $52 billion, compared with $47 billion last year. Based on the preliminary figures, the September price index for all crops was down 2.4 percent from August and 2.4 percent below a year earlier. Both wheat and feed grains were down from August, while soybeans were unchanged. The August index for livestock and products was down 0.6 percent from August, but was 8.1 percent above the year-earlier average. ``Compared with August, lower prices for hogs, cattle and calves in September more than offset higher prices for broilers, eggs and milk,'' the report said. Milk prices rose 10 cents in September to an average of $14.40 per l00 pounds from a revised August average of $14.30 per hundredweight. That was up 40 cents from September 1989. Vegetable prices dropped 5.8 percent from August and were down 1.5 percent from a year earlier. Tomatoes led the September declines. Fruit prices rose 8 percent from August and were up 1.5 percent from a year ago. Apples led September gain, followed by oranges and grapefruit. The report said: -Cattle averaged $75.50 per 100 pounds of live weight nationally, down from $76.10 in August but up from $68.20 in September 1989. Those are averages for all types of cattle sold as beef. -Hogs averaged $52.60 per 100 pounds, down from $55.90 in August but above the average of $43.40 a year earlier. -Corn, at $2.26 a bushel, was down from $2.51 in August and $2.29 a year earlier. -Wheat prices at the farm, according to preliminary figures, averaged $2.48 per bushel, compared with $2.58 in August and $3.72 a year earlier. -Rice averaged $6.44 per 100 pounds, compared with $6.64 in August and $7.59 in September 1989. -Soybeans were $6.13 per bushel, unchanged from August but up from $5.70 a year earlier. -Upland cotton was reported at 65.2 cents per pound, compared with 64.6 in August and 63.9 a year earlier. -Eggs were 68.5 cents per dozen, compared with 65.6 in August and 71.2 in September 1989. -Milk was $14.40 per 100 pounds, up from $14.30 in August and the average of $14 a year ago. -Broilers were 35.2 cents per pound, live weight, compared with 33.2 cents in August and 36.1 cents a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators Want Corporate Japan to Pay for Insulting U.S. Blacks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS `Noises' to `Nissan' in 3rd graf
DOC.TEXT: Demonstrators outside the Japanese Embassy on Friday called for a boycott against Japanese products in the wake of a Tokyo cabinet minister's remark lumping together prostitutes and American blacks. ``No Japanese goods under the Christmas tree in 1990,'' declared Eugene Jackson, president of Black African Network, to the cheers of 100 demonstrators. The protest was organized by the NAACP. ``Nix Nissan,'' ``Kream Kawasaki,'' ``Sayonara Sony,'' ``Hook Honda,'' ``Disregard Datsun,'' ``Forget Fujitsu'' and ``Terminate Toyota'' appeared on placards carried by demonstrators chanting ``Japan No, America Yes.'' Other placards demanded the resignation of Justice Minister Seiroku Kajiyama, the minister whose remark triggered a trans-Pacific furor. Kajiyama said prostitutes settling in a neighborhood spoil its atmosphere, ``like in America when neighborhoods become mixed because blacks move in, and whites are forced out.'' The Japanese Embassy said Kajiyama earlier this week apologized for the remark as ``inappropriate,'' and on Thursday called on U.S. Ambassador Michael Armacost, reiterated the apology and asked the ambassador to convey it to the American people. Black leaders called the apology inadequate. NAACP Executive Director Benjamin L. Hooks said he would try to protest personally to Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu during Kaifu's visit this weekend. Kaifu and President George Bush were scheduled to meet at the United Nations. Charles R. Sherill of Harvey, Illinois, chairman of the National Association of Black-Owned Broadcasters, said he would ask the organization of 225 radio and television stations to pull Japanese-related programming from the airwaves. That would include CBS Records, owned by the Sony Corporation, he said, adding, ``Our dignity is more important to us than any black entertainer.'' ``We're ready to stop listening to Michael Jackson,'' a top singer on CBS records, said Vernon Goins, president of NAACP Youth at Georgetown University. Pennsylvania state legislator David Richardson read the gathering a letter to Japanese Ambassador Ryohei Murata, declaring ``it is indeed ironic that black Americans are poised to sacrifice their lives in the Middle East to protect the world's interests, including Japan's, at a time when Japanese leaders demonstrate such unconscionable racist bigotry.'' The letter was sent in behalf of more than 7,000 black elected officials of the National Black Caucuses of State Legislators and local officials and of the National Conference of Black Mayors.

DOC.HEAD: Darden Challenger Headed for Military Duty
DOC.TEXT: Republican congressional candidate Al Beverly said Friday his campaign will be helped by his activation for duty in the Army Reserves. But he said he didn't accept the assignment to get an edge on his Democratic opponent, Rep. Buddy Darden. Beverly, the 36-year-old GOP nominee for Darden's seat, said he has received orders to report for active duty Monday due to the Persian Gulf crisis. He declined to say where he will be sent or how long his reserve duty will last. ``It is, at this time, something beneficial politically to be seen in this role. But it isn't something I invented,'' said Beverly, captain of the 320th Military Intelligence Company headquartered at Fort Gillem. ``They specifically asked that I volunteer for this mission,'' he said. ``They basically made an offer I could not refuse.'' Earlier this month, at Beverly's request, Darden investigated and found that Beverly would not have to resign his candidacy if called to active duty.
DOC.HEAD: Parris: Discrimination Against Majorities Is Worse
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Rep. Stan Parris says ``it is worse to discriminate against majorities'' than against minorities and that he opposes affirmative action hiring plans. In a debate against his Democratic opponent, Parris said he believes in a ``classless, raceless, sexless society.'' In connection with civil rights legislation, ``The thing we have to avoid above all else is reverse discrimination'' which results when laws impose racial hiring quotas, said Parris, R-Va. ``It is bad to discriminate against minorities,'' Parris added. ``It is worse to discriminate against majorities.'' Parris' Democratic rival is Alexandria mayor James Moran, who said he supports affirmative action hiring programs. After the debate, Parris said that when the principle of discrimination applies ``against majorities in a democracy'' it is more harmful than discrimination against minorities. Parris spokesman Mark Strand said later that the congressman's ``principal stand is that discrimination is wrong.'' The debate was on Thursday.
DOC.HEAD: GOP Says Dems Used `Enemies List' to Harass Contributors
DOC.TEXT: A complaint filed with the State Elections Board says Assembly Democrats compiled an ``enemies list'' of Republican campaign contributors, then used it to harass them in an effort to dry up support for GOP legislative candidates. In the complaint, Assembly Republican Leader David Prosser asked the Elections Board to investigate his claims that the list was used to ``threaten, harass and intimidate'' Republican contributors. ``Lobbyists have told me they have been threatened (and) that their clients have been threatened,'' Prosser said at a news conference. He did not identify the lobbyists. Among those named were Assembly Speaker Thomas Loftus, the Democratic candidate for governor, and a number of other legislative leaders, including Reps. Barbara Notestein and Walter Kunicki, both of Milwaukee, the current and immediate past chair of the Assembly Democratic Campaign Committee. ``We don't know anything about it,'' said Michele Carrier, a Loftus campaign aide. ``Tom hasn't had anything to do with the committee for months.'' ``It's absurd,'' Notestein said. ``I think this thing is laughable. It also shows he (Prosser) is desperate'' in his efforts to help Republicans win legislative races, she said. The complaint was filed Thursday.
DOC.HEAD: Poll: Weicker Retains Substantial Lead
DOC.TEXT: Connecticut Party candidate Lowell P. Weicker Jr. continues to hold a substantial lead in the three-way race for governor, although his support has dipped, a poll released Friday indicates. A Hartford Courant-Connecticut Poll conducted from Sept. 18 to 25 found Weicker was preferred by 34 percent of respondents, Republican John G. Rowland by 18 percent and Democrat Bruce A. Morrison by 15 percent. Thirty-three percent were undecided. The poll of 517 people who identified themselves as registered voters had a margin of error of plus or minus 5 percentage points, so neither Rowland nor Morrison could be said to hold the No. 2 spot. The people were selected randomly and interviewed by telephone. Weicker had been favored by 41 percent of the voters surveyed in Courant-Connecticut polls done in May and June.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Confirms SEC Nominee
DOC.TEXT: The full Senate confirmed the nomination Friday of Richard Y. Roberts to the Securities and Exchange Commission. Roberts, a former top aide to Sen. Richard Shelby, D-Ala., was nominated by President Bush last month to fill the last vacancy on the five-member commission. The chairman and the commissioners, all appointed by the president, serve five-year terms on the commission which regulates stocks, bonds and the exchanges that trade in them as well as other financial markets. Roberts, 39, graduated in 1973 from Auburn University with an engineering degree. He received law degrees from the University of Alabama School of Law in 1976 and George Washington University in 1981. He left Shelby's staff in April to join a private law firm.

DOC.HEAD: Final Stone to be Placed Atop National Cathedral
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last four grafs pvs, beginning `Bishop Charles ...' with 4 grafs to CORRECT that Perry is provost, sted bishop, and CLARIFY that Haines is succeeding Walker, sted Perry.
DOC.TEXT: After 83 years, the final stone will be placed atop Washington Cathedral's St. Paul Tower on Saturday, fulfilling Pierre L'Enfant's vision of a great ``church for national purposes.'' President Bush will be on hand, just as President Theodore Roosevelt was when a foundation stone quarried in Bethlehem was laid at noon Sept. 29, 1907. The church is the seat of the bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Washington, but also calls itself a ``place of prayer for all people'' and has often held interdenominational services. Bush is an Episcopalian. The final stone, a 1,000-pound chunk of Indiana limestone carved in the shape of a folded leaf, will be lifted to its perch on the cathedral's southwest pinnacle, 234 feet above the ground, by a giant crane. Partly sunny and warm weather is predicted. Jean Grigsby, a spokeswoman for the cathedral, said at least 10,000 people were expected, about as many as attended the 1907 ceremony. L'Enfant, the French-born architect and engineer hired by George Washington to lay out the nation's capital, included a nationl church in his plan. That plan was never fully realized. The 873,021-square foot building, roughly 14th century English Gothic in style, is the sixth largest cathedral in the world. St. Peter's in Rome is the largest, followed by one in Seville, the unfinished St. John the Divine in New York and cathedrals in Liverpool and Milan. Although it is known as Washington National Cathedral, the official name of the building is the Cathedral Church of St. Peter and St. Paul. Constructionbegan at the east end with the laying of the foundation stone in what is now Bethlehem Chapel. The twin towers at the west end, a tenth of a mile away, are named for Sts. Peter and Paul. Work on the cathedral was halted during World War I and World War II and stopped again in 1977 because of a shortage of funds. It was resumed in 1980. President Dwight D. Eisenhower's funeral was held in the cathedral. President Woodrow Wilson is buried there. Seven bishops have presided over it. The Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. and the Rev. Desmond Tutu have spoken from its pulpit. The 150,000-ton church was built in the traditional stone-on-stone method of the medieval cathedral builders, although with modern equipment. It has no steel reinforcement, but is supported by flying buttresses. It is set on 53 acres on Mount St. Alban, the highest point in Washington. Saturday's ceremony will be followed by a service of consecration Sunday. Provost Charles A. Perry, who played a key role in the completion of the cathedral, will deliver his final sermon at the consecration. He is moving on to become president of the Episcopal Church Divinity School of the Pacific in Berkeley, Calif. As chief administrator of the cathedral, Perry argued at a crucial point in 1983 that by building on a pay-as-you go basis, the cathedral could both complete its west towers and expand its program of outreach to the poor. Bishop John T. Walker, who inaugurated the final phase of construction in 1980, shortly after becoming bishop, died after heart surgery on Sept. 30, 1989, the day of a service marking the beginning of the final year of construction. He is buried in the cathedral crypt. His successor, Bishop John T. Haines, will be installed Nov. 15.

DOC.HEAD: South African Military Facing More Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Sixteen military units will be disbanded and two air bases closed in troop cutbacks prompted by lessening tensions and escalating economic woes in South Africa, officials said Friday. President F.W. de Klerk has said defense forces can be reduced because of declining regional tensions, partly linked to the government's plan to end apartheid. Meanwhile, rising prices and a spreading recession has pressured officials to cut military spending - yet still leaving South Africa with the region's most powerful armed forces. Earlier this year, the navy was cut by 25 percent. Gen. Jannie Geldenhuys, head of the armed services, said 11 air force units and five army units would be disbanded or consolidated. Two air bases will be closed, he said. The Defense Ministry did not say how many troops would be involved in the cuts or how many would leave the military. South Africa has about 95,000 troops, about two-thirds of whom are conscripts. Spending cuts will also mean reductions in training and exercises, and withdrawal of some weapons and other equipment, the officials said. Geldenhuys said the air forces's Buccaneer jet bombers and Cessna light trainer aircraft would be withdrawn from service. Radar coverage will also be reduced, he said. The cuts will not reduce the military's offensive capability, officials said. Neighboring nations have much smaller and weaker defense forces, according to military analysts. Defense Ministry officials declined to confirm a report Friday in Business Day newspaper that defense spending would be cut by at least 5 percent, or about $200 million. Government officials said the state-run Armscor weapons company would also be hit by the spending cuts. New projects would be halted or reduced, and workers will be laid off. Armscor has dismissed about 2,000 workers this year. The company now employs about 20,000 people. Armscor was set up by the government to produce weapons and munitions after the United Nations imposed an embargo on South Africa to protest the white-run government's apartheid policies. The company produces everything from tanks and artillery to ammunition and has become a major arms exporter.

DOC.HEAD: Sallie Mae Will Take Over Student Loan Program
DOC.TEXT: The Education Department said Friday it plans to turn over the $9 billion portfolio of a financially troubled student-loan guarantee agency to Sallie Mae, the Student Loan Marketing Association. Sallie Mae will handle the portfolio of the Higher Education Assistance Foundation, or HEAF, one of the largest guarantee agencies in the Guaranteed Student Loan program, officials said at a news conference. HEAF is in financial difficulty because of a loan portfolio that included a high percentage of loans to vocational schools whose students defaulted in large numbers. Officials said about $3 billion was in default. Under the federal loan program, students borrow from banks and one of the non-profit guarantee agencies insures the loan. The government then reinsures the loan. In a prepared statement, Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos said an agreement in principle was signed with Sallie Mae for a three-year wind-down of HEAF's existing portfolio, which will be managed by a new subsidiary of Sallie Mae. Education officials said Sallie Mae would receive a fee of up to $20 million from the government. The United Student Aid Funds also had submitted a proposal to take over HEAF.

DOC.HEAD: Afghan Resistance to Send Delegation to Moscow for Prisoner Talks
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the Afghan resistance will send a delegation to Moscow at the invitation of the Russian President Boris Yeltsin to discuss the return of Soviet prisoners in Afghanistan, state television reported. The president of the ``Mujahedeen Transitional Government,'' Sibghatullah Mojadeddi, will name a delegation to travel to the Soviet capital, Russian Federation lawmaker Iona Andronov told the news program Vremya. The report did not cite a date for the talks. At least 300 Soviet soldiers are being held by the Afghan guerrilla fighters, known as Mujahedeen, according to the Soviet Defense Ministry, the state news agency Tass reported. The Soviet Union ended its 10-year military intervention in Afghanistan last February, but continues to support the government of Najib. The Afghan resistance has denied holding large numbers of Soviet military prisoners. But resistance leaders have accused the Soviet government of moving many Afghan children from their homeland and keeping them in the Soviet Union against the wishes of their relatives.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Aide Says U.S. May Push for New U.N. Action Against Iraq
DOC.TEXT: The exiled ruler of Kuwait gave President Bush a graphic account Friday of the Iraqi occupation of his country that, according to a Bush aide, could lead the president to push for tougher U.N. action against Saddam Hussein. Asked if the Kuwaiti report would prompt Bush to seek U.N.-backed military action against Iraq, the president's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, replied, ``That's one of those things that's conceivable.'' One administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said it was more likely that a request would come before the United Nations within a week or so, probably from Kuwait, seeking a condemnation of Iraq's treatment of Kuwait. The official said the United States would support such a resolution, but does not anticipate it would include military action. ``We're not at that point yet,'' the official said. Instead, such a resolution would highlight allegations of atrocities in Kuwait and recommend action ``that makes Iraq accountable,'' possibly by demanding future financial reparations to the Kuwaitis, the source said. Sheik Jabir al-Ahmed al-Sabah, the emir of Kuwait, told Bush that the Iraqis were destroying and looting his country, with ``terrifying conditions'' that include taking patients off life supports and removing babies from incubators so the equipment could be shipped back to Iraq, Scowcroft said. For his part, Bush said after the meeting that ``Iraqi aggression has ransacked and pillaged a once-peaceful and secure country; its population assaulted, incarcerated, intimidated and even murdered.'' Bush said Saddam was trying to wipe Kuwait, ``off the face of the map.'' Scowcroft, meeting with reporters, said he thought ``this whole element of what the Iraqis are doing inside Kuwait to a whole people could conceivably be the subject of another U.N. action.'' But he said the administration was not actively pursuing that. Asked if the emir had asked for a military strike to drive out Saddam's forces, Scowcroft said: ``No, he did not. Not in so many words. You can subliminally read between the lines if you wish. ... The two had a lengthy discussion of attitudes, public opinion in the Arab world.'' Scowcroft would not discuss the prospects for U.S. military action but did say Bush and the emir had discussed options beyond the U.N. economic sanctions. The adviser described the emir as contending that ``his country is being destroyed right now and that the longer the situation goes on the way it is the less there will be of what is recognizable as Kuwait.'' Asked how long the United States is willing to wait before taking other action, Scowcroft said, ``It's in everyone's interest to see whether or not there is a peaceful resolution of this'' by giving the trade embargo a chance to have an effect, he said. But he added, ``There is no question that what's happening inside Kuwait affects the timetable.'' The United Nations already has passed eight resolutions condemning Saddam's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and has imposing a sea and air trade embargo against Iraq. Scowcroft, briefing reporters on the meeting, said the atrocities and destruction inside Kuwait ``really are worthy of world attention, and a U.N. resolution is one way to bring that kind of attention on it. This is not just a peaceful occupation. This is a destruction of a people.'' He said the emir had described forcible movement of Kuwaitis from the southern part of the kingdom, with their identification papers being given to Iraqis and Palestinians being moved in from the north in ``sort of a repopulation.'' The emir also described widespread looting, including the seizure of medical equipment for shipment to Iraq. Bush said as the emir left that ``America's resolve to end this aggression against Kuwait remains firm and undiminished.'' The emir fled his homeland by car during Saddam's Aug. 2 military invasion, and now maintains his headquarters in Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: Dispute Shows Deep Divisions Still in Clean Air Bill
DOC.TEXT: A dispute Friday about how to combat urban smog exposed the deep divisions that remain between House and Senate negotiators as they try to craft a compromise clean air bill in the final weeks of the legislative session. ``We have consumed nearly two weeks without making any progress,'' said Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., chairman of the House-Senate conference. ``We are still miles apart on some issues.'' During a meeting that some called ``critical'' to getting a clean air bill completed before Congress adjourns next month, the Senate flatly rejected a House proposal for pollution controls on automobiles and accused the House of stalling because it had taken 11 days to prepare. The negotiations, which began July 13 has focused in recent weeks on what pollution controls to impose on automobiles and requirements for a limited phase-in of alternative fuel vehicles. The issue has been of major importance to Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the House delegation. Dingell's state is home to the major U.S. automakers. Senators had complained for days that the House wasn't responding to a proposal submitted in mid-September. Then, when the House proposal was received, the Senate quickly rejected it as being ``so unacceptable that it cannot even serve as a basis of discussion.'' Dingell accused the senator of engaging in speechmaking instead of focusing on the issue. ``I feel what's going on is a delay strategy,'' said Sen. John Chafee, R-R.I., suggesting that staunch opponents of the clean air bill may succeed in blocking it in the final days of Congress. Both the House and Senate earlier this year overwhelmingly approved clean air bills that impose tough new pollution controls on utilities, factories and automobiles. But efforts to work out differences in the two bills have made only slow progress. Earlier this week, President Bush raised the possibility that the bill may die if the pace of negotiations isn't quickened. Friday's squabble centered on concerns from Senate negotiators about provisions that would require tougher emission controls on automobiles and the phase-in of alternative fuel vehicles to reduce urban smog. Baucus, Chafee and other senators called the House proposal a step backward from the legislation already approved by the House and Senate. Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., in turn accused the senators of misunderstanding the offer. ``I don't think you've looked at this proposal,'' he told senators. At the heart of the sometimes raucous debate was concern - also expressed by state pollution control officials - that the House proposal would prevent other states from adopting the strong auto pollution control measures being taken by California. There was also concern that an ambitious program to require the use of alternative-fuel vehicles by fleet operators and a separate pilot program for alternative-fuel personal passenger cars were being weakened. However, Waxman contended that states would be allowed to more easily adopt the California pollution control standards under the proposal and said the fleet vehicle program would cover more cities and be stronger. But senators remained unconvinced. ``I think there's an element of mistrust on each side,'' said Sen. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo. Noting the complexity of the massive and highly technical clean air legislation, he said: ``There aren't 15 people in the whole city that know what's in here.'' After about three hours of discussions, Baucus and Dingell agreed to turn the matter over to staff and schedule another public conference Tuesday. Aside from the motor vehicle section of the bill, the conferees must still tackle sections dealing with acid rain controls, toxic chemical emissions from industrial plants, requirements on the use of cleaner gasoline blends in some urban areas, and whether to provide assistance to workers who lose their jobs because of tougher pollution control requirements.

DOC.HEAD: US Announces First Aid to Cambodia in 15 Years
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration signed on Friday agreements providing $2 million to meet health needs of Cambodian children. It is the first U.S. government aid earmarked for that country in 15 years. The announcement was a further signal of the improving relations between the United States and Cambodia's Vietnamese-backed government and came on the eve of a meeting Saturday between Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Vietnam's Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach. The aid funds will be administered by the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) and World Vision Relief and Development. The announcement by the U.S. Agency for International Development said the UNICEF program involves immunizations, oral rehydration, nutrition and health education. The $800,000 grant for World Vision will be used to upgrade a pediatric hospital in Phnom Penh, the Cambodian capital. U.S. aid to Cambodia was suspended after the communist Khmer Rouge triumph there in 1975. Congress recently lifted a legal prohibition on such aid. The Bush administration has been expanding diplomatic contacts with both Hanoi and Phnom Penh out of concern that the Khmer Rouge rebel group might force its way back into power. The Khmer Rouge is widely accused of killing hundreds of thousands during its 3{-year rule in the 1970's. Also Friday, a $9.8 million humanitarian aid agreement was signed with the president of the Soviet Republic of Armenia. It was described as the first A.I.D. program in the Soviet Union. But the United States provided substantial assistance to Armenia following the December 1988 earthquake there.

DOC.HEAD: Officials: Medicine Trader Mistook Killer Drug for Cough Syrup
DOC.TEXT: A medicine trader who mistook a poisonous chemical for a cough syrup ingredient is to blame for the deaths of at least 109 children, government officials said. The case also illustrates the widespread problem of fake and dangerous drugs sold in this West African nation. Such durgs claim hundreds of lives annually, authorities say. Investigators quoted in Lagos newspapers' Saturday editions said the unidentified trader bought unlabeled drums believed to contain harmless glycol, but which actually held ethylene glycol, a poisonous chemical stolen from an oil company's warehouses. Ethylene glycol causes kidney failure. The trader poured the chemical into smaller bottles labeled as propylene glycol, used commonly in Nigeria as a solvent for the preparation of cough syrup. The bottles bore the name of a Dutch company. Investigators were trying to determine whether the trader forged the labels or used old bottles, the newspaper said. The trader has been arrested, but the person who sold him the ethylene glycol was still being sought Friday. Forty percent to 50 percent of drugs available in Nigeria are bogus or substandard, said the United Nations' World Health Organization representative in Nigeria, S.H. Brewer-Graves, last April. Drugs are sold in licensed and unlicensed stores, as well as by street hawkers and vendors in market places. Under laws passed last year, those convicted of medicine fraud could face up to one year in prison and a maximum fine of about $127, a large amount for most Nigerians.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Hinges on Seven Photos, But Attorneys Disagree on Focus
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors in the nation's first obscenity trial of an art gallery and its director said Friday the case hinges on seven Robert Mapplethorpe photographs, but defense lawyers said that focus is misplaced. ``The state's case is, in some respects, very simple,'' said prosecutor Frank Prouty. ``The pictures are the state's case ... The issue is not the First Amendment. The issue is obscenity; the issue is also displaying pictures of children in the state of nudity.'' Prouty said the jury's only duty is to determine the truthfulness of what the indictments allege - that two of the photos show children with their genitals exposed and five photos show homosexual sex acts. But attorney Marc Mezibov, who represents the Contemporary Arts Center, told jurors that there's more to the case. ``This is not about photographs. It is about people,'' he said. The gallery and its director, Dennis Barrie, are charged with pandering obscenity and using children in nudity related material, based on photographs in the 175-photo exhibit, ``Robert Mapplethorpe: The Perfect Moment.'' It drew more than 80,000 people during its seven-week appearance. The Mapplethorpe exhibit closed May 26 and now is on display in Boston. A grand jury viewed the exhibit April 7 before returning the indictments. If convicted of both charges, Barrie could be sentenced to one year in jail and fined $2,000. The gallery, which marked its 50th anniversary last year, could be fined $10,000 for conviction on both counts. ``We don't want any breaks. We don't want any sympathy. We want a fair shake,'' Mezibov told the jury. Opening statements were heard Friday in Hamilton County Municipal Court after the eight-person jury returned from a brief tour of the gallery. Attorney H. Louis Sirkin, who represents Barrie, previously told jurors that Mapplethorpe was a homosexual and that some of the photographs depicted sexually explicit acts. ``It was a retrospective ... a biography of an individual by showing his works,'' Sirkin said. ``This particular photographer not only did beautiful pictures, he also did some other pictures that are not so beautiful. But they were pictures of the real world to him, a world that he was surrounded by and he was a part of.'' Mapplethorpe died of acquired immune deficiency syndrome in March 1989 at age 42. Sirkin said the gallery believed the educational and cultural value outweighed other considerations in fulfilling its mission to display contemporary art. ``There was controversy, but there was only one intent and purpose ... to add to the cultural enhancement of the citizens of this city and this area,'' he said. ``It was brought here not to appeal to anyone's prurient interest. It was brought here to teach and to show ... to show the world this brilliant photographer and some of the inner makings of that man and some of the torture that, perhaps, he suffered.'' The prosecution presented two witnesses, police officers who testified that they saw the seven photographs on display at the gallery. Testimony will resume Monday and is expected to continue all next week.

DOC.HEAD: Nigerians Parade Military Might, Artillery Fire Jeopardizes Peace
DOC.TEXT: Nigerian troops paraded tanks in a show of force through Monrovia on Friday as the sounds of gunfire indicated a weeklong cease-fire was in danger of collapse in the Liberian capital. Meanwhile, a Nigerian freighter carrying 150 tons of rice, canned food and cooking oil was unloaded in port - the first major food shipment since July to reach a capital where even the most basic of foodstuffs are in scarce supply. About 1,100 West African troops arrived in Monrovia this week with a new field commander, Nigeria's Brig. Gen. Joshua Dogonyaro. Gen. Dogonyaro toured the city in a long motorcade that included Mohawk tanks and armored personnal carriers. He also met at the U.S. Embassy with Ambassador Peter de Vos, and called on the British charge d'affaires, Steven Seaman. Rebel leader Charles Taylor had vowed to attack the five-nation West African task force if it sent reinforcements. Military experts and diplomats said cannon fire heard in the morning appeared to come from Taylor's rebels. It wasn't known who, if anyone, the guns were leveled upon. Taylor, who has declared himself provisional president of Liberia, announced a unilateral truce Saturday that has been respected by the opposing rebel army of Prince Johson and by troops remaining loyal to slain President Samuel Doe. Taylor wants to organize elections Oct. 10 to choose a Cabinet to lead the country - but insists that he must head any government. Taylor began the 9-month-old civil war when he invaded from Ivory Coast in December. Doe was tortured and slain by Prince Johnson's rebels this month. Taylor's right to the presidency is challenged by Prince Johnson and by political science professor Amos Sawyer, who was chosen interim president at a meeting of Liberian exiles Aug. 30 held under the auspices of the Economic Community of West African States. Under the West African plan, Sawyer would return to organize elections in which he would not be allowed to be a candidate. Taylor has refused to let Sawyer return, saying he is a puppet of the West Africans. Sawyer arrived in Sierra Leone on Friday and said he would return to Monrovia when it was safe to do so. Taylor's force has been estimated at as many as 15,000 troops, but most are untrained teen-agers. The arrival of new West African forces - boosting the total force to above 4,000 troops - clearly establishes the five-nation army as the most powerful in the country. The West African army's stated purpose is to put an end to a war that has claimed more than 5,000 civilian lives. About 3,000 West African refugees from Monrovia arrived Friday in Freetown, Sierra Leone, aboard the Nigerian warship Ambe. The refugees, who said they had not eaten for three days, told reporters the war in Liberia was far from over. They told stories of brutal killings. ``A few days ago, some rebels burst into our refugee camp, seized three of our number and shot them saying, `We just feel like killing a few people,''' one refugee said. The rebels belonged to Johnson's faction, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Date Set for Serbian elections, Police Disperse Demonstrators
DOC.TEXT: The rebellious republic of Slovenia edged closer to independence Friday, and Communist-ruled rival Serbia pushed for more centralized power in a new constitution. Slovenia's Parliament passed amendments to the republic's constitution declaring its laws take precedence over federal ones. The communist-dominated Parliament in Serbia, the country's largest republic, adopted a new constitution that enshrines a multiparty system but also reasserts direct rule over Kosovo - a once-autonomous province mainly populated by ethnic Albanians striving for independence. Serbia closed Kosovo's Parliament in July, after it proclaimed sovereignty. Serb authorities seized control of Albanian-language media and laid off ethnic Albanians who went on strike to protest the crackdown. The state news agency Tanjug reported Friday that police arrested an ethnic Albanian journalist for attending an illegal sssion of the Kosovo Parliament that was held Sept. 7 to declare the province's sovereignty. About 60 ethnic Albanians have been killed in demonstrations against Serb rule the past 18 months. Leaders in Slovenia and Croatia, which like Slovenia ousted Communists in free elections this year, have criticized Serbia's action in Kosovo. Yugoslavia, created in 1918, is being pulled apart by ethnic and political differences among its six ethnically diverse republics.
