In Croatia, police used tear gas and clubs Friday to disperse 2,000 Serb demonstrators in Petrinje who had surrounded a police station and set up roadblocks, Belgrade television reported. Tensions in the republic between the Serb minority and the majority Croats have been exacerbated after a center-right government was elected this spring. In August, the Croatian government declared illegal a Serbian plebiscite on the autonomy of the Serb minority, comprising some 11 percent of Croatia's population of five million. Belgrade television said the Serb demonstrators were protesting against plans to move weapons belonging to police reservists away from the town, apparently to prevent Serbs seeking greater autonomy within the republic from obtaining them. The report said similar protests were held in Glina and Obrovac. It gave no further details. Under Serbia's new constitution, political and judicial power will be centered in Belgrade - the republican and national capital - formally wresting autonomy from Kosovo and Serbia's second province, Vojvojdina. Neither province was consulted about the new document, despite relevant provisions in Yugoslavia's 1974 federal constitution.

DOC.HEAD: President Bows to Pressure, Dismisses Cabinet Minister
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, bowing to pressure from her advisory council, has dismissed a Cabinet minister accused by the panel of corruption and incompetence. The 19-member Council of State had demanded the ouster of Public Works Minister Jean-Pierre Moise Pierre-Louis as part of its quest for fair and non-violent national elections. Pierre-Louise will be replaced by Pierre Foucauld, a civil service engineer, the state-run newspaper L'Union reported Friday. The council was created to share power with the presidency shortly before Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot was appointed in March. But council members claimed she has ignored their advice, and they have been demanding since August that she resign. The council said Pierre-Louise's March 15 appointment was made without its approval. The advisory panel is supposed to have veto power over the president's decisions. ``Our first report on him revealed he had been dismissed from the Public Works Ministry for embezzlement,'' council president Louis Roy said Friday. ``As time went by, our scruples were vindicated.'' As acting finance minister from June to August, Pierre-Louis was constantly under fire for alleged mismanagement of public funds. ``Pierre-Louis should not only be fired, he should be brought to trial,'' said Roy. The council also has assailed Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot for failing to crack down on politically related violence and corruption in the army. It claims her provisional government has not dealt effectively with Haiti's grave economic problems. The president argues that only an elected government can carry out the sort of sweeping changes demanded by the council and others. Feuding among the president, the council and the Unity Assembly, the country's largest political coalition, had threatened to derail presidential, legislative and municipal elections now set for Dec. 16. This week, three major political parties announced they would campaign in the elections. They previously had refused to take part in elections under Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot's administration. Their decision followed a two-day visit to Haiti last week by former President Carter, who pressed for early elections. The last attempt to hold democratic elections in this nation of 6 million resulted in an election day massacre on Nov. 29, 1987, when army-backed thugs shot and hacked to death at least 34 voters at polling stations.

DOC.HEAD: Airman Shot in Shoulder
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon said Friday that an airman suffered a gunshot wound in his shoulder at a facility in Saudi Arabia. The Air Force, which is investigating the Thursday evening incident, said it is unable to determine whether the shooting was an act of terrorism. The airman, who was not identified, is a general purpose mechanic with the 833rd Transportation Squadron based at Hollomon Air Force Base in New Mexico. He is in good condition at the 354th Tactical Fighter Wing's Air Transportable Hospital, the Pentagon said. The airman was assigned to the transportation unit supporting the 354th and 23rd Tactical Fighter Wing operations as part of Operation Desert Shield.

DOC.HEAD: Mechanical Problem Delays Search for United Jet's Cargo Door
DOC.TEXT: A mechanical problem aboard a submarine delayed the search Friday for a second piece of a cargo door that tore off a United Airlines jet last year, a Navy spokeswoman said. The submarine Sea Cliff and its support ship returned to Pearl Harbor on Friday to await the arrival of a part needed to correct the problem, said Lt. Cmdr. Sandy Stairs, a Pacific Fleet spokeswoman. She said she didn't know the nature of the problem. The submarine recovered half of the door Wednesday in 14,100 feet of water 90 miles south of Honolulu. Its crew thought it also spotted another piece of the door about 200 yards away. The National Transportation Safety Board intends to examine the door in an effort to learn why it broke off of United Flight 811 over the Pacific Ocean on Feb. 24, 1989. Nine people died in the accident.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Reveal Past Secret Police Connections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with session took 12 hours, about a dozen lawmakers spoke, de Maiziere's comments. Picks up 11th graf pvs, `Eberhard Schiffner...'
DOC.TEXT: In a rare display of guilt from a disappearing government, East German lawmakers trooped to the podium of Parliament on Friday and revealed their ties to the dreaded security arm of the former Communist regime. One Cabinet minister resigned after admitting he had contacts with the notorious secret police, or Stasi, while about a dozen lawmakers came up to the microphone to deny or explain the accusations against them. The scene was a remarkable display of soul-searching by a troubled government in the final days of its brief existence. The first freely elected Parliament in East German history will meet one more time before it disbands on Wednesday, when the nation merges with West Germany. Friday's anguished session lasted 12 hours. In one of its last acts, Parliament voted overwhelmingly to ask a committee investigating the secret police to release the names of 56 officials, three of them ministers and the rest Parliament members, who were purportedly on the secret police payroll. Lawmakers previously had authorized the committee to investigate individual members of Parliament for ties to the despised police unit. Parliament also voted Friday to ask the committee to divulge the names of the nine lawmakers in the 400-member Parliament who refused to authorize the committee to investigate their secret police records. Lawmakers gave those on the list a chance to address the accusations. Construction Minister Axel Viehweger did - he promptly resigned. He said he had contacts with the secret police while he was on the energy council in the city of Dresden during the former government, which was toppled by a popular uprising last year. Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere told Parliament that the investigatory committee informed him Sept. 13 that three of his ministers had worked for the Stasi. He said one has resigned - an apparent reference to Viehweger - and two others had taken leaves of absence. A total of 10 members of de Maiziere's 24-member Cabinet have stepped down since he took office earlier this year. It wasn't known which he was referring to. The lawmakers who described their contacts with the secret police said such ties were required under the old government. All denied giving the Stasi information that hurt anyone. Eberhard Schiffner, a Christian Democrat, said he was the head of a state veterinary practice in 1963. He had to give information about his practice to the secret police, he said. He said he was not in a position to immediately detail the contacts. ``I need time, I need access (to his secret police file) and I need legal advice,'' he said. Bernhardt Opitz, a lawmaker from the Free Democrat Party, dismissed the allegations against him as ``a pack of lies and inventions.'' ``The committee plays as judge and jury,'' he said angrily. Brigitte Zschoche, a member of the reformed Communist Party, said she had contact with the secret police - when she was paid a recruiting visit by the Stasi in 1960. Former Research and Technology Minister Frank Terpe, who resigned last month when his Social Democrat party left the governing coalition, denied he worked for the secret police. Since the fall of the Communist government that ruled for four decades, the nation has been obsessed with how to purge the tens of thousands of former Stasi informants and agents from influential roles in politics and business. The Stasi, many of whose members held other jobs they used as a cover, helped keep the former hard-line government in power through stifling surveillance, intimidation and - allegedly - murder. Because they and other elite members of the old government had access to power, connections and money, they were able to maintain some control of the nation after a new, inexperienced democratic government was elected in March. There have been reports that many former functionaries and Stasi agents are running businesses that were once state-owned but have now been freed to operate as private enterprises.

DOC.HEAD: Study Shows Three-Quarters of Inner-City Children Witness Violence
With AM-Children-Host City, Bjt ^LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Seventy-four percent of Chicago's inner-city children have witnessed a slaying, shooting, stabbing or robbery, according to a study, and experts worry about the impact such violence has on youngsters' mental health. ``People think if they're chronically exposed to this kind of violence kids adapt to it,'' said Dr. Carl Bell, a psychiatrist at the University of Illinois School of Medicine. ``But they're wrong. If children who witness crimes appear withdrawn or silent, it's a symptom of the damage. They just shut off.'' The survey of more than 1,000 elementary and high school children on Chicago's South Side found that of students who witnessed violent crimes, in about half the cases the victim was a friend, family member or neighbor. In addition, 46 percent of the students reported that they had been victims of violent crimes themselves. And the victims aren't receiving the attention and counseling they need, said Bell, also head of the Community Mental Health Council, which conducted the survey. ``There are basically three areas where people impacted by witnessing violence show up - in the criminal justice system, in the mental health system or as a problem with the Board of Education,'' Bell said. He said witnessing or being a victim of violence teaches that violence is a way to address problems. As a result, the youths often have difficulty dealing with their own aggression, Bell said. ``You also see elements of nihilism,'' he said. ``If you see people getting killed, you start to think that dying soon is inevitable. Some kids get chronically depressed, withdrawn.'' He said officials need to develop a consistent policy on dealing with the children. ``They could develop from that a cadre of professionals able to deal with homicides and other community violence like shootings or stabbings,'' Bell said. ``That's also true in Detroit,'' said Anne Milko-Delpier, program coordinator for Detroit's Family Bereavement Center. ``There are not a lot of professionals who are trained to deal with kids who witness violent crimes like homicides.'' Milko-Delpier said Detroit's court system refers families of homicide victims under the age of 21 to the center, a program run by a nonprofit private social services agency called the Children's Center. She also said she was surprised at the Chicago survey's figures, adding she believes the number of children witnessing violent crimes in Detroit is definitely lower, although no study has been done. Officials in Philadelphia also could offer no comparable figures on children who witness violent crimes. But the number is probably increasing, said Kemi Adeleye, a director at Families of Murder Victims, which deals with some of the young witnesses. ``Homicide crimes are getting quite common around here,'' said Adeleye, whose agency is associated with the Philadelphia district attorney's office. ``But many say they just kind of get used to it. It's probably not so much that they get used to violent crimes, but rather it becomes such a frequent thing that they are no longer as shocked by it.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Awarded City Hall For Delinquent Court Judgment
DOC.TEXT: A man who was awarded City Hall as compensation for a multimillion-dollar court judgment needs the money, not the building, his brother said. ``We're not interested in actually owning part of East St. Louis,'' said Richard DeBow, 59, of Bargaintown, N.J. DeBow's brother, Walter, was awarded the building and 220 acres of city-owned property Thursday by a circuit court judge in nearby Belleville. ``If the city paid us $1,025,000 tomorrow, we would probably give it back, but at this point we're looking for a for-sale sign,'' said the family's attorney, Clyde Kuehn. Stunned city officials said they would appeal. Walter DeBow, 55, suffered permanent brain damage after being beaten into a coma by a fellow prisoner at the city jail more than six years ago. He has no short-term memory and is being cared for at a head-injury rehabilitation center in New Jersey. DeBow, who was in court Thursday, was in jail for a traffic charge of illegal transportation of alcohol at the time of the beating. He won a $3.4 million judgment in 1985. With interest it has risen to $4 million. Financially strapped East St. Louis still owes at least $1 million, Kuehn said. Judge Roger Scrivner's property award was the only way to guarantee DeBow would get his money, said Kuehn. ``I think this decision is just a major miscarriage of justice and demonstrates bias against the city of East St. Louis,'' said City Attorney Eric Vickers. The 4-year-old City Hall is worth $10 million, Vickers said, and city officials had been negotiating with a company to sell the other property for $5 million to a company that wants to build a trash recycling plant. In the meantime, the city has tried to pay off DeBow's award by selling $5.2 million in bonds, but Kuehn said they are only worth $2.8 million. DeBow will continue to hold the bonds, however, and collect payments on them, his lawyer said. East St. Louis is saddled with debts estimated at $47 million, and Gov. James R. Thompson signed a $34 million bailout bill Aug. 30. The money is to come from state bond issues. The population of the city, which has one of the highest homicide rates in the country, fell from 55,000 in 1980 to 40,000 this year, according to Census Bureau estimates. ``With all the financial problems we've had, this is just icing on the cake,'' said City Clerk Alzada Christian Carr.

DOC.HEAD: Armed Services Chairman Says War More Likely
With AM-US-Gulf
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee said Friday he believes the Bush administration ``is looking more favorably'' toward a war with Iraq before the first of the year. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., said he based his assessment on four things: The lessening chances of Kuwait regaining its independence without war; cooler weather in prospect in the Persian Gulf in coming months; the Moslems' January pilgrimmage to Mecca, which would make fighting then more difficult; and a more hawkish tone from the administration. He also said he expects Iraq to have biological weapons that could be used by year's end. Aspin spoke at a meeting of a reporters' breakfast group. His comments were repeated later by his press secretary, Lynn Reddy. Pressed by reporters to say war was likely in the eight-week standoff in the Persian Gulf, Aspin refused to make that prediction. He did say, however: ``The administration is looking more favorably on an early war option,'' according to his aide. The comments by Aspin came as President Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, said it was possible that the administration would seek U.N.-backed military action against Iraq based on a Kuwaiti report of Iraqi destruction of the occupied country. ``That's one of those things that's conceivable,'' Scowcroft said. At the breakfast, Aspin said the economic sanctions against Iraq, prompted by its invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, have been succeesful in denying money to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. However, Aspin said he does not believe the sanctions will allow the United States and other nations to achieve the political goal of forcing Iraq to back down and withdraw from Kuwait. The Wisconsin Democrat, one of several lawmakers who met with Bush and other administration officials last week, also said U.S. forces deployed to the Persian Gulf as part of Operation Desert Shield will be ready in the next several weeks for any military action. Earlier this week, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said he sees an increasing likelihood that Saddam will lash out with military force to try to break the stranglehold of the economic embargo. Cheney said the administration had forseen that a key point of danger in the standoff with Saddam would arise once the sanctions begin crippling the Iraqi economy. ``We may have seen in the last 48 or 72 hours the beginning commentary from him that would indicate that the sanctions are beginning to bite,'' Cheney said. In a speech taped for U.S. viewers, Saddam said U.S. forces deployed in the gulf region face the prospect of bigger losses than those suffered by Americans in the Vietnam War. ``We may have seen with his threats in the past couple of days that he may resort to military force in response to the sanctions,'' Cheney said.

DOC.HEAD: Illinois High Court Rules Children Can't Be Forced to Take Donor Tests
DOC.TEXT: The Illinois Supreme Court on Friday upheld a ruling that 3-year-old twins cannot be forced to be tested as potential bone-marrow donors for their leukemia-stricken half-brother. The decision upholding a Cook County Circuit Court ruling was another setback for Tamas Bosze and his son, Jean-Pierre, 12, whom doctors say might die without a marrow transplant. Cook County Circuit Judge Monica Reynolds ruled Sept. 6 that forcing the twins to take a blood test to determine whether they could be marrow donors for Jean-Pierre would violate their constitutional right to privacy. Bosze's lawyer, Edward Jordan, said he did not know if Bosze would appeal the case to the U.S. Supreme Court, his final recourse. He said the Illinois Supreme Court has not yet released the reasons for its decision. Jordan said the father and son were disappointed but that the decision was not totally unexpected. ``In every case, especially difficult cases, there is as much chance of losing as there is of winning,'' he said. The twins' mother, Nancy Curran, was ``pleased and very relieved,'' said her lawyer, Beverly Pekala. The case moved into the courts in early July after Curran, of Elk Grove Village, refused Bosze's request to have the twins tested. She contended the marrow-extraction procedure, which involves inserting a long needle into the hip bone or breast bone, would be risky and painful. Bosze, of Hoffman Estates, is the father of the twins, but he and Curran were never married. He and his son's mother are incompatible marrow donors for Jean-Pierre, as is the boy's brother and another half-sister.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Workers Will Report to Work Monday, Even if It's Brief
With AM-Budget Talks
DOC.TEXT: Federal workers are being told to report for work Monday but to be prepared to go home if there's no agreement between Congress and the White House on how to pay them. The instructions to go to work as usual were contained in a memorandum from Budget Director Richard Darman to agency heads Friday. In the absence of legislation to keep the government operating beyond the start of the new fiscal year Monday, non-essential workers would be sent home within three hours if a government ``phase-down'' is launched, Darman's memo said. Federal workers complained earlier about the confusion surrounding what they should do. Before Darman's memo was released late in the afternoon, workers were being told to listen to the radio over the weekend. ``This is absolutely no way to run any kind of ship,'' said John Sturdivant, president of the 700,000-member American Federation of Government Employees. ``It's just ridiculous that we've always got to operate on the basis of crisis. People don't know whether they're supposed to go to work, whether they have a full-time job or what,'' Sturdivant said. About 1.1 million federal workers received notices a month ago that they might be furloughed up to 22 days if automatic Gramm-Rudman deficit reduction budget cuts kick in on Monday. The furloughs and the phase-down are two separate threats facing federal workers. Most of those furloughs probably won't start until later in the week if no budget accord is reached; The phase-down would occur Monday if Congress doesn't pass - or President Bush refused to sign - temporary legislation to keep the government in operation. If such legislation were signed but the Gramm-Rudman cuts took effect, the furloughs probably would not start until later in the week. Also Friday, the federation sued to exempt Social Security employees from the automatic budget cuts. The suit, filed in U.S. District Court, contends those 60,000 workers should be excluded because their salaries are not paid out of general treasury funds. Instead, the suit notes, those workers are paid from the Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Program, which is exempt from the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction act that will trigger $85 billion if no budget agreement is reached.

DOC.HEAD: Movie Stunt Man Arrested in String of Cab Robberies
DOC.TEXT: A stunt man who has appeared in several major movies was arrested in connection with a string of armed robberies that targeted cab drivers, police said. Lance Guecia was charged Thursday with eight counts of first-degree robbery and criminal possession of a weapon for the crime spree that stretched from June 16 to Wednesday, said Sgt. Nick Vreeland, a police spokesman. First-degree robbery carries a five-to-15-year sentence. Guecia, 30, allegedly used a knife to rob the drivers. Police said he also robbed a neighborhood deli twice and was foiled in a third effort when the owner chased him out with a baseball bat. No one was injured in the incidents. Vreeland said Guecia told police he was a heroin addict and needed money for the drug. Guecia has worked in such movies as ``Fort Apache: The Bronx,'' starring Paul Newman, ``Legal Eagles,'' with Robert Redford, and ``King of New York,'' the new Christopher Walken film. He was arrested Wednesday when a robbery victim spotted him walking in the Manhattan neighborhood where all of the crimes occurred, Vreeland said.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Says It Planted Bomb at Meeting on Terrorism
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with bombs in Belfast, details on London bomb. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility Friday for planting a bomb at an international conference on terrorism in central London and said its target was a government minister. The bomb was hidden in a plastic lunch box and taped to a lectern the speakers were to use. The explosive was set to go off at 10:30 a.m., 30 minutes after the meeting was to begin, police said. ``The ability of the IRA to target British cabinet ministers while, less than a mile away, British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher holds a crisis meeting to find a way to stop IRA attacks, demonstrates the daring of the IRA and its ability to strike at will,'' the IRA said in a statement in Dublin. Police defused the bomb after it was discovered by chance by a sound engineer at Thursday's one-day conference at the Royal Overseas League in Piccadilly. Police and private security guards missed the bomb in earlier sweeps. Foreign Office Minister William Waldegrave was due to address the conference. Waldegrave is not in the Cabinet but is one of five deputies to Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd. The IRA's statement said an ``active service unit'' had ``succeeded in breaching security to place a bomb at the Royal Overseas League conference.'' The IRA statement was issued to a Dublin news agency and signed with the IRA's traditional nom de guerre, P. O'Neill. Mrs. Thatcher was meeting with her Cabinet at her official residence in Downing Street when the bomb was discovered. London's police chief, Sir Peter Imbert, also was scheduled to address the conference. Commander George Churchill-Coleman, head of Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist squad, said the sophisticated device contained enough plastic explosives to kill ``the the speaker and other people as well.'' Waldegrave was to have been the first speaker, but a change in his schedule forced a last-minute switch to the afternoon. An unidentified IRA spokesman was quoted in a London newspaper on Saturday as vowing to escalate attacks in mainland Britain in its fight to end British rule in Northern Ireland. ``They are rattled and as long as they persist with their illogical and illegal claim to Ireland, we will not only continue to rattle them, but will rattle them harder,'' the IRA spokesman told The Independent newspaper. In the Northern Ireland capital, Belfast, police blamed the IRA for planting four explosive devices packed in radio cassette holders. Two of the devices exploded early Friday in a shop and a restaurant, causing no injuries. The other two were spotted by department store clerks and defused, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Showers, Thunderstorms Over Florida and Central United States
DOC.TEXT: Scattered showers and thunderstorms hit Florida and parts of the central United States on Friday, with flood worries along the Rio Grande in Texas, but most of the country was clear. Rain trailing a cold front moving across the nation fell in parts of Colorado, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Kansas, Iowa, Indiana and Michigan. Heavy rain that pummeled Florida overnight continued Friday, with as much as three-quarters of an inch reported between mid-morning and early afternoon. Temperatures warmed into the 80s across much of the south central and southeastern United States by afternoon. Readings were only in the 50s and 60s in many central and midwestern states. Most of the West was in the 60s and 70s. A flood warning remained in effect for the Rio Grande from Presidio, Texas through Big Bend National Park to the mouth of the Pecos River below Langtry. Thick fog reduced visibility to near zero in the lower Susquehanna Valley of Pennsylvania, and around Philadelphia. High wind warnings were in effect for parts of Alaska, with gusts reaching 75 mh reported at Ketchikan Friday morning. Friday's low for the Lower 48 states was 32 degrees at West Yellowstone, Mont.

DOC.HEAD: Study Shows Three-Quarters of Inner-City Children Witness Violence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmits a0679 to make keyword conform to listing on AM-News Digest.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Children-Host City, Bjt ^LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Seventy-four percent of Chicago's inner-city children have witnessed a slaying, shooting, stabbing or robbery, according to a study, and experts worry about the impact such violence has on youngsters' mental health. ``People think if they're chronically exposed to this kind of violence kids adapt to it,'' said Dr. Carl Bell, a psychiatrist at the University of Illinois School of Medicine. ``But they're wrong. If children who witness crimes appear withdrawn or silent, it's a symptom of the damage. They just shut off.'' The survey of more than 1,000 elementary and high school children on Chicago's South Side found that of students who witnessed violent crimes, in about half the cases the victim was a friend, family member or neighbor. In addition, 46 percent of the students reported that they had been victims of violent crimes themselves. And the victims aren't receiving the attention and counseling they need, said Bell, also head of the Community Mental Health Council, which conducted the survey. ``There are basically three areas where people impacted by witnessing violence show up - in the criminal justice system, in the mental health system or as a problem with the Board of Education,'' Bell said. He said witnessing or being a victim of violence teaches that violence is a way to address problems. As a result, the youths often have difficulty dealing with their own aggression, Bell said. ``You also see elements of nihilism,'' he said. ``If you see people getting killed, you start to think that dying soon is inevitable. Some kids get chronically depressed, withdrawn.'' He said officials need to develop a consistent policy on dealing with the children. ``They could develop from that a cadre of professionals able to deal with homicides and other community violence like shootings or stabbings,'' Bell said. ``That's also true in Detroit,'' said Anne Milko-Delpier, program coordinator for Detroit's Family Bereavement Center. ``There are not a lot of professionals who are trained to deal with kids who witness violent crimes like homicides.'' Milko-Delpier said Detroit's court system refers families of homicide victims under the age of 21 to the center, a program run by a nonprofit private social services agency called the Children's Center. She also said she was surprised at the Chicago survey's figures, adding she believes the number of children witnessing violent crimes in Detroit is definitely lower, although no study has been done. Officials in Philadelphia also could offer no comparable figures on children who witness violent crimes. But the number is probably increasing, said Kemi Adeleye, a director at Families of Murder Victims, which deals with some of the young witnesses. ``Homicide crimes are getting quite common around here,'' said Adeleye, whose agency is associated with the Philadelphia district attorney's office. ``But many say they just kind of get used to it. It's probably not so much that they get used to violent crimes, but rather it becomes such a frequent thing that they are no longer as shocked by it.''

DOC.HEAD: Poland, Czechoslovakia, Romania, Bulgaria Offer Gulf Help
DOC.TEXT: Four East European countries regarded as military foes of the West barely a year ago have offered assistance to the international military force defending Saudi Arabia and enforcing U.N. sanctions against Iraq, the U.S. State Department said Friday. Poland, Czechoslovakia, and Romania have offered medical facilities and Bulgaria said it will provide 400 soldiers, the department said. ``We welcome these offers, which demonstrate the solidarity of the international community in opposing Iraqi aggression,'' the statement said. It added that it was up to Saudi Arabia whether to accept the offers. The president of Bulgaria, Zhelyu Zhelev, met President Bush Friday after earlier telling reporters his country has intended to contribute ground troops from the outset of the gulf crisis but delayed out of concern for aggravating the hardships of 700 Bulgarian workers trapped in Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. Zhelev said Bulgaria would act soon to dispatch the military unit, and was making contact with Saudi Arabia through U.S. officials. Czechoslovakia, like Bulgaria, has no diplomatic relations with Saudi Arabia. Its foreign minister, Jiri Dienstbier, told the Washington Foreign Affairs Council Friday his country is prepared to send a team of chemical warfare specialists and a field hospital to the gulf. ``First, we have to be invited,'' he said, adding Czechoslovakia would welcome it if the U.N. Security Council issued a blanket invitation to all nations to form a U.N. peacekeeping force. Dienstbier's aides said the Czechoslovak team could include up to 200 personnel, including doctors, nurses and specialists in treating injuries caused by poison gas, which Iraq has stockpiled and in 1988 used against its Kurdish minority.

DOC.HEAD: Two Killed, Six Injured After Toxic Gases Leak From Plant Furnace
DOC.TEXT: Toxic gases leaked from a furnace at a south Mississippi manufacturing plant Friday, killing two maintenance workers and injuring six others. The eight were repairing the furnace at Magnatek, Inc. early Friday when the deadly leaks occurred, said plant manager Dennis Kokaisel. The furnace is used to harden steel. ``What happened is still under investigation and the cause has not been determined,'' Kokaisel said. A. de Jean King Sr., area director of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, said his investigators were at the scene but it was too early to pinpoint the source of the leak or the materials involved. Kokaisel identified the dead workers as John Hosey, 52, the crew foreman, and Bertram Bass, 27. He said four other workers were treated at area hospitals and released. Two were admitted to Simpson General Hospital for observation, Kokaisel said. Authorities said the gases were confined to the plant and no one outside its boundaries was evacuated. There was no fire or explosion. Nearby Simpson County Academy was closed for the day as a safety precaution, said headmaster Hamp Gaston. The 421-student school is located about 200 yards from the plant. About 100 of the plant's 1,400 employees were at work at the time of the accident, said Kokaisel. Gary Hall of the Mississippi Emergency Management Agency said the leaking gases may have included natural gas, liquid nitrogen and liquid hydrogen, all toxic. Kokaisel said he could not confirm what gases were involved but added that those three are all used at the plant.

DOC.HEAD: City Performs Annual Chore of Receiving World VIPs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to CORRECT to 71 world leaders sted heads of state and DELETE erroneous reference to 90 foreign ministers and DELETES erroneous reference to 160. Picks up 7th graf, `Our Indianapolis...'.
DOC.TEXT: The Big Apple is going through its autumnal rite of safeguarding and entertaining the world's potentates and premiers as they arrive for the U.N. General Assembly. Their numbers are swollen this year by the Persian Gulf crisis and the U.N. World Summit for Children. Seventy-one world leaders, including President Bush, are scheduled to attend the two-day Summit for Children beginning Saturday. It's billed as the largest gathering ever of world leaders. On Friday, several of them zipped around the city: President Patricio Aylwin of Chile speaking at a foreign affairs forum; Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu picking up an honorary degree at New York University; Queen Fabiola of Belgium visiting the Covenant House shelter for young runaways. Some of the top-ranking officials expected in town are staying at their country's U.N. missions. For the rest, and their often large entourages, hotels readied welcomes. ``Our Indianapolis 500,'' was the way Jim Mastrangelo, sales manager of the United Nations Plaza Hotel, described the coming days. But cars at low - or no - speed were what city officials fretted about. ``This will be the largest number of world dignitaries assembled in New York at one time,'' said city Transportation Commissioner Lucius Riccio. ``There is the potential for a very large international gridlock.'' Many places where the diplomats go, demonstrators are bound to follow. About a score of protests and rallies pegged to U.N. events are planned. And the city will have its usual complement of unrelated distractions. For example, a dinner for the Italian foreign minister is scheduled Saturday night at a trendy downtown restaurant co-owned by movie star Robert DeNiro. But should any dignitary decide to pop into a fast-food joint for a quick afternoon snack, they could run into the Coalition to Liberate Animals Worldwide. The coalition intends making things uncomfortable for meat-eaters at various chain eateries in midtown. Another potential for snarled traffic is that motorcades could meet moviemakers. Three feature films are being shot on the streets of Manhattan and a fourth in Brooklyn. Police plan to set up traffic freezes for no one but President Bush. He is expected Saturday and will address the United Nations on Monday. A freeze immobilizes everything - vehicles and pedestrians - along the president's route, and while police say freezes will be no more than 15 minutes, they have been known to last an hour. Shoppers at the swank Bergdorf Goodman for Men witnessed a sweep Thursday by phalanxes of security men, in advance of a browse by a foreign bigwig. ``They're big shoppers,'' said Elizabeth Maguire, speaking for the Plaza Hotel, where Suzan Mubarak, wife of the Egyptian president, and other international guests are staying. ``But the rumor is that they've all been clued into Secaucus,'' she added, referring to a bustling discount center across the Hudson River in New Jersey. Police presence in midtown will escalate through the weekend, with round-the-clock details of as many as 900 officers on duty Saturday, 950 Sunday and 1,600 Monday. Amid the elaborate precautions for the summit on saving the world's children, a dark counterpoint was the continued vulnerability of New York City's youth to violence. Nine children have been shot in the city since Sunday, the latest a 13-year-old who died when a gun went off as it was being passed among his friends. In the last two months, seven children have died of random gunshots.

DOC.HEAD: SAC Commander Gen. John T. Chain to Retire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, ``Chain's successor,'' with one graf to UPDATE with Bush's choice for Chain's successor
DOC.TEXT: Gen. John T. Chain is retiring from the Air Force after more than 34 years, most recently as commander of the Strategic Air Command, the center said Friday. Chain, 55, will retire Feb. 1, 1991. The four-star general has been in charge of the nation's nuclear command center since June 1986. The president has nominated Lt. Gen. George L. Butler, 51, director of strategic plans and poolicy for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, for promotion to general and to replace Chain, the Pentagon said. The longevity of military service is limited according to grade. Chain was approaching his limit of 35 years. SAC is the country's major nuclear deterrent force, with an armory of bombers, tankers, reconnaissance aircraft and intercontinental ballistic missiles. Chain, a native of Wilmington, Del., has not disclosed his retirement plans.

DOC.HEAD: PBS Says `The Civil War' Ratings Are Highest in Its History
DOC.TEXT: ``The Civil War,'' the epic, 11-hour documentary shown over five nights this week, was the most-watched series in the history of the Public Broadcasting Service, PBS officials said Friday. ``It's been a glorious week for public television,'' said Jennifer Lawson, PBS vice president for national programming. PBS said ``The Civil War'' was seen in about 14 million homes each evening. Overall, the documentary by filmmaker Ken Burns averaged a 9.0 rating and a 13 share. Its concluding episode Thursday night, drew an 8.9 rating and a 14 share, according to A.C. Nielsen Co. figures. A ratings point represents 931,000 television households, and a share is a percentage of all television sets tuned in to a show in its time period. PBS said it will rebroadcast the series in January and July 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Wall Company Ordered to Pay $5.1 Million in Dupont Plaza Blaze
DOC.TEXT: A federal jury on Friday ordered a manufacturer of room partitions to pay $5.1 million in connection with a 1986 New Year's Eve arson fire that killed 97 hotel guests. The U.S. District Court jury found Air Wall Inc. guilty of nine counts of negligence and 10 counts of failure to warn users about possible hazards associated with its foam-filled dividers at the Dupont Plaza Hotel. It was not immediately clear what potential hazards were cited by the jury, which decided the walls contributed to the fast-moving fire linked to a labor dispute in Puerto Rico's most populous city. In a separate trial, three former hotel employees were convicted of murder in 1987 for setting the fire to pressure management to give into union demands. The union itself has denied any responsibility. The fire broke out in a ballroom on the first floor of the 22-story hotel and most of the victims were trapped in the casino. The beachside hotel, which has still not reopened, was filled with nearly 1,000 guests at the time. Also, 140 people were injured. Air Wall was acquitted of 17 other counts, including all 12 counts of productive defectiveness. Five other companies that supplied rugs, dressers and foam cushions used by the hotel were acquitted of all charges following seven days of jury deliberations to end the 15-month trial. Defense attorney Harold Vicente said Air Wall would appeal to the First Circuit of Appeals in Boston on grounds of confusion among the jurors. ``If the product was not defective, what did we have to warn about,'' Vicente said following the verdict. It was second phase of one of the largest disaster-related lawsuits in U.S. history. The first phase ended in May 1989 when Judge Raymond L. Acosta accepted a $100 million settlement of hundreds of individual lawsuits stemming from the Dec. 31, 1986. Judge Acosta now must decide whether to go ahead with the third phase of the trial, which entails suits and countersuits filed by some of the firms and insurers, or proceed to the remaining 264 individual suits. Friday's verdict stemmed from 12 lawsuits filed against hotel suppliers by survivors and relatives of people killed in the fire. Wyoming-based Air Wall manufactured portable Styrofoam-filled partitions used on the floor of the hotel ballroom. The jury determined the four companies that have owned Air Wall at various times since 1962 must share in paying damages. They are: White Consolidated Industries Inc., Aircoustic Wall Manufacturing Co., ACW Airwall Inc. and Hufcor Inc. Hector Martinez, a lawyer for the four firms, said the appeal would be based on jurors' confusion caused by the complicated nature of the case and the voluminous trial documentation. He said there were about 15,000 pages of testimony alone. ``I think I have a very good argument for appeal and I am very pleased with the result,'' Vicente agreed. He explained that he had expected a much higher damage award. Originally, the suits filed against his clients totaled $25 million. Lawyers for the plaintiffs also said they were satisfied with the jury award. Attorney Francisco Troncoso said the award breaks ground for settlements in the individual cases are tried. Companies cleared by the jury of liability were: Drexel Heritage Furnishings Industries of North Carolina, Dan River Inc. of Virginia, Lewis Industries Inc. of California, Foss Manufacturing Company Inc. of Massaschussetts and Wolf Gordon Inc. of New York. Drexel Heritage was the supplier of dressers that were stored in the ballroom at the time of the fire. Dan River, Wolf Gordo and Foss supplied rugs used on the walls and floor of the ballroom, and Lewis Industries was the manufacturer of the foam used to fill sofa cushions stored in the ballroom. The fourth and final phase of the litigation concerns suits filed by the owners of the hotel against the Teamsters Union.

Their numbers are swollen this year by the Persian Gulf crisis and the U.N. World Summit for Children. Seventy-one world leaders, including President Bush, are scheduled to attend the two-day Summit for Children beginning Saturday. It's billed as the largest gathering ever of world leaders.

DOC.HEAD: Students Vow To Occupy Campus Buildings Until Demands Met
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 8 grafs to show talks stalemated, students angry at Barry, picks up 2nd graf prv, `for the first time...' DELETES 6th graf prv, `The students ... the protesters' to tighten
DOC.TEXT: Talks broke down Friday evening between student activists demanding sweeping improvements at the University of the District Columbia and school and city officials trying to end a three-day student takeover of university buildings. Attorneys representing the students said they were angered by remarks made by Mayor Marion Barry after emerging from talks with student leaders. The students say they are not receiving a quality education and have demanded the resignation of most of the school's board of trustees. Barry said negotiations had failed because attorneys for the students were taking a hard line stance against the university. The mayor said he was frustrated by the lack of progress and has no plans to return to the campus unless the negotiations are salvaged. Charles Pearson, one of the attorneys Barry said was holding up a resolution, said, ``We will not back down because someone slanders our integrity. We will not sell the students out.'' The students said they will not end their protests despite statements by school officials that they are prepared to resume regular classes on Monday. They vowed to retain control of two campus buildings until a majority of the school's trustees resign. ``For the first time in a long time, the city is going to get a new administration,'' student protest leader Mark Thompson said. ``There's no reason why the university shouldn't start anew as well.'' Thompson and other students met with the 15-member trustee panel, city council members, and Barry in an attempt to resolve an impasse that began Wednesday. The students' chief demand is that 11 of the trustees resign. Barry and the council approve recommendations for the non-paying posts, but are powerless to force a trustee to quit. ``I support what ... those young people up there want,'' said city council member Harry Thomas after emerging from a 90-minute meeting with a group of students. ``I support them 100 percent.'' The students claim the board has taken a number of actions that have threatened the quality of education at UDC, a public institution with an enrollment of about 12,000. Students took over a campus building Wednesday, saying they were upset about several trustee actions, including a plan to spend $1.6 million for renovations to a library so a controversial artwork, ``The Dinner Party,'' can be installed there. Students said the money could be better spent in improving academic programs. Several UDC departments have had problems maintaining their accreditations.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Names New Show ``America Tonight''
DOC.TEXT: CBS News' late-evening weeknight series, which had no title when CBS announced it earlier this month, will premiere Monday under the name ``America Tonight,'' the network said Friday. The half-hour series, with Charles Kuralt in New York and Lesley Stahl in Washington, will start at 11:30 p.m. EDT, principally competing against ABC's 10-year-old ``Nightline.'' Begun as a series of Persian Gulf specials after Iraq's Aug. 2 takeover of Kuwait, the CBS series will examine several major topics each night. Its premiere will include a Middle East update, a CBS spokeswoman said.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney Fails to Get Gag Order in Gainesville Investigation
DOC.TEXT: The attorney for an inmate under investigation in the slayings of five college students failed to get a gag order on Friday silencing public suspicion by police, prosecutors and the news media. Stephen Michael Bates, facing burglary and assault charges in a separate case, has not been charged in the multiple student slayings in Gainesville, but has been named as a possible suspect. ``We don't feel he did it. We feel they're in a position to clear him or not clear him. They haven't done it,'' said Polk County Assistant Public Defender Robert Norgard. ``I feel he's just being used.'' Circuit Judge J. Tim Strickland rejected the gag order request but said Norgard was free to file the motion again later. ``What we are going to do is see what happens as far as publicity,'' Norgard said in a telephone interview. Bates, 30, is accused of armed burglary, aggravated assault and battery in Polk County and is being held on $100,500 bond. He allegedly broke into a woman's home and threatened her and her daughter with a knife. Bates probably will go to trial in January and could face up to life in prison if convicted, his attorney said. ``If you were facing a criminal charge that normally wouldn't draw any publicity and you were listed as a suspect in the Gainesville murders, you wouldn't feel too comfortable,'' Norgard said. ``The mere fact of being mentioned as a suspect is pretty negative.'' Gainseville authorities have listed Bates as one of eight possible suspects in the student killings, but no charges have been filed. The only other suspect identified by investigators is Edward Lewis Humphrey, 18, jailed in Brevard County on $1 million bail on unrelated charges stemming from a beating suffered by his grandmother. His trial is scheduled for early October. The nude, mutilated bodies of Sonja Larson, 18, and Christina Powell, 17, were found in their Gainesville apartment Aug. 26. Hours later, the decapitated body of Christina Hoyt, 17, was discovered. The bodies of Manuel Taboada and Tracy Paules, both 23, were found Aug. 28 in the apartment they shared. Several news organizations retained Tampa lawyer Carol LoCicero to fight any gag order, which she has said would be unconstitutional prior restraint.

DOC.HEAD: Chief of Staff Defends VA Hospital Accused of Poor Patient Care
DOC.TEXT: The chief of staff of a Veterans Administration hospital on Friday defended the institution's medical care, calling a critical network television report erroneous and distorted. But in Washington, one Ohio senator called for an investigation and another called for the hospital director's suspension until the matter is resolved. ABC's ``PrimeTime Live'' reported Thursday that it used hidden cameras to record examples of unsanitary conditions and poor patient care during three days at the Wade Park VA Hospital. The hospital's chief of staff, Dr. Murray Altose, blasted the report as unfair. ``I'm saying it isn't substantiated and it's grossly distorted,'' Altose said. ``It's not the way things are at this medical center. That picture was a grossly distorted representation that's full of patently erroneous allegations.'' Rep. Mary Rose Oakar, D-Ohio, said House Veterans Affairs Committee Chairman G.V. Sonny Montgomery, D-Miss., has agreed to investigate the allegations. Sen John Glenn, D-Ohio, also called for Veterans Affairs Secretary Ed Derwinski to investigate, and Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, said the hospital's director, Dr. Peter Stajduhar, should be suspended until the issue is resolved. ``PrimeTime Live'' reported that, among other things, bloodstained needles were not disposed of properly, asbestos was removed near patient quarters and one paralyzed patient was not fed for three days. Altose said that there are likely to be some failings in the quality of medical care in any large hospital dealing with seriously ill patients. He also said it was improper to draw conclusions based on the brief video shown in the report. The Cleveland hospital was selected for the investigation because it was ``a typical representation'' of the care at VA hospitals, ABC spokeswoman Rena Terracuso said. Altose said the allegations would be investigated and a VA medical inspector would visit the hospital. ``We welcome that visit,'' he said. ``We trust that he will look at, in depth, the goings on in this place and establish clearly, as we contend, that there is absolutely nothing to hide. There are not terrible things going on. This is in fact a fine medical center.''

DOC.HEAD: Gunman Had Firearms Despite History of Mental Illness, Criminal Record
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents of 7th graf, `He harangued....'.
DOC.TEXT: A gunman who killed a college student in a hostage standoff apparently stockpiled his weapons legally despite a history of criminal and mental problems, officials said Friday. Mehrdad Dashti was killed Thursday by police after a night of terror and sexual perversion at a popular student tavern near the University of California in Berkeley. The attack by the heavily armed man prompted calls for tighter gun control. ``Either this man with a history of being severely mentally disturbed was able to go in and legally buy a gun, or someone bought them for him and the gun registration laws aren't worth the paper they're written on,'' said Berkeley Mayor Loni Hancock. Dashti, 30, shared an apartment with Fred Smith, who described him as a devout Moslem who kept a 9mm semiautomatic pistol, a .45-caliber handgun, a .22-caliber pistol and a semiautomatic rifle. Dashti seized control of Henry's Publick House & Grille at the Durant Hotel, where he held 33 people hostage. Armed with three pistols and firing intermittently, he wounded several people and killed UC Berkeley student John Nicholas Sheehy, 22. He harangued American women as ``slutty'' and singled out blonde women for sexual abuse. He forced them to ``drop their pants'' and directed male hostages to sexually molest them with carrots he brought with him, said Phil Kim, an architecture student who escaped early in the siege. ``Yes, it happened,'' said a 26-year-old female hostage. ``This guy came up to me and apologized. I told him not to worry. We kind of faked it. I think most everyone else did too. It was beyond horrible.'' The standoff ended when police stormed the bar and killed Dashti. Of the nine people Dashti wounded, four remained hospitalized Friday, listed in good condition. The Iranian-born killer emigrated to the United States in the late 1970s and established permanent residency status by marrying an American woman in 1984. They divorced in 1987. Smith, 19, said the guns worried him at first, but Dashti assured him he was just a collector and that all were registered. The roomate said he didn't know about Dashti's mental problems or criminal record. Among Dashti's papers was a county health department document saying he had been diagnsed as a paranoid schizophrenic and was limited in his ability ``to think clearly, interact with others appropriately (and) control (his) impulses.'' A bottle of the medication stelazine, used for psychotics, was found in his bathroom. Dashti sent registered letters to President Bush, U.S. Supreme Court Chief Justice William Rehnquist and San Francisco Mayor Art Agnos, complaining that his brain was being used ``as some kind of communications device, radiolike, and the messages that are to be broadcasted out are sent to my mind and sent out from there.'' The letters to Bush and Rehnquist did not contain specific threats and Dashti was never investigated by the Secret Service, said agent Gene Thompson in San Francisco. He kept photocopies of those letters and others he wrote to the local FBI, the head of the federal Department of Health and Human Services, and ``the authority in charge.'' According to Alameda County probation officials, Dashti said ``he'd heard the voices of demons'' before he was arrested in 1988 for ramming 48 cars in Berkeley and Albany with his car. Dashti was wanted by San Francisco police for investigation of grand theft and other charges for allegedly trying to withdraw $16,000 from a bank account authorities said he helped set up last year with stolen checks. Dashti also was convicted for petty theft in 1979 and 1983. Neither the alleged felonies nor the misdemeanor convictions would have made it illegal for Dashti to buy guns. Similar calls for increased gun controls followed the January 1989 schoolyard massacre in Stockton, but laws passed afterward affected only assault rifles, not handguns like those wielded by Dashti. ``This terrible tragedy shows that the laws and the system are failing,'' Hancock said.

DOC.HEAD: Grenade Kills Soldier's Son in French Military Area
DOC.TEXT: Assailants tossed three grenades into a crowded cafe, killing the 9-year-old son of a French soldier and injuring 17 other people, including the boy's parents, officials said Friday. No one immediately claimed responsibility for the attack Thursday night in Djibouti, a small African country on the Red Sea that is used as a staging area for French forces sent to the Persian Gulf region. The cafe is frequented by French military personnel, and there was speculation the attack could represent a protest against France's military deployment against Iraq. All but two of those injured were French, officials said. The others were a West German and a Djiboutian, officials said. Six people remained hospitalized Friday, including the parents of the dead boy, according to medical officials. French President Francois Mitterrand expressed his ``horror'' at the ``cowardly attack.'' The harbor and airport in Djibouti, a former French territory, serve as support bases for French naval forces. There are 3,850 French troops stationed permanently in the small nation cradled between Ethiopia and Somalia. Interior Minister Khaireh Allaleh Hared said the attack was carried out by four people. The attackers arrived on foot, threw three grenades into the crowd on the terrace and left in a stolen taxi, according to Anne Suard, first secretary at the French Embassy in Djibouti. The taxi was found abandoned about 21 miles southwest of the capital, Hared said. The owner of the vehicle later was found tied up in the countryside. French soldiers were ordered to return to their base. The French commander, Gen. Claude Gautier, announced new security measures would be taken. The victim was the son of a soldier identified only as Sergeant-Major Nervet. Officials of the French army hospital said Nervet and his wive were in serious condition after being hit by grenade fragments in the abdomen. One of the injured people said the child, seated on his father's knee, shielded the man from the blast, medical officials said. After the attack, an unexploded grenade was found in front of the terrace of the L'Historil Cafe, about 100 yards away. In March 1987, a terrorist attack at L'Historil killed 12 people.

DOC.HEAD: Forest Service Adopts Thomas Plan; Logging May Fall Further
DOC.TEXT: The Forest Service on Friday adopted a plan to protect the northern spotted owl that Northwest lawmakers said will cause greater cuts in logging than the White House predicted last week. The service said it will follow guidelines put forth by Forest Service biologist Jack Ward Thomas in April. At that time, the service estimated the Thomas plan would cause Northwest federal timber harvests to fall by nearly 50 percent and result in the loss of more than 20,000 jobs. President Bush backed a White House task force last week that said the owl could be saved from extinction by reducing next year's harvests by only about 20 percent - from this year's 3.85 billion board feet to about 3 billion board feet. Rep. Denny Smith, R-Ore., a backer of the timber industry and critic of Thomas, said the new announcement on Friday means harvests will tumble to about 2.6 billion board feet. ``While the task force might have come forward saying we will cut 3.2 billion board feet, this means we have just accepted 2.6 billion. This is just a further cave-in to the folks that are trying to put us out of business,'' Smith said. The action came as environmentalists were preparing to return to federal court in Seattle to try to force the federal agency to accept a scientifically sound plan to protect the owl's habitat in the Northwest's old-growth forests. The Fish and Wildlife Service declared the rare owl a threatened species under the Endangered Species Act on June 22. Lawmakers said the Thomas proposal would be the most sweeping protection of wildlife in the history of the act, banning logging on 3 million acres of national forests currently open to harvests - an area larger than the state of Maryland.

DOC.HEAD: Court Puts Measures Back on Oregon Ballot
DOC.TEXT: The Oregon Supreme Court on Friday restored five voter initiative measures to the Nov. 6 ballot, reversing a ruling that had disqualified them on a technicality. The state high court announced its unanimous decision after hearing arguments on the appeal. The court had no further comment, saying written opinions would be issued at a later date. One of the five issues put back on the ballot would allow tax credits for partent who sent their children to parochial schools. Marion County Circuit Judge Richard Barber ruled Monday that the five initiatives were not eligible for the ballot because they lacked financial statements. The statements weren't included because of an earlier court rulings saying state officials missed a deadline for formally approving them. State law requires that financial estimates be printed on ballots and in the state Voter's Pamphlet for measures having a substantial impact on the state treasury. Other measures affected by the high court ruling would limit property taxes, shut down the Trojan nuclear plant until waste disposal requirements are met, ban some non-recyclable packaging, and set up a pilot work program for welfare applicants. In a secondary ruling, the Supreme Court upheld the earlier court decisions that had struck financial impact statements from three measures on grounds officials missed a deadline for approving them. Lawyers for backers of some measures told the Supreme Court the public's initiative rights shouldn't be breached because of procedural mistakes by the government. Mike Reynolds, an assistant attorney general, said the fiscal statement law is ambiguous and should be construed ``so as not to abort the right of initiative.'' But Robert Durham, a lawyer for foes of the tax measures, said voters have a ``material right'' to have financial statements. The measures his clients oppose have ``potentially catastrophic, multi-billion dollar impacts,'' he said. Elections officials have said the fiscal statements might be posted in voting booths as a substitute for having them on the ballot or in the Voters' Pamphlet.

DOC.HEAD: Burma Says Reports on Detention of Embassy Staff Exaggerated
DOC.TEXT: The military government Friday dismissed as exaggerations reports about international reaction to detentions and interrogations of Burmese staff at some foreign embassies. A Foreign Ministry statement broadcast on state radio and television was issued in response to radio reports about the action at the British, U.S. and Australian Embassies. The British Broadcasting Corp. and the Voice of America reported Friday that protests were filed by the 12 members of the European Community and other countries including Japan, Canada and the United States. But the Burmese statement said the protests were filed separately by the nations since last week. ``The broadcast gave the impression that the international community was collectively protesting the legal measures taken by the Burmese government,'' the foreign ministry statement said. ``It is regrettable to note that what should have been a simple diplomatic exercise by a few diplomats in the Rnngoon diplomatic corps has become grossly exaggerated,'' it said. A diplomat in Bangkok Thursday said the Burmese government had detained Burmese staff of the Australian, British and U.S. embassies. He also said armed troops entered the compound of the West German Embassy last week and that similar action had been taken a number of times against U.S. and British diplomatic compounds. In Washington Thursday, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said the United States had strongly protested after Burmese officials detained and interrogated four employees of the U.S. Embassy. The military government has detained large numbers of dissidents since it seized power in 1988 by crushing a democracy movement.

DOC.HEAD: Nearly 8,000 Military Positions To Be Cut In Washington State
DOC.TEXT: The Army announced Friday the deactivation of the 9th Motorized Infantry Division and the activation of a separate motorized brigade at Fort Lewis, Wash., as part of a five-year military reduction plan. The deactivation of the 9th will eliminate approximately 7,900 military positions at Fort Lewis by the end of fiscal 1992. It will also trim about 226 civilian and 121 military support slots from a total civilian work force at Fort Lewis of 3,842. It was not clear how large the new brigade would be. Brigades generally have about 2,000 personnel. Over the next several years population at the base will eventually grow by 3,000 as a result of the Army's plans to close Fort Ord, Calif., and ship 10,000 soldiers of Fort Ord's 7th Light Infantry division to Fort Lewis, said George Behan, press secretary to Rep. Norm Dicks, D-Wash. Behan said 2,900 military personnel will be cut on Oct. 1, another 3,100 in the next fiscal year and 1,900 in fiscal 1992. ``This is part of the overall effort over the next five years that the Army is planning for a reduction in size and the move of people into the reserves,'' said Kraig Naasz, press secretary to Sen. Slade Gorton, R-Wash. Naasz said the Senate Armed Services Committee wants to cut 100,000 people from the nation's current military forces over the next five years. There are now about 2.1 million men and women in the armed forces. The army has 18 active divisions, ranging from less than 10,000 to more than 15,000 troops.

DOC.HEAD: Driver Stoned to Death During Protest Strike
DOC.TEXT: Protesters stoned to death a taxi driver Friday during a three-day strike against government-authorized price increases, police said. One other person was killed and 30 were injured - including a couple burned in their car - in strike-related violence since Wednesday. Police said they arrested 300 people, but strike organizers claimed Friday at least 1,000 protesters had been detained. The strike was called to protest a government belt-tightening program imposed in August to control inflation and bolster the Caribbean nation's sagging economy. The country's nine major unions did not take part, limiting the impact of the strike. Government subsidies have been lifted from many basic consumer items such as flour and rice. Insome cases, prices doubled or tripled. The state-controlled gasoline prices have tripled to nearly $1.50 per gallon since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, and the government began gasoline rationing earlier this week. Pedro Bautista, 37, was attacked after driving his cab into a street barricaded with burning tires in San Cristobal, about 17 miles east of the capital. Police spokesman Ramon de la Cruz Martinez said Bautista was pulled from the taxi and pelted with stones, and died later at a hospital. The protest was led by a new political alliance, the Popular Organizations Collective, with support from five leftist political parties. Three students were killed last Sunday making a bomb at the state university.On Wednesday, police in Santiago, the country's second-largest city, said they discovered an arsenal of homemade bombs and explosives. The Popular Organizations Collective denied any connection with the university deaths or the arsenal. A two-day nationwide strike in August paralyzed the nation of 7 million people and led to clashes between police and protesters. At least 12 people were killed, 60 were wounded and 2,000 arrested.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Upholds Texas At-Large Elections For Judges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf, `A three-judge...'. to CORRECT that 15 sted 13 judges comprise full panel, but only 13 took part on voting question. SUBS last graf to CLARIFY that ruling in Mississippi case upheld by special three-judge panel sted 5th Circuit.
DOC.TEXT: The Texas system of electing district judges by countywide voting was upheld Friday by a federal appeals court that said questions about possibly diluted minority voting strength do not apply. Protections against diluting the voting power of minorities have no bearing on the election of judges because they are not public servants, the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled 12-1. Judge Sam D. Johnson of Austin, Texas, in a scathing 47-page dissent, wrote: ``The majority opinion is not simply wrong, it is dangerous.'' The decision affects nine Texas counties but has possible broader applications. It came hours before a similar challenge was to be argued in a Baton Rouge federal court. Another challenge is pending in Georgia, which is in a different federal appeals court circuit. The majority opinion, written by Judge Thomas Gibbs Gee of Houston, said judges, unlike legislators and other elected officials, are not public servants. In fact, they often must defy public opinion to carry out the law, he wrote. Gee wrote that Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act, an amendment passed in 1982, was a test to determine what dilutes voting strength, but it stopped short of imposing such a test for judicial offices. ``Should Congress seek to install such a test for judicial elections, it must say so plainly,'' he wrote. ``Instead, it has thus far plainly said the contrary.'' In his dissent, Johnson called the majority decision completely isolated from other rulings. ``No previous court has ever even suggested that judicial elections might be exempt from the reach of Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act,'' he wrote. ``To the contrary, this court ... had earlier concluded that Section 2 applied to all elections, including judicial elections. ``Not only does the majority opinion reverse this two-year-old precedent, but it also demonstrates a shocking lack of concern for the urgently argued position of the attorney general, who has consistently maintained that the Voting Rights Act reaches all elections.'' The case was brought to court by the League of United Latin American Citizens, which argued that countywide voting for state judges in nine urban counties prevents minorities from electing the candidates they want. U.S. District Judge Lucius Bunton of Midland agreed and ordered the state to divide the nine counties into electoral subdistricts. Those counties - Dallas, Harris, Bexar, Tarrant, Travis, Lubbock, Midland, Ector and Jefferson - elect 172 of Texas' 390 district judges. A three-judge panel of the 5th Circuit upheld the Texas system, however. It then brought the case back before the entire panel for reconsideration. Thirteen of the 15 circuit court members participated. An attorney for the group said they'll appeal to the Supreme Court. ``We think that any election system that discriminates on the basis of race and ethnicity is inconsistent with the most basic Democratic principles of our society,'' said Rolando Rios of San Antonio. The Texas and Louisiana cases are virtually identical. ``We're just delighted with the opinion,'' said John Kennedy, legal counsel for Louisiana Gov. Buddy Roemer. ``It's a complete victory.'' In the Louisiana case, U.S. District Judge John Parker ordered that 11 districts be redesigned to enhance the chance of electing black judges. Only six of Louisiana's 254 district and appellate court judges are black. Also at issue in Louisiana is a state Supreme Court district in New Orleans, the only district in the state represented by two justices elected at large. A similar challenge in Mississippi led to special judicial elections being held in 1989 under a federal court order. U.S. District Judge William H. Barbour Jr. of Jackson was the first federal judge in the nation to apply Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act to judicial elections. His ruling, which said the state's judicial districts discriminated against blacks, was upheld by a special three-judge federal panel appointed to review the decision.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Appeals Court Rules Mississippi Colleges Don't Discriminate
DOC.TEXT: Years of discrimination at Mississippi state colleges are over, a federal appeals court ruled Friday. ``The record makes clear that Mississippi has adopted and implemented race neutral policies for operating its colleges and universities and that all students have real freedom of choice to attend the college or university they wish,'' Judge John M. Duhe Jr. wrote in Friday's majority decision issued by the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in New Orleans. The 10-4 decision by the appeals court reversed a finding by a three-judge panel of the 5th Circuit that Mississippi illegally operates separate universities for blacks and whites and that opening admissions to all races in 1962 didn't go far enough. Mississippi operates three predominantly black universities and five that have a majority of white students. The late Jake Ayers filed the suit in 1975 on behalf of his son, Jake Ayers Jr., then in high school, and 20 other black students. The case was closely watched in Louisiana, where a similar challenge is pending over the status of predominantly black schools like Grambling, Southern, and others. William F. Goodman Jr. of Jackson, attorney for the State College Board, praised the ruling. ``It removes the doubts about the legality of the Mississippi system of higher education,'' Goodman said. ``Secondly, the decision vindicates the efforts of many people over the past 20 years who have worked so hard to integrate the system.'' Morris Kinsey, chairman of the education committee of the Mississippi NAACP, said the decision creates another obstacle to getting more funding for black colleges. ``I am stunned by this one,'' Kinsey said. ``I guess we'll just have to take our appeal further. We were concerned that when we had the arguments before the full court that they were not interested in our arguments.'' Justice Department officials in Washington, who argued Mississippi fostered discrimination through college admission requirements and failing to upgrade facilities at black schools, said they were reviewing the decision and would not have any immediate comment. Chief Judge Charles Clark of Mississippi did not take part in the decision.

Saddam Hussein is moving to transform Kuwait into an Iraqi province by altering the country's demography, erasing its national identity and removing its infrastructure, U.S. analysts say. ``What we are seeing is the de-Kuwaitization of Kuwait. This is the history of the Iraqi regime,'' one U.S. official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The Iraqi president has been changing Kuwait since the Aug. 2 invasion - even renaming streets and institutions to eliminate signs of the ousted government, officials said. Every passing day takes the country further away from what it once was. At the same time, the Kuwaiti resistance inside the occupied country is faltering. ---= MANILA, Philippines (AP) - A court today convicted 16 soldiers in the murder of President Corazon Aquino's husband but failed to say who ordered the assassination which set the stage for the 1986 revolution. The impact of the decision was further clouded by the court's acquittal of 20 people in the 1983 slaying of Sen. Benigno ``Ninoy'' Aquino, the country's top opposition leader at the time. Other defendants, including a former military chief of staff, have fled the country to avoid prosecution. The verdict in the 3{-year trial was announced on the first anniversary of the death of the late dictator Ferdinand Marcos, who many Filipinos believe ordered the Aquino's slaying. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is wielding less and less power and is in danger of becoming irrelevant as restive Soviet republics wrest authority from the central government, a senior administration official says. The official, insisting on anonymity, said Thursday that Gorbachev's loss of power is a bigger threat to him than any coup by the military. Rumors of a military takeover have surfaced in Moscow in recent days, but the senior official discounted that possibility. It is highly unusual that a government official - even when guaranteed protection against being identified - would offer such a candid and damaging assessment of a world leader of Gorbachev's stature. Moreover, the portrayal of Gorbachev as a faltering figure clashes with the picture that President Bush tried to project when he flew thousands of miles to Helsinki this month to stand alongside the Soviet president in a demonstration that the superpowers are united against Iraq in the Persian Gulf crisis. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Supreme Court nominee David Souter can expect an easy confirmation vote in the Senate next week following a lopsided endorsement by the Judiciary Committee. But the breadth of voting support enjoyed by the Nw Hampshire jurist belies widespread doubt lawmakers are expressing about what kind of justice he'll make. ``I will vote for Judge Souter's confirmation. I do not do so enthusiastically,'' Judiciary Committee Chairman Joseph Biden said before his panel voted 13-1 in favor of Souter on Thursday. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., was the dissenter. If President Bush takes the ease of Souter's approval as a sign it can easily win an even more conservative choice in the future, he would be wrong, said Biden, D-Del.
