DOC.HEAD: Common Sense and Capital Gains
DOC.TEXT: Does it make sense to penalize the middle class in order to deny the wealthy? Elected officials argued in recent weeks that to accede to President Bush's wish and lower the maximum capital gains tax to 15 percent from 28 percent would disproportionately benefit the rich. That would never do, they said. What many opponents failed to explain is that a lower tax also would benefit the hard-working middle class, including many farmers, owners of small businesses, small investors and various other less-than-rich Americans. It would help farmers who built up a valuable property from nothing and who now wish to retire, homeowners whose financial gains on a property sale exceed the deductible limit, entrepreneurs who created value out of an idea. The big investor would benefit from lower taxes, but so would the investor who put $3,000 into stocks in 1985, saw them ``grow'' to $3,500 in 1990, and who, after taxes, commissions and inflation, has about a $180 profit. Had that person put the money in a relatively riskless savings account earning just over 5 percent annually, the after-tax, after-inflation profit might have been more than double that. This is but one example of inconsistencies in the capital gains debate, during which the issue became so embroiled in politics that several of the important financial and social implications were lost. It takes capital investments, for example, to develop new businesses which create wealth, provide jobs and eventually grow large enough to compete with larger companies, thus adding to market competition and fair pricing. It takes people with ideas, too, and often those people do not have the capital. Unlike existing businesses that have ready access to capital from pension funds, the beginners must beg for capital. And they must offer something in return. What they offer investors is a reasonable hope that the company will succeed and repay them for accepting the risk and the long-term commitment of their funds. In the capital gains debate, profit was mentioned far more than risk, but profit is never assured in capital investments, whereas risk is. Risk means the possibility of loss, and that possibility is high. Small companies often fail. There has to be a good inducement, therefore, for investors to commit money to risky but economically and socially worthwhile ventures. But taxes and long-term inflation, beginners will tell you, sometimes destroy that inducement. Throughout the debate, references were made to the tax-deferred aspect of capital investments, but less was said about the long-term commitment of those funds, which, of course, precludes their use in any other way. That issue might seem minor, but that commitment of funds can be for a lifetime, during which the investor might build a large operation but have a relatively small income. His wealth is committed; it cannot be withdrawn. Perhaps the most positive result of the debate was to clarify the meaning of profit. If profit really was what it was defined as being by otherwise informed people, then everyone would be rich. Inflation, they said, was profit. On reflection, everyone understands that inflation is a minus. It is deducted from ``profit.'' Ten percent inflation wipes out a 5 percent wage increase and leaves you with a 5 percent loss, not a profit. Somehow, that reasoning was not always applied to capital gains, where inflation was called profit even by political leaders who claimed to have thoroughly analyzed the issue. In fact, inflation was actually taxed as profit. That irony at least has been clarified.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Monday, October 1.

For Release Thursday PMs, Oct. 4 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Italy's Communist Party Admits to Role in 100s of Postwar Killings
DOC.TEXT: An aging Communist has reopened one of the darkest chapters of Italy's postwar history, charging that his party was behind a three-year reign of terror in a region dubbed the ``triangle of death.'' The Communist, Otello Montanari, has accused his party of covering up its members' role in the hundreds of killings that plagued north-central Italy for years after dictator Benito Mussolini was killed. He also revealed that the Communist Party helped the killers flee to Czechoslovakia. In response to his charges, the Communist Party has finally admitted it bore some responsibility for the rash of slayings in the so-called ``triangle of death.'' The disclosures by Montanari, 65, have shocked many Italians and led to a re-evaluation of the anti-Fascist Resistance, one of the country's most revered ideals. The debate has also widened a split in the West's largest Communist Party, already reeling from the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe. ``Forty-five years have gone by. It's time to attentively judge these affairs. It is necessary for democracy, for the Resistance,'' Montanari said in an Aug. 28 letter to a Bologna newspaper that sparked the debate. The triangle of death was part of the ``red zone'' of northern Italy. Even today, it is dominated by the Communist Party, the country's second-biggest party. When Mussolini was killed in April 1945, Communists and other Resistance fighters went on a two-month orgy of revenge. At least 12,000 people, most suspected of supporting fascism, were slain before a new government restored order. But in the triangle of death - bounded by the cities of Modena, Reggio Emilia and Bologna - the killings continued for another three years. Hundreds more people were slain, including former Fascist officials, factory managers, landowners and Roman Catholic priests. Montanari, a former partisan and party leader in Reggio Emilia, charged some Communist officials in the area had ``an attitude of tolerance, of covering-up and even of close cooperation'' with the killers. ``Whoever knows about it, must speak,'' he appealed. His call has led to an outpouring of new details in national newspapers and on television from Communists and relatives of victims, some breaking decades of silence. Their accounts, as well as newly publicized academic research, indicate Communist ex-partisans carried out many of the killings. They depict a Communist Party leadership that publicly blamed ex-Fascists for the murders, but secretly helped scores of those responsible to escape to Yugoslavia and then Czechoslovakia, which had come under Communist rule. ``It has been the end of a myth,'' said Ennio Dinolfo, a professor at the University of Florence who has written a book about Italian history from 1943-53. ``The party did its best to keep this hidden.'' The disclosures have sometimes been painful for a country that often seems to gloss over its Fascist past while enshrining the Resistance. ``It was Italy's one claim to respectability'' after the war, noted Oxford University historian Denis Mack Smith, a specialist on Italy. The new accusations have particularly angered the older, hard-line members of the Communist Party. Many took part in the Resistance, which included a large number of Communists and other parties. ``To repudiate the Resistance means to destroy the principal pillar on which the civil co-existence of the postwar period is built,'' said five party officials, all former partisans, in a statement. Two thousand people gathered in Reggio Emilia on Sept. 8 for a silent march to protest a hastily called congress by neo-Fascists to re-examine the killings in the triangle of death. ``Hands off the Resistance,'' read one of their signs. The Communists emphasize that their postwar leader, Palmiro Togliatti, condemned the violence in the triangle of death. But the young reformers who now dominate the Italian Communist Party, or PCI, have called for ``glasnost'' and a re-examination of the period. ``The initiative of Otello Montanari ... brings to light the responsibility of the PCI and of its leadership, and we must reflect on this,'' said Piero Fassino, the party's director of organization. Part of the controversy about the killings is why the information has only emerged now, more than a decade after scholars began discovering it. Some observers say the younger Communists are trying to use the disclosures to discredit their older rivals, who oppose efforts to reform the party and drop the Communist name. Others say the information has emerged because the Communists fear Czechoslovakia's new democratic government might have made some of it public soon. Giorgio Bocca, a newspaper columnist and author of several books on postwar Italy, said the scandal is tied to the decline of the Communist Party in recent years. ``When the PCI was strong, everybody shut up, even the middle-class newspapers,'' he said in a telephone interview. He and others say that the dominant Christian Democrat party worked closely with the opposition Communists in the past, and didn't want to embarrass them.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Thursday PMs, Oct. 4
$Adv05
For Release Friday PMs, Oct. 5 and Thereafter ^Peace Corps Volunteers Pioneering in Eastern Europe
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: The idealism that cushioned East Europeans through last year's democratic upheavals has begun to wane. But a small group of Americans is hoping to show there is still a place for such dreams. The first Peace Corps volunteers in Eastern Europe are infecting Hungarians with some of the idealism on which America has prospered. For Hungarians and other East Europeans, the initial euphoria at throwing off four decades of Communism has given way to gloom as people struggle to make ends meet amid inflation, unemployment and the vageries of a new political and economic system. The 57 enthusiastic Peace Corps volunteers are teaching a valuable skill that will help break down four decades of Cold War barriers. They also will help alleviate a sense of isolation inevitable after 40 years of Soviet domination, anti-Western propaganda and restricted travel. Bonita Plymale, 39, who has been assigned to a new teacher-training college, said she thought Hungarians also felt cut off because their language is unrelated to any of the main European language families and difficult to learn. Dave Billett, 27, a volunteer at a dilapidated school on Budapest's Csepel island - a workers' district - said the contact with Americans enabled Hungarians to see that ``the basic human (and) societal problems are the same'' in the West. Hungarian teachers have told volunteers they gain confidence from conversation with native English teachers. Behind the Iron Curtain, English teachers themselves often have never spoken to native speakers. For the Peace Corps, the assignments in Hungary and Poland fulfill what director Paul Coverdell says was a long-standing goal of bringing U.S. skills and culture to Eastern Europe. The Cold War kept the Peace Corps out for four decades. Now, ``the wall is down and the Peace Corps is clambering over it,'' Coverdell said in an interview at the organization's cramped Budapest office. The volunteers who took up teaching posts in every county in Hungary in September were all ages and from varied backgrounds. But they were united in a desire to contribute to Hungary's struggle to get equal with the West in democratic principles and opportunities. Plymale traced her motivation for leaving Highland High School in Albuquerque, N.M., after 17 years to the ideals of the 1960s, when the Peace Corps got off the ground. ``I think there are many people in the United States who are taking stock of what they're doing and maybe going back to some of the ideals we had in the late 60s and early 70s,'' she said. Another reason she cited is likely to surprise Hungarians, dazzled by the variety of goods available in the West to consumers who can afford to buy them. Plymale, who headed her school's English department for the last six years, said she wanted to get away from ``worrying about how much money I'm making.'' Coverdell said interest in the Peace Corps has increased dramatically recently, partly as a result of rapid changes around the world. It was President Bush who proposed during his visit to Hungary in July 1989 that Peace Corps volunteers come to Hungary and Poland. Coverdell said he hopes the organization, which has about 7,000 volunteers in Africa, Asia and Central and South America, will send people soon to most countries in the former East bloc. A Peace Corps program is to begin in Prague, Czechoslovakia, in November. Coverdell said Bulgaria and Yugoslavia are also interested in English teachers. In Romania, a team is looking at children's health to determine whether the Peace Corps could be of assistance. Laszlo Vida, a senior Hungarian Education Ministry official, said he hopes to see the Peace Corps program expanded. ``We are very pleased to have the Peace Corps here,'' Vida said. Students appeared to echo that enthusiasm. On the second day of class, children in his secondary school begged him to stay beyond the two-year Peace Corps assignment, Billett said. Plymale and Billett, a freelance TV production manager in Hollywood before he joined the Peace Corps, both said that in addition to telling Hungarians about the United States, they had a lot to learn from the Hungarians. Plymale said she found the Hungarian educational system ``excellent'' and hoped to learn new techniques. Billett, who is eager to learn Hungarian, was impressed with stories he has heard from Hungarians about their experience of the past 40 years. Despite the hardship, he said, ``they still have a sense of humor.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Friday PMs, Oct. 5

For release PMs Mon, Oct. 1, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: PBS' Top Science Show Opens Season with ... a Comedy-Drama?
DOC.TEXT: The most delightful program on television Tuesday night is a mystery-comedy-espionage thriller about a mild-mannered astronomer who tracks down a KGB-financed spy ring. It's the true story of Clifford Stoll, a tale of suspense, high technology, international intrigue, wonderful sight gags - even a shower scene! - and it's the season premiere of ``Nova,'' PBS' fine science documentary series. ``The KGB, the Computer and Me,'' is Stoll's account, re-enacted by him and the other people involved, of his two-year hunt for a computer hacker who had systematically penetrated the U.S. network of military and academic computers. In August 1986, Stoll was a stock comic figure of academe: a scientist whose grant had expired. With his wiry shock of dark hair and laid-back wardrobe, he looks more like a Grateful Dead fan (which he is) than an astronomer. Fortunately for him and the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory at the University of California at Berkeley, the lab needed a manager for its computer system, and he was hired. On his first day in his new job, the boss asks him to track down a 75-cent discrepancy in the computer billing report. ``Thousands of dollars of charges, off by 75 cents, didn't sound like much,'' Stoll noted, ``but it was an interesting problem. A big error would mean an obvious bug in the system, easy to find and fix. ``But 75 cents? That was a challenge!'' And thereby hangs a fascinating story about science, scientists and the business of doing science. The 75-cent error eventually led Stoll to the electronic fingerprints of a hacker who'd used a personal computer and telephone connection to break into the Berkeley computer system from far away. ``He was really like a burglar who knows a few ways to burglarize a house and uses them over and over again,'' Stoll recounted in a telephone interview. ``He tries the front door, the back door, and pushes on a couple of windows, and when he can't get in, he moves on. ``He figures, `Sooner or later I'll find one where somebody left the key in the door.' '' Tight computer security - like burglar bars on windows - make the ``environment'' more difficult for its legitimate occupants as well as potential invaders. The hacker was exploiting the system's openness. Once inside the computer, the hacker used standard programming techniques to exploit a ``bug'' in the computer's operating system and take it over. Invisibly, the hacker had made himself a ``super-user'' able to read, write, erase and remove any file in the program. Stoll was angry and appalled. Part of the lab's computer system is used in high-energy radiation therapy for certain brain tumors. The hacker was fooling with computer programs that aim heavy radiation into living people's brains. ``When you screw around with systems that you don't know about, you can't predict what the effects will be,'' Stoll said. ``He thought he knew and he didn't.'' It would have been a simple matter to lock out the hacker, fix the bug in the system and wrap things up, but Stoll wanted to catch him or her or it. And, to his growing concern, the hacker was using the Lawrence Berkeley computer to move around on the network of university and non-classified Defense Department computers around the country. The hacker was intruding into military databases, defense contractors, even the Pentagon. True, none of the material was classified, but it also wasn't the kind of information you read in the newspapers, either. Stoll went to the FBI. A 75-cent error? They weren't interested. Stoll's quest ultimately led him to ``various three-letter agencies'' that included the CIA and the ultra-secret NSA. ``It was frustrating to find people who really are bureaucrats, who very much want to help but can't because of the structure of where they work,'' Stoll said. ``The rumors that you hear are true: The government would like to help you, but it can't. It just doesn't know how,'' he said. Stoll persisted, and his efforts eventually led to the arrest, trial and conviction of a group of West German hackers with links to the KGB. Stoll even testified at their trial. The story he re-enacts, and his equally fascinating book about the case, ``The Cuckoo's Egg,'' are about science, Stoll insists. ``A lot of the time we think the idea of science is to come up with answers,'' he said. ``That is so bogus! ``If you're doing good science, you don't care what the answer is. You want to find the process, the method. You passionately want to find the procedure. It seems to me the work I did in catching this hacker would have been just as satisfying if it had turned out to be some teen-ager down the block.'' --- Elsewhere in television ... THE AMERICAN EXPERIENCE: PBS's excellent documentary series, ``The American Experience,'' starts tonight with ``Lindbergh,'' a one-hour portrait of the great aviator that tries to look beyond the legend and find the man. Narrated by Stacy Keach, the program features seldom seen archival footage and photos, and new interviews with his wife, the often reclusive Anne Morrow Lindbergh, and two of the Lindberghs' children.

DOC.HEAD: Uncertainty Pervades Election Outlook in House Races
DOC.TEXT: Elections for the nation's 435 House seats are likely to yield only slight shifts in power, but analysts caution that this year's voting could be among the most volatile and unpredictable in years. November's balloting will follow ``one of the strangest 18 months in recent political history,'' analyst Charles Cook says of a period that has seen upheavals in Eastern Europe, the Persian Gulf, domestic issues and the American economy. Few are willing to bet on where it all will lead, but most analysts and operatives are guessing that Democrats will pad their 258-to-176 majority by less than 10 seats. In normal times, that would be a face-saving outcome for Republicans. As the party in control of the White House, the GOP historically could expect to lose 15 or more House seats in an off-year election. Several factors would seem to favor the GOP this time around. President Bush enjoys near-record popularity ratings, his standing increased by his handling of the Middle East crisis. And polls show a general public disgust with Congress, which is controlled by the Democrats. But on the other side of the ledger, the economy - among the most powerful determinants of political fortune - is headed downward. And Republicans are being forced to defend more so-called ``open'' seats, where there is no incumbent seeking re-election, because 11 otherwise safe GOP House members are running for the Senate or state offices. The effect of the volatility has been to put most races into slow motion. Congress, which had planned to adjourn by Oct. 5 so members could go home and campaign, now is unlikely to get out of Washington until Oct. 20 or so. Issues that have taken on local importance, from abortion to taxes and the savings and loan crisis, have had to compete for air time and headlines with developments in Iraq and Kuwait. Political experts say the effect will be to compress the intense part of the election season into the final two weeks. For one in five House districts, that will make no difference. Seventy-six incumbent lawmakers - 42 Democrats and 34 Republicans - will coast to re-election without major party opposition. And, as has become common in House contests, few of their colleagues have much to worry about. Political analysts single out fewer than two dozen races where the incumbent is endangered. Topping that list are Reps. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., Charles Pashayan, R-Calif., and Denny Smith, R-Ore., all of whom are linked to the $500 billion scandal over the failure of the savings and loan industry. A handful of others are in trouble because of political or ethical problems: - Rep. Arlan Stangeland, R-Minn., got in hot water for running up hundreds of long-distance calls to a former female staffer on his official House credit card. - It was revealed that Rep. Roy Dyson, D-Md., who accepts large contributions from the defense industry in his capacity as an Armed Services Committee member, claimed conscientious objector status during the Vietnam War. - Rep. Stan Parris, R-Va., said during a debate with his Democratic opponent that he opposes affirmative action because ``it is worse to discriminate against majorities'' than against racial minorities. And always vulnerable are freshmen, many of whom won narrowly in 1988 and have yet to establish themselves firmly in their new seats: Ben Jones, D-Ga.; George Sangmeister, D-Ill.; Bill Sarpalius, D-Texas; Greg Laughlin, D-Texas; Peter Hoagland, D-Neb.; Jolene Unsoeld, D-Wash.; Craig James, R-Fla.; Ron Machtley, R-R.I.; and Peter Smith, R-Vt. Most of the action, and the attention of Democratic and Republican party operatives, focuses on the 29 open seats where there is no incumbent. Eleven are seats previously held by Democrats, and 18 were formerly GOP seats. One hotspot is Maine's First District, where Democrat Joseph Brennan is running to get back his old job as governor. Fighting for Brennan's House seat are Democratic state Sen. Tom Andrews and Republican David Emery, who is making a comeback bid. Also tough for Democrats to defend is the Cincinnati district of Thomas Luken, who is retiring. Luken's son, Mayor Charles Luken, is vying against Ken Blackwell, a former Cincinnati mayor and official of the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Blackwell is the GOP's best hope of electing a black Republican to a House seat in five decades. A slugfest has developed in the Texas, where Democratic Rep. Marvin Leath is retiring. State Sen. Chet Edwards, a Democrat, is running to replace him against Republican Hugh Shine, a state House member. Shine has been attacking Edwards for appearing at a fund-raiser for a gay and lesbian group in Houston last year. Democrats see their best hopes at picking open seats in Arkansas, where Democrat-turned-Republican Tommy Robinson left his seat to run for governor; and in Rhode Island, Hawaii, Iowa and Idaho, where Republican House members are running for Senate seats.

DOC.HEAD: 500 Years Later, Latin American Indians Renew Fight Against Whites
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: From Mexico to Chile, millions of Latin American Indians, descendants of warriors who fought the Spanish conquerors five centuries ago, are again rising against the white man. The new fighting spirit was sparked by official plans to celebrate in 1992 the 500th year of the discovery of America by Spain. But the real goals are better living conditions and equal rights to land, schools, health care and jobs. A survey by Associated Press correspondents shows the region's 30 million Indians are by far the poorest segment of Latin America's 437 million residents. Various reports from U.N. agencies, governments and private groups had come to the same conclusion, based on Indians' poor general living conditions, generally inadequate housing, lack of frequent access to utilities, and even more limited access, if any, to education. Most non-Indian Latin Americans view the discovery celebrations as a tribute to the merging of the European and Indian culture, and to the Spanish legacy. For the Indians, it is a sour reminder of what they see as bloody conquest and material and cultural spoliation. The Spanish conquerors transferred tons of gold and silver to Spain from the newly discovered land, especially from Mexico and Peru, after dominating the natives in bloody wars. ``The Spanish conquest must be repudiated. Celebrating it would shameful and the justification of a massacre,'' said Manuel Castro, an Indian leader in Ecuador. Nearly everywhere in Latin America, Indian organizations are protesting the plans for solemnly marking the centennial, which includes a visit to the region in October by the Spanish king and queen. Many are seeking elimination of Columbus Day - Oct. 12 - as a holiday. They demand it be declared ``a day of Indian dignity.'' Genaro Dominguez, leader of the Regional Coordinating Agency of nndian Peoples in Mexico, Central America and the Caribbean said that instead of marking Oct. 12 with a tribute to Columbus, Indians in his region are paying homage to Mexico's Indian leader, Cuahutemoc. But the new fight centers most on demands for progress on Indians' social and economic problems. About 300 delegates from 120 Indian groups gathered last July in Quito, Ecuador, and passed a resolution vowing to fight for autonomy, saying the centennial ``opens a new stage in the struggle of our peoples.'' Indians in Latin America seldom have access to their nations' job market. Those who emigrate to the cities often end up getting low menial jobs, though there have been reports of Indian professional success stories recently in Guatemala, and most complain of what they call discrimination from ``the white man.'' Others remaining in wartorn countryside such as El Salvador and Peru live in shacks in ``reducciones,'' small plots of generally poor land, remnants of the sprawling territories their ancestors once owned. Most reducciones lack basic services such as electricity and running water. Besides, urban emigration worsens racism and discrimination, said Marcelino Cayuqueo, an Araucano Indian leader in Argentina. In addition to facing widespread prejudices, ``such as the belief that all Indians are lazy, dirty and drink too much,'' said Chilean Mapuche Indian leader Jose Ancan, many of them develop what sociologists call ``the Indian syndrome.'' Cayuqueo described the syndrome ``as an instinctive rejection by Indians to accept their condition as such.'' That's a common problem among Mexico's 15 million Indians, nearly one-fourth of the Mexican population. Those who emigrate to the cities usually only get modest jobs, such as domestic work, or end up begging in the streets. Arturo Warman, an executive of Mexico's Institute of Indian Studies, said there are about 5 million Indians ``living under extreme poverty'' in that country. Illiteracy is rampant. About 350,000 Indians in Honduras are reported plagued by poverty and disease, living in hamlets in remote mountain areas. Meliton Garcia, a Mexican Indian leader, said the proper way to mark the centennial would be ``by solving our problems.'' Indian leaders say the solution to their problems must begin with the recognition by the governments of their ethnic traditions, cultures, language and religions, and the restoration of their land. Last month, 800 Bolivian Indians walked through the jungle lowlands from Amazonia to the mountain city of La Paz to demand land from the government. President Jaime Paz Zamora promised to meet their demands. In Bolivia, where Indians or dominantly Indian mixed-race people account for about 80 percent of a population of 6.9 million, they complain of discrimination from the white minority. Most Indian leaders complain they also lack legislation to protect them. Or, if it exists, it doesn't work. ``The laws are good in theory, but they are not implemented, or simply there is no money,'' said Julio Estrada, secretary of the Colombian National Organization. In Ecuador, Indians account for 35 percent of the Andean nation's 10 million people. Last August, they showed their strength by staging two ``uprisings'' - for three days, they seized a number of highways and farms to press the government for solutions to their problems. Indians angrily dispute the notion of discovery of their land by the Spaniards, saying, ``You don't discover a land that is already populated.'' They also reject the Roman Catholic Church joining the celebrations to mark the ``evangelization'' on the New World. ``They imposed their God on people who already had their God or Gods,'' said Mapuche leader Ancan. Added Juan Carlos Ramirez, executive director of Costa Rica's National Commission of Indian Affairs, ``The celebrations have been poorly conceived. The notion of discovery is diminishing to Indian peoples.'' Political groups, especially from the left, and some missionary organizations have gained influence over the Indian movement. The Mexico-based Council for the Restoration of Indian Rights admitted that the combative opposition to the centennial celebrations ``has political connotations.'' One of the most widespread and controversial Indian demands is the restoration of part of their ancestors' land they claim was illegally taken from them by force by white farmers. ``We want restoration of our land now,'' said Numa Mallorquiin, an Indian leader in Paraguay. Indians also claim they will not be fully integrated to the societies in their country unless the governments officially implement bilingual education in the schools. War is long gone, but violence is often still part of life for Indians, including a handful of tribes still living in primitive isolation. In Brazil, where conquerors came from Portugal, not Spain, the Missionary Indian Council, a Catholic group promoting Indian rights, recently denounced what it called ``the genocide of the Yanomani,'' considered the world's largest primitive tribe. Since 1987, the Council said, 1,500 out of 9,000 Yanomanis in northern Brazil have been killed by white men attracted by gold and diamond mines discovered on their land. An offshoot of the Yanomanis not known to exist was discovered this summer in southern Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Dividends Become Increasingly Vulnerable to Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Has Chase Manhattan Bank become the trendsetter among banks when it comes to slashing dividends? That question has had the industry abuzz ever since Chase sliced its payout to shareholders in half little more than a week ago. Regionals Midlantic Corp. and Southeast Banking Corp. shortly thereafter said that they would cut or eliminate their dividends, followed by similar announcement from the bigger Bank of Boston. ``We're still in a very awkward phase here,'' said Merrill Lynch & Co. analyst Judah Kraushaar. ``Many banks are reluctant to compare themselves with Chase.'' Still, experts agree that Chase's move takes the edge off other institutions, which now feel they can trim dividends without a major public relations disaster. High dividend yields - which have been approaching 20 percent of earnings for some big banks - have helped lure investors and prop up the price of bank stocks for some time. But it seems that support is weakening. Bank stock prices have gone into a tailspin. Among issues that touched lows for the past year are Bank of New York, Bankers Trust, J.P. Morgan, Manufacturers Hanover, NCNB Corp. and First Chicago, among others. Citicorp, for example, traded as high as $35.50 a share in the past 52 weeks but has sunk to around $14. Its $1.78 dividend represents nearly 8 percent of the current stock price. ``Many people got used to idea that bank dividends are sacrosanct, but given the way stock prices are being pounded, there is a growing expectation within the institutional community that banks simply cannot sustain these dividends,'' one industry observer said. Chase said halving its regular dividend to $1.20 per common share on an annual basis was part of its move to ``reach higher levels of capital.'' Analysts have estimated the move could save Chase as much as $150 million a year. Saddled with non-performing debt to Third World countries and bad domestic real estate loans, banks' ability to increase earnings has been severely curtailed. Among institutions viewed as particularly vulnerable are the Bank of New York, Chemical Bank, Citibank and First Chicago, Kraushaar said, because their core capital, or owners' equity, has declined below 4 percent. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. plans to approve a rule by the end of the year that would allow only the strongest banks - about one in five - to maintain a minimum core capital level of 3 percent. Others would be required to maintain minimums ranging between 4 percent and 5 percent. Cutting or eliminating dividends would give banks a quick fix, since money not paid out to investors could be poured back into earnings coffers. But long-term problems still plague the industry. A weakening economy, a real estate market expected to get worse before it improves, and a decline in general business activity - from mergers and acquisitions to businesses' capital spending plans - will deprive banks of old revenue sources for some time to come. One thing that would prop up bank stocks would be ``a lot of excess capacity coming out of the banking industry,'' Kraushaar said, or in other words, mergers between large institutions. ``They could try to cut out lots of redundancies and build earnings through cost cutting,'' he said. The trick for investors is to identify the institutions that will survive.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Still Sees Potential for Senate Gains in November Elections
DOC.TEXT: Republican hopes of slashing the Democrats' 55-45 Senate majority hinge on the potential for a voter earthquake to shake things up in the final weeks before Election Day. Republicans so far have been unable to turn the electorate against a swath of Democratic incumbents whom the GOP identified earlier this year as potentially vulnerable. All but one Democratic incumbent is leading in the polls. But Democrats concede the Republican claim that voters have been distracted by the crisis in the Persian Gulf and are just starting to focus on the races. ``Six weeks out, and voters are only now paying attention,'' said Anita Dunn, spokeswoman for the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee. ``I don't think any lead right now is very meaningful.'' Sen. Don Nickles, R-Okla., chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, recalled that in 1980 and 1986, the last two years where the Senate changed parties, ``the races really didn't close until the last three weeks.'' The GOP is ``certainly within striking distance'' in many races this year, even if the polls don't always show it, he said. The list includes Iowa, Michigan, Illinois, Hawaii, Nebraska, Montana and Rhode Island. If Republicans get most of the breaks, which Nickles says is unlikely, they could pick up the five seats needed to wrest control from the Democrats. But the GOP clearly would be satisfied with gaining just two or three seats, which would make the Democrats especially vulnerable in 1992, when many who barely won office in 1986 are up for re-election for the first time. Currently, Hawaii Sen. Daniel Akaka is the only incumbent Democrat who is behind in the polls, and not by much. Akaka was appointed to the Senate earlier this year to fill the seat of the late Spark Matsunaga. Akaka is running against his former House colleague, Republican Rep. Pat Saiki. Iowa has been a brawl for months between Democratic Sen. Tom Harkin and Republican Rep. Tom Tauke. Republicans say Tauke is whittling away at Harkin's lead, but Democrats say Tauke was hurt by the disclosure that he accepted a congressional pay raise he had campaigned against. Tauke said he took the money, but later donated it to charity. The GOP's heavy recruitment of candidates from the House of Representatives hasn't worked so well in other cases. Michigan, Illinois and Rhode Island are states where the Democratic incumbents have held tenaciously to leads in polls despite tough opposition from GOP House members. In Michigan, incumbent Democrat Carl Levin was preferred by voters 2-1 over Rep. Bill Schuette in a recent poll, despite an aggressive television campaign by the Republican challenger. President Bush interceded to get Illinois Rep. Lynn Martin the GOP nomination to challenge Sen. Paul Simon, but the Democrat has maintained a solid lead in the polls. Rhode Island Rep. Claudine Schneider has proven statewide appeal in that tiny state. But she's still struggling to chip away at the popularity of incumbent Democratic Sen. Claiborne Pell. Earlier this year, Republicans considered Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., as the most vulnerable of their targets. But Baucus has climbed in the polls in recent weeks to a solid 25-point lead over conservative Lt. Gov. Allen Kolstad. While disappointed that more hasn't happened in those races, the GOP sees new opportunity in Massachusetts, where voters in the primary threw out the Democratic Party slate for state officers. Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., has been indirectly hurt. Previously considered safe, Kerry suddenly is just barely ahead of challenger Rappaport in the polls. Rappaport already has run a television ad linking Kerry with unpopular Gov. Michael Dukakis. But Republicans may have trouble using the ``throw the rascals out'' tactic in many of the states where they have been most hopeful, since they recruited so many sitting or former members of Congress as candidates. Democrats are confident Kerry will hold his seat, just as Republicans are confident Jesse Helms of North Carolina will win, even though he's in a dead heat in the polls with former Charlotte mayor Harvey Gantt. Both sides point to longshot chances against the others' incumbents in other states, and Democrats are behind but still hope to grab one or more of the three seats where Republican incumbents are retiring in Colorado, Idaho and New Hampshire. But perhaps the most unusual race of the year is one where both parties concede the outcome - that Sen. J. Bennett Johnston, D-La., will win re-election. The big question is whether Johnston can capture 50 percent of the vote in Louisiana's Oct. 6 open primary and avoid a runoff in November with the sure second-place finisher - former Ku Klux Klansman David Duke. Republicans are so worried that Duke will represent their party on the ticket that they have virtually abandoned the campaign of their chosen candidate, Ben Bagert, in hopes Johnston can avoid a runoff.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Reserve Tapped, FDIC Bolstered, Milken Waits
DOC.TEXT: One reserve will be tapped and another bolstered as federal officials wrestle with two of the economy's biggest enemies: rising oil prices and a declining bank insurance fund. Within a span of 24 hours this past week, President Bush announced the sale of 5 release was designed to slow the increase in crude prices, which have risen steadily since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. The FDIC premium hike was aimed at shoring up the sagging banking business. Although the oil only amounts to a few drops from the total 590 million barrels in reserve, the release was significant for its symbolism. Bush's ``test'' sale signaled his willingness to tap the reserve to counter the effects of the Persian Gulf crisis. Germany, Japan and other nations also were considering dipping into their strategic reserves. Bush took some mild heat for the move because it was intended to dampen speculation in the oil markets, not to fill a supply void. The reserve was put in place following the oil shocks of the early 1970s to counter oil shortages, not high prices. Oil prices continued to advance in the futures market following the announcement, but some analysts said regular reserve sales could help stabilize the market over the long term. On the banking front, the pressure for a decision on insurance premiums had been building for weeks as the health of the nation's biggest banks deteriorated. Several major banks announced restructuring plans, including job reductions and rare dividend cuts. The rash of dividend cuts, initiated by Chase Manhattan Corp., shocked the stock market, which had grown accustomed to regular payouts from the big banks. One government report showed losses from bank failures had whittled the insurance fund to $11.4 billion at the end of June, down 14 percent from the end of last year. L. William Seidman, FDIC chairman, said he expected the insurance fund to lose $3 billion this year, half again as much as previously estimated. The increase in insurance premiums will force banks to pay 19.5 cents for every $100 in deposits, up from 12 cents this year. If a bank passed the full increase on to customers, somebody with $10,000 in a savings account would lose $7.50 in interest over a year.
DOC.HEAD: MARKETS: Banks, Oil Dragging Down Stocks
DOC.TEXT: Economic worries intensified the market's recent slide, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average below the 2,500 mark to levels not seen since May 1989. The Dow's 12 percent erosion since the first of the year was persuading many experts that a bear market had arrived. The damage was even more severe in Tokyo, where the Nikkei average of Japanese stocks suffered more huge losses on concerns about the Gulf and Japan's own banking sector. The Nikkei average, off more than 45 percent on the year, dropped below the depths reached in the 1987 market crash.
DOC.HEAD: ECONOMY: Barely Perceptible Growth
DOC.TEXT: The economic news from Washington was not encouraging. A report on the gross national product showed the economy virtually ground to a halt in the second quarter, growing a mere 0.4 percent. The National Association of Business Economists, usually an optimistic group, said more than half of the professional forecasters surveyed in late August and early September believed a recession already had begun or was around the corner. The government said its own economic forecasting gauge sank 1.2 percent in August, the steepest drop in nearly three years. A study from the Conference Board, a business lobby group, said consumer confidence in August remained at its lowest level since the 1982 recession.
DOC.HEAD: PEOPLE: Milken Faces the Music
DOC.TEXT: Deposed junk-bond king Michael Milken returned to the headlines as the government and his defense lawyers prepared to play out the final chapter of his story in open court. Milken was due to be sentenced Monday on the six felony counts to which he pleaded guilty in April. But U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood put off the sentencing after being inundated with hundreds of pages of documents from both the prosecution and defense painting starkly different portraits of the financier. Prosecutors alleged a broad pattern of wrongdoing by Milken well beyond the crimes he admitted, and they urged the judge to impose a stiff prison sentence. The defense refuted the additional allegations and described Milken as a generous, warm human being who should work with ghetto youth, not go to jail. The judge also received hundreds of letters from members of the public, split along the same lines. Postponing the sentencing would allow time for a special hearing early in October to determine the real Milken. Ivan Boesky, Milken's chief accuser, could be called to testify.
DOC.HEAD: COMPANIES: A Deal For MCA Emerges
DOC.TEXT: The stock of entertainment giant MCA Inc. shot up in response to a reported merger deal with Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. Trading around $34 before the news broke, MCA shares climbed to near $60 in anticipation of the offer, which could bring between $70 and $90 per share. In addition to making MCA stockholders rich, the proposed $7 billion acquisition would combine two top players in entertainment hardware and software. The combination would mirror one established when Sony Corp. bought Columbia Pictures Entertainment for $5 billion last year. While the idea revived concerns about Japanese purchases of valuable U.S. assets, the deal looked good for both sides. Analysts said both needed to grow to compete against Sony and Time Warner Inc., two of the biggest competitors in the field.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Weekend Editions Sept. 29-30

DOC.HEAD: For Weekend Editions Sept. 29-30
DOC.TEXT: There's more declining on Wall Street these days than just stock prices. The number of shares changing has dwindled, and analysts say the slowdown in momentum means the market probably has not hit bottom. ``Low volume unfortunately shows the sellers have not done their dastardly deed yet,'' said Alfred E. Goldman, a vice president at St. Louis-based A.G. Edwards & Sons Inc. He contends that because there are more sellers than buyers, it takes more time to accommodate their desire to unload stocks, and that keeps volume depressed. Volume on the Big Board averaged 171.48 million shares a day this past week. That's higher than the 149.08 million-share daily average the week before, but still considered low. Most market observers would prefer to see that average in the 200-million-shares-a-day range. Higher volume and increased volatility would be interpreted as a postive sign in a bear market. The key to the stock market is not simply whether the Dow Jones industrial average moves up or down. Volume generally adds credibitity to market moves, so a rally on high volume says more about investors' confidence in stocks than a move up on light volume. The weeks when daily Big Board trading volume averaged more than 200 million shares a day have been few and far between this year. Up until August, however, the Dow average usually rose when the pace of trading quickened. For example, the Dow was up 63 points on the week in mid-May, when volume averaged 234 million shares a day. But Iraq's invasion of Kuwait marked a turning point. Since then average daily volume has pretty much held below 200 million shares, and when activity has neared that level, the Dow average has tumbled - in some cases nearly 100 points on the week - rathe than advance. ``The invasion intensified two trajectories of the U.S. economy that are negative for stocks,'' said Marc Chandler, an analyst at IDEA, a consulting firm. Those are ``higher inflation from higher oil prices . . . and an economic slowdown,'' both of which cut corporate profitability and give investors excuses for losing confidence in stocks. The quiet in the market, as evidenced by low volume, ``suggests that investors - both big and small ones - have become afraid because the risks of investing now in particular stocks are much higher,'' said Hugh Johnson, senior vice president at First Albany Corp. ``There's more uncertainty today than any time I can recall in the past 10 years.'' The Dow Jones average closed Friday at 2,452.48, down 59.90 on the week and off 428.21 points for the third quarter. The best-performing industry groups in the quarter were oil drilling, which advanced nearly 10 percent, integrated major oil companies, oil equipment and services, and precious metals, according to Dow Jones & Co. Industry groups that took the biggest hit were lodging, home constructionand casinos, each down more than 40 percent. The New York Stock Exchange composite index settled at 167.85, down 3.18 on the week; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market dropped 27.74 to 334.51, and the American Stock Exchange market value index was down 8.29 at 307.72.

DOC.HEAD: Shares Lower at Midday
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the London Stock Exchange were sharply lower at midday Friday in thin volume. Dealers predicted shares would drift lower through the afternoon as the general malaise affecting the futures market transferred to the shares market. At midday the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 22.6 points, or 1.1 percent, at 1,986.5. Volume at midday was 224.3 million shares.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Plunge Further, Dollar Higher
DOC.TEXT: Uncertainty about the Middle East and discouraged individual investors sent stock prices plunging to the lowest point in 3{ years in Tokyo today. The dollar closed higher against the Japanese yen. The closely watched 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average shed 788.41 points, or 3.62 percent, to finish at 20,983.50. Estimated volume on the exchange's first section was 450 million shares. It was the lowest close since March 3, 1987, when the closely watched average ended the day at 20,971.39 points. Friday's finish was also lower than the October 1987 Black Monday drop to 21,910.08. On Thursday, the index lost 478.71 points, or 2.15 percent, closing at 21,771.91. Analysts blamed fears of war in the Middle East, high interest rates, and climbing oil prices for sidelining institutional investors. Benchmark Brent crude prices broke the general upward trend today by falling slightly in Asia. Brent crude for November delivery was valued at about $39.15 to $39.25 a barrel, or about 10 to 15 cents below levels seen late Thursday in New York. The stock market's own downward momentum, in addition to higher interest rates, has lured institutional money to other investment vehicles with higher returns, analysts said. ``Institutional investors are taking a safety first approach,'' said Peter Tasker, a strategist for Kleinwort Benson International. The sharp drop since Wednesday, however, resulted largely from individual investors liquidating big portions of their holdings to meet margin calls from brokers, brokers said. The market has dropped by close to half since its all-time high of 38,915.87 points at the end of last year. ``It is a really serious condition. We have not seen as serious a condition in Japanese history,'' said Akira Yasui, head of research for County Natwest Securities Japan. ``The reverse asset effect that we have now will change the Japanese economy,'' he said. Capital expenditures by small and medium-sized industries, for instance, could drop in the next quarter because a bearish stock market and high interest rates would make raising money difficult. Individual investors, whose stock profits propelled them into a frenzy of consumption in the last couple of years, will feel the pinch. ``Normal consumption will be fairly firm. But the wealth that was created by the rise in equities and land prices ... is going to disappear,'' Tasker said. Analysts said the market probably will continue to decline, particularly if a war breaks out in the Persian Gulf region, but no one knows how far it will fall. Several mentioned a striking lack of panic in general, despite a sell-off that hit the market in the afternoon on a rumor - quickly denied - of bombings in Iraq. Fears about the Middle East have benefited the dollar, dealers said. The dollar finished at 137.95 yen, up 0.45 yen from Thursday's 137.50-yen close. The currency opened at 138.33 and trading ranged between 137.65 yen and 138.38 yen. Unless there is a war, the dollar will move in the 135-138 yen range ``for a while'' although some dealers think the currency is still generally heading down, said Masato Hayashi, chief customer dealer for the Bank of Tokyo. The stock market's steep slide also has weakened the yen. But activity on the currency markets should pick up on Monday, the start of the fiscal year's second half, he said. In bond dealings, the yield of the benchmark No.119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 8.690 percent by 3 p.m. (2 a.m. EDT) from Thursday's 8.680-percent close. Their price was lower at 80.73 points from 80.79.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Guild Authorizes Strike If Talks Stall At San Francisco Papers
DOC.TEXT: A union representing about 1,200 San Francisco newspaper workers unanimously authorized a strike if contract talks fail to forge an agreement soon. ``We've been bargaining since last February, and our members are increasingly upset that no contract has been reached yet,'' said Bernie Beck of the Northern California Newspaper Guild's unit at the San Francisco Chronicle. Local Guild President Steven R. Michael said after Thursday's strike authorization vote that he hoped a strike wouldn't be necessary. No deadline for completion of contract talks had been set, he said. The Guild represents reporters and certain other employees at the Chronicle, Examiner and the Newspaper Agency, the jointly owned company that prints and distributes both papers. They have worked without a contract since Feb. 2. The current contract contains an ``evergreen clause,'' which means it remains in force until a new agreement is reached, Beck said. He said that publishers ``still are at some distance about work rules'' and that negotiations about things such as wages and hours haven't even begun. In all, about 4,500 employees, represented by the 10 unions, are working without contracts at the two papers and Newspaper Agency. The Conference of Newspaper Unions will represent all 10 unions in wage and economic bargaining, which is expected to begin next week.

DOC.HEAD: Layoffs Would Hit Specialty Foods Hardest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: stands for PM-Farm Scene
DOC.TEXT: About 7,500 people who inspect beef, pork, chicken soup and Aunt Linda's favorite brand of liver sausage will forfeit a big hunk of their October paychecks if no federal spending deal is worked out. Moreover, if the mandatory cutbacks are put in place Monday as scheduled without a new budget agreement, that special brand of liver sausage made by a tiny mom-and-pop operation back in the hills may vanish entirely. That's because no one is allowed to sell meat and poultry products unless it is checked by federal inspectors. And the inspectors are going to take unpaid holidays - furloughs - next month. Department of Agriculture officials say they do not expect severe shortages at food stores, but they acknowledge that some specialty items from small processors could be hit hard. Final notices to the nation's 7,000 federally inspected plants were sent out Thursday by Lester M. Crawford, head of the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service, or FSIS. ``When the furlough becomes effective, the meat and poultry industry may not engage in any activities that require inspection,'' Crawford told plant owners. Effectively, this will halt production of meat and poultry on those days specified by Crawford as his agency's furlough period. And the four-day layoff will continue each two-week pay cycle, perhaps until 140 days of furlough time has been logged. Bill Hudnall, the agency's deputy administrator for adminstrative management, said about 5,900 federal inspectors check on the nation's supply of meat and poultry, along with 1,300 veterinarians and 300 food technologists. They make pp the inspection force of FSIS - about 82 percent of the agency's work force. Most of the FSIS budget goes for salaries. Total spending by FSIS was projected at about $440.9 million in the 1991 fiscal year that begins Monday. A mandatory cutback under the Gramm-Rudman budget-balancing law would lop off $143.3 million. The 32.4 percent across-the-board cuts in federal spending, collectively called a sequester of funds, would require layoffs of FSIS employees beginning Oct. 9, 10, 11 and 12. Much of the record 37.7 billion pounds of beef that will be turned out by plants next year will be produced from cattle slaughtered in Colorado, Kansas, Nebraska and Texas. Huge poultry plants operate in Arkansas, Georgia, Maryland, North Carolina and other states where broilers and turkeys are produced. A record 33.7 billion pounds of poultry are expected next year. ``We have some plants that operate two or three shifts a day, and they would have maybe 20 inspectors per shift,'' Hudnall said in an interview. ``We could have a single plant, counting all the shifts, with 45 or 50, even 60 (FSIS) employees, but that would be unusual.'' ``We probably have 3,000 of our inspectors in 200 plants,'' Hudnall said. ``That means the other 4,500 people are spread among the other 6,500 to 6,700 plants.'' Most of these are processing plants that use meat and poultry to make soup, stew, sausage and other items. Federal law dating back to the early years of the century requires full-time, continuous inspection at all slaughtering operations. Processing, however, is not required to be under constant federal inspection. ``A lot of these are very, very small,'' Hudnall said. ``They are one, two or three people that produce a regional sausage or ethnic food - and they're scattered all over the place.'' There have been money-saving sequesters before, but each time Congress has provided supplemental appropriations to keep the inspection services operating. But the one scheduled for October is the biggest yet. If the layoffs are enforced to the hilt, Hudnall said they would idle plants for ``over half the year.'' The hardship on federal inspectors would be obvious. Slaughter inspectors are paid $20,195 to $26,252 per year, he said. Processing inspectors earn in the range of $24,705 to $32,121. Many earn overtime, too, which is mainly paid for by the meat companies.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Corp. Posts Record Loss
DOC.NOTE: Eds: All dollar figures have been converted to U.S. dollars.
DOC.TEXT: Bond Corp Holdings Ltd. on Friday posted Australia's largest annual corporate loss of $1.86 billion, two days after financier Alan Bond's resignation. Bond Corp.'s deficit for the year ended June 30 included large losses at Bell Resources Ltd. and at the G. Heileman Brewing Co. Inc., of the United States. The loss was more than double the previous year's deficit of $813 million. On Wednesday, Bond resigned as head of his holding company and Peter Lucas was appointed chairman of the organization. Bond Corp. directors said Friday the results did not include the profit from the disposal of Australian brewing assets to a joint venture involving Bell Reources and New Zealand brewer Lion Nathan Ltd. The loss included $348 million in Bond's Bell Resources investments and $308 million in Heileman Brewing.

DOC.HEAD: Government Clears Oil Companies Of Gasoline Price Fixing
DOC.TEXT: The Office of Fair Trading on Friday cleared five oil companies of fixing gasoline pump prices in the face of rising crude oil prices that followed the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. The office's director general, Gordon Borrie, said the industry's reaction to events in the Persian Gulf followed a ``pattern one would expect in a competitive market.'' The office launched its inquiry Aug. 24 and asked for information of price increases from the five major oil companies operating in Britain: British Petroleum Co. PLC, Royal Dutch Shell Group of Cos., Texaco Inc., Mobil Corp. and Exxon Corp. Excess profits didn't appear to be generated at retail, wholesale, or refining stages of the industry, Borrie said. He noted that increased demand since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait had generated ``windfall profits'' at the production stage. But he said it was a question of public policy, not competition policy, whether moves should be made to moderate price rises or redistribute windfalls.

DOC.HEAD: Municipal Investors Starting To Push Up Yields
DOC.TEXT: Municipal bond investors afraid financial troubles like Philadelphia's may crop up elsewhere are beginning to demand higher returns for their risk. But some analysts say the yields have to get higher to make it worth investing in municipalities that face severe budget deficits, particularly those in the slumping Northeast. For cities and states already strapped, higher yields raise the cost of borrowing money. Massachusetts on Thursday had to offer yields as high as 7.97 percent for a $1.3 billion package of revenue bonds. That was about 1.5 percentage points higher than a Maryland offering earlier in the week. The Massachusetts bonds were rated BBB by Standard & Poor's Corp., while the Maryland issue got the highest AAA rating. Massachusetts is running a budget deficit only two months into its fiscal year. The so-called quality spread, which compares yields of lower-rated municipal bonds to the highest rated, has been very narrow recently, but is begining to widen, analysts say. Yields on 30-year A-rated revenue bonds are running 45 to 55 hundredths of a percentage point higher than the yields for AAA-rated general obligation bonds, according to Municipal Market Data Inc. The quality spreads are narrower for shorter-term issues. Investors ``concerns are legitimate in that quality spreads are still so narrow that they're not getting paid for their credit risk,'' said George Friedlander, municipal market analyst at Smith Barney, Upham & Co. Philadelphia's inability to sell about $375 million in short-term notes and officials' predictions that the city will run out of cash around Dec. 1, have prompted municipal bond investors to begin focusing on credit quality. While the market continues to be driven by developments in the Middle East, concern has been growing since early summer over how budget deficits and recession, which cuts into tax revenues, would affect the ability of cities and states to make debt payments. ``We have been concerned about the trend in a lot of state and local governments asked to bear a larger share of entitlements and other programs required by the federal government, while at same time revenue counted on to pay for the programs is not there,'' said Neal Atterman, municipal research director at Kidder, Peabody & Co. The stock price of MBIA, a major municipal bond insurer, has been particularly hard hit by the worries over credit quality. The stock last week sunk to around $25 from about $37 the week before. Many investors feel MBIA is heavily exposed to Philadelphia's debt and could suffer if Philadelphia defaults. However, the company said exposure to Philadelphia debt is not excessive and Standard & Poor's affirmed MBIA's AAA rating. Standard & Poor's and Moody's Investors Service Inc., have lowered their ratings on Philadelphia's general obligation bonds, which are backed by the city's faith and credit. S&P ranks the bonds at CCC and Moody's puts them at B, giving the debt junk-bond status. General obligation bonds are usually viewed as more secure than revenue bonds, which depend on user fees such as bridge tolls to make payments. However, some are beginning to look at selected revenue bonds as more recession-proof since it has been Philadelphia's general obligation bonds that are considered to be the larger credit risk. ``We've been of the philosophy that some are better off with a set revenue stream. People are still going to pay tolls in a recession,'' said Nicole Anderes, head of municipal research at New York-based Roosevelt & Cross Inc., an investment firm that focuses on Northeast municipalities. Some see the chances of Pennsylvania allowing its largest city to default as slim and point out that investors who held on to their bonds during the fiscal crises in New York and Cleveland during the 1970s survived intact. For the investor who could survive a long period of illiquidity, it might be worth the risk, some say. Steven J. Hueglin, executive vice president at Gabriele, Hueglin & Cashman Inc., says Philadelphia's bonds are a good speculative investment, particularly the general obigation issue.

Wheat prices rose slightly also on the USDA report of an unexpectedly small harvest in that grain. DOC.HEAD: Midway Airlines Cuts Workforce By 500, Cites Fuel Costs
DOC.TEXT: Midway Airlines began cutting 500 people from its workforce today, and blamed rising fuel costs as the cause. Chicago-based Midway also said it would end service to Savannah, Ga., on Nov. 1 and reduce its service to 11 other cities beginning Oct. 15. ``These actions are necessitated by escalating fuel costs brought on by the Persian Gulf crisis,'' Midway Chairman David Hinson said in a statement. ``Midway, as well as other airlines, is actively addressing the need to adjust system flying in order to reduce operating costs and produce a better balance between capacity and passenger demand,'' Hinson said. The reduction will affect 10 percent of Midway's work force, said spokeswoman Sandra Allen. She said most of the 500 positions will be eliminated through layoffs that will be phased in through Nov. 1. Some jobs will be eliminated by not filling positions vacated during the past several weeks, Allen said. She said all departments in the company will be affected but declined to release specific numbers. Hinson said Midway also plans to withdraw eight of its least fuel efficient aircraft from its fleet and replace them with more efficient MD-80 jetliners made by McDonnell Douglas Corp. He said Midway took delivery of three MD-80s this month and expects to receive four more by year end. Midway Airlines and Midway Commuter serve 59 cities in the United States, Canada, the Virgin Islands and the Bahamas. The airline has major hubs in Chicago and Philadelphia.
