DOC.HEAD: Non-Union Coal Companies Opposing Health Plan Bailout
DOC.TEXT: Plans to rescue two United Mine Workers health care funds, now staggering under an $88 million deficit, are stirring anxiety among non-union coal operators. The operators fear a new industry-wide coal tax will be proposed to bail out the troubled 1950 and 1974 UMW health benefit trusts, which serve 127,052 retired union miners, widows and dependents. ``That's the big buzzword this week in the industry, a growing feeling that (non-union companies) may have to pay something,'' said Marc Cohen, coal analyst for Kidder Peabody & Co. in New York. In March, U.S. Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole appointed an 11-member commission to study the trusts. The panel, which has no lawmaking power, will release its recommendations at two meetings, scheduled for Oct. 11 and Oct. 17 in Washington. Henry Perritt, vice chairman of the commission, said Thursday there's been no decision on financing the trusts' rescue but indicated some type of industrywide financing is being considered. ``There is fairly strong evidence that the problem of health care obligation for retirees can't be solved in the long run without some kind of broadening of the financing obligations,'' said Perritt. The panel also is looking at ways to improve the delivery of health care services to retirees, said Perritt. ``My hope is, we'll be able to put together a whole package to address the financing side and address the care delivery side that takes advantage of the thinking that's being expressed in the national dialogue on health care policy,'' said Perritt. The panel will hold the last in a series of public hearings Oct. 10 in Washington, where the coal tax issue is expected to dominate discussions. Mrs. Dole formed the commission on the heels of the UMW's 10{-month strike against the Pittston Co. The strike was triggered in part when the company stopped paying into the funds; Pittston said the payments hurt its competitiveness in the export market. Pittston settled with the union and contributed a $10 million lump-sum payment into the 1950 health fund. The 1950 and 1974 funds are financed by coal companies that sign the national UMW labor agreement, known as the Bituminous Coal Operators Association contract. But there are fewer BCOA companies to uupport the health plan than needed to keep it in the black. About half of the industry's work force are union members. Now the 1950 fund faces a $73 million deficit while the 1974 fund is $15 million in debt. Other problems include the high cost of health care and a federal lawsuit alleging mismanagement of the fund. The funds are separate from the union and are operated by independent trustees. The funds' dilemma has delayed payments for health care services in the coalfields. Retirees and their families have problems finding drugstores that accept the UMWA health plan card. Earlier this month, eight non-union coal companies protested the rumored bailout plan in a letter to Labor Secretary Dole. ``It would be an unprecedented projection of federal power into labor management relations in this country to require union-free companies to pay for benefits available only to union members,'' the letter said. It was signed by officials for Quaker Coal Co.; Shell Mining Co.; Mapco Coal Co.; Addington Resources; Coastal Energy Co.; Arco Coal Co.; Kerr-McGee Coal Corp.; and Santa Fe Pacific Coal Corp. ``Forcing non-involved companies to pick up the bill for parties' failure to confront their economic problems in collective bargaining would establish an inappropriate and potentially catastrophic public policy,'' the letter said. One probable solution is transferring money from the union's fat pension fund to bail out the health trust. Last year, the 1950 and 1974 pension trusts showed $5.17 billion in assets after subtracting liabilities, according to UMW documents. Last year, Sen. Jay Rockefeller, D-W.Va., introduced a bill allowing transfer of money from the overfunded pension trusts to the ailing health care trusts. The bill also would have required non-union companies pay into the benefit trusts. Rockefeller's bill has been placed on hold pending the commission's report. Provisions of the Rockefeller bill, including the pension fund transfer, have been looked on favorably by the commission, said two sources familiar with the study, who requested anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Survival Eastern's Major Accomplishment, But Even That's In Doubt
DOC.TEXT: Martin Shugrue was telling a campus audience the other day that his ``100 Days'' campaign at Eastern was a victory. ``What victory?'' shouted one of the striking Eastern Machinists union members who joined students for Shugrue's speech at Florida International University. ``Survival, dear friend. Survival,'' was Shugrue's answer. But even that minimal accomplishment is in doubt as an airline industry downturn, steepened by soaring oil prices, worsens Eastern's viability. ``It's worse because everybody's worse,'' said Robert Joedicke, airline analyst for Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``There's no way you can make up the immediate rise in fuel prices.'' Jet fuel prices have soared since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, driving up the cost of oil. The major airlines have increased fares - some of them twice - but with passenger traffic already sluggish, they can't raise them to match the higher fuel costs. For Eastern, things are even worse. ``Like most carriers, they're between the rock and the hard place,'' Joedicke said. Not only that, the airline was already in a financial bind that's ``a hard thing to carry on.'' Eastern filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection 1{ years ago and has seen operating losses continue at more than $2 million a day. Its second-quarter operating loss was $234.4 million and Shugrue has indicated third-quarter results won't be comforting for increasingly nervous creditors. Shugrue this week expressed frustration about the impact of the Persian Gulf crisis, which has increased Eastern's fuel costs from 56 cents a gallon to 96 cents. It came, he said, as the airline was making progress. In August, its load capacity was 72 percent. Eastern was showing its strongest signs of progress since it began rebuilding from the crippling March 4, 1989, strike led by Machinists and joined by pilots and flight attendants after years of labor-management tension. The company also recently announced a major push to draw business travelers by offering special rates, expanded first-class cabins, and amenities like airphones for every seat to a better wine list. Eastern also unveiled special flights to winter vacation destinations for frequent fliers. While industry analysts saw the efforts as good long-term strategy, doubts have risen about whether Eastern has a long term. Shugrue said Eastern would need to fly at 102 percent capacity to break even at current fuel prices. He asked for presidential intervention, such as President Bush's announcement this week to draw on the country's Strategic Petroleum Reserve of crude oil. A former pilot and veteran airline executive, Shugrue says he's against industry ``re-regulation'' or government involvement in corporate affairs. But, he added, ``Forces outside our control must be managed by a higher authority.'' ``Someone has to evaluate the present situation and develop some guidelines to ... stanch the flow of corporate blood, restore jobs,'' Shugrue said. ``This could be the script, sometime in the foreseesable future in early 199 maybe - U.S. air traffic shared by only four carriers ... all other airlines have fallen to the wayside,'' he said. Shugrue argued that the ``mega-carrier'' scenario has serious national implications. The giant carriers would focus their quest for riches abroad, he said, and fares for U.S. consumers would skyrocket while travel choices decreased. Meanwhile, industrywide problems may reduce Eastern's alternatives. A long-discussed merger with Continental seems unlikely, analysts say, and while Eastern and Northwest Airlines have been talking, the tightening market probably would make it difficult for Northwest to afford a takeover. Eastern is dependent upon Bankruptcy Judge Burton Lifland's willingness to allow continued draws on an escrow account to keep it operating. On Thursday, he authorized the release of $50 million. The judge has made clear he wants to make sure Eastern has had every chance to stay alive and preserve the jobs of 17,000 employees. Analysts expect the judge to give Eastern's corporate fare strategy, which begins Monday, time to work. ``The judge wants to give Eastern as much time as possible,'' said Ray Neidl of Dillon Read & Co. ``So even if the unsecured creditors step up their lobbying for liquidation, if Eastern can show some progress, that can be diffused. But the clock is ticking.''

DOC.HEAD: Problems Remain But Budget Deal Begins to Jell
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1 graf for 9th graf, Without a, to CORRECT by removing VA nurses from those who face furloughs. Adds food and drug inspectors. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: House Speaker Thomas Foley said today that although congressional and White House bargainers are near a $500 billion budget deal, disputes remain that leave wide-scale slashes in federal programs looming for Monday. ``There are some remaining issues that are very difficult that remain to be resolved,'' said Foley, D-Wash. Negotiators, still divided over whether to impose new taxes on the wealthy and other issues, planned to meet through the weekend if necessary in hopes of agreeing to a package. Congress planned a rare Sunday session to deal with the fiscal crisis. More than four months of talks have brought tentative agreements to cut defense and domestic programs and raise the government's take on items ranging from gasoline to Medicare premiums, officials familiar with the talks said Thursday. But at nearly 1:30 a.m. today, negotiators broke for the evening saying they could not yet shake hands on a pact. ``So close and yet we're not quite there,'' said House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., as he and other bargainers ended their back-room meeting in the Capitol. The major question remained whether Democrats would finally agree to a reduction in the capital gains tax - a longtime demand of President Bush - and which levies on the wealthy would be boosted to compensate. ``We're still working on all of that,'' said House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. Without a budget deal, federal drug agents, food and drug inspectors and many of the government's 2.1 million civilian workers faced furloughs beginning Monday. The lack of an agreement would trigger $85 billion in spending cuts. Social Security, soldiers' salaries and many initiatives for the poor are exempted, but most federal programs faced immediate budget slashes of about one-third. At the talks, Republicans were willing to abandon the president's insistence to lower the rates of the capital gains tax, which is charged against the profits of property sales, officials said. Instead, they were willing to leave current rates alone and exempt from the levy increases in the value of an asset due to inflation. But insistent that most benefits of the tax cut would go to the wealthy, Democrats were holding out for a counter-balancing tax increase on the well-to-do. Several options were under consideration, including raising tax rates on the richest Americans and limiting their deductions. A rate increase would represent a significant political victory for Democrats over Bush, whose 1988 campaign is best remembered for his chant of ``No new taxes.'' The two sides have tentatively agreed to hold defense spending to $170 billion below the amount it would need to stay even with inflation over the next five years, including a $10 billion cut next year. The growth of benefit programs would be slowed by $120 billion, half of it coming from Medicare. Participants in the program, which provides health care to 33 million elderly and disabled people, would bear half the cuts. Much of the savings would come from a $5.70 increase in the $28.60 payment they make monthly for doctors' coverage. Doctors and hospitals would have to swallow the other half of the Medicare reductions. Over five years, support payments to farmers would be cut $12 billion and benefits for civil servants would drop by $14 billion. Although not yet agreed to, it appeared likely that Social Security recipients would be hit for $20 billion in savings, either by having cost-of-living increases delayed or the taxes on their benefits increased. Tax increases tentatively set were an 8-cent-per-gallon increase in the federal gasoline levy, already at 9 cents; a separate tax on all fuels based on their energy content; and a 10 percent tax on luxury items including yachts, furs and jewelry. Democrats would like to boost the income tax rate on the wealthiest Americans above its current 28 percent. People who fall just below the top bracket must pay taxes of 33 percent, and Democrats would like to increase the top rate to at least 31 percent, officials said. As an alternative, they are considering a plan limiting the deductions people who earn above $100,000 can claim to 90 or 95 percent of what they would otherwise be entitled. Democrats also have proposed lifting the earnings ceiling above which Medicare taxes are not taken out of paychecks. As part of Social Security withholding, people now pay a 1.45 percent tax to support Medicare on earnings up to $51,300 per year. They pay nothing on money they earn above that amount. Under the proposal, that ceiling would be lifted to $65,000 or $75,000.

DOC.HEAD: House Passes Market Reform-Program Trading Bill
DOC.TEXT: A stock market reform bill expanding the Securities and Exchange Commission's powers to monitor major Wall Street players and intervene during stock market emergencies was passed unanimously by the House on Friday. The bill was approved on a voice vote. House passage of the Market Reform Act of 1990, which the Senate approved on Tuesday, sends the bill to the White House for President Bush's signature. The bill was agreed upon after a month of discussions between House and Senate staffers. It will allow the SEC to regulate program trading - the controversial computer-driven trading strategy - during times of extreme market turbulence. In addition, the compromise market reform bill contains provisions passed separately by both the House and Senate earlier this year. One expands the authority of the SEC chairman to shut down the securities markets, with presidential permission, in times of market emergency. Previously only the president could order a trading halt. Other provisions: - Require large securities traders to report their market positions to the SEC. - Mandate coordinated clearance and settlement of stocks, options and futures contracts between the SEC and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. - Require the Treasury Department, Federal Reserve Board, the CFTC and SEC to report annually to Congress on their efforts to protect the integrity of the markets. - Give the SEC authority to assess the financial health of the parent holding companies of broker-dealers. Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the one-time junk bond giant of Wall Street, collapsed in February after the failure of its parent holding company, which SEC officials have complained they had no authority to monitor. The original House version, the Securities Markets Reform Act passed in June, contained a provision giving the SEC authority to limit program trading ``during periods of extraordinary market volatility'' - the sharp climbs or drops in stock prices. The original Senate version, the Market Reform Act which passed last month, did not have a program trading provision. Critics of program trading, the rapid-fire transactions through computerized buy and sell programs of enormous blocks of stocks, blame it for worsening the 1987 stock market crash and the 190-point market drop last Oct. 13. They are especially critical of one form of program trading, index arbitrage, in which speculators try to take advantage of small, brief price differences between the stock and futures markets by simultaneously buying large orders in one market while selling in the other. The version passed by the Senate narrowed slightly the scope of the SEC's authority. It gives the SEC rulemaking authority to prohibit during times of ``extraordinary market volatility any trading practice'' in securities that the agency previously has found ``contributed significantly'' to the threat to orderly markets or ``is reasonably certain'' to do so.

DOC.HEAD: Swissair Rejects U.S. Planes in Favor of European Airbus
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf to CORRECT spelling of `Boelkow.'
DOC.TEXT: Switzerland's flag carrier Swissair on Friday announced it will buy 26 new aircraft made by the European Airbus consortium in preference to ones made by McDonnell Douglas Corp. The company said it had taken out options on an additional 26 Airbus machines to replace its aging short-haul fleet of MD-81s. A statement said the investment was worth the equivalent of about $1.8 billion, the largest in Swissair's 60-year history. The statement said the firm order consisted of seven A320s, with a 133-seat capacity, and nineteen 170-seat A321s. It said the first of these would be delivered in January 1995 and the last in March 1998. The company described the Airbus aircraft as ``particularly easy on the environment.'' Airbus is a consortium of Aerospatiale of France, Messerschmitt-Boelkow-Blohm of West Germany, British Aerospace and Construcciones Aeronauticas of Spain. The decision was made at a Swissair board meeting in Zurich. Also at the meeting, Hannes Goetz, chief executive of the Swiss company Georg Fischer AG, was named as Swissair's new board chairman. The appointment, which must be approved by the shareholders, would become effective in April 1992 when current chairman Armin Baltensweiler is due to retire.

DOC.HEAD: Beans Lower, Grains Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures fell and grains were mixed at the close of thin, quiet trading Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Soybeans opened with early support following yesterday's after-closing release of the Agriculture Department's quarterly report on the estimated stockpile of grains in the United States. But that support quickly eroded amid pressure from the upcoming expected better-than-normal harvest and little export demand, analysts said. Traders had expected slight gains in the soybean and grain markets Friday but were surprised by lackluster trading, said David Armstrong, an analyst for AgriVisor Services Inc. in Bloomington. ``The (USDA) report obviously wasn't enough to bring any new buying, and there wasn't any bad news to bring a lot of selling,'' Armstrong said. Wheat futures also opened slightly higher but fell on professional selling and continued questions about whether the Soviet Union will accept a government offer to buy subsidized wheat flour. Corn suffered from minimal near-term export demand and the approach of active harvesting. At the close, wheat futures were 1\ cents lower to { cent higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.78 a bushel; corn futures were { cent lower to { cent higher with December at $2.28 a bushel; oats were 3 cents to 5 five cents higher with December at $1.21 a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents to } cent lower with November at $6.17.

DOC.HEAD: BAT Affiliate in Pact to Acquire U.S. Savings and Loan
DOC.TEXT: BAT Industries PLC, the British tobacco and financial services conglomerate, said Friday its affiliate Imasco Ltd. of Canada will buy a New York state savings and loan for $150 million. BAT disclosed the agreement between Imasco's Canada Trust and First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Rochester, N.Y. First Federal has $5.6 billion in assets and 65 offices throughout New York state. BAT holds a 40 percent stake in Imasco, a Canadian tobacco and financial services concern.

DOC.HEAD: MARKETS: Banks, Oil Dragging Down Stocks
DOC.TEXT: Economic worries intensified the market's recent slide, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average below the 2,500 mark to levels not seen since May 1989. The Dow's 12 percent erosion since the first of the year was persuading many experts that a bear market had arrived. The damage was even more severe in Tokyo, where the Nikkei average of Japanese stocks suffered more huge losses on concerns about the Gulf and Japan's own banking sector. The Nikkei average, off more than 45 percent on the year, dropped below the depths reached in the 1987 market crash.
DOC.HEAD: ECONOMY: Barely Perceptible Growth
DOC.TEXT: The economic news from Washington was not encouraging. A report on the gross national product showed the economy virtually ground to a halt in the second quarter, growing a mere 0.4 percent. The National Association of Business Economists, usually an optimistic group, said more than half of the professional forecasters surveyed in late August and early September believed a recession already had begun or was around the corner. The government said its own economic forecasting gauge sank 1.2 percent in August, the steepest drop in nearly three years. A study from the Conference Board, a business lobby group, said consumer confidence in August remained at its lowest level since the 1982 recession.
DOC.HEAD: PEOPLE: Milken Faces the Music
DOC.TEXT: Deposed junk-bond king Michael Milken returned to the headlines as the government and his defense lawyers prepared to play out the final chapter of his story in open court. Milken was due to be sentenced Monday on the six felony counts to which he pleaded guilty in April. But U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood put off the sentencing after being inundated with hundreds of pages of documents from both the prosecution and defense painting starkly different portraits of the financier. Prosecutors alleged a broad pattern of wrongdoing by Milken well beyond the crimes he admitted, and they urged the judge to impose a stiff prison sentence. The defense refuted the additional allegations and described Milken as a generous, warm human being who should work with ghetto youth, not go to jail. The judge also received hundreds of letters from members of the public, split along the same lines. Postponing the sentencing would allow time for a special hearing early in October to determine the real Milken. Ivan Boesky, Milken's chief accuser, could be called to testify.
DOC.HEAD: COMPANIES: A Deal For MCA Emerges
DOC.TEXT: The stock of entertainment giant MCA Inc. shot up in response to a reported merger deal with Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. Trading around $34 before the news broke, MCA shares climbed to near $60 in anticipation of the offer, which could bring between $70 and $90 per share. In addition to making MCA stockholders rich, the proposed $7 billion acquisition would combine two top players in entertainment hardware and software. The combination would mirror one established when Sony Corp. bought Columbia Pictures Entertainment for $5 billion last year. While the idea revived concerns about Japanese purchases of valuable U.S. assets, the deal looked good for both sides. Analysts said both needed to grow to compete against Sony and Time Warner Inc., two of the biggest competitors in the field.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Seeks To Regain Initiative in Economic Reform
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with seven sted nine republics signing protocol in 2nd and new 15-18th grafs; RECASTS 7th graf on factories to be transformed over five years. A longer version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, struggling to maintain central control over Soviet political and economic life, plans to transform 550 armament factories to civilian production, his spokesman said Friday. Gorbachev and top aides met to complete the conversion plan as representatives of seven Soviet republics agreed to bypass central authorities in working out a new system of economic and political cooperation. The Supreme Soviet parliament has been unable to pass a cohesive reform plan, and on Monday granted Gorbachev extraordinary powers to transform the national economy from a planned to a market system. Representatives of nine of the 15 Soviet republics and the mayor of Leningrad, dissatisfied with Gorbachev's reforms, met in the Estonian capital of Tallinn and signed a protocol establishing an Economic Consultative Committee to coordinate their own shift to a market economy. Gorbachev's plan to shift hundreds of defense plants to civilian production appeared designed to quell fears of a military resurgence and to assure people the central government was acting to meet consumer demands. Presidential spokesman Vitaly N. Ignatenko told reporters that Gorbachev was meeting late Friday with members of the advisory Presidential Council to cement plans to shift arms plants to the production of processed food, medicine, electronics and other goods desperately needed in the faltering Soviet economy. The 550 factories would be converted in stages over the next five years to produce 270 billion rubles ($472.5 billion) worth of goods for civilian use from 1990 through 1995, twice the level as during the previous five-year period, Ignatenko told a briefing. On Thursday, Gorbachev issued his first decree under the enhanced powers, threatening businesses with fines if they did not fulfill supply contracts to government retailers. Ignatenko denied that ordering businesses to meet the contracts contradicted Gorbachev's stated intent of transforming the nation. The measures, Ignatenko said, ``are designed to stabilize the situation and move to a market economy as soon as possible. They do not mean that Mr. Gorbachev has rejected his own ideas.'' Gorbachev, meeting in the Kremlin with the chairman of the General Electric Corp., Jack Welch, acknowledged that ``the Soviet Union is living through a dramatic, tough, but creative time.'' ``The Soviet people understand the need to radicalize the economic reform, revitalize finances, change the forms and types of property ownership and move to market mechanisms,'' the state news agency Tass quoted Gorbachev as telling Welch. Representatives of nine Soviet republics met in Tallinn to find a way to speed the reforms. All but two Soviet republics, including the Russian Federation, have declared some form of sovereignty from central authorities since March, and the protocol affirmed the right of the republics to chart their own political and economic course. But the protocol echoed one aspect of the decree Gorbachev issued Thursday, directing republics to ``maintain existing economic ties for he period of transition to the market...'' Signing the protocol were officials from Russia, the largest and wealthiest republic, the three Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, as well as Armenia, Kirghizia, and Moldavia, the Estonian news agency reported. Leningrad Mayor Anatoly Sobchak also attended, the reports said. Leningrad is the second largest Soviet city. Representatives from Tadzhikistan and Byelorussia attended the session but did not sign the protocol, it said. The three Baltic republics have said they will not sign the new union treaty that Gorbachev is preparing to unite the republics into a loose confederation. The protocol signed Friday expressed support for efforts by the republics to negotiate bilateral economic, political and cultural treaties bypassing the central government.

DOC.HEAD: Mexico Debt Increases
DOC.TEXT: The Mexican government's foreign debt has increased because of the Persian Gulf crisis, nearly wiping out any additional revenue from increased crude oil exports, the newspaper El Financiero reported Friday. Treasury Department documents say the debt shot up by $1.1 billion to $75.6 billion since Aug. 2, mostly because of the drop of the U.S. dollar against the Japanese yen and Western European currencies. The bulk of Mexico's foreign trade and debt is carried out in U.S. dollars, while an estimated 21.5 percent is in non-dollar currencies, the newspaper said. Service on the debt will increase by $101 million this year because of rising interest rates, El Financiero said. Mexico increased its crude oil exports by 100,000 barrels a day to 1.325 million barrels to help make up for the shortage caused by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Ends Higher in U.S. in Slow Trading
DOC.TEXT: The dollar gained against all major currencies except its Canadian counterpart in unusually slow U.S. trading Friday after moving mostly lower overseas. Gold prices posted minor losses and gains in world trading. The dollar traded within a narrow band on domestic and foreign markets. The typically light volume that ordinarily occurs on Fridays was curtailed even further by the approaching end to the month, calendar year quarter and half of Japan's fiscal year. All three occur Sunday. The start of the Jewish Yom Kippur holiday, which began at sundown Friday, also lightened liquidity because some dealers left work early. Traders were reluctant to stake out significant new positions and institutional currency investors were finishing up seasonal paperwork. What buying there was in the dollar reflected traders' hedging against a possible escalation in the Middle East conflict over the weekend. The dollar is traditionally considered a safe investment haven at times of international turmoil. Financial markets regarded the latest U.S. economic reading merely as confirmation of what has been widely known for some time. The Commerce Department report on the government's chief economic forecasting gauge had virtually no lasting impact on the dollar. The Index of Leading Indicators tumbled 1.2 percent in August, its steepest fall in three years. It was viewed as another signal of a possible recession ahead for the United States. The dollar firmed against the Japanese yen in Tokyo where another selloff on the stock market chipped away confidence in the country's currency. The dollar rose 0.45 yen to a closing 137.95 yen in the Japanese capital. Later in London, it was quoted at 138.15 yen and at 138.50 yen late in New York, up from 137.98 yen late Thursday. The British pound rose in London and traded at $1.8735 late in the session, compared to $1.8690 late Thursday. DOC.HEAD: No Judgment Day Yet For Leading Figure in Wall Street Fraud Case
With BC-Milken-Chronology and BC-Milken-Sentences
DOC.TEXT: After nearly four years of government and public scrutiny, a shattered career and a humiliating guilty plea in Wall Street's worst scandal, Michael Milken thought he had neared judgment day. But Milken's legal rite of reckoning in a Manhattan federal courtroom on Monday was postponed for reasons that could be either ominous or fortunate for the 44-year-old prince of junk-bond financing. U.S. District Judge Kimba M. Wood decided late last week to delay sentencing and hold an extraordinary hearing into numerous allegations of criminal conduct by Milken that extend far beyond his six admitted felonies of conspiracy, securities fraud, mail fraud and aiding and abetting tax fraud. She said the hearing, likely to take place in mid-October, would help her better understand whether Milken's crimes were aberrant as the defense has claimed or systematic as alleged by the government. Wood is relatively new to the bench but widely acclaimed for careful handling of her first nationally prominent criminal sentencing. Faced with mountains of documents from both sides of the case, painting widely divergent pictures of the accused, she chose to solicit more information. The hearing she has proposed presents formidable new hurdles for each side. The government will have to lay out its evidence that Milken was not only a crook, but an unrepentant one. Milken's lawyers will be put in the uncomfortable position of deflecting those punches in a public forum, which is something they had hoped to avoid. ``The purpose is not to establish whether a defendant is guilty of every unadmitted defense. That is precisely the opportunity the government chooses to forego when it accepts a guilty plea to fewer than all of the alleged crimes,'' Wood told the lawyers for both sides at a pre-sentence hearing. ``Rather, the purpose of considering unadmitted conduct is to give the court a sense of the defendant's character as it is reflected in his conduct.'' Wood's decision seemed to catch the prosecution and defense by surprise as it tossed them into vaguely charted legal waters. It also left unresolved the final chapter of the tortuous Milken story, which began after Ivan Boesky pleaded guilty to securities fraud in November 1986 and put the government on the trail of the Drexel Burnham Lambert junk-bond wizard. Some lawyers even suggested the hearing raised the remote possibility that Milken, who tearfully pleaded guilty to the six counts in April after insisting he was innocent of any wrongdoing, would scrap that deal and gamble anew on a full-blown jury trial. ``Obviously the hearing is going to complicate things,'' said Harry First, a New York University law school expert on white-collar crime. ``I think this is fairly uncharted stuff.'' Others said it was the first time a judge in a white-collar case had ordered what is known in legal circles as a Fatico hearing. It is named after Carmine Fatico, a truck hijacker who was sentenced partly on the basis of a hearing into an uncharged crime: his alleged membership in the Mafia. ``If the government wants the judge to consider something you weren't convicted of, the defense has a right to challenge it,'' said lawyer Thomas Puccio, a former assistant U.S. attorney who prosecuted the Fatico case. ``That's what the hearing is for.'' If Wood were to conclude Milken engaged in a pattern of cheating, bribery, insider trading and obstruction of justice from the junk-bond trading desk at Drexel, as the prosecution alleged in its sentencing memorandum, she would likely order a fairly harsh sentence. On the other hand, if she found him the benign, generous philanthropist depicted by the defense, she'd be more inclined to give him a relatively mild punishment. In any case, Wood cannot order Milken imprisoned for more than the 28-year maximum on the six counts in his plea. Many lawyers have said she might sentence him to far less even if she believed elements of the prosecutors' portrayal, because he has promised to cooperate in other probes. Milken is the biggest figure to fall in the securities fraud scandals of the '80s, as measured by his prominence and the record $600 million in fines and penalties he agreed to pay in his plea bargain. By contrast, Boesky paid $100 million, pleaded guilty to one count and received a three-year term. Investment banker Dennis B. Levine got two years imprisonment and a $362,000 fine for insider trading; mergers specialist Martin A. Siegel received a two-month prison term, 3,000 hours of community service and five years probation. Some legal experts interpreted Wood's decision to hold a special hearing as a sign that she found little to guide her toward a fair sentence from either the defense or the prosecution. Prosecutors implied Milken should get at least six times the punishment of Boesky since he paid six times the fine and admitted six times the crimes. Wood seemed to reject that implication at the pre-sentencing hearing last week. But she seemed no more persuaded by the defense's testimonials from people ranging from Milken's childhood math teacher to the Los Angeles police chief, beseeching her to view Milken as a contrite first-time offender who didn't care much about money and gave most of it away. Milken's defenders urged her to spare him from prison and let him work with inner-city children. What ultimately may arise from Wood's special hearing, legal experts say, is the first substantive look at the true strength of the government's case against Milken had it gone to trial. ``I applaud what she did,'' said John Coffee, a Columbia Law School professor who has been following Milken's case. ``Now we're really going to get to that truth-finding function that the criminal justice system is designed for,'' he said. ``We're going to have people tell us what happened.''
DOC.NOTE: End adv Sunday Sept. 30

DOC.HEAD: Important Dates in the Michael Milken Case
With BC-Milken
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of key developments in the prosecution of former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. junk-bond chief Michael Milken: Nov. 14, 1986 - Stock speculator Ivan Boesky pays $100 million to settle charges of insider trading on information supplied by investment banker Dennis Levine. He agrees to cooperate with investigators and plead guilty to a single criminal charge. Boesky later is sentenced to three years in prison. Late 1986 - Published reports link Milken to an illegal insider trading network led by Boesky. Sept. 7, 1988 - The Securities and Exchange Commission accuses Drexel, Milken and three others of violating a wide range of securities laws, most in connection with Boesky. Dec. 21 - Drexel agrees to plead guilty to six felonies and pay a record $650 million in fines and restitution to settle the biggest securities fraud probe in history. March 29, 1989 - A federal grand jury indicts Milken, brother Lowell, and former Drexel trader Bruce Lee Newberg on 98 counts of racketeering and fraud largely based on information supplied by Boesky. Potential penalties and fines total $12 billion plus possible prison terms. April 7 - The Milkens plead innocent. Newberg enters an innocent plea later. April 13 - Drexel and the SEC announce a settlement of the civil fraud case that subjects the firm to federal monitoring for three years and forces it to sever ties with Milken. June 15 - Milken resigns after 19 years at Drexel to form his own consulting firm. Lowell Milken quits to return to practicing law. Sept. 11 - Drexel formally pleads guilty to six felonies and begins paying its fine. Feb. 13, 1990 - Drexel's parent company files for federal bankruptcy court protection after defaulting on debts and begins laying off employees. March 19 - Prosecutors promise to bring a new indictment with broader charges against Milken by the week of April 16. April 4 - Boesky is released from federal custody after completing two years of a three-year term. April 19 - Four months of negotiations intensify between the government and Milken for a possible plea bargain to settle the case as a deadline looms for the new indictment. April 24 - Milken pleads guilty to six felonies including conspiracy, securities fraud, mail fraud and assisting in the filing of a false tax return, carrying a total maximum sentence of 28 years imprisonment. Four of the counts directly involve Boesky. Milken also agrees to pay $600 million in restitution and fines and cooperate with the government after sentencing, set for Oct. 1. Sept. 24 - U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood orders pre-sentencing memorandums released to the public because of the enormous interest in the case. Federal prosecutors urge her to give Milken a severe punishment, based partly on crimes Milken hasn't admitted. Defense attorneys ask Wood to consider only the six charges in his guilty plea and urge her to sentence him to community service. Sept. 27 - Wood delays Milken's sentencing to hold an extraordinary two-week hearing in mid-October to consider the government's array of unproven charges against him. She says the purpose of the hearing is to gain a greater insight into Milken's character in order to fashion a fair sentence.
DOC.NOTE: End adv Sunday Sept. 30

DOC.HEAD: Gold, Energy Futures Slide
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices followed energy prices in an upward spiral Friday but slipped late in the day amid signs the government is trying to halt runaway speculation that produced a volatile week on the commodity and stock markets. Gold settled $3.30 to $2.50 lower on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for delivery in September at $402.50 a troy ounce. Energy futures showed signs of breaking the $40-a-barrel barrier once again Friday, but fell in the last hour of trading after the House OK'd plans to ``test'' release 15 million gallons of crude from the strategic oil reserves. Light sweet crude oil settled 3 cents lower to 45 cents higher with November at $39.51 a barrel; heating oil was .10 cent lower to .61 cent higher with October at $1.0498 a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .97 cent to .24 cent lower with October at $1.0176 a gallon. Optimism that a federal budget compromise will be reached over the weekend and speculation that President Bush was prepared to take unspecified action should crude top $40 also contributed to the turnaround, analysts said. On other commodity markets, silver and platinum extended their losses; soybean futures prices slipped; grains were mixed; livestock futures were mixed; and pork futures were higher. Platinum rallied from an opening low on the New York Mercantile Exchange and settled $3.70 to $4.20 lower with October at $433.10 a troy ounce. Silver settled 2.5 cents to 1 cent lower on the Commodity Exchange with October at $4.761 an ounce. Soybean futures fell and grains were mixed during a day of thin, quiet trading on the Chicago Board of Trade. Soybeans opened with early support following yesterday's after-closing release of the Agriculture Department's quarterly report on the estimated stockpile of grains in the United States. But that support quickly eroded amid pressure from the upcoming expected better-than-normal harvest and little export demand, analysts said. Traders had expected slight gains in the soybean and grain markets but were surprised by lackluster trading, said David Armstrong, an analyst for AgriVisor Services Inc. in Bloomington. ``The (USDA) report obviously wasn't enough to bring any new buying, and there wasn't any bad news to bring a lot of selling,'' Armstrong said. Wheat futures also opened slightly higher but fell on professional selling and continued questions about whether the Soviet Union will accept a government offer to buy subsidized wheat flour. Corn suffered from minimal near-term export demand and the approach of active harvesting. Wheat futures settled 1\ cents lower to \ cent higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.77} a bushel; corn futures were { cent lower to { cent higher with December at $2.28 a bushel; oats were 3} cents to 5 cents higher with December at $1.21 a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents to } cent lower with November at $6.17{. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, live and feeder cattle futures prices were mixed, reflecting optimism about a federal budget agreement. Live hog futures ended mostly higher as traders awaited the after-closing release of the Agriculture Department's third-quarter hogs and pigs report, which showed a lower-than-expected herd and smaller numbers kept for breeding and marketing than was forecast. Pork bellies futures were boosted by hog futures prices and speculation that frozen pork bellies stocks are nearly depleted, leaving the burden of bacon demand to the fresh market. Live cattle settled .53 cent lower to .20 cent higher with October at 79.05 cents a pound; feeder cattle futures were .20 cent lower to .07 cent higher with October at 86.97 cents a pound; hogs were .05 cent lower to .97 cent higher with October at 54.82 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were unchanged to .97 cent higher with February at 58.20 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Xerox To Announce Product It Calls Most Important Since Copier
DOC.TEXT: Xerox Corp. plans to unveil a product Tuesday it calls its most important development since it introduced the modern copying machine 31 years ago. The new device is a combination copier, fax, image scanner and document printer designed to tie together these now-separate operations at large companies. Using the machine, a worker could push a button on his desktop computer and order up one - or several hundred - high-quality, bound copies of a 50-page report. He also could send a fax of a computer document to another computer user, industry analysts say. In addition, the machine could electronically ``scan in'' paper documents that then could be stored in a computer or manipulated on a computer screen. ``It's really meant to bring the copier into the computer network,'' said Ann Palermo, an analyst at the market research firm International Data Corp. The device is considered a gamble by Xerox, which has been disappointed in the past by making technological breakthroughs only to lose the market for them to other companies. ``They have spent a fortune on the development of this system,'' said Eugene Glazer, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. He said the research cost ran into the hundreds of millions of dollars. ``The people that have seen it are very impressed,'' he said. But, he added, the market potential for the device - expected to cost at least $200,000 - is uncertain. ``They're trying to create a market, and the question is, can they create it at that price,'' said Peter Enderlin, an analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham and Co. Added Glazer, ``They'll be introducing it into a difficult economic environment, where the budgets of potential user organizations will be under constraints.'' Xerox wouldn't discuss details of the product, but it called a news conference Tuesday in New York to make what it called its most important announcement since it introduced the automatic, plain paper copier in 1959. It did say the announcement is a follow-up to its unveiling last month of a new personal computer and software designed to tie together computer users throughout a company. Xerox apparently views the new device as a way for companies to centralize control over the proliferation of paper and computer documents. The machine could be another step in the long-promised ``paperless'' office since it would allow paper documents to be stored on computers instead of in file cabinets. Such electronic ``imaging'' systems are offered by other companies but have not yet found a mass market. Computer industry giants such as International Business Machines Corp. and Unisys Corp. have stepped up their promotion of imaging devices in recent months, but most are aimed at specific markets, particularly banking. ``A product like this, if it's at a low enough price and has enough features, could really help drive the growth of document image processing,'' Enderlin said of the Xerox machine. Ms. Palermo said the new machine, believed to be called the Docutech Publisher, could replace print shops at major companies. She said high-speed printing devices used for high-quality, multiple-copy reproduction cost about $150,000, so the anticipated price of the Xerox machine is not out of line. Enderlin said investors apparently aren't excited about the announcement. Xerox's stock price has fallen in recent weeks, as has the market in general, since news of the machine began to appear. Last month, Eastman Kodak Co. unveiled a new high-speed document printer also designed to work with networks of desktop computers. But the machine lacks the faxing and scanning capabilities of the Xerox model. Analysts say no similar machine exists, but the most likely potential competitor would be Kodak, along with Japanese copier giants such as Canon. Xerox invented the personal computer, the ``user-friendly'' graphical software to run it and the computer control device called the ``mouse,'' only to see them slip out of its hands and enrich competitors who marketed them better. But despite the money Xerox spent on developing the new office machine, no one is predicting the Stamford, Conn.-based company will be hurt if it fails to catch on. ``The core copier business will keep going for quite a few more years, based on replacements and the service business,'' Enderlin said.

DOC.HEAD: Company Spinning Off Slumping Pet Foods Division, Announces Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: Whitman Corp. on Friday announced it will spin off its slumping Pet foods division, consolidate several of its operations and lay off about 1,000 employees. The company said it will take a charge against its third-quarter earnings to pay for the spinoff and cost-cutting program, which will cause losses for the quarter and year. The reorganization is an attempt by the consumer products conglomerate to cope with lagging profitability, particularly at its Pet specialty food unit and its Hussman Corp. division. ``We are taking this action because we believe it holds the best potential for increasing shareholder value over time,'' said James Cozad, Whitman chairman and chief executive officer. ``The restructuring will also produce a substantial reduction in costs by eliminating positions throughout the organization,'' Cozad said in a news release. ``And it will put us in a strong position to build for the future.'' Pet, which provides about half the company's sales and profits, is suffering from sinking market shares and lower profit margins. The division's reported operating income now is about 10 percent below last year's level, Whitman said. Miles Marsh, Whitman president and chief operating officer, will become chairman and CEO of Pet when it is spun off, the company said. To cover the cost of the spinoff, Whitman will take a special one-time after-tax charge against third quarter earnings of $150 million, it said. The charge will cause a ``substantial net loss'' in Whitman's third quarter and a loss for the full year, the company said. About 1,000 jobs throughout Whitman's organization will be eliminated through attrition, retirements and terminations. Whitman - which also owns Midas International, Pepsi-Cola General Bottlers and the Hussmann food-equipment unit - attempted earlier this year to sell Hussmann, but withdrew it from the market after failing to receive high enough bids. Hussmann, which had a weak first half, will have operating income down about 20 percent from last year, Whitman reported.

DOC.HEAD: Possible Gulf War and Recession Fears Plague Commodity Markets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with Friday trading, adds weekly price trends.
DOC.TEXT: Energy and gold futures prices soared, dipped and rose again in a roller coaster week where Americans worried about a one-two punch of war in the Middle East and a recession at home. Rumors of conflict in the Middle East ran rampant last week through the commodity exchanges, compounding worries about signs of a slowdown in the economy, analysts said. ``(Oil) seems to be the main thing the stock market and exchanges are looking at,'' said Jim Ritterbusch, an energy analyst with Paine Webber Inc. in Chicago. ``The economy is definitely weakening as a result of the sharp increases in energy prices,'' he said. ``It certainly is going to impede economic growth and most likely result in a recession - if we aren't already there.'' Gold rose on three days of war-panic buying before recession fears sent prices spiralling downward to follow silver and platinum, which fell to their lowest levels in years, analysts said. Grains, soybeans and meat futures prices were mixed as traders contented themselves with profit-taking. Energy prices plowed forward despite President Bush's midweek announcement that the United States would sell 5 million barrels from the strategic oil reserves. The move, widely seen as one made to calm rising fears following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, did nothing to stop light sweet crude oil from reaching record highs. On Thursday, crude topped $40 a barrel mark for the first time before falling back. The contract for November delivery of crude oil on the New York Mercantile Exchange closed down 3 cents Friday at $38.65, compared with $35.60 a week earlier. Prices fell after reaching a high of $39.95 late in the day after the House approved a plan for a 15 million ``test'' draw from the petroleum reserves instead of Bush's announced 5 million-gallon draw. Gasoline and heating prices rose sharply throughout the week as forecasters predicted colder than normal temperatures through December in the Northeast and part of the Great Plains. Those areas account for the heaviest use of fuel oil in the country.
DOC.HEAD: Precious Metals
DOC.TEXT: Silver and platinum plummeted on recession fears. The two commodities, used mostly in industrial manufacturing, posted steep losses despite high usage in the United States. Platinum, used in automobile manufacturing, fell amid reports that the Soviet Union sold huge quantities for badly needed cash. Gold passed the $400 mark as traders followed energy futures, but fell on Thursday as speculators temporarily put aside fears over the Middle East crisis. It closed slightly higher Friday.
DOC.HEAD: Grains and Soybeans
DOC.TEXT: Wheat futures gained early in the week on the Chicago Board of Trade amid reports that the government has offered to sell subsidized wheat flour to the Soviet Union, Algeria and other countries. But worries that the Soviet Union has not given a commitment to buy and professional selling Friday pushed the crop lower. Corn futures suffered thin, lackluster trading throughout the week after forecasters predicted near-ideal temperatures in the regions where it is grown. Soybeans futures were lower during the first half of the week in advance of the Agriculture Department's release Thursday of its quarterly grain stocks report. Prices later rallied after the USDA reported a lower-than-expected harvest but fell again as speculators waited for the Soviet Union to accept a government offer to buy subsidized wheat flour.
DOC.HEAD: Livestock and Meat
DOC.TEXT: Meat futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange suffered losses early in the week amid speculation that demand for the products will slow if the economy weakens further and the possibility that U.S. packing plants will close in mid-October if there is failure to reach a federal budget agreement by Monday. The losses gave way to cautious optimism at the week's close on word from budget negotiators that a weekend agreement was possible. Here are some weekly commodity price trends: Grain and soybean futures advanced on the Chicago Board of Trade.
